When he stops for water, the pump he finds does not have any more water in it except for a few drops, which are warm and unsatisfying. Also, the few drops that he does get taste like battery acid, leaving a harsh, chemical aftertaste in his mouth. So this is not very good for the cyclist, as the harsh environment presents a significant challenge to his journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the author changes the mood by not only telling us how the cyclist feels, but also by describing his environment. As he's leaving the “reservoir campground” he’s feeling pretty good because he’s just leaving “the serenity of an early-summer evening and he’s headed toward “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite.” He’s in a beautiful setting and this affects the cyclist because he’s anticipating another one, filled with natural beauty and comfort. However, when he moves to the “ghost town” and the “sun was beginning to beat down” he’s less confident and becoming more doubtful about the men's advice, sensing the growing desolation. However, he’s still optimistic, finally finding it funny that it was once “a thriving little spot,” a stark contrast to its current state. Next, when the cyclist comes to “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral” he knows that things are in bad shape and he desperately needs water. However, all they have is a “tar-like substance” so he moves on, having no choice but to continue his arduous trek. When he comes to the “rough road, tumbleweeds and a ridiculously large snake” it effects the cyclist by letting him know that things are at their worst and he can either give up, or keep pushing through the adversity. I doubt it could get any worse, and so does the cyclist, feeling the full weight of his predicament. Finally, at the end the cyclist enters a “rather modern bathroom” and things are back to civilization for him, so he feels relaxed, relieved and much better, having successfully navigated the harsh and unforgiving landscape.

There are several features of the setting that affects the cyclist on his journey. There is a profound lack of water, he is in the middle of nowhere, and nobody is there to offer assistance. Due to the lack of water, this feature really affects the cyclist profoundly. He will need water in order to move and get through his journey, as it is essential for his stamina. Water is the main thing he should have to sustain his energy. He could end up getting severely dehydrated and it might cause him to collapse right in the middle of the street, a dangerous situation. Therefore water is one feature that critically affects the cyclist. Furthermore he is in the middle of nowhere, a remote and isolated area. There are no buildings or anything around, not even gas stations, so there is nowhere he can stop and if he had money he would be able to buy about two or three bottles of water and maybe even a few snacks to replenish himself. That is another feature that will significantly affect him. Lastly nobody is around in the area to help him out or offer any aid. Let’s say that he gets lost and he will need direction to get wherever he is going; well, there is nobody around to help him get around or provide guidance. In conclusion those are the several main features that will definitely affect the cyclist throughout his difficult and lonely journey.

The settings affect the cyclists for many reasons. One, if the setting is nice, the rider can concentrate on the scenery and not only on the pain they are having, which provides a mental distraction. Also, if the setting is not very nice, the rider would probably concentrate more on the pain than they would the scenery, making the journey feel longer and more arduous. Another thing is if the setting is very hilly and the rider has to drive over it, it would not feel the greatest, adding physical strain. The cyclist would get even more pain than before, plus the cyclist could get dehydrated faster from the increased exertion. The setting, with all its physical and visual characteristics, really does affect the cyclist's overall experience and endurance.

The setting in the story affected the cyclist by him going through obstacles to get to town. The setting was in a desert in California in June, a time of intense heat and dryness. The cyclist also had a severe lack of water and when he found a pump he said it was black and tasted like battery acid, which was completely undrinkable. And then he stopped for directions and the men gave him the oldest set of directions, which were confusing and seemingly unreliable. So the cyclist said he would stick to his trusty map, deciding to rely on his own resources to navigate the challenging terrain and reach his destination.

In the text, the features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist, primarily influencing his emotional state. For example, the text states, “There was no one in sight, not a building, or structure of any kind.” This profound isolation made the cyclist very lonely and they started to lose hope of finding water. Secondly, the text stated, "In an ironic twist the building abandoned years easlier, by the looks of it-had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory." This discovery made the cyclist lose more hope, after he thought the building would have people in it and he got excited, only to be met with further disappointment. Lastly, the text states, “GRAPE AND @CAPS1’S FISH CAMP.” The sight of this building, suggesting a possible source of aid, gave the cyclist a renewed sense of hope and happiness for finding a place to get a drink. Ultimately, the setting’s features greatly affect the cyclist's feelings, dictating his swings between despair and optimism.

The features of the setting made the cyclist’s ride longer and harder than he expected, presenting a series of physical challenges. When the cyclist first headed out the road was flat and smooth, allowing for easier progress. Halfway through his trip the “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” The cyclist continues to pedal even though he was slowed down to 12 mph, demonstrating his determination. The hills made the ride slower and harder because of the increased effort required to climb each incline. Towards the end of the hills he had to make it “Over one long, crippling hill.” The word “crippling” is used to show the physical affect that the hill had on him, suggesting exhaustion and strain. The hills were a feature of the setting which made the cyclist’s ride longer, harder, and more physically demanding, testing his endurance to its limits.

There are numerous features in the setting that effect the cyclist, creating obstacles during his journey. For example, the rough road posed a significant challenge, jostling the bike and rider. Another example is the tumble weed, which rolled across the path and could have caused a loss of control, and the snake also affected the cyclist, introducing an element of sudden danger and requiring evasive action. Each of these environmental elements presented a unique difficulty that the cyclist had to navigate. In conclusion, those are the reasons the setting affects the cyclist, shaping his experience through both the terrain and the wildlife he encounters.

The sun, the amount of miles, and the people are all reasons why the setting affects the cyclist, impacting him both physically and mentally. For example, the sun was beating down on him every time and the cyclist seemed to complain that it was so hot, adding to his physical discomfort. Also, he said that he really didn’t seem to notice it through in his mind it affected the cyclist, suggesting a subconscious drain on his morale. Next, the amount of miles that the cyclist was biking affected him mentally because people kept giving him distances that seemed to stretch on endlessly, creating a psychological burden. These factors combined to make his journey more arduous, demonstrating how the environment can wear down a traveler's resolve over a long distance.

The setting is like a desert with no water or people civilizations anywhere around him, creating a landscape of profound isolation. This makes him more worried because if he dies no one will know for days or weeks probably, compounding his anxiety with the fear of disappearing without a trace in the vast, empty terrain. The complete absence of any sign of life or aid turns the environment into a silent, threatening presence. This overwhelming solitude and the associated risks are central to understanding the cyclist's precarious situation and his growing sense of vulnerability.

There are several features that the cyclist encountered, and all of them significantly affected his journey. For example, the phrase “several rusty bumps,” quoted from the text, explains that he wasn’t riding on smooth ground but was instead navigating rough, hard, and bumpy terrain. This uneven surface made the ride physically jarring and difficult to manage. Also, he had a huge lack of water; he was severely water depleted, which sapped his energy to the point that he couldn't even go the speed limit. He was going only 12 mph, a pace far slower than the potential 55 mph he could have been traveling. The sign stating, “Rough roads ahead Do not exceed posted speed limit,” is another quote expressing the specific dangers in the ride that he was risking by merely being on that path. All these things combined made the cyclist profoundly uncomfortable, dangerously dehydrated, and very tired by the end of his arduous trip.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” was a very large factor of the story and was actually the cause of the protagonist’s problem throughout his ordeal. First, it started off with the large, steep hills he had to ride up, making him work much harder and tire himself out quickly from the constant exertion. Next, the big problem was the oppressive heat of June, as indicated by the quote, “and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because…” The heat was so severe because it made him overheat, thus rapidly depleting his critical water supply, which he needed to survive, and it presented the large, almost inevitable risk of falling from a heatstroke and dying. The heat also made the sight of the abandoned Juice Factory all the more ironic and bitter for the protagonist. The text describes, “A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen.” In the unbearable heat with no water left and who knows how many miles left to cycle, this image really made him feel like the sorriest, unluckiest man in the world. The setting overall, therefore, seemed almost crafted to make the protagonist not only suffer from the natural elements but also from man-made reminders that seemed meant purely to taunt him for his suffering.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly because it is hard to go far on a bike when the place you are riding through is dry, abandoned, quiet, intensely hot, and relentlessly straight forward. The text tells you that the setting is abandoned when it says, “there was none in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind." This description of complete isolation would make it incredibly hard for a cyclist because you need a consistent and good water supply, and that is hard to maintain when there is nothing and no one around for miles. The barren landscape offers no respite or resources, turning the journey into a solitary struggle against the elements.

The cyclist chose to take an old abandoned route to his destination. The route had, in some places, no buildings at all to be seen, making the cyclist lose hope of finding his desperately needed water. From the beginning until the end, there was no one else on the route, making him completely alone and isolated. So if something were to happen, such as an accident or illness, who would know or be there to help? During his adventure, he ran out of water, making him dehydrated, a condition that certainly didn’t help his deteriorating physical state. The setting of the story, with its isolation and lack of resources, seems truly tragic for the cyclist, emphasizing his vulnerability and the harshness of his chosen path.

The features of the setting effected the cyclist very much throughout his journey. The text says, “The sun was beginning to beat down.” The hot, relentless sun was making the cyclist sweat profusely, causing him to lose precious bodily water. This was making him become dehydrated faster, weakening his stamina. Furthermore, the text states, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." The hills the cyclist had to ride up were physically demanding, wearing him out more quickly and causing him to become tired faster from the constant climbing. However, a moment of relief came when the text notes, “I stumbled into a rather modern in bathroom and drank deeply from the sink." This modern bathroom provided access to good, cold water. This allowed the cyclist to drink from it and replenish his fluids. The water revitalized the cyclist, allowing him to regain some of his lost strength and continue on his way, demonstrating how a single feature in the setting could provide a crucial, life-saving reprieve.

In the essay “DO NOT Exceed posted speed limit,” it is a clear cut fight for survival as it seems that this man is fighting desperately to stay alive. As I know, cyclists often pedal for hours at a time and sometimes for hundreds of miles; if he was biking where green grass and cool mountains collide, the tone and mood of the essay would have been completely different. He uses vivid sentences such as “...of two hundred degrees, deteriorating brain, birds would pick me up clean and drop from heatstroke.” THESE DETAILS all make me want to read further in the essay to see if he will be okay by the end of his harrowing journey. I know what the feeling is when you are low on fluids because I have chronic dehydration. I couldn’t imagine biking and only seeing desert hiss and passing tumble weed, with no relief in sight. It sounds like an awful, draining experience. If he were somewhere cooler and more colorful, his experience wouldn't have been so horrific, proving how deeply the setting influenced his ordeal.

There are many ways that the setting affected the cyclist throughout his journey. One significant way is highlighted in the story when it describes that it was very hot; this intense heat meant he could become severely dehydrated and could possibly have suffered a heat stroke. Furthermore, the roads were described as windy, which presented another major challenge. This could be a serious problem because if he is already tired and fatigued, he might not be able to navigate the sharp turns properly. He might just keep going straight and then get lost even more, exacerbating his dire situation. That is all about how the various challenging features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist in the story and his struggle for survival.

The features in the setting of "Rough Road ahead" significantly affect the cyclist and his difficult journey. First of all, the extreme weather causes most of his pressing problems. Since the cyclist was biking in a California desert in June, the temperature had to be in the high NUM1's. This intense, relentless heat causes him to become dangerously dehydrated, which is evident when he states, "I had been hitting my water bottles quite regularly." The heat therefore causes the cyclist to drink his water excessively and run out of his vital supply far too quickly. Also, the objects the cyclist comes across on his journey affect him directly. For example, while riding on a rough path, "a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me." This obstacle saves the biker's progress and most likely scared him, adding to his mental strain. The cyclist is greatly affected by the various harsh features in the story setting, each posing a unique threat.

The cyclist was profoundly affected by the oppressive heat of his environment. The fact that it was June, that he was in the desert, and that he was running low on water were the key factors that almost lead to his own down fall. This incredibly hot desert setting sounds utterly hostile and unforgiving, and I’m genuinely surprised he lived through such an ordeal and that he was that lucky to survive. His experience underscores the life-threatening nature of the landscape he traversed.

The features of the setting had initially misled the cyclist, creating a false sense of security. When he had first left the town where the old men advised him, the cyclist had high hopes as he looked at the scenery and enjoyed seeing very little sign of the impending struggle. This early part of the journey, with its more benign appearance, contrasted sharply with the severe challenges he would soon face, showing how the setting's deception played a role in his plight.

The setting affects the cyclist in a large way, creating a profoundly difficult journey for him. He began to lose hope, grew increasingly tired, and began to think he was going to die under the relentless conditions. The settings played the biggest role in this decline. It was very hot with no people or buildings around him for respite. He had very little water in his possession and no place to get anymore, a fact that weighed heavily on his mind. He then encountered a large snake, which made the situation worse because he was suddenly in fear with no one around to help him. If he would have followed his own directions instead of the old men he met earlier, he likely would not have had this problem. Ultimately, the setting around him really made his trip a hard one, defined by the complete absence of water, people, towns, or buildings to offer any relief or safety.

The features of the setting in the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” greatly affected the cyclist, dictating the emotional arc of his experience. In the beginning of this man’s journey he was confident in his abilities, a feeling mirrored by his surroundings. He states, “I rode in the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” The cyclist was prepared for an exciting day and the initial setting supported this feeling, as he notes, "The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them." However, as the setting began to change and his water ran out, the cyclist's attitude changed drastically. He was “traveling through the high deserts of California in June” without much water and begun to feel desperate. As more and more abandoned buildings and deserted towns appeared on his route, he sank deeper into despair. He recalls, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake - it really did look like a diamondback - blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” He was in the middle of nowhere with no one around, and because of this harsh and lonely setting he lost all hope of surviving. He became convinced he was going to die of heat stroke, not having any water left, on these short rolling hills and under the extremely hot sun. The cyclist was profoundly affected by the features of the setting, going from confidence, to desperation and despair, and then finally to relief; the distinct changes in setting directly caused his change in attitude throughout this arduous journey.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” affect the cyclist in major ways, primarily by deepening his sense of desperation. First, when the cyclist sees the grape juice factory, he is painfully reminded that he is out of water and is doubtful about even living. The text states, “…A young man pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head” (Kurmaskie). This advertisement serves as a cruel contrast to his own parched state. The text later states, "At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path..." (Kurmaskie), a detail which tells that the cyclist feels depressed and is majorly affected by these desolate sights. This encounter with the barren landscape and the mocking advertisement could and would later ruin his self esteem and make him think about dying, as the setting systematically strips away his morale.

The cyclist went on a rough journey, and he was explaining how tiring and difficult it was for him going from town to town. He had to deal with a severe lack of water, which was a constant source of anxiety. Furthermore, he faced the danger of poisonous snakes on the lonely road, adding a layer of fear to his exhaustion. The condition of the road itself also presented a significant challenge, making his travel even more arduous. All of these elements combined to create an overwhelmingly harsh experience for the cyclist, testing his physical and mental limits throughout his trek.

The setting of the essay didn’t really help the author at all on his journey, instead presenting a series of discouraging obstacles. There were not many structures on the way to offer shelter or assistance. Either that, or the towns he came across were said to be “a ghost town,” which couldn’t have reassured the author that things were going his way. It also was very hot during his journey, a fact underscored when the author says he is “traveling through the deserts of California in June.” Deserts are very hot places and June is during summer which is the hottest month, so it had to have been extremely hot and humid. All this must have taken a toll on his morale and physical state because he never really saw anything reassuring until the last town he reached with the bait store. So the setting, with its heat and desolation, definitely had to have affected his confidence and his energy levels throughout the difficult trip.

The features that set the affect of the cyclist is very clear in case of this essay which resene when it @CAPS1 the signs that said “Rough @CAPS2 ahead: Do not Exceed posted Speed Limit.” That had to slow down his bike, forcing him to navigate the uneven terrain with greater caution and physical effort. “Then he said that their were no building or cars nowhere,” a description which underscores the profound isolation of the location. This complete absence of any signs of life or potential aid intensified his vulnerability, making the journey through the desolate landscape a solitary and demanding trial. The setting, therefore, directly shaped his experience by imposing physical challenges and a deep sense of solitude.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. In the essay, it states, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time-say, before the last world war-but on that morning it fit the tradition of a ghost town.” This statement might affect the cyclist in the way that, they fear if they get into any trouble there is no one around to help out. This statement can also mean that they fear that they are going the wrong way, as the desolation contradicts expectations of a populated route. The different features of the journey of the cyclist in the essay, many would fear the outcome, if they over fear the journey and turned “old timers” who had never left their porches, in order to experience such things. The features of the setting affected the cyclist because, forty miles into the desert, I arrived at the first “toun”. The cyclist trusted a man that didn't know much about the world, he thought that the guy would know how to get to the place he was looking for. The cyclist took his advice, he thought that he would be there really soon so he start to drink his water really fast, misjudging the distance and the harshness of the route. He realized that he was out of water and the park he was going to wasn't anywhere near. The cyclist got frustrated and angry he was now crossing the desert which was making him tired and dehydrated, the vast, empty landscape amplifying his sense of desperation. He pased this road that was a rough road with tumbleweeds and snakes he kept on going until he sow the “@CAPS1 Juice” company. He hurried there, went into the bathroom drank same water. When he got out an old men asked if he needed directions, the cyclist said no, his pride and frustration now overshadowing his earlier need for guidance, a change brought on by the taxing journey.

During the passage “Do not exceed speed limit”, the cyclist endures many hardships. One of those countless hardships was the setting that he was in. while he was lost, thirsty, and exhausted, he remained all the while in “The high deserts of California in June”. This shows that the temperature most of been unbearable, with the scorching sun beating down relentlessly. This would cause the cyclist to tire out and dehydrate faster than usual, sapping his strength with every mile. Also, the surface he was riding on had many steep hills, as it is said when he says “over one long, crippling hill,” This shows that the hills took a lot of energy to get up, adding a grueling physical challenge to his journey. And finally, the author says that “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind." This shows that if he needed help, there was no one around to lend him a hand, leaving him entirely to his own devices. That is how the setting affected the cyclist in a negative way, each feature of the environment conspiring against his progress and well-being.

It affects the cyclist because in the beginning the text talks about the old man. It also talks about basically saying their information is out of date, also in other words he should have just followed his own map in the first place. The cyclist's journey is shaped by this initial dismissal of local advice, leading to a series of difficulties that could have been avoided. This realization comes too late, as the physical challenges of the ride are compounded by the mental regret of ignoring a potentially valuable warning. Ultimately, the experience teaches a lesson about the importance of preparation and respecting local knowledge, even when it seems outdated or irrelevant at the outset.

In the stories, don’t exceed posted speed limit, there are some very descriptive settings. In the stories these settings have a great effect on the cyclist. Through these our settings the effects change, with some good effects and some harsh effects. The first setting that is described is, "the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them." This setting gives you a vivid picture of where the cyclist is heading and also establishes a happy, expectant sort of mood. Yet the pretty picture is about to change. Not so much further into the cyclist's ride he noticed a change of terrain, as "flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." At this point the cyclist is short on water, and is becoming very tired. Seeing this difficult landscape just crushes his spirit. Riding hills is hard, but riding hills without knowing of something good waiting for you on the other side is even harder. Both of these, very different settings gives off very different feeling. The first one makes you think he is going to have an easy, enjoyable bike ride, but this all changes when he hits those horrible hills. Just the thought of having to ride over miles of hills makes your legs hurt. Over all the features of the setting supposed an intense bike ride for the cyclist, followed by a reward of a beautiful place, creating a narrative of struggle and potential redemption.

The author had to bike through extremely hot weather. This made him feel sweat a lot, which is clearly shown in the narration that states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt.” This intense dehydration caused him to drink water until he ran out, a situation described when the narration states, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” In a state of desperation, he then had to suck on pebbles to stimulate saliva, an action which he acknowledged he could have choked on. The narration confirms this danger, stating, “With any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat.” This sequence of events illustrates how the harsh setting directly led to a physically perilous situation for the cyclist, pushing him to the brink of his endurance.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” there were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. The most challenging problem faced by the author was the lack of water, which became apparent when he tried to pump some: “I pumped that handle for several minutes but the water wouldn’t calm down nor I tried a drip or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” When the cyclist set out for the next stretch of his journey, he came to a road that read “Rough road ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The terrain got more bumpy and hard to cross, which affected the determination the cyclist had left. He then regretted not listening to the old men, as he didn’t think they knew what they were talking about due to the fact they never left their porches. As you can see, the setting most definitely effected the cyclist in both physical and mental ways, challenging his body and his preconceived notions about the local advice he had received.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist in several distinct ways. One way it affects the cyclist is by being intensely hot, as the text states: "I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June." This extreme heat poses a direct threat to his health and stamina. Another way it affects the cyclist is by being bumpy and difficult to traverse, like it says in the text with the road sign: "ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT." This rough terrain challenges his physical endurance and control over his bicycle. Together, these environmental factors create a journey that is both physically demanding and hazardous, demonstrating how the setting directly influences the cyclist's experience and safety throughout his ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by influencing the mood of the cyclist and what happens as he journeys through the desert toward a town. For example, his mood changes significantly when an old man asks him for a map, and his attitude shifts from a cautiousness of the new road he was on, then to terror when he thought he was going to die, as he thinks, “I was gonna die and the birds would pick me clean,” and finally to a sense of pride when the old man asks for the map and the author states, “I own a very good map.” But as he journeys to Yosemite, the setting itself changes when he travels through a desert-type place and then stops at a bait shop to rest, before probably continuing on his merry way to his final destination. The evolving landscape directly mirrors the internal shifts in his emotional state throughout the trip.

Joe Kurmaskie's 'Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit' demonstrated that the features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. First off, the cyclist was in the desert on a bicycle, a mode of travel that demanded significant physical exertion. This affected her because if they had been in a car, or on a bus, a lot less energy would have been used up, making the journey far less strenuous. Secondly, the cyclist started running out of water, a critical situation in the arid environment. This setting didn’t help because they were on a bike, which increased their need to stay hydrated under the relentless sun. Another setting that affected the plot was the presence of deserted towns along the route. If they hadn’t been deserted, everything would have been better, as the cyclist could have found supplies and respite. Ultimately, these environmental features affected the cyclist a great deal, shaping the entire challenging experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist such that it was affecting his determination to continue. For example, after many miles he looked upon the “ramshackled shed, several rusty bumps and the corral… This sight troubled me.” In the desert, his water tasted like the flavor of “battery acid,” a detail that highlights the harshness of his surroundings. It also goes on to say that the journey was a “test for my inner spirit,” pushing him to his mental and physical limits. It also states that he went along with only a few drops of water through the fields of tumbleweeds, a vivid image of his scarcity. This passage shows the numerous obstacles he had to go through, which he did overcome, and he made it with a little confidence restored. Although his situation was somewhat unbearable, he still kept striving on, demonstrating resilience against the oppressive setting.

The setting of the story affects the cyclist throughout most of the narrative. The intense heat made him hot and thirsty, while the arduous travel gave him a profound lack of energy and created a desperate need for water. In one paragraph the writer says one of the hills was “long and arduous,” a description that underscores the physical challenge. The hill was wearing him out and draining what was left of his energy, leaving him exhausted. The setting of the story was the biggest factor in his struggle; the road was not flat but bumpy, and the temperature was extreme. These difficult conditions worked in concert to challenge his endurance at every turn of his journey.

The setting easily can affect the cyclist in many ways throughout his journey. The area in which the cyclist was traveling seemed to be abandoned, which doesn’t give a well-thinking feeling to this person, creating a sense of isolation. If a town was abandoned or a road was, automatically then there won’t be any noticeable building structures for a while, cutting off potential aid. Also, the layout and shape of the road seemed to be very dangerous for the cyclist, not only because of the narrow and rocky path but because of the local wildlife. In the text, it says how a diamondback snake, poisonous, was directly in front of the cyclist, a immediate physical threat. That example explains how the wildlife might extend to more dangerous creatures, increasing the peril. Finally, the temperature, whether it was hot or cold, meant the cyclist was limited in water, and being completely dehydrated was a huge caution for him. The combined conditions of the setting the cyclist was in became a significant disadvantage for his progress and safety.

The different settings that the cyclist had to navigate were challenging mountains or hills, steep winding roads, and the vast, arid California desert in June. As well as he was running out of water, the intense heat and isolation compounded his physical struggle, making each terrain a significant test of his endurance and will. The cumulative effect of these harsh environments created a journey defined by relentless difficulty and a constant battle against the elements.

How the features of the setting affect the cyclist by taking and not had the right setting is a central point. The features are just not right and and they could be changed around a little bit and still have about the same meaning of the essay, such as swapping the order of the desert and mountain sections. So I think they should change it around to better illustrate the progression of challenges, as the core idea of a difficult journey would remain effectively communicated through the adjusted sequence of environmental obstacles.

The features of the setting have an affect on the cyclist. He is going on this bike ride through the deserts of California in June. This obviously is going to have an affect on him because it will be very fast and physically draining. At one point he says, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed.” Furthermore, the setting of having all these ghost towns was troubling to him because no one else was around and he was beginning to run out of water. The weather outside was starting to get to him, and he said, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage…” When you're pedaling through the desert on a hot day it is going to have effects on you, primarily dehydration and exhaustion. If he was in a different setting this feeling of despair would not be present in the story. That is how the setting affects the cyclist, by shaping his physical state and mental outlook throughout the arduous journey.

There are many ways the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One feature is the weather. When a cyclist is on a trip the weather could affect the setting greatly. An example, if it started to rain the roads could become very slippery and dangerous to ride your bike on. The cyclist and his bike could crash and die, just cause of the weather. Another feature is the animals. An animal is important cause any were you go there are different animals that do different things. If the cyclist knows the animals around the area that he is traveling he could keep safe and not be harmed, for instance by avoiding snakes on a desert path. It’s better to know the area and feel safe, then not knowing what’s going to happen next, as this awareness directly impacts his security and peace of mind during the ride.

As the features changed in the setting it becomes harder for the cyclist. At first the cyclist started off pretty easy. He had flat, smooth roads to go through. He started out before the sun could get to him. “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over it.” He kept his mind off the sun and this helped him. Then, he got to a highway that made it kind of harder. “I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” So he had to pedal harder and it would tire him faster. “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path. Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state was difficult.” By the tumble weeds that means he was in the desert during a hot period of time. So he had little water left and he was becoming dehydrated. This was a hard task for him to overcome. By the terrain changing it become harder for him, demonstrating how each new environmental feature introduced a fresh physical challenge to his journey.

The setting in this short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is a hot, sunny desert, in which all towns have been abandoned. “The sun was beginning to beat down” as the cyclist embarked on his journey. When he arrived at the first town, it fit the definition of a ghost town perfectly, with its silent, skeletal structures standing stark against the barren landscape. The cyclist at this point is not only tired but also increasingly worried about the lack of water, a concern that grows with every mile. The harsh setting and the cyclist’s deteriorating state run side by side, each amplifying the severity of the other in this desolate environment.

In the story there are many effects the cyclist deals with. He has to go through a lot of bad things just to finish the arduous race. The cyclist had to watch out for a rough road he was going over, its potholes and cracks threatening to throw him from his bike. Also the whole time he was racing he had to watch out for diamondback snakes, their coiled forms a potential danger on the sun-baked asphalt. However, the cyclist's biggest problem throughout the entire race was water. He ran out quickly, his supply proving woefully inadequate. When he saw the factory and stopped, he was so desperate that he put rocks in his mouth to make him forget about water and to let his saliva circulate. The cyclist had to go through all these problems, which ultimately made it show that he possessed immense determination to persevere.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. He was riding along on a route he had little confidence would end up anywhere, a path that seemed to lead only into more emptiness. That being the first time ever being on that road and having only out-of-date knowledge about it made the cyclist rethink his entire plan. The temperature was very hot, there was little shade, and the sun was beating down on him relentlessly. The route was very discouraging. All the cyclist wanted was water and the route kept taunting him with false hope. At the first town he noticed a water pump, but all he could get from it was sludge and water that tasted like battery acid. Next he came to a deserted old building that proved to be an old bottling factory for Welch’s grape juice. Time and again, the cyclist would appear to be closing in on something to drink, but be left with nothing but dust and disappointment.

During the cyclist's bike ride the unbearable conditions changed his attitude. When he first starts, the reader can sense his frustration because of the old-timers and their vague directions. Then as he begins his journey and realizes that he might not have enough water, his attitude changes to one of concern. The cyclist goes from frustrated to briefly loving the scenery, thinking, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them,” but this hope is short-lived as the conditions changed to even more unbearable heat. He decided to just give up, his spirit broken by the relentless environment. Until he got a second wind of courage, he continued on, “slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” When he finally saw Gary and Wilber’s fish camp, he realized he was safe at last, his arduous journey finally over.

The bicyclist from “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit” was affected in many ways from the environment. The most talked about feature in the environment was the critical lack of water. The bicyclist felt he was going to die because there was no water and he was really dehydrated, his throat parched and his body weakening. Another dominant feature was the oppressive heat. It was really hot where the narrator was bicycling. When it is that hot, the heat dehydrates you rapidly. So the narrator was being pushed to his physical limit because of the heat. Also, everyone was gone from the towns so every town he came to was haunting him with its emptiness until he got mad at the lodgers he had talked to and was really frustrated by their poor advice. The smooth flat road gave way to rolling hills, which made it significantly harder for him to ride, sapping his remaining energy. Lastly, the snake in the road affected him because he had to swerve to avoid it. All of these environmental things combined to test his endurance and will to continue.

“Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie is truly a story of man against nature. Here is a man who is completely alone except for his bike, the barren landscape and relentless sun. First he notices the sun, over head him, expected from a California June, but not none the less oppressive. Then next come the rolling hills and the steep incline in elevation, going up hill means his body working harder, and burning calories and depleting his much needed water supply. Then there is the man's mental torture. A speed limit of sixty-five, where he is going a tough twelve. And worse a billboard of “a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth,” this truly hit his emotions, showing him exactly what was out of reach. In this story every element of his surrounding, from the heat to the hills, contributed to his profound sense of hopelessness and struggle.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly. For one, the conditions of the road were awful, cracked and uneven from the harsh sun. Two, the cyclist said there was a huge snake blocking his path, a coiled menace on the asphalt, as well as the occasional tumbleweed drifting ominously across his path. The biggest affect on the cyclist was the critical lack of water combined with the unbearable, shimmering heat, and he was deeply tired, his energy sapped. Those are the powerful affects the features of the setting had on the cyclist, creating a journey of immense difficulty.

If I had a choice to ride a bike in California or Vermont, it would be a no-brainer to bike in Vermont. The temperature in Vermont would be much cooler and more temperate than the scorching heat in California. In the story the cyclist complains about the "wide rings of dried sweat" on his clothes and the very real possibility of heatstroke. It is proven that when temperatures rise, you tend to lose more water and essential salts from your body. Had the cyclist chosen a cooler site at a different time of year he wouldn't have struggled so severely with dehydration on his bike ride, making for a much more pleasant and safer journey.

The features of the setting in the story affected the cyclist a lot, shaping his entire experience. In the morning when he began his trip, he was eager and determined to get to his destination, full of optimism. Although it took him forty miles to get to the first “town,” he didn’t seem to mind at first. “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them,” is what crossed his mind before the sun began to beat down in earnest. Meaning that he didn’t mind or wasn't particularly troubled by the distance at the time. But the farther his trip went, the hotter it became, and the less water supply he had left in his bottles. Once he passed a couple of “troubling sights,” because they were abandoned and no one was around to help, he began to worry in earnest. The cyclist got to the point that he started to suck on pebbles, in a desperate order to circulate the last spit he had in his mouth. In his desperation he finally saw a sign for hope that gave him the strength in order to continue on. When he arrived at GARY AND SONS FISH CAMP, his emotions, and mind changed from being lugubrious, to becoming thankful and profoundly relieved for the respite.

During his cycling trip, the author had to endure extreme heat, face snakes, deal with little or no shade and survive a dire lack of water, all problems directly related to the setting of Yosemite National Park. The author, cyclist Joe Kurmaskie, writes of becoming dangerously dehydrated, and describes, “the sun was beginning to beat down and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” Another struggle for him was crossing the path of a “ridiculously large snake” and then trying to keep his balance in his dehydrated and weakened state. Kurmaskie ran out of water, due to the extreme, unrelenting heat, and upon finally reaching a water pump, finds the water to be unfit for drinking and “in the neighborhood of zoo degrees,” or scalding hot. Another setting-related issue for Kurmaskie was the fact the area seemed completely deserted and he had to continue for many more miles until he was able to find a spot with clean, cool water where he could finally rest and properly rehydrate his exhausted body.

The features of the setting were very affective in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” It affected the cyclist because in one part of the setting it went to rolling hills. That’s going to be hard to pedal a bike on, requiring immense physical effort and draining his energy. Another way the setting affected the cyclist is at one point tumbleweeds were in his way. If they get caught on the bike it could have caused him to fall and it could harm him, creating a dangerous obstacle. Lastly, the road started getting rough up ahead which could be hard to ride over potholes and things like that, jolting his bike and making the journey uncomfortable and unstable. Therefore, the setting was significantly affecting the cyclist throughout his challenging ride.

The features of the setting keep affecting the cyclist because first its hopeful then he realizes its hopeless. He was laughing when people told him the right directions and now “It was sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had energy to feel bad for self,” said the cyclist when he was referring back to the first town. The reason this affects the cyclist is at first he was going good, feeling confident and energetic on his journey. Then he got thirsty and bad things happened, like his water supply running low and his strength fading, which shifted his mood from optimism to despair. This progression from hope to hopelessness shows how the journey's conditions gradually wore him down, and that is how it affected the cyclist.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” written by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affected the author in many ways. One feature was the hills, which posed a significant physical challenge to his progress. The speed limit affected the author because he felt that he was moving too slow, especially when compared to the pace of the cars on the road. In the story when it says “I was doing a water-depleting fifteen,” is evidence of this, indicating that his slow, arduous pace was also rapidly consuming his vital water supply. This combination of terrain and regulation directly impacted his physical state and his perception of the journey.

This is how the setting effects the cyclist. One is the hot dry California desert heat. It was making him hot and thirsty which was making him low on water. The hot desert heat had made water a foreign-like substance which he could not drink from the well, as it was dry or inaccessible. The water bottle only contained a few tantalizing sips which was not enough to quench his thirst, leaving him parched and desperate. The hot heat that would make birds pick him dry; all of those examples make it hard for the reader to take the old timer’s advice. It made him realize that in time comes wisdom and youth can make silly mistakes, like underestimating the desert. The heat had made it only a trip for his inner soul to survive, testing his mental fortitude. That is how the setting effects the cyclist.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist mainly because he was in a desert. There were no stores, no rivers or lakes, it was very hot, the roads were long and there were even snakes on the road. It made it harder for him because he didn’t have much water to drink, and the relentless heat and lack of resources created a constant state of physical strain and dehydration. The isolation and harsh environmental conditions compounded his difficulties, making the simple act of cycling a formidable challenge for survival.

Many features in the setting affect the cyclist, shaping his journey through hope and disappointment. Several main features include the cars leading to a town that isn't really a town anymore, and the water pump. Both of these examples gave him hope but none gave him relief. The town he first saw could have given him water, but it was all run down and weakened. He reflects, “I arrived at the first ‘town’. This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time... refer the @NUM1 word war.” He is saying that the town could’ve given him more water and energy, but it appeared that it was over for this town, offering only a hollow promise. Additionally, he biked across a water pump that was well needed, a potential oasis. He tried to pump water but got no success, noting, “I pumped the handle for several minutes but the water wouldn’t cool down.” A working water pump would’ve been huge for him, giving him more strength to bike and revitalizing his spirits. However, once again it was very misleading, leaving him as parched as before. These encounters consistently presented the illusion of aid while providing no tangible relief for his arduous journey.

This is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, primarily through physical challenge and environmental conditions. One example is “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” That changes the effect because by saying that it will show how tired he is going to be or the work trying to make it over the hills, demanding greater physical exertion. Another example would be “high deserts of California in June.” That’s saying its hot outside and very tiring, creating a harsh and draining atmosphere. I think it means that because in California its really hot and in June the “summer time” its very tiring, exacerbating his fatigue and thirst. The terrain and climate thus work in concert to intensify the difficulty of his ride. That is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, defining the struggle of his journey.

The features affect the cyclist because of how the road is made, directly influencing his speed and effort. If the road is a downhill ride the cyclist might ride faster, gaining a welcome respite. Conversely, the road might be up the hill so he would have to go slow, straining his muscles and consuming his energy. There could be a possibility that the road might have bumpy rocks or grass on it that could be something tough to ride through, jolting his body and demanding constant vigilance. Each type of surface presents a different kind of obstacle, from smooth sailing to grueling climbs. So the affect on the cyclist is depending on how the roads are made, with every mile presenting a new physical test that dictates the pace and nature of his travel.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist because the worst the features get the more he wants water, intensifying his thirst. For example, in the essay it said at some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculous large snake blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. When I think of tumbleweeds I think of dryness because it is like dry grass and when I think of snakes I think of heat because that is the time for snakes to come out when it gets hot, creating a landscape of aridity. So the cyclist was thinking about dryness of his throat and the dryness of his surroundings making him want water desperately. Another feature is when he seen a sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth, a cruel mirage. This image probably made the cyclist wishing he could have that cold refreshing drink, taunting him with what he lacked. These environmental cues constantly remind him of his dehydration, making his need for water all-consuming.

In “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclist was effected by the features of the setting, which guided and challenged her journey. She was first effected by the old men which told her a “shortcut” to her ride to Yosemite National Park, setting her on a difficult path. Then she was effected by a ghost towns which had no water to give her, dashing her hopes for replenishment. Then she was almost dehydrated when she came to a rickety road which had a few tumbleweed and a huge snake which was quite difficult to get by, presenting both physical and psychological obstacles. Then at the end she came upon “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp” where she decided to make decisions herself, taking control of her situation. All of these things in the setting affected the cyclist in a negative way except “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp” which saved her from dehydration, providing the crucial aid she desperately needed to continue.

In the short story, “Rough Road Ahead”, the cyclist faced with many problems. One of these is the feature of setting. I believe it has a big affect. The setting is in a desert, which is very hot, there is no water around and usually nobody lives in a desert. A crucial thing is that he was running out of water. In the text it says, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Another setting of the book that affects the cyclist is that it is in June. June is a very hot month, especially when the cyclist is in a desert traveling many miles, and this intense heat directly contributes to his rapid dehydration and physical exhaustion. Ultimately, the harsh desert environment and the scorching June heat combine to create a formidable challenge for the cyclist, testing his limits and will to continue.

The settings of a cyclist affects the way a cyclist performs. If the weather is too hot then the cyclist might slow down because of the sun beating down on them, causing fatigue and sweat. If it's too cold, the cyclist puts on more clothes which might weigh them down from achieving the speed they need to obtain. The bike itself has to be stable, and the terrain is a major factor. Riding on rough roads affects braking, speeding, and requires chains to be in good condition. Furthermore, the area where the cyclist rides sets the mood. If it's a nice scenery the cyclist might be in a wonderful mood, as opposed to the scenery being dark and gloomy with nasty weather behind it, where the cyclist might not be as happy as they could be. These types of things collectively help determine how settings can affect the cyclist, influencing both their physical performance and their mental state.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead” the setting greatly affects the cyclist. The oppressive desert climate bears down upon the cyclist. For example, the route he takes is not only isolated, but also has no place to get water. The heat and lack of water combine for a deadly risk of dehydration upon the cyclist. The setting now forces the cyclist to become more determined if he wants to live, pushing him to his physical limits. He must continue and pray for a town to come up, so he can restock on water and become hydrated once again. This relentless environment is the central conflict, shaping his struggle for survival and his ultimate resolve to persevere against the odds.

Many different things affected the cyclist on his way to Yosemite National Park, but the environment he was in played the biggest role in his journey. The cyclist was in a dry, desert area where tumble weeds were more common than people. When the cyclist came across the old men and asked them for directions, they led him to a “ghost town” where there was no water for the dehydrated cyclist who had been baking in the extremely dry, hot weather. This caused a problem where the cyclist thought that he would die in the desert because of the weather, the misleading directions he was given, and the critical lack of water. When the cyclist came across the bait shop he knew he was saved. He became rehydrated and wisely declined directions from an old man because these features of the setting are what caused his problems in the first place: old men, dry weather, and the desperate need for water. His experience demonstrates how the setting was both an antagonist and a teacher, guiding his decisions by the end.

There are a couple things that affect the cyclist in the story. One of the ways he is affected is dehydration. In the story about dehydration it says “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” A good effect on the cyclist was having no one in sight to slow him down on his bike ride. A bad effect on him was that he learned not to ask for direction from a guy, as he reflects that "heat strokes on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't left their porch in a decade, caused me to laugh". One more thing that got in his way was the poisonous snake. "At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake--It really did look like a diamond back... Blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me". These obstacles, from the climate to the wildlife, collectively shaped his difficult journey through the desert landscape.

The cyclist, not knowing where he was going, received incorrect information and unfortunately followed it. He had initially been excited, believing he knew his destination. Along his arduous journey, he was affected by a number of environmental factors, such as the relentless sun. The summer weather conditions of his expedition and the large snake he encountered posed significant challenges. He was severely affected by the sun because he was dehydrating rapidly, and he almost had no water left. The increasing heat made the journey very difficult for him and made his mood strange and disoriented. While attempting to follow the direction, he was further disheartened by a big snake he encountered on the case, which startled him. He was scared that he was going to be attacked and had to cautiously make his way past it. These features affected him profoundly because he didn't know where he was going and he felt utterly lost. Consequently, he ended up going in the wrong direction, a situation for which he was not prepared, especially given the harsh summer weather. It was extremely hot, and he was riding a bicycle, not a car, which exposed him directly to the elements and intensified his struggle.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist and his train of thought, leading him into a spiral of despair. On page @NUM1 it says, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” This statement gives a strong sense of the oppressive heat and effectively foreshadows the critical lack of water he will experience later on. The environmental pressure continues as he passes a snake, noting he was “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” So the cyclist is most likely beginning to feel dizzy and weak, which causes him to start losing hope. On page @NUM2 he reveals his growing fear, saying, “I could drop from heatstroke,” meaning he’s starting to imagine the worst possible outcomes. This thought process affects him deeply because he’s beginning to lose faith and thinks he’s not going to make it to safety. On page @NUM3, his despair reaches its peak when he says, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” By this point, the harsh and unforgiving conditions he was enduring were profoundly rough and making him worry intensely about his survival. This progression clearly illustrates how the features of the setting affected the cyclist's mental state throughout the story.

With little water, the setting was distinctly unhelpful and actively hostile to the cyclist. Joe @PERSON1 emphasized the isolation, saying, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind” (@PERSON1). After having received bad directions from a few old men, having people passing by in cars or nearby stores would probably have helped the cyclist immensely for asking for proper directions. The lack of resources is further highlighted when @PERSON1 described "working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength" (@PERSON1). Having no water to replenish one's body will inevitably lead to weakness and physical instability, which is a severe problem when one is in the middle of nowhere. @PERSON1 also noted the challenging terrain, stating, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (@PERSON1). With little water left and a body growing progressively weaker, it must have been incredibly hard to navigate the physical exertion of going up and down those slopes. Furthermore, @PERSON1 also said, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (@PERSON1), which conjures images of dust filling one's lungs and the relentless heat from the sun, making it increasingly harder for the body to function properly under such duress.

The setting in the story profoundly affected the cyclist, creating a formidable obstacle to his journey. The narrative takes place in June, a time when it is notoriously very hot, and as a result, the cyclist is getting dangerously dehydrated. One can vividly imagine how intensely hot it became when the text stated, “wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage,” illustrating both the physical discomfort and the mental fatigue induced by the heat. It also sounded in the story that the temperature felt unbearably high, as if it were two hundred degrees, with the sun beating down mercilessly upon him. This oppressive atmosphere directly contributed to his physical strain and growing sense of desperation, demonstrating the powerful influence of the environment on his experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways, compounding the difficulties of his journey. For example, it was June and he was cycling through the @CAPS1 of California, a region known for its extreme summer climate. It was very hot, and the heat rapidly dehydrated him, sapping his strength. Furthermore, he did not know where he was going, so he had to rely on directions from other people, which introduced an element of uncertainty and potential for error. The cumulative effect of the heat and his poor navigation meant he had to struggle constantly against dehydration and disorientation. These are the primary factors that negatively affected the cyclist throughout his challenging ordeal.

The features of the settings in “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie were rough and challenging. A biker rides through Todi, California, which is a rough and desolate area to ride. The ride was so hot and long that he was severely dehydrated, with dried sweat caking the skin around his neck. The solo cyclist emphasizes the isolation, saying, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” He had nowhere to get water or food, as the landscape was completely deserted. He had the grim thought that if he died, no one would find him quickly, and the birds would pick his bones clean. Ultimately, the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Kurmaskie shows that a solo cyclist must be very independent and resilient.

In the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist faced many obstacles throughout his arduous journey. For example, he had to get directions to Yosemite National Park from a group of elder men he encountered, but the directions were based on their old memories and the information was sadly out of date. In addition, the cyclist had to make a critical decision when he came to a fork in the road, choosing the path the old men said would lead to a town nearly eighteen miles down the road. Furthermore, the cyclist ran into a series of challenges, from flat roads that eventually gave way to rolling hills, to snakes blocking his path, and finally a dangerous state of dehydration that could have killed him. In conclusion, this man overcame numerous physical and navigational obstacles to successfully reach his destination at Yosemite National Park.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects the cyclist in various different ways. First of all, he listened to the directions from an old man, which led him to be on the wrong and more difficult path. He travels through the hot June day in the California deserts, where the odds are against him from the very start. He describes his predicament, stating, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I needed a drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” From the angle of this description, you can tell that he is exhausted and almost out of water. This harsh environment puts a lot of strain on the cyclist, but he manages to persevere through the adversity.

The setting clearly has a huge effect on the cyclist and the progression of his journey. The flat roads are easy and smooth to ride on, providing a brief respite, but as the road changes to short, rolling hills, the biking becomes significantly more difficult. This is supported by the sentence that reads, "Over are long, crippling hill..." This shows that the hill is a very challenging and draining obstacle for him to overcome. He is also affected by the various things that come with the change in terrain, which highlight the remoteness. For example, one sentence reads "...tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake it really did look like a diamondback-blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me." This detail stresses how isolated the area in which he is biking really is, and shows how the setting mentally and physically impacts his entire trip, demanding constant vigilance and effort.

The effect of the setting begins with two old timers sitting on their front porch out in the desert, men who had been there since Carter was in office. It was starting to become daylight, and the cyclist realized he had to travel many miles to get to the next town. So he gets on his bike and begins the long ride to the next town under the rising sun. The posted speed limit on the road is 55 miles per hour, but he was only going 12 miles per hour, his pace just like a slow water flow. He was riding up and down the rolling hills, feeling the strain of the continuous elevation changes. He finally got to the next town, achieving his goal and securing his chance to live and recover from the demanding trek.

The setting of the essay affects the cyclist significantly because he becomes lost after asking for directions from a group of old people. Their instructions, which were likely confusing or inaccurate, lead him astray in an unfamiliar area. This pivotal moment, driven entirely by the setting's inhabitants, directly causes his subsequent disorientation and struggle to find his way, ultimately shaping the entire course of his difficult journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in a lot of ways. In the essay, the author describes how the setting is hot, it is bumpy, it makes him sweat, it makes him tired, and he is also running out of water from his thirst. The road gets very rocky at one point, which makes the cycling arduous. The narrator states, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1), indicating a sudden change in the landscape's difficulty. There is also a photograph that shows how rough the terrain is, providing visual proof of the challenging environment. It is barren with nothing around it, offering no relief or resources for the weary traveler.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the cyclist is dehydrated and has to ride on horrible conditions of a road, with obstacles like snakes and hills. All of these features act like an obstacle course, which makes it hard to do what he’s trying to do, which is receive water. Also, with the cyclist being hot and in need of water, he at this point is delirious and most likely doesn’t know what’s going on. In the story, the author's main feature of the setting is the road, as indicated by the sign, “Rough road ahead.” This explains the cyclist having to go on a rough road, and doing that while dehydrated is very dangerous. These are some of the key features of the setting that negatively affect the cyclist and his physical state.

The settings have a huge affect on the cyclist. When he first comes to the “@CAPS1 town” he isn’t really worried; he is kind of laughing and thinks it's funny by saying, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time - say, before the last world war.” Then after he says that, it says he chuckled. When he gets to the dark in the road with the risky pipe of water, he begins to switch into conservation mode and begins to get scared. He says, “I would comer water- a test at my inner spirit,” this showing that he was scared. After he sees the abandoned Grape juice factory, he says something like birds are going to pick him clean and leave behind some expensive biking gear. This definitely shows that he is giving up. Another thing that would back this up is when he talks about writing in his diary about the old men who gives him these directions. When he finally reaches the bait shop he is relieved and goes to the bathroom and drinks water. He also says that he will buy bait even though he doesn’t have a rod. These examples show the many ways the setting affected the cyclist, from his initial amusement to his final desperation and relief.

In the story, "Do not exceed posted speed limit," the features of the setting effect the cyclist. To keep cool on a hot summer day, it might be necessary for one to find shade. Just to add to the misfortune of the story, "There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind." This factor does not help the cyclist at all; in fact, all it does is make the cyclist more exhausted and isolated. Another element in the story that effects the cyclist is the lack of water. Early on in the story the author explains, "The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips." With more miles to go, the cyclist starts to loose hope of making it to his destination alive. The feature of rolling hills also affects the cyclist. The cyclist is already tired enough, and just to add to his misfortune, "flat roads was replaced by short, rolling hills." Although the hills are short, they still could have put impact on him because of the repetitive nature of the hills. Many features of the story effected the mood and the physical state of the cyclist throughout his journey.

The features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist. It affected him because the sign was saying @NUM1 miles and then he was in the first town, thinking that he was getting excited and he was almost done, believing he was going at a fast pace. When the cyclist finally got to the first town, he said that it looked completely dead, with no signs of life. And then after he kept moving, he gradually began to understand that he wasn't getting anywhere. Then after some more thinking, he noticed with frustration that he had listened to some old folks who had never even been off their own porch. So after the cyclist had hit the first desolate town, he had known right then and there that he should never listen to old folks ever again. Because that first town had looked like nobody has been in it for years, a lesson he would not soon forget.

The features of the setting on the way to Yosemite National Park greatly affected the cyclist. On the long journey to the park, the cyclist had encountered the oppressive heat of the California desert. Besides the relentless heat, the cyclist had to overcome the rough terrain of the short, rolling hills, which were deceptively challenging. This strenuous effort made the cyclist tired and weary, sapping his strength. Adding to his growing weakness, and the extreme heat, he also ran out of water, causing him to become dangerously dehydrated. He noted, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke...laugh.” This difficult trip through the harsh California desert greatly affected the cyclist by causing great exhaustion and dehydration, testing his limits.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the climate could be intensely hot, the road could be bumpy and difficult, and the town could be completely deserted. For example, a sign reading, "Rough Road Ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit," would present a serious challenge for a cyclist who is already thirsty. And if he is thirsty and has no water, he would probably barely make it up the steep hills, his energy fading. And with no town available for getting water, his thirst would become overwhelming. The "first town" might have been a thriving little spot at one point, but another warning was that it fit the description of a ghost town's outskirts. With no water available there, his situation became truly dire.

Hot conditions, a lack of water, and being lost—all are ways the features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, it was incredibly hot. In one sentence he says the sun was beginning to beat down mercilessly. He also noted that the water in his bottle felt around two-hundred degrees, too hot to drink. That sweat was pouring all over him, so he had to be really suffering from the heat. Next, the critical lack of water affected him and his performance deeply. The reason was that he was dying in need of a drink. He tried everything to get water but made it through with almost no water left, pushing his endurance. Lastly, he was completely lost, as the map that he had was wrong and the trip wasn't what he had expected. But in the end, he was relieved to have persevered. So even with all these negative effects, he still managed to come to a positive resolution. Basically, this story is explaining how if you try your hardest, never give up, and try new things, you are most likely to succeed in life and other endeavors you @MONTH1 take part in. So one should always try their best and make a way for their life and plans.

The conditions the cyclist has to face are always either problems or helpers on his journey. Say there is a rocky up-hill part of the trail; that will most definitely slow him down significantly, requiring immense effort. But if there is a nice smooth downhill part immediately after, that will speed him up considerably and take a lot of the work of pedaling off his hands, providing a welcome respite. The terrain, therefore, directly dictates the rhythm and difficulty of his ride.

The cyclist lost hope because he was in the California desert in June, a time of year known for its extreme, oppressive heat. The cyclist started to lose hope because there was a rusty water pump that pumped out battery-acid tasting water, making it completely undrinkable and worsening his dire thirst. When he saw the sign “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, he was very cautious, his spirits sinking further with each difficult pedal stroke. The cyclist thought for sure that he was going to die out there, his mind conjuring images of failure and defeat. The cyclist also felt lonely because in the text it says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This profound isolation, combined with the harsh reality of the California desert, made him think he was going to die out there, completely alone and forgotten.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, he describes his trying biking trip through California, a journey that tested his physical and mental limits. In the essay, he describes the weather with “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” While this statement does not directly characterize the weather, the reader can confirm a clear image of the sweltering heat of a desert in the summer, a heat that is relentless and draining. When the author comes across the “ghost town” followed by the dilapidated shack, and finally the sign that read “Rough Road Ahead,” his hope of finding Yosemite Park was gone, replaced by a deep-seated dread. The hopelessness of the situation made the author want to give up, thinking that he was going to die out in the desert from dehydration and exhaustion, a fear that became increasingly real. This can be related to anyone that has been lost in unfavorable conditions, and the feeling of helplessness and fear that goes along with it. It feels like everything is against you, with nothing working in your favor, and this is what the author experiences in his description of his trip in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” a powerful account of human vulnerability.

The setting affects the cyclist in that the exhaustion was getting to him, weighing down his limbs and clouding his thoughts. What made it worse was that he was out in the heat sweating, which also caused dehydration, creating a vicious cycle of physical depletion. The unrelenting sun and the vast, empty landscape contributed to a growing sense of fatigue and despair.
