Every element of the desert environment seemed designed to sap his remaining strength, leaving him feeling utterly spent and vulnerable to the harsh conditions. This combination of factors made his journey not just physically demanding, but also a profound mental challenge.

To begin with, a feature that affected the cyclist was a lack of water; this is shown when the speaker says when he tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. That was one of the biggest factors he had risked, as finding a viable water source was critical for his survival in the desert. The terrible taste made it impossible to drink, turning a potential respite into another source of disappointment. This encounter with the undrinkable water from the old pump deepened his sense of crisis, highlighting how a single resource could mean the difference between continuing and succumbing. His hope for relief was dashed, compounding the physical hardship of his journey.

As the reader listened and followed the directions of the old-timers, he faced many issues and also learned a lesson about self-reliance. As he began to ride into the daybreak of morning, he had strong legs and even a smile on his face, full of optimism for the adventure ahead. As time went on, he soon became close to out of water and suffered a loss of energy, the initial enthusiasm fading under the harsh realities of the journey. The intense summer day made him sweat and began to think that the birds would pluck at his body as if he would die on his ride to Yosemite, a grim thought born of extreme fatigue. When he finally got to a town, he soon refreshed himself and learned that he would start to begin to follow his own way of getting to places, realizing the value of his own judgment over blindly following the advice of others. This hard-won wisdom became the most valuable souvenir from his challenging trek through the desert.

The features of the setting in the essay “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” affected the cyclist in a profoundly negative way. The more and more he rode through the desolate landscape, he thought more negatively and had a lot of doubt. The cyclist was not very confident, he thought he wouldn’t make it and his mind was filled with grim possibilities. For example, when the cyclist notices nothing in sight, his tone changes to one of deep uncertainty. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon telling myself that if I could make it that far , I’d be fine”. He seemed unsure and a little nervous, his resolve weakening with each empty mile. As the journey continued, the cyclist loses hope it seems, his thoughts turning to despair. “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary”. He does not see himself finishing this journey the more and more he rides in the middle of nowhere with nothing to be seen except the recurring “Rough Road Ahead” signs, which only reinforce his isolation and the immense difficulty of his task, ultimately leading him to a state of mental defeat.

The features in the setting are very effective and challenging to the cyclist. He is in a desert area of California and he has a critically limited water supply. It is very hot and very dry, with the sun beating down relentlessly. He barely had any water to drink and he had to go a long way in the hot and humid weather, which drained his energy quickly. The deficiency of water could have made him became dehydrated, a serious risk in such an exposed environment. Another significant obstacle that he had during this biking trip to Yosemite National Park was the series of hills that he faced. At the beginning, he was on flat terrain, but now he has steep hills that he has to pedal up that makes it a lot harder for him, demanding greater physical exertion. One other frightening obstacle that he faced was the snake he ran into on the path. That setting had many obstacles for this guy, each one testing his limits. If it wasn't for the oppressive heat and the critical lack of water, he might have been able to make it a little easier, but combined, these elements created an overwhelmingly difficult journey.

The features of the setting strongly affected the cyclist, presenting a series of physical trials. The rolling hills were the cyclist’s most challenging problem because they were long and crippling, seeming to stretch on forever. Maneuvering down the hill would take a lot of energy and determination from the cyclist, as would the arduous climb back up. Considering the cyclist was already tired and sweating from riding on rough roads and passing a large snake, riding on these relentless rolling hills would be extremely difficult, pushing him to his absolute limit. The features of the setting were not helping the cyclist stay healthy because their extreme difficulty was causing the cyclist to become dehydrated and possibly drop from heatstroke under the harsh sun. However, the cyclist kept a positive attitude and did not give up, focusing on the goal ahead. His determination saved him as he felt immense relief when he finally came across the "Gary and wilbells fish camp," a sign of civilization and respite. In conclusion, the features of the setting affected the cyclist because they forced him to work extra hard and put forth more effort than he anticipated, but with determination, you can accomplish anything and overcome the challenges of the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” directly influencing his mental state. The cyclist mood seems to change as the road and setting does, growing darker with the increasing difficulty. The narration states, “ a large high way sign jumped out at me. I read : Rough road ahead : Do not exceed posted speed limit … sometimes life can feel so cruel (Kurmaskie).” This sign symbolizes the escalating hardship he faces. Slowly as the terrain gets harder and harder the cyclist feels worse and worse, his energy and optimism depleting in tandem. Every time he believes there is a town he gets happy, a brief spark of hope, but his dreams are soon crushed by the reality of the empty landscape. One can see in the picture the hard cycling terrain that can affect the cyclist, making him tired due to the lack of water and the growing sense of hopelessness he feels as he loses energy and begins to believe he will die alone in the vast, unforgiving environment.

Some features of the setting that affected the cyclist were signs that had speed limits, which dictated the pace of his travel. The sign affected the speed of the cyclist, forcing him to slow down and navigate with extra caution on the difficult path. Another significant feature was a steep hill on the route, which presented a major physical challenge. This affected the cyclist by making him tired and causing physical strain, as evidenced when he said “I wipe the sweat from my eyes,” a clear sign of his exertion and fatigue. These elements of the setting, though simple, directly shaped his experience by imposing both mental and physical demands on his journey, demonstrating how the environment can dictate the rhythm and difficulty of travel.

The setting had a huge effect on the cyclist. One significant effect was the severe lack of water in the area he was in, which was a vast, arid desert. The profound lack of people in the desolate area didn’t help the cyclist out at all, offering no chance for assistance. The steep, unending hills on the road made it more tough on the cyclist because they drained what little energy he had left in his weary body. Also, the relentless sun beating down on him made his body more warm, causing dehydration and making it harder for him to focus on the difficult task at hand. Ultimately, the harsh environment proved to be a formidable adversary to his journey.

In the setting of “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is greatly affected. In the beginning, the author is enjoying a nice campground outside Lodi, California, when some “old-timers” told the cyclist directions. From his point of view, "they'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing off out land marks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy aunt." So the cyclist used that information and it wasn't for the better, as their directions led him astray. He found himself on a difficult and unexpected path, a consequence of trusting their confident but flawed advice. This experience taught him a valuable lesson about the reliability of information.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly. When an old man had told him, "do you know where to go?" the other guy was like, "yes sir! I own a very good map," but the reality of the journey changed for the man riding the bike. He saw all of those towns and a sign that said "Rough Road Ahead," a warning he had not anticipated. What had changed was he saw all of those buildings and towns, and he was going and going, realizing the landscape was more demanding than his map suggested. I think he might stick with the future, learning to rely on more than just old assurances. This decision will likely guide his travels from now on.

In the story, the cyclist faced many problems, one of the biggest being the terrain that he had to maneuver through. The terrain was relentlessly hilly; having to go up a steep hill on a bike is tiring and wears you out faster than flat land would, making him use more of his dwindling energy. The oppressive heat was also unbearable, making it harder for him to focus, and the cyclist did everything he could to stay conscious while maneuvering through the terrain. The deserted landscape, a huge desert of rolling mountains, offered no respite as he pushed forward, finding no civilization anywhere to get a crucial refill of water. For example, if the terrain wasn’t as hilled then it would have made it easier for him, using less energy and causing less strain on his legs. The heat of the desert beating down on him probably slowed his progress considerably, as heat will make you move slower. A cyclist moving down a burning road with no shade will make the journey seem longer and nearly impossible. In the end, his sheer will and determination got him through the landscape, so he could finally get the water he needed to finish his arduous trip.

In this essay, the features of the setting cause the cyclist to become irritated toward the old men. In this essay, old men give the cyclist directions, and instead of using a reliable map, he takes their advice. However, their information is out of date, and it takes the cyclist through exhausting rolling hills and bumpy, poorly maintained roads. The cyclist uses all of his energy to get to unknown towns of no importance, and he finds himself with no water in the desolate area. The cyclist blames the old men for giving him directions that wasted his energy and led him astray. However, he should really become angry with himself for taking their advice, and not using a credible map or seeking real, verified directions. This introspection marks an important realization about personal responsibility.

The setting of where you are riding has a lot to do with the cyclist, influencing both their physical state and mental attitude. In my own opinion, I think the setting is the most important part of the entire cycling experience. A pleasant environment can uplift the spirit and make the ride enjoyable, while a harsh one can drain both energy and morale. The surroundings directly shape the cyclist's journey, making the context in which they ride fundamentally significant to the outcome and their overall feeling about the trip.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting greatly affects the cyclist and his mindset. When the scenery is pretty and cheery, he is happy as well. This is shown when the author writes, “enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer-evening.” This quote describes the scenery as a serene or peaceful place. His happiness is found in the first part of the quote when he said, “enjoyed.” One does not enjoy something unless they are happy or in a cheery mindset. Therefore, the peaceful scenery affected the cyclist by making him happy. The same can be said for dreary scenery too. This is found when the author says, “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.” This quote describes the scenery as a place that has tumbleweeds. Stereotypically, tumbleweeds are found in dreary and lonely places. This lonely scenery takes its toll on the cyclist. He becomes pessimistic and is thinking of all that could go wrong, not all that could get better. This is found around us every day. The poor and homeless who live with a low standard of living are often said to be affected by their grim surroundings. In conclusion, the setting does affect the cyclist and his mindset drastically, proving how deeply our environment influences our inner state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the setting changed so drastically. The flat wide open road turned into “short, rolling hills.” Because he was already running out of water, the changing terrain was making it harder for him to have the will power and determination to go up and down these hills. His determination started to fade because he started to see wide open lands with nothing but “tumbleweeds and ridiculously large snakes.” He felt like he was going to dehydrate because the sun was beating down and he had no water left. He used pebbles that he had found to put in his mouth to help circulate the saliva he had left. He even wishes that he would choke on one because he feels so useless and defeated by the harsh landscape. The oppressive features of the setting ultimately overwhelm his spirit and physical capacity.

In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit”, by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist faces many hardships on his way to Yosemite due to the features of the setting. The fact that it was a hot summer’s day contributed to his hardships. With little water, it was easier for him to get dehydrated. In the text, the author writes, “...I could drop from heat stroke, on a gorgeous day in June.” (Kurmaskie, @NUM1). This lets the reader know that the heat of June was very dangerous to the cyclist. There was also nobody around except “Old timers who haven’t left the confines of their perches since water was in offing” (Kurmaskie, @NUM2). The narrator stresses his viewpoint on taking directions from these people since their directions are poor. It can be inferred that he meant they were obviously out of date when giving directions since the ones they gave him were not correct. The cyclist in this story had a rough time getting to his destination due to the setting, which presented both environmental and social obstacles that complicated his journey significantly.

The terrain in “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie presented many difficulties the cyclist had to cope with. He was already lacking water from the arduous journey and then the environment turned against him. The narration states, “I noticed the terrain changing; flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This means the cyclist is going to put forth more energy to make it up these hills, energy he barely has. This exertion will drain almost all the energy the cyclist has left. Another example is, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This means that the cyclist is in the middle of nowhere with barely any water and energy, causing even more problems as the desolate landscape saps his morale. In conclusion, the setting in, “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie caused many problems for the cyclist, demonstrating how the physical challenges of the terrain are a central conflict in the narrative.

In the story “Rough road ahead” the setting affects the cyclist significantly. The cyclist is affected by the lack of water, the considerable distance he has to travel, and the challenging hilly terrain. The line, “The water bottles contain only a few tantalizing sips. wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt,” powerfully illustrates his severe dehydration and the exhausting heat. The physical strain is further amplified by the relentless, steep hills that drain his remaining energy. Ultimately, the harsh setting affected the cyclist a lot in the story, creating a formidable obstacle course for his journey.

The cyclist has it hard in the difficult conditions; the lack of water, the intense heat, and the rough terrain are all things that made his ride harder. First, the lack of water took a toll on the amount of energy he had to keep going, leaving him parched and weak. Second, the oppressive heat also affected his trip profoundly; it made it hard for him to keep going to the point where he thought he would die, imagining the birds would pick at his dead body. Last, the terrain didn’t help his progress. The trip had many steep hills and that used a lot of his energy, making the journey even more arduous. In conclusion, those are the primary things that worked against the cyclist throughout his challenging ride.

The cyclist was being affected by several key elements of his environment. One way is the intense heat, which caused him to drink more water until he ran out completely, leaving him desperately thirsty. The next way is the misleading old men who gave him bad directions, leading him astray and wasting his precious energy. Another way was the long distance combined with the bad terrain, which consistently slowed him down and wore him out. The last reason is the unexpected snake on the path, which caused a delay and forced him to stop. All of these environmental factors contributed to the immense difficulty of his cycling trip.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways throughout his arduous journey. He was riding his bike across a remote and desolate place with no cars, no people, no water, or no food available to him. This isolation and lack of resources made it a dangerous journey for him, testing his limits both physically and mentally. Despite the overwhelming challenges presented by the unforgiving landscape, he demonstrated great perseverance and he made it to his destination in the end.

The features of the setting do affect the cyclist in his struggle. One example is the condition of his water jar, which is nearly empty and offers little relief from his thirst. The cracked and dry earth of the terrain reflects the overall harshness of his environment, making every rotation of his bicycle tires a laborious effort. This simple detail of the jar's state highlights his vulnerability and the scarcity of resources. Therefore, the setting's features directly impact his physical state and his chances of success on the difficult road.

The features of the setting can affect the cyclist because, say that there was nothing around. It might make you want to go faster and let out your inner speed demon when there are no obstacles in sight. That’s all I can really tell you. Because personally I don’t think the setting of where you ride your bike doesn’t even matter that much for a casual ride. Possibly for a dedicated bicyclist it can influence performance, but to me I don’t even think so, as the act of cycling itself is what counts most.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly, because there are no cars, buildings, water, or people in sight to offer any comfort or aid. It goes from a flat road to endless rolling hills, which sap his energy and spirit. Even though he had no water he was determined to keep pedaling, pushing through the fatigue. He sees a sign that reads, “Rough road Ahead, do not exceed posted speed limit.” At this point he had no water left and he was pretty much in the middle of nowhere, with no signs of life. If I was in his situation I would feel completely hopeless, as there was no sign of hope or rescue. He just saw endless rolling hills and that was all, a landscape that offered no solace. Then when he saw the building over the hills he thought he was home free, a feeling of immense relief washing over him. So he pedaled up to the building, and discovered that with all the others it was abandoned, crushing his spirit. The cyclist thought he was going to die there, alone. In conclusion the features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist because seeing nothing gives him no hope and amplifies his despair. If he had cars and buildings on both sides of him that probably would have given him some confidence, but that was not the case for him. He is in the middle of nowhere, a stark and unforgiving environment. He finally came to a bend and said, “Then, as easily as rounding a bend my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me,” as he finally found his way to safety.

There are many features of the setting that affect the cyclist on his difficult journey. His dehydration started with the sun beating down on him relentlessly, creating an intense thirst for water. He was mainly affected when he was out of water and rode by an abandoned Welch's grape juice factory, a cruel reminder of his need. “A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head,” he thought in despair. Then when he had almost nothing left he spotted a bait shop in the distance, a potential source of help. “Somehow I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope,” he recounted, describing his struggle. “Then, as easily as rounding a bend my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me,” he realized upon seeing a sign that read, “Gary and Mary’s Fish camp – If you want bait for the big ones we’re your best bet,” thus revealing his troubles were finally over and he had found a place of refuge.

The features of the setting that the author cycled through definitely affect not only his mood, but his physical condition throughout the journey. To start, it is mentioned that he is in “the high deserts of California in June,” where it is implied that the weather is intensely hot, causing the author to sweat profusely as he bikes along under the scorching sun. Next there is a change in terrain and he soon approaches “rolling hills” which are naturally more difficult and exhausting to bike on than flat ground. Finally the author sees a sign that reads “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT” and becomes discouraged because his bike is not even capable of reaching the speed limit, but he still has to manage getting past the rough road, which jolts his body and strains his muscles. After passing this difficult stretch he approaches a faded picture of a boy drinking juice that is posted on an old juice factory. Seeing this sign most likely perpetuates his thirst and leaves him feeling more exhausted and frustrated than before, as it taunts him with what he cannot have. Such features of his surroundings played a large part in the author’s change in mood from determined to disheartened, showing how the environment directly shaped his experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly throughout his arduous journey. First, is the beating sun, whose relentless heat dehydrates him and almost kills him under its powerful rays. The rocky road is also a significant factor, as its uneven surface takes up the precious time and energy he has to perform, making every pedal stroke a struggle. Another key ingredient of the setting was the vast, empty desert surrounding him, which offered no respite. There was no one to help him and there wasn't a place to get water for miles, increasing his sense of isolation and danger. In conclusion the setting was a big factor in the story, as its harsh and unforgiving elements directly challenged his endurance and will to survive.

The setting affects the biker in many ways. For one, he is riding through the high deserts of California during the month of June. It is naturally hot in the summer, but in the desert, it is twice as hot, with the sun beating down relentlessly. This means he will dehydrate quicker, and will need more water. The only water the biker can find is from an old pump, but he couldn’t drink it since it was so hot and nasty tasting. “When I tried a drop it had the flavor of battery acid” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). His route was completely deserted, so nobody could help him. Also, the terrain was bad, with steep and unrelenting grades. The hills caused him to use more of his energy, which he needed to stay alive. “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke caused me to laugh,” (@NUM1). He also encountered dangerous animals like the diamond black rattlesnake, adding another layer of physical danger. The setting also affected him mentally because he was silently yelling at himself since he took directions from the old men. He knew he should have taken the right way, instead of trying a short cut that he now realizes is abandoned and dangerous. The biker is being affected in these many ways, both mentally and physically, by the unforgiving environment.

The setting causes major problems for the cyclist in the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The cyclist was faced with a vast desert, traveling in extreme humid temperatures and with no water in sight. He encounters poisonous snakes and areas of no buildings or civilization all together, leaving him utterly isolated. The effect on him was the main conflict of the essay. He had no water during some of the trip and lost all hope, sinking into despair. He told himself that it was no use. In the story it says, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die…”. The extreme measures of the setting caused the cyclist to lose control, putting stones in his mouth to stop thinking of his thirst and to stimulate some saliva. Over all, the setting caused the cyclist major problems, physically, and mentally, pushing him to his absolute limits.

The ways that the setting affects the cyclist include how the road is shaped or the challenge of riding up the hills and the roughness of the road itself. There was a sign where it said “rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit.” That sign was crucial; if he didn’t see it he would have exceeded the speed or not known what speed to maintain as a cyclist and could have gotten seriously hurt. The road was made for cars, so the speed limit is hard to judge and the surface is unforgiving for a bicycle. These physical aspects of the setting directly influenced his safety and the difficulty of his journey, demonstrating how the environment dictates the terms of his travel.

In the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie the setting affects the cyclist. One setting that affected him was the first part of his journey. In this setting he used up his water and it was intensely hot. This affected the cyclist because he was starting to feel dehydrated and thought he was going to die from the heat. The text showed this when it said “I could drop from heat stroke”. Later when the cyclist came to an abandoned juice factory he thought about how thirsty he was, which taunted him. This affected him because usually when you think about thirst you get thirstier. This also made him feel disappointed and frustrated. The final setting affected him because he had finally found water and was no longer thirsty, providing a moment of relief. That is how the different settings affected the cyclist throughout his arduous trip.

On that long bike ride the cyclist was profoundly affected by the setting. He was affected by the lack of water, the intense heat and the bad directions he received. Throughout the story the cyclist ran out of water due to bad directions from some men, which led him astray. "Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” He ran out of water and became dangerously dehydrated through his trip. The heat played a major part in his dehydration during the bike ride under the scorching sun. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The trip was made even longer and more arduous due to some bad directions from some old men. “Because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh.” The gentlemen gave him wrong directions because in their time that was right information, but the land has since changed and the directions were obsolete. When going on bike rides the setting of the rides is a great help or a bad hindrance. The cyclist experienced firsthand how the setting of a bike ride can affect him a great deal, shaping his entire experience.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist very much. For example, the sun was beginning to beat down, its intense rays creating a shimmering haze on the asphalt ahead. Another example, I was hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, draining them faster than anticipated. The setting was hot and dry, a parched landscape that seemed to suck the moisture from the very air. It affected the cyclist very much, draining his energy and wilting his resolve. It was to the point of dying, where every pedal stroke was a monumental effort against the oppressive heat.

The cyclist in this essay was a very brave man. He had many obstacles in his journey but he still made it. Nature was most definitely not on his side that day, presenting a series of relentless challenges. He had to ride his bike up and down hills several times which wears you out very quickly, leaving his legs burning with fatigue. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills, a constant drain on his dwindling reserves. After he got through the hills, he came to a sign that read, “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT”. Now he has to go through bumpy roads, the jarring vibrations adding a new layer of misery to the ride. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. Now the poor guy had to deal with snakes bigger than him, forcing a cautious and nervous detour. Thankfully he got by the snake, alive, his heart pounding from the close encounter. Over one long crippling hill, a building came into view, sparking a flicker of hope. The man thinks he found someplace to get water, but it’s an abandoned building, its windows dark and empty. By the looks of it, it had been a Welch’s grape Juice Factory and bottling plant, a cruel irony that offered no relief to his profound thirst.

The setting affects the cyclist because it is hot, therefore he gets thirsty. When he says “the sun was beating on me” this shows it was hot, the relentless heat radiating from the sky and the road surface. The direct and powerful sunlight caused him to sweat profusely, rapidly depleting his body's fluids. That's one of the reasons why he was tired and dehydrated, as the harsh environmental conditions directly contributed to his physical state, leaving him exhausted and longing for water.

The feature of the setting affect the cyclist about old timers giving him wrong information about taking this short cut he was going to take. This misleading advice led him into a more difficult and isolated terrain than he had anticipated. Running out of water and energy, he was beginning to doubt himself and consider giving up on the race. It says he felt a growing sense of despair as the promised easy route turned into a grueling test of endurance, where the unforgiving landscape amplified his physical and mental struggles, pushing him toward the brink of surrender.

In the piece, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist felt black humor, despair and then relief due to the features of the setting. The cyclist felt black humor, due to the features. This was because it was very ironic where he was. It was a hot desert and he needed something to drink. He passes a closed juice factory, a sight so perfectly contrary to his needs that it sparked his black humor. The cyclist felt despair due to the features. This was because as far as he could see, "There was no one in sight, not a building, car, structure of any kind." This vast and empty desolation gave him the feeling there was no chance he could survive, a profound loneliness that made him despair. The cyclist felt relief later on due to the features. He eventually got to a bait shop. When he saw this living establishment, a sign of other people, he felt immense relief. Of this, it is written, "Then as easily as the turn of a page, hobbles, thirst and fear were all behind me." In this piece the features of the setting were ultimately what determined how the cyclist felt throughout his arduous journey.

In the essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by @PERSON1, many features of the setting effect the cyclist. First, when he arrived at the first “town” and said, “this place might have been a thriving little spot at one time – say, before the last world war.” This deserted ghost town setting was like a joke and had a small effect on the cyclist because it was the beginning of the day and he still had a good water supply, so his spirits were not yet fully diminished. Though when he arrived at the ramshackle shed surrounded by several rusty pumps the effect it had wasn’t so mild. He says, “The sight was troubling,” as the promise of water turned into a visual cue of decay. Then when he got on his hands and knees and started working the pump the situation didn’t get much better. All that came out was a drop or two that tasted like battery acid, a deeply unsatisfying and disheartening result. Lastly, when he arrived at an abandoned Welch’s Grape juice factory after several miles. This had a very wearing effect on him since the water supply was low and he had cycled into disappointment after disappointment, each location reinforcing the barrenness of the landscape. This setting in this essay seemed very abandoned and hopeless, creating a formidable physical and mental challenge. It was only determination that got this cyclist through it, pushing past the desolation that surrounded him.

The story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” is about a cyclist who got bad directions to Yosemite National Park and has a depleting water supply in extreme heat. He is doubtful that he will make his journey because he is dehydrated and dizzy, his physical state deteriorating with each passing mile under the relentless sun. The incorrect guidance led him into a remote and arid area, far from any reliable source of help or refreshment. His condition worsens as the journey continues, with the heat and lack of water creating a genuine crisis. This combination of factors places him in a perilous situation where his ultimate success is uncertain, testing his limits in the harsh environment.

The setting in this story is important because if you don’t have a setting then the narrative will not make sense; setting is a foundational element that everyone can understand and utilize. It can be anywhere or anything, from a bustling city to a quiet countryside, providing the context for the events that unfold. The setting helps put the whole story back together, giving the actions of the characters a place to happen and a atmosphere to influence them. The setting in this story is @LOCATION1 spending time with his family, which grounds the narrative in a specific, relatable environment. Setting is a very important part in a movie or video, as it establishes the visual and emotional tone for the entire production, making the story cohesive and immersive for the audience.

The way I would set my affected cyclist is by him riding through a challenging and unexpected landscape. He would be moving through something you would never think he can get through, an environment that seems insurmountable at first glance. This could be a vast, sun-scorched desert or a steep, rocky mountain pass that tests his endurance to the absolute limit. Then, by overcoming his initial intention to give up, he finds a deeper strength and resolve within himself. The difficult setting acts as the primary obstacle that he must conquer, ultimately leading to his personal triumph and the successful completion of his arduous journey.

The features of the setting in, “Rough Road Ahead” affect the cyclist profoundly. The cyclist started at a campground and was conversing with some old dodgers, and he asks them how to get to Yosemite, and they tell him a shortcut that turns out to be out of date and leads him astray. On the road to Yosemite he sees nothing except abandoned towns, which heightens his sense of isolation and desperation. He is really thirsty and there’s no water anywhere, a constant and gnawing need that dominates his thoughts. He thought he was going to die, a fear that became increasingly real. He said, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” a vivid and grim image of his anticipated fate. It was a hot summer day and there were tumbleweeds and snakes by the road, making him feel hotter and more thirsty than he would be if it was cooler and if there was a big river flowing by the road for relief. But it was hot and dry in California and desert-like, a harsh and unforgiving climate. It made him feel like he was dying because he was in the middle of nowhere with no signs of life or aid, and therefore the setting deeply and negatively affected the cyclist throughout his misdirected journey.

This cyclist had the challenging conditions of the land to deal with, navigating a harsh and unforgiving environment. He didn’t have too much water with him, and there wasn't a good source anywhere near him that he could see, which heightened his sense of vulnerability. He just had to keep going, pushing forward despite the mounting difficulties. He also talked about how the road was rough, with uneven terrain that jolted his bike and body. This was conflicting on how long it took him to get to the next place with water, as the difficult path seemed to stretch the journey interminably. More over he was in a desert area, a vast expanse of sand and rock. The air was dry and hot, the oppressive heat was making him sweat profusely, and that was leading him to become dangerously dehydrated, a constant threat on his arduous trek.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the distinct features of the setting profoundly effect the cyclist. They effect the cyclist’s confidence, and hope, shaping his mental state throughout the ordeal. I say this because through out the story he sees things that would consern other people, like the towns that are suppose to be the best end up as “Ghost towns” and the road changes from flat to demanding hills. Yet he continues on and then says, in a moment of despair, “what I believed was my last burst of energy,” and “I was going to die.” The cyclist dosent think he can continue but manages to keep going, desperately hoping that the next horizon will reveal a building or something, a sign of salvation. Hope saved his life because if he had given in to the belief that he could not continue, he truly could have died, demonstrating the power of perseverance against a bleak backdrop.

The physical features of the setting directly affect the cyclist, creating a relentless challenge. One reason the features of the setting affect him is because it is intensely hot outside which makes him need more water, depleting his limited supply rapidly. An example of this is the statement, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” Another compelling example of being hot outside is the description, “A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” This overwhelming heat from the environment relentlessly compounds his physical struggle, leaving him in a constant battle against dehydration and exhaustion.

In the short story “Rough Road Ahead” a cyclist is pushed through an extremely harsh setting while trying to get to Yosemite National Park. In the story the narrator takes a trip to Yosemite National park after getting directions from two older men; what the narrator doesn't know is that the road ahead is indeed rough and unforgiving. One narrator states, “I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state,” highlighting his physical deterioration. The narrator is really taking a beating from the travel, and the jagged rocks and dry climate is really taking a toll on his endurance and spirit. From reading this story the setting does not do any good for him other than the general store he finds in the end, which offers a brief respite. Like the title states, the setting of this story was accurately a “Rough Road Ahead,” defining his entire difficult journey.

The setting affects the cyclist through its specific features because if the cyclist was riding in a different, cooler location around june the affect of the month would not had been that harsh. The intense summer heat significantly amplified the challenges he faced. But overall the setting out begin in a hot place with limited water was not a good thing, creating a scenario of constant physical strain. The cyclist is affected by the setting through its direct impact on his body and resources, proving how environment dictates the difficulty of an endeavor.

Being a cyclist and in the condition he was in would be even worse in the setting he was in, such as the oppressive heat of California, and the difficult condition of the hilly path he was on. Him being so hot and tired from the difficult, steep trail would be worse with having the critical lack of supply of water. The author was very dehydrated, his throat parched and dry, and was on the verge of fainting from the exertion. If it were not so hot and the terrain less demanding, the cyclist would have been in a much better condition, able to continue his journey without such severe distress.

The cyclist in the article almost died from severe dehydration and heat stroke and wrote his misadventure in a light hearted, humourous way. I commend him for almost dying and laughing about it and then turning around and blaming it on old people, which adds a layer of ironic wit to his harrowing tale. He is an inspiration for reckless young folk who might see folly as an adventure. Oh yeah, and the setting was a vast, unforgiving desert, which amplified the danger of his situation immensely.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the time setting very much affects the cyclist during the story. One of the things that affect him during the story is that it was a very hot, sun scorching day, with relentless heat bearing down. Also he ran out of water and there was nothing but barren desert and poisonous snakes around, increasing his sense of isolation. Another thing is that when he ran out of water there was no snakes or warmers, just empty desert, so he started to become very thirsty and desperate. In the essay it also said he reached a part where he saw a sign that said “Rough Road Ahead, Do not exceed posted speed limit”, so the road conditions starting to get rough for him, which was another effect. In the end of the essay he reaches a camp where it is all peace and relaxed, and they have cold water there, this affects him because he feels replenished and finally safe. All these different features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly throughout his arduous journey.

The setting was affecting the character, because as the day got hotter he got thirstier, his physical state deteriorating with the rising temperature. Also because when he got to the sign about rough roads ahead, the environment itself seemed to issue a warning. He started to get worried and kinda paranoid about what lay ahead, so that’s how the setting affected him, shaping his mental state as much as his physical one.

There was a number of things that affected the cyclists during his travel. First off, at the old town there wasn’t any real water he could drink, the well being dry or the water undrinkable. So he was out of water and was going to be thirsty for the remainder of his journey. Also, it’s the middle of June in California, it’s very hot and the sun is going to wear him out pretty quickly, sapping his energy. Another thing that affected the cyclist is the steep hills he has to go up and down, which demanded great physical effort. For example, he says “Over one long, crippling hill”, he’s saying the hills are very hard for him and a significant obstacle. The setting of this essay was the California desert in June, which had the most significant impact on the cyclist compared to all other setting features. In the fifth paragraph, the reader learns that the author was “travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” My prior knowledge confirms that California is generally a very hot place, especially in the desert during June, the hottest month of the year. These extreme conditions would have greatly affected the cyclist, who was riding for over fifty miles through this arid landscape with a limited supply of water. This situation put him at a great risk for dehydration, a state he confirms he reaches in the last line of paragraph ten. The combination of the unforgiving terrain and the extremely hot conditions would inevitably make the cyclist very tired and severely dehydrated, thereby making his arduous journey to @CAPS1 @ORGANIZATION1 all the more difficult and dangerous.

The various features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist in many ways during his journey. He was isolated in a vast desert, with no one to provide him with reliable information and no nearby towns that were still operational. Compounding this, it was an exceptionally hot summer day with no accessible water sources nearby. These environmental factors collectively impacted the cyclist by causing physical distress; he was not sweating properly, suffered from a dry mouth, and had no energy, which led to him having a lot of doubt that he would not complete his journey alive. In the story, the cyclist explicitly reveals his despair, stating, ''I picked up some pebble and put them in my mouth. With my luer. I'd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. It didn’t really matter. I was going to die.'' This statement shows the depth of his doubt and hopelessness. Furthermore, every time he reached a potential source of help, such as a town or a building, he found it abandoned. The cruel irony of discovering an abandoned building that was once a Welch's Grape Juice factory and bottling plant only served to mock his plight and make him feel even thirstier. In these ways, the harsh features of the setting directly and severely affected the cyclist's physical and mental state.

The setting in the story greatly affected the cyclist, primarily because the main setting was a desert where he was riding his bike. The desert environment is notoriously hot and dry, meaning he needed significantly more water to stay hydrated than he would have if he were riding in a cooler, shaded area like the woods or in a cold, snowy climate. Furthermore, the physical challenges of the landscape added to his ordeal; there were numerous hills on his travel route that he had to ride his bike up, which requires considerably more physical energy and exertion. Consequently, this increased effort again meant he would have needed more water than if the road had been consistently flat. Finally, the specific terrain of the desert also introduced other dangers, such as the animals he ran into, including a snake, which could have seriously hurt him. Because the setting of the story was in this demanding desert environment, the cyclist was affected more both physically and mentally than he had initially thought he would be.

In this paragraph, I will be explaining some specific features of the setting that affected the cyclist during his journey. One significant effect was caused by the uneven, bumpy roads he was trying to cycle on. If the road surface had been flat and smooth, he would not have had to be as vigilant; however, the bumpy roads forced him to constantly look out for hazards like loose rocks and deep holes in the road to avoid an accident. Another major affect was caused by the presence of hills along his path. Ascending these inclines required him to put out a much greater amount of energy than if the route had been just flat, rapidly depleting his stamina. These challenging physical features of the landscape posed constant obstacles, and those are the key reasons that explain how the features of the setting negatively affected the cyclist.

Some features of the setting significantly affected the cyclist on his difficult journey to Yosemite. Starting off, the advice from ad men who had not seen the changes in the world for about a decade gave the cyclist a bad start with misleading information about a shortcut. If the cyclist had not gotten this faulty shortcut information, he likely would not have ended up without water in a series of abandoned towns. When the cyclist arrives at some old, rusty pumps, he decided to check them out to see if there was any water left. The water he found was not only warm but also tasted terrible, like battery acid, making it undrinkable. The cyclist decided to keep going despite this setback, even though he was running dangerously low on water. Later, when he came across a snake in the road, he had to navigate past it while in what he describes as his “dehydrated state.” I would imagine this would be particularly dangerous if one could not focus well on the road ahead due to exhaustion. He then came upon the @ORGANIZATION1 building, which he found to be dilapidated and abandoned. He obviously could not get any water there, seeing the poor and derelict condition the building was in. As a direct result of having no access to water, the cyclist became severely dehydrated, and unfortunately, there were no functional stops for water available on his journey that day to Yosemite.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways; it was like a crazy maze, the road he was on, and him not really knowing where he was going didn’t help him, or not having enough water. The confusing network of paths offered no clear direction, and the physical strain was compounded by his dwindling supplies. This combination of navigational difficulty and resource scarcity created a formidable challenge. This is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, demonstrating the profound impact of environment on an individual's journey.

The cyclist's adventure was very much affected by his setting. It seemed as though the worse his setting became, the worse he personally felt. For example, when he hit the ghost town, he just laughed with a hint of disbelief. Once he got to the fork in the road, he saw less of the once existing civilization, and he says, “This sight is troubling,” as the signs of life faded away. Once he moves on, he gets more discouraged by the "Rough Road Ahead" sign, a clear omen of the physical hardship to come. It seems as though the more dehydrated he gets, the worse things became for him, his physical state mirroring the bleak landscape. The climate in the story also becomes increasingly difficult. The land at first was flat and easy to ride, but as it got harder to bike on, the cyclist grew increasingly wary and delirious, but knew he had to keep going. The area in which the cyclist was in, with its unforgiving terrain and climate, had an enormous effect on him emotionally, eroding his spirit step by step.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him in a near death situation. He said “sometimes life can be so cruel,” because he was running out of water, running out of strength, and running out of patience all at once. Also a snake, which "it really did look like a diamond back," could have killed him, adding a sudden, visceral threat to his ordeal. He was in the desert and anything could happen, a place of relentless danger. The setting of old men who didn't know anything and the oppressive heat could have killed the cyclist by leading him astray and sapping his vitality. The situation would have been entirely different if it were anywhere else, but the desert's specific features created a perfect storm of peril.

The cyclist's problem in the story is dehydration, and the California terrain is the cause. California is full of long deserts that can exceed extreme temperatures in summer, and the cyclist was exerting himself, so dehydration was an inevitable consequence. In the story the cyclist says, “I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June,” so the setting is obviously a hazard, where even beautiful weather masks a deadly risk. The arid, sun-scorched landscape directly creates the central conflict of his physical survival, proving the environment itself is a primary antagonist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a very serious way. The features cause him to consider he might die soon, as well as present a variety of challenges to him. The setting takes place in the deserts of California, in early summer. There are no other people in there, no establishments, towns, etc.; another dangerous feature of the setting, in addition to it being in a desert in summer, is its abandoned state, for example the author notes the town “might have been a thriving little spot at one time—sat, before the last world war”. The cyclist is given almost a hopelessness as well as determination to survive as he runs out of water. For example he says, “I was going to lie…slowly gaining elevation while losing hope,” capturing his internal struggle. The author makes the trip to a fishing camp and survives. He learns, because the setting is now lifeless and deserted, to not listen to old people who remember the current setting as it was many decades earlier. Because the features of the setting nearly kill the cyclist, the cyclist learns a lesson about the harsh reality of the present landscape versus nostalgic memory.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the author was exhausted and dehydrated, and as she was riding her bike there was no place for her to stop and fill up her water bottle. The arid landscape offered no relief, with the relentless sun beating down and the path stretching onward without a single service station or public rest area in view. This lack of basic amenities directly intensified her physical struggle, highlighting how the environment itself posed a significant challenge to her journey. Ultimately, the unforgiving setting became a central antagonist in her narrative, testing her endurance to its limits.

The road was deserted; there wasn't a building, car, or house in sight. He was stuck and helpless in the middle of nowhere without any water or food, where poisonous snakes and the intense heat could make him collapse. The sheer isolation was absolute, with only the empty horizon stretching out in every direction under a blistering sun. This complete lack of resources or assistance turned the setting into a direct threat to his survival. In such a desolate place, the environment itself was the greatest danger he faced.

The cyclist on her trip sees a lot of features that would discourage her. She is riding in the high deserts of California in June (Kurmaskie). We all know deserts are steaming hot and dry, especially in June. She also encounters hills (Kurmaskie); to make matters worse, she was travelling on hills in the extreme heat. The combination of the scorching sun and the demanding inclines created a grueling challenge that tested her resolve. Though the cyclist goes through many perilous obstacles, she makes it to a camp and lives. "I could see the horizon, telling myself that I could make it that far, I'd be fine" (Kurmaskie). This shows the author's dedication and that if you don't give up, you will be fine, proving that perseverance can overcome even the most daunting physical settings.

In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the setting is an all-important factor. The author feels the need to describe the path that the cyclist is following and the details of each place he stops, such as “one ramshackle shed…and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule…” and “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite…” These vivid descriptions paint a clear picture of the rapidly changing scenery through which the cyclist travels. In a story such as this, setting is of great importance, especially since it is so dynamically shifting. The story itself would be of much different quality, likely for a lower quality, if the author never put emphasis on the areas that the cyclist rode past; this story would not be worth reading if the author were not as skilled a writer as he is. The careful attention to the environment is therefore essential to the narrative's power and appeal.

The setting of the cyclist was harsh; the weather was too intense to be cycling your heart out all day. The sun was relentless, and the air was heavy with heat, making every pedal stroke a test of willpower against the oppressive conditions. This extreme environment directly challenged the cyclist's physical limits and determination. Ultimately, the severity of the setting defined the entire experience, turning the journey into a formidable trial of endurance.

The features of the setting significantly affect cyclists because if you are a person riding a bike, you might have to worry about falling off your bike or running out of water. If you keep at a fast pace and do not have any water, then you can get severely dehydrated. In the essay, it tells how he had run out of water and he thought he was going to die; he had become dehydrated but luckily he had found somewhere to get something to drink. This highlights how the physical environment, particularly the heat and lack of resources, directly impacts a cyclist's physical state and survival. Ultimately, the setting proves to be a critical factor that can dictate the success or failure of a cycling journey.

In the story "Do Not Exceed the Stated Limit," the man's ride gets pretty rough. Because he took the old men's advice on a shortcut, the once enjoyable ride became a harrowing ordeal through a desolate landscape. The path he was promised turned out to be treacherous and unforgiving, leading him far from any source of help or water. This poor decision, based on misguided guidance, transformed a simple bike trip into a desperate struggle for survival. The narrative shows how a single choice, influenced by the setting and its inhabitants, can drastically alter the entire experience of a journey.

The cyclist in the essay goes through phases that affect him differently according to the setting. At first, the cyclist knows where he is and is very familiar with his location. He is excited for his ride and ready to accomplish it. He then shows up at a “ghost town.” He begins to have doubt in his mind about what the old men told him. This place was completely deserted and there was no water for him. He began to feel discouraged when he passed the grape juice factory and he seriously believed this was the end for him. His hope and enjoyment finally returned to him after he saw the sign for the bait shop, which promised a chance for respite and hydration. The biker's feelings and attitude changed as often as the setting did, demonstrating a clear link between his emotional state and his physical surroundings. This constant shift illustrates the powerful and direct influence that a journey's environment has on a traveler's psyche.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. At first when he sees the tall pines and the river he is calm and chilled out. But when he sees the abandoned “@PERSON1’s Grape Juice” factory he becomes desperate and thinks he is going to die out in the desert. A guy travels to @ORGANIZATION1 where he meets “old timers” and they give him a “shortcut” to the park. He then goes on his bike to the park taking their “shortcut.” While traveling he starts to run out of water and then he thinks he is going to die out in the desert. “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This quote means now that he is out in the desert he thinks he is going to die since he has no more water. This relates because he becomes desperate for water because he is out in the desert in the middle of June, a time of extreme heat. The setting's harsh and isolated nature directly creates the crisis of dehydration and despair, proving that the environment is a central character in his story.

The features of a setting can affect a cyclist very well or not. It depends on what conditions are happening. For example, he could fall on a rocky trail, and the outcome would depend on whether he has a traveling first aid kit to treat his wounds. Similarly, a sudden change in weather, like a rainstorm, could either be a refreshing cool-down or a dangerous situation leading to hypothermia. The setting presents challenges and resources that directly influence the cyclist's experience and safety. Therefore, the journey's quality is inherently tied to the specific features and conditions of the environment through which one travels.

Setting is a very important element to the story “Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie. Kurmaskie experienced a harsh scenery with high temperatures, low water supply, and the constant threat of wild animals. High temperatures without an efficient supply of water can lead to heatstroke, hyperthermia, severe dehydration and even death. It is very important to always be prepared with enough food and water to sustain yourself through an event such as being lost in such an unforgiving landscape. Dealing with wild life can also be a significant obstacle, as encounters are unpredictable. You never know how any animal is going to react to your presence so you must be as cautionary as possible around non-domesticated animals for your own safety. In conclusion, scenery and setting of a story can make all the difference of how interesting a story can be and how informative, for instance, if Kurmaskie had experienced no harsh weather with plenty of food and water riding through a flat small town in @LOCATION1 the story would not be as interesting or impactful.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie. The setting effects how fast, hard and long the cyclist needs to pedal, directly influencing his journey's difficulty. For example, a road sign declared “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The cyclist was going a mere 12 mph, where the posted speed limit was 55 mph, highlighting the vast difference between his pace and that of motorized travel. The cyclist was beginning to lose hope after reading the sign, but he kept going, demonstrating his determination. Furthermore, not only was the land adding pressure to the cyclist, but so does the oppressive heat from the sun. For instance, the cyclist says, “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke,” showing his physical vulnerability. The heat begins to affect the authors health and his perseverance, creating a dual challenge. Ultimately, the setting profoundly affects the mental and physical strain the cyclist has to endure throughout his arduous trip.

This story was a great motivation for older men, showing that they can still be healthy and feel like a teenager again through determination and effort. It showed how much effort he put into his goal and how he managed to survive the demanding journey. For forty miles he peddled, striving through the harsh conditions for forty miles to drink the same water the cyclist was describing, which made for an interesting and compelling story not giving up. His perseverance serves as a powerful example that age does not have to be a barrier to adventure and achieving one's personal goals, proving that spirit and willpower are truly ageless qualities.

The setting affects a cyclist profoundly because the environmental condition determines the pace and even how fast they could travel across a given terrain. Challenging landscapes and severe weather inevitably slow progress and demand greater physical exertion, directly impacting the cyclist's speed and overall travel time. This relationship between the environment and the rider's capabilities is a fundamental aspect of any long-distance cycling narrative, illustrating how external factors shape the journey's rhythm and challenges from start to finish.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist in Joe Kurmaskie's narrative. For example, the cyclist was in California, which is an extremely hot place in the desert in June, amplifying the risk of heat-related illness. These features made dehydration a more keen possibility and a constant concern. Another example, is from paragraph ten, which explains how the rough road, tumbleweeds, and a large snake made it hard for the cyclist to keep his balance, especially without water to maintain his strength. Also, the essay describes a building with a poster of a small child drinking a refreshing glass of juice; this mental image made the cyclist think more about water and become very thirsty, tormenting him psychologically. Although their was some positive effects of the setting on the cyclist as well. The small pebbles aloud him to keep his mouth moist and not think so much of his thirst, providing minor relief. Also, the bait shop eventually allowed him to obtain something to drink, and not die from dehydration, offering a crucial reprieve that enabled him to continue his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way it affects the cyclist is because of the weather condition. Being that it is very hot outside, the cyclist does not have enough water to combat the intense heat. Another way it affects the cyclist is because of the condition alongside the road. For example, the tumbleweeds and the snakes present physical obstacles and potential dangers. Being that it's not out of the question, the desert is most likely in the process of a drought and he gets very dehydrated from the combined effects of the sun and the arid environment. I believe these are the reasons the setting is so challenging because it all makes a lot of sense and significantly affects the cyclist's journey and well-being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the lack of accessible, cool water was the biggest thing he faced. Without cool water he had nothing to reboost his energy after hours of pedaling. He would get tired out faster under the relentless sun. Even if he does find water its hot, like when he says, "brackish water feeling some where in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees." This shows how in "the high desert of June," the water is all very hot, having been heated by the surrounding earth. Even after he pumped the well for several minutes the water still wouldn’t cool down because the hot desert had baked everything above and below ground. So when you go to get something liquid which heats and cools faster than solids it will be hot and unrefreshing. Also the rough road made it difficult for the cyclist to travel it efficiently. We know the roads are rough when he says, “large highway signs dumped out at me. It read ROUGH ROAD AHEAD DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT." This also shows you couldn’t go fast without risking a fall or damage to his bicycle.

The cyclist is severely dehydrated from his journey. He has had a lack of water for a significant distance before he realizes “that the old men would have been right, had he been riding," before the last word war, about the scarcity of resources. But any “town” he rode into, was just a run down, deserted, and abandoned piece of desert, offering no relief. He says, “It was a sad, hopeless, laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself,” which indicates that he was getting more and more dehydrated, but was not quite ready to give up entirely. He still had enough energy to keep going, pushing forward even as “hope was fading” with each empty mile. Then all at once after climbing a large hill he gains all hope back at the sight of civilization. He sees “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp” and knows his ordeal is nearly over. The rider is safe now, he stumbles into the modern looking bathroom and drinks from the sink, finally quenching his powerful thirst. He is now safe, ready to ride again, and avoid all men who haven’t moved from their front porches in years, having learned a hard lesson about the desert.

The harsh setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie made the journey for the cyclist more difficult due to the hot weather and the inconsistency of the pavement. The very hot June day was a cause of the cyclist slowing down, as evidenced by the line, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This proves that the cyclist is very hot and suffering due to the intense summer heat, which saps his strength. Another factor of the cyclist slowing down is the inconsistent quality of the pavement on the road, as noted when “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This change in terrain proves that the road itself could be slowing the cyclist also, forcing him to expend more energy. It seems the cyclist has a lot against him from both the environment and the path itself. But if he keeps his head up and perseveres through these hardships, he can make it to his destination of “Yosemite.”

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by the hotness of the deserts of California because the cyclist was sweating profusely, and quickly drinking through his water bottles without a ready supply for a refill. The extreme heat directly contributed to his physical strain and dehydration. Also when the cyclist saw the building in the distance, he thought he could rest in the shade and maybe even get a ride to where he was going to escape the harsh conditions. But, the building was abandoned years earlier with broken windows and dust, so the cyclist couldn’t stop and find the help he desperately needed, forcing him to continue his arduous journey. These are some of the key features of the setting that negatively affect the cyclist's progress and physical state.

Several features of the setting that affected the cyclist were time of year, the desert land, the lack of civilization, the lack of resources ñ especially water, and the rugged characteristics of the land. The cyclist was traveling during the summer time, which was the hottest time of the year. He was also traveling through the deserts which create an even hotter climate. ìI was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,î was a quote from the selection that tells us this. If he had been traveling in the cooler winter months, for example, he would have been more comfortable. Throughout his trip, the author does not after come desert civilization. He runs into a deserted factory and miles of land without people, which emphasizes his isolation. The fact that he is traveling through desert terrain also helps us realize that water is scarce. He has trouble finding a place to get water, which made the trip extra hard and discouraging. ìI was going to dieî he says, showing his desperation. As he travels farther, the land also becomes harder to travel on. ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,î and this characteristic is a setting, like the others, that negatively affects the cyclist by making his journey harder and more physically demanding.

The cyclist's surroundings did have an affect. In paragraph two the cyclist describes how ìI enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening." To have a wonderful day to begin with was a reassuring assurance that everything would be fine. Confidence was a factor because of the beautiful weather as well as he knew a short cut. In a later paragraph the cyclist mentions how old men looked at his map and pointed out ìthis breezy jaunt.î The cyclist just thought his life got a little easier. Then in another paragraph the cyclist comes upon the "traditional definition of a ghost town." This setting was nothing like the old men were talking about; it was desolate and abandoned. "Twenty miles up the road, i came to a fork of sorts." In the next paragraph, this caused confusion and worry. "This sight was troubling." "I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." The cyclist was "hitting my water bottles pretty regularly," indicating his growing thirst. This setting made the cyclist uncomfortable as well as the heat that felt like "two hundred degrees." The cyclist then began puzzled and distraught. "I notices the terrain changing" in this quote the cyclist's settings would have caused confusion. But in the end the cyclist succeeded in his arduous journey.

The features of the setting in *Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit* by Joe Kurmaskie affect the cyclist because the cyclist is in a desert with no water and trying to find a town that is further than he thinks. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the road could be damaged or there could be a lot of hills, making the ride difficult. When the cyclist takes off on the road again he has plenty of water, strong legs and enjoys the sunny and warm day. This shows that by this time his confidence was lost because of the insane heat and unbearable terrain.
