The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. When he starts off, he is bright and happy, just as the scenery is nice and calming. There is a pace that makes him feel like nothing is wrong, as he notes, “I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” After about @NUM1 miles on the cold road, however, his morale was getting low, and he came to his second abundant place. He then felt a little disturbed and worried because he needed to find a place with water. “This site was trebling,” he thought. There he finds a water plant and his hopes rise a bit, until he discovers the water isn’t good. “A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brickish water feeling some which is in the neighborhood of two hundred trees.” So he moves on and finally he reaches life-giving water! He is so relieved he can’t believe his luck. “Then as easily as rounding a body my troubles, thirst and fear were all behind me.” Ultimately, the setting affects his mood in a very big way; the cyclist feels precisely as the setting looks, from serene to desperate and back again.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist. One way it impacts him is because it is so hot and he doesn’t have any water left, which creates a deep sense of urgency. Also, because there are so many abandoned buildings and ghost towns, this gives him a false hope that he will be able to get the water he desperately needs from these desolate places. The emptiness of the structures mirrors his own growing desperation, and the harsh, dry environment directly dictates his declining physical state and anxious mental outlook throughout his difficult journey.

Almost all of the cyclist’s surroundings are old and barren, dominated by hot @CAPS1-like weather. The road itself is hard to ride on, changing from a flat path to a more challenging one, as “Flat Road was replaced by short rolling hills.” So his ride was a very rough and tiresome one, with the unforgiving terrain and the oppressive heat combining to drain his energy and intensify the physical difficulty of his journey through the bleak landscape.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by undermining his confidence in where he’s going and how he’s going to get there. Having no water in such a vast and demanding landscape creates a profound sense of uncertainty and vulnerability. The sheer scale and emptiness of the environment erode his self-assurance, making every mile a test of his resolve and casting doubt on his entire route and his ability to complete the journey successfully.

If the sun had not been so blaring and the road so treacherous, his journey would have been different. Also, the “devation” often bothers the author because he had to get over the dry conditions and dehydration, which were constant physical and mental challenges. The relentless environmental factors directly shaped his experience, proving that the harshness of the setting was the primary source of his hardship and struggle.

When cycling or doing any outdoor sport, the setting matters greatly. If its cold you need a jacket for warmth, and if it's hot you need water to prevent dehydration. Depending on how secure the location is, the consequences could range from minor inconvenience to a matter of life or death. It could be realy hilly and you might get tired quickly, and if you have no water in such a demanding terrain you could die. Also it depends if its in a city burbed, a small town, a vast desert, or a busy highway; all these environmental factors play a huge roll in determining the safety and success of a cycling journey. Ultimately, a cyclist's preparation and experience are profoundly shaped by the specific characteristics of the route they choose to take.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in critical ways. The cyclist was in California in June weather, a time known for intense heat. If it wasnít so hot, he wouldnít have needed water as badly and his body would not have been under such strain. He wouldnít have been sweating as much, conserving his vital fluids. Also, there werenít any buildings or cars around, so there wasnít anyone to help him in an emergency. ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structures of any kind.î This profound isolation, combined with the harsh climate, shows how critical features of the setting could affect the cyclist's physical state and his chances of survival.

In the essay, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î written by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting directly affect the cyclist. One feature that affects him is that he is cycling ìthrough the high deserts of California in Juneî(Kurmaskie). This specific location and time of year affect him by ensuring he would be dehydrated faster under the relentless sun. The cyclist, who is the author, is so dehydrated before he can make it to the next town that he resorted to desperate measures, as he ìgathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in [his] mouthî(Kurmaskie) to stimulate saliva. This vivid detail underscores the powerful and dangerous impact of the environmental conditions on his journey.

In the essay Do not exceed posted speed limit by Joe Kurmaskie, the surrounding setting profoundly affected the cyclist. The setting was somewhere outside Lodi, California in early summer, a period of rising temperatures. The cyclist took advice from some old men that led him to difficult and isolated places that were challenging to get out of. As the sun beat down and his water started to deplete, getting to Yosemite was much harder. The cyclist was traveling through high deserts of California in June, a notoriously hot and dry region. When the terrain started to change from flat road to rolling hills the cyclist pushed himself even harder to get to his destination, further draining his energy. The sun and hot air dehydrated him faster, accelerating his physical decline. After traveling over, "along, crippling hill,î the cyclist had to stop and even tried sucking on a pebble in an effort to take his mind off his overwhelming thirst. When he finally found a habited store he was exhausted and profoundly relieved. The features of the setting had a big effect on the cyclist; the weather dehydrated him while the demanding terrain exhausted him, demonstrating how environment shapes a journey's outcome.

The settings in the essay affected the cyclist mentally and physically. The fact that he was riding through the desert in June affected how long his water supply lasted, causing it to diminish rapidly. If he had been riding in the cooler seasons then his water supply wouldíve lasted longer and he wouldíve had more energy for the arduous trip. Since the town the old men had told the cyclist about was abandoned that also affected the cyclist because he had to keep on going even though he was getting weaker and his hopes for respite were dashed. What affected the cyclist most, I think was when he arrived at the bait store. If that had been abandoned like everything else, the cyclist wouldíve likely died from dehydration and exhaustion. Luckily though it wasnít and he was able to drink life-saving water. The factory affected him mentally because the picture of the boy was haunting him in a way due to the fact he was drinking juice, something the cyclist couldínt do in his parched state. All in all, I think the conditions that the cyclist was in affected him profoundly. Since Iíve fainted from dehydration before I know how it feels to be without water. First you get a head ache; then your mouth dries up and desperation gets in and finally you get dizzy, a progression the cyclist experienced firsthand.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affects the cyclist's physical and mental state. There are negative and positive effects for each state. The physical effects on the cyclist because of the settings are all apparent throughout the story. For example, when the cyclist reaches @PERSON2 and @PERSON1’s Fish Camp, he is able to hydrate once again. This positive physical effect makes the cyclist healthy and safe once more. The setting also affects the cyclist mentally very substantially. This can be seen when the cyclist is in the comfortable camp around in @LOCATION1. He feels happy and secure in this pleasant area. This positive mental effect prepares the cyclist to go on the trip to Yosemite with renewed vigor. Also, when the cyclist reaches the “Ramshackle” @CAPS2, several rusty pumps, and a corral, he feels troubled and anxious. He is negatively affected mentally by the little amount of available water and the desolate sight. In addition, the cyclist felt "sad" and "hopeless" when cycling in the dry, arid terrain under the harsh sun. The cyclist is in the worst mental state in this unforgiving place. Finally, the cyclist felt profoundly relieved upon seeing the fish camp. He describes the feeling by saying that his troubles are now “behind” him. The setting's positive effect in this instance changes his mental state from negative to positive. Ultimately, setting was the main factor in deciding the cyclist’s physical and mental state, affecting him in both positive and negative ways almost equally in the story.

The setting made the cyclist feel intensely lonely. The cyclist lost hope quickly because she never saw any people or sources of water on the long, empty way. The cyclist said they saw a “ghost town,” which deepened the sense of isolation. Before he got to the fish camp the cyclist saw no one and was becoming dangerously dehydrated. This physical strain caused him to lose hope and at some points he thought he was going to die, completely alone. For example, he says, "I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean," a vivid thought that shows his despair. It is clear that the harsh, desolate setting affected the cyclist in a very negative way, both physically and emotionally, pushing him to the brink of his endurance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly because he was traveling through a dense forest. This was a bumpy trip with a lot of troubles and obstacles along the way, such as uneven paths and difficult terrain. This was a long and arduous trip that tested his limits. But he made it through the challenging journey, enduring the physical strain and mental fatigue, and he emerged tough with a story to tell in the end. His perseverance through the forest setting ultimately led to a sense of accomplishment.

The setting of the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” affects the cyclist's physical condition and emotional attitude profoundly. In the beginning of the essay the cyclist, “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on [his] face.” It was not too hot yet in the morning, and the air was still cool. So, the cyclist was happy and strong, filled with optimism. He was confident he could conquer anything the road presented. As the day grew on, “the sun was beginning to beat down” with increasing intensity. He was beginning to drink lots of water but he was still confident and strong, pushing forward. “I came to a ramshackle shed [and] several rusty pumps the sight was troubling,” and his confidence began to wane. The cyclist was travelling in the hot deserts of California, a harsh and unforgiving landscape. He was becoming tired and thirsty, his body straining. He had to save as much water as possible, which added to his anxiety. What started as a confident ride into the desert became a desperate survival ride. Once the cyclist finds water he is immensely relieved, his spirits lifting. He feels more confident and can ride to his destination with renewed purpose. The weather and setting can affect us emotionally and physically; just like in the essay, the cyclist became tired both physically and emotionally as the hot, sunny day went on, demonstrating the power of environment over human endurance.

As the cyclist begins his journey, he is confident and excited to have been offered new directions from some “old wise men” which promise a convenient shortcut. His initial water supply is mediocre and his attitude is willed against the flat and hilly terrain, until he realizes the directions are way off target and his situation becomes dire. The cyclist was making his way to Yosemite when he came to the first “town” but it wasn't a town but more of a ghost dwelling, increasing his sense of unease. As he continued, hoping the shortcut offered by the old “codgers” would actually materialize, he realized he was utterly alone in the hot desert with a depleting water supply and a dwindling spirit. He was deeply disturbed that he had chosen to follow the advice from the older men and through his pain and despair, encouraged himself by deciding he would never listen to their type again. The cyclist felt screwed over by the bad advice, yet through his sheer will and determination, by rationing his remaining water and mentally choosing to cycle for each hill one at a time, he endured his physical, emotional and mental trials. He lived to learn the valuable lesson of never consulting old “codgers” on mapping issues, because their information would most likely be outdated and unreliable.

The whys the setting affected the cyclist is that the hotter it was the more water that he drank, creating a direct link between the rising temperature and his diminishing supply. Also the further he traveled the more tired he got which caused him to get hotter from the physical exertion and which caused him to drink more of his water, establishing a difficult cycle of fatigue and dehydration.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly in his determined ride. At first he seemed at ease talking about the cool pines and rushing rivers he was going to encounter once getting to Yosemite, envisioning a pleasant journey. After a strenuous ride he started to get nervous and wonder if he was even going to survive, his initial confidence fading. He was running out of water and he thought he saw a diamondback, his mind playing tricks from the heat and exhaustion. Once he reached the rolling hills he saw a posted speed limit sign saying not to exceed the speed limit of 55 m.p.h. He was doing a ''water depleting 12 m.p.h.'' and began to wonder how he was going to survive the relentless pace. At the end of the rolling hills he came to an old Welch’s grape factory, wondering why his life was so cruel as to lead him there. After that he was determined to survive and make it to his destination, his resolve hardening. He picked out spires on the horizon and rode to them, making his way across the vast desert. He finally made it to “Only and Wilber’s fish camp where he knew he was safe and would survive, his arduous journey complete.

The hot, dry, and barren setting affected the cyclist greatly. Barren is a hot, dry and abandoned place, offering no relief from the sun. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the setting has lots of hills, making the ride physically demanding. Also there was no water available in the environment, a critical problem. During the cyclist's journey he was faced with many adversities and challenges. Mostly the driver was fatigued and out of water. In the essay it says how he arrived at the first town and was in search for water. It said "This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time-say, before the last world war." The feature of the setting affected the cyclist because of the bad conditions of the road and the hot sun and the vast deserts and the low amount of energy supply he had left. The rough, cracked pavement made pedaling arduous, while the relentless sun beat down upon him, sapping his strength further. The seemingly endless deserts offered no shade or relief, stretching out in all directions. With his energy reserves nearly depleted, these reasons why the journey was so difficult became overwhelmingly clear, testing his physical and mental resolve to the absolute limit.

As if a long bike ride through the city isn’t grueling enough, the author of this story had it much worse. First the climate was a recipe for a disaster. “High deserts of California in June.” The heat is clearly a debilitating factor as is direct sunlight and the lack of humidity. If the cyclist did not have the proper gear he could be hurt by all three of these factors. Secondly, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This meant his endurance is being tested because it is going to require tolerance, energy and will power to climb each individual hill. Most importantly, with his lack of water in his bottles, all of these characteristics were harmful. Within a desert, water is to be found nowhere. In hot weather, the water bottles will turn warm and in direct sunlight, water could even evaporate over time. To me, it seems like the setting and the weather were the perfect combination for doing much more harm than good, creating an environment designed to exhaust and defeat a traveler.

The features that affect the cyclist is the lack of water he slows his pace and clouds his judgment. Another is the directions from the old men that probably aren’t up to date nowadays, leading him on a path that may no longer be accurate or safe. This combination of physical scarcity and potentially misleading information creates a situation where the cyclist must navigate not only the physical terrain but also the uncertainties of outdated local knowledge, compounding the difficulties of his journey significantly.

The setting explains an early summer evening with some eccentric men. The mood that he would be in would probably be lively and suggestible. “Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice…” (Kurmaskie) says that if you were very lively, I would take that as a way of being drunk without being drunk, and doing whatever someone thinks you should do without knowing you are being persuaded to do it. This describes a state of impulsive enthusiasm, where the cyclist's judgment was likely overshadowed by the spirited atmosphere and the charismatic, though perhaps unreliable, guidance of the locals he encountered.

The setting causes difficult problems for the cyclist and introduces tough hazards. The weather is intensely hot, and just enduring the high temperatures is challenging enough, but journeying through a vast desert with a limited supply of water had to be a miserable experience. The relentless warmth of the desert had a profound affect on the cyclist and caused him to be overcome with fatigue. This physical drain delayed him from getting to his destination quicker as well, slowing his progress considerably. Not only did he have to endure the tough weather, but he also faced hazardous conditions throughout his ride. There were specific times when obstacles like tumbleweeds crossed his path and he even encountered a ridiculously large snake. Such encounters delayed him further as he had to take precious time to cycle carefully around these impediments. As you can see, this combination of environmental and physical challenges made for a profoundly difficult journey for the rider and deeply affected the cyclist's morale and pace.

The features surrounding the cyclist effect him greatly, creating a landscape of profound isolation. All he has around him are endless, rolling hills, rough terraine under his tires, and vast expanses of sand punctuated by drifting tumble weeds. These desolate features leave him thinking he will die because there is no visible life around him, no sign of other people or sustenance. Everything is dry and vivid in its harshness, and that is exactly how it makes him feel internally—parched and exposed. The discovery of an old, rusty water pump only reinforces this despair, showing that it hasnít been used in ages and is completely derelict. The fact that only black, unusable tar pumped out from it is no help to his negative thought of life, confirming his fears of being stranded without aid in an unforgiving environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, ranging from the oppressive temperature, the bleak surroundings, and the critical availability of water. One can imagine the cruelty of the heat beating down on him while riding down the lonely roads, a condition that would make anyone feel tired and exhausted also. Iíd feel uncapable and would do the same in his situation, losing my sense of direction and purpose. Lastly, the severe lack of water made him scared for his basic survival. For example, his resolution to ìconserve my water and go instead for an hour or so a lest of my inner spirit,î indicates the depth of his concern. In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the author uses features of the setting to show the effects on the cyclist, building a narrative of struggle and determination. In the essay the rider gets directions from two old men on a perch, relying on their local knowledge. The essay explicitly said, ìNever accept braid advice from a collection of old- timers who havenít let be able centres of their porch since carter was in office. ìThis shows the old men could be wrong and that places can change over time, making their guidance potentially unreliable. Also, on this supposed short cut he almost runs out of water, which becomes a major crisis. The essay ststed I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or se ñ a test of my inner spirit. He is running out of his vital water supply but has to summon the determination to get to his destination. Lastly the terrain itself affects him profoundly. The Hills prove to be a particular challenge, especially with a limited supply of water to sustain his energy. The essay states that flat roads were upleed by sheed, rolling hills. This shows he is extremely determined to press on despite the exhausting topography. Even though the hills added considerably to the struggle, he ultimately made it through the difficult passage. That is how the author effectively used features of the setting to add to the overall struggle and test the resolve of the cyclist on his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because they figured that the local people, like the old-timers on the porch, were old enough and had seen what was going on in the area for many years. Having been through that situation themselves and possessing a deep familiarity with the landscape, they were well experienced and seemed to know more about what was going on and the potential routes. Consequently, the cyclist felt that people should listen to them and trust their judgment, even if the advice ultimately led to unforeseen difficulties and challenges on the road ahead. This dynamic highlights how the social setting, represented by the locals, directly influenced the cyclist's decisions and subsequent experiences.

After the cyclist spoke to the “old timers who hadn’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” his confidence in them began to wane. He entered the desert happy, hopeful and determined, his spirits high with the promise of a quicker route. As his water reservoir began to disappear, and he approached the sight of the old shed, a dry canal and a couple of water pumps, he began to feel touched by a sense of impending failure. He made an attempt to get the water from the pumps and it was hot and “tasted like battery acid,” utterly undrinkable. As he rode on, his confidence only faded more with each difficult mile. He travelled through the desert and encountered a “ridiculously large snake,” which heightened his anxiety while he was already running dangerously low on water. Finally he saw a building in the distance, which ironically enough was an abandoned juice factory; a sign featuring a lemur sipping on some succulent icy liquid teased ruin, and he began to lose all hope. He didn’t think he would make it to his destination or anywhere else for that matter, his journey seemingly over. Although after approaching the old factory, he came across a bait shop where his hope and energy was finally founded, offering him a real chance at salvation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few significant ways. For example, the features of the “Rough Road” didn't allow him to arrive as fast as he hoped, so he was driving on a reduced speed limit, which slowed his progress considerably. Second, the fact that he was driving through a desert became starkly apparent when a large snake made its way onto the road, causing the man to have to "ease past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state," a tense and precarious moment. Furthermore, because he was driving through the desert, he got so hot and started to get dehydrated from a profound lack of water, which sapped his strength. Lastly, the feature that there weren't any buildings for many miles meant he was left lost and didn't have anywhere to stop and ask for directions, compounding his isolation. These few features of the harsh environment definitely affected the cyclist profoundly throughout his arduous journey.

There were many features of the setting that affect the cyclist to make his difficult journey to Yosemite. First, it was the old timers at the reservoir campground. For example “I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” This is stating that without enough water to keep him cool he felt as if he were going to die, highlighting the extreme peril created by the setting. In ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist by gradually wearing him out and pushing his limits of hope and survival skills. At first, the cyclist enters a deserted town but he remains calm and amused by this, as shown in the sentence, ìI chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on.î Soon after, the cyclist is troubled by the sight of a ìramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, through the high deserts of California in June.î He is visibly agitated by this discovery, makes a significant dent in his precious water supply, and unfortunately continues his journey. At the point where he is still isolated and lost beyond repair, the cyclist tries to stay hopeful but soon suffers a breakdown. He reflects on his deteriorating condition, thinking, ìTelling myself that if I could make it that far, Iíd be okay.î The features of the setting become more and more disappointed at each leg of the journey for the cyclist, systematically eroding his spirit.

In the beginning of the cyclists journey, he is very happy and carefree, full of optimism. The cyclist comes to the first deserted town, and the setting isnít described in detail because the cyclist is not worried yet, his spirits still high. After leaving the first town the cyclist barely noticed the oppressive heat because, ìthe cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.î The cyclist still has high spirits at this stage, looking forward to his destination. The cyclist begins to get genuinely thirsty when he comes upon a water pump, a potential oasis. He attempts to get water but the pump isnít in working condition, which is a major disappointment. Until this point in the story the road has been mostly flat and straight, offering little resistance. Then the cyclist notices that the road has some challenging hills in it, complicating his progress. At this point the cyclist has no water and is very dehydrated, his strength fading. After one particularly difficult hill the cyclist sees a building, a sign of possible respite. The building is an abandoned grape juice factory, which is ironic considering the state the cyclist is in and his intense thirst. The cyclist sucks on rocks as a last resort to create saliva and gives up hope of living, when he finally comes upon a fish camp. He gets life-saving water from the bathroom and all is well, his hope restored. The setting in this story affects the cyclist because as the setting changes, so do the cyclist moods and feelings about survival and the danger he is in, demonstrating the direct link between environment and mental state.

The heat, remoteness of the area, and the rough road all significantly affected the cyclist on his arduous journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly in the story. The harsh desert climate takes damage onto the cyclist by quickly depleting his water supply, leaving him dangerously thirsty. He also began to get worried when every town the old men told him about turned out to be a ghost town, with empty buildings offering no help. This created doubt in the cyclist's mind that he might not survive the “shortcut” told of by the old men, adding a heavy psychological burden to his already difficult physical ordeal.

The features in the setting affect the cyclist because there are different kinds of hills, which demand varying levels of effort. He has to watch out for rocks in the middle of the road that could cause a fall. He has to make sure he has a lot of water because it looks like he is in the desert, a landscape devoid of natural water sources. There are no cars around, but he still has to look for any cars in case they came out of nowhere on the isolated road. There are a lot of turns that require his constant attention and careful steering. It is very hot so he has to make sure he does not have a heatstroke from the intense sun. There are no places where he can stop because there is no shade offering a moment of relief. There are no stores where he can stop and get water and food at either, leaving him completely self-reliant. That is the challenging setting of the cyclist.

In the story, the condition of the problem often affected the mood of the cyclist, shifting it from determination to anxiety. For example, when the sign said, “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit,” it introduced a new layer of caution to his journey. At this time he saw a snake, and he was scared, so he eased past trying to keep balance while he was already dehydrated and weak. The dry and hot climate began to become a serious problem for the cyclist, draining his spirits as much as his physical strength.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, primarily through the scarcity of resources. For example, he could have tried to drink the battery-tasting water if he had no other choice, or his situation would have worsened if he didn't get enough clean water on time. Driving a bike on a long-distance journey, with no water or any other supplies, is very energy-consuming and physically demanding. So you have to plan trips like that very wisely, considering the harsh and isolated environment. This careful planning is essential for survival and success on such a demanding route.

In the story, the setting greatly affects the cyclist, presenting a series of interconnected challenges. The cyclist, pedaling through California, is obviously very hot in the “beautiful @DATE1,” where the sun beats down relentlessly. He also runs out of water, which nearly dooms him as dehydration sets in. But that’s not the worst of it; the steep hills make him run out of water and energy even quicker, compounding his physical strain. There are also no places to stop for water, no shops or shelters along the rugged path. The cyclist is lucky he survived the rugged terrain of California, a testament to his endurance against the oppressive setting.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, defining the difficulties he encounters. There were many features that affect the cyclist, creating a series of difficult obstacles throughout his journey. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed limit,” the features of the setting had a great deal to do with the cyclist, directly shaping his difficult experience. The way the features of the setting effect the cyclist in what was, going through hot neighborhoods and very road that made her dehydrated and effected her journey including the long cycling which he had to go up. In the story, the cyclist starts out with a lot of confidence that he can complete the whole ride, feeling strong and prepared. But after he left first town he had been riding for a long time and desperately needed water, so he stoped at a fork in the road he had just to;to get water from a pump which tastes like battery acid, leaving him still thirsty. Then as he progressed further in his trip he came to a sign that said “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed speed limit”(Joe Kurmaskie pg @NUM1) This part of his trip made it very challenging by making him face rough roads and mountains that he had to cross which sucked the water out of him, pushing him to his physical limits. Then as he came over the last mountain, he saw a sign for a gart store, a sight that brought him immense relief. The features of the setting in the essay entitled “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist in an tagonizing manner, testing his endurance to its very limit. He is dehydrated and exhausted due to the conditions of the environment he was in, a barren and unforgiving landscape. the cyclist became dehydrated because of not only a lack of water, but also the scorching heat of the desert, which created a constant, oppressive demand for fluids. He sweat to much to the point that he lost an enormous amount of bodily fluids, leaving him weak and disoriented. The cyclist also was traveling on unpaved road which required more energy than traveling on one that is paved, further draining his already depleted strength. Therefore the cyclist became so exausted that he almost died, a clear testament to the severe impact of his surroundings. These are the ways the environment the cyclist was in affected him so profoundly.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in ways of feeling doubtful, confident, determined, and relieved. For example, he feels doubtful when he has hardly any water and has no clue where he is or where he is going to end up, lost on a remote and unfamiliar road. He first felt confident when the old people on the porch told him how to go, believing their advice would lead him correctly, and then at the end when he says he will listen to his map next time, showing a return of self-assurance. He was also determined because he wanted to get to the next town, which he does, pushing through his fatigue and thirst, and that achievement also makes him relieved, renewing his desire to ultimately get to Yosemite National Park. That is how the setting, through its challenges and occasional guidance, profoundly affects the cyclist's emotional state throughout his journey.

The features of the setting in which the cyclist finds himself change his outlook on the trip. When he first begins his trip, the road is fine and manageable, so he becomes confident and optimistic about his ride. When the terrain began to change, becoming harsh and unforgiving, he writes, “sometimes life can feel so cruel,” and he grows despairing as he faces new terrain with so little water, feeling completely worn down. When he begins to see a building in the distance, he becomes hopeful and determined, pedaling harder toward what he believes is salvation. However, when he realizes it's an old, deserted juice factory, he grows bitter and disappointed at the false promise. When he leaves the factory, he feels he has lost all hope, a sentiment captured when he writes, “somehow i climbed away from the abandoned factory of of juice and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope." At the end, when he is revived with water at a small store, he almost looks back on the journey comically, recognizing the absurdity of his suffering. The rider knows that his outlook drastically changed depending on the setting through his journey, from hope to despair and back again.

The features of California and the fact that the cyclist was near Yosemite made the terrain rugged and dangerous for him. California has a very hot, arid climate and is near a desert, so the need for water for the cyclist was much greater than if he had been cycling in a cooler, more temperate location. In the story, the cyclist had to travel through desert-like conditions with a severely limited water supply, which intensified his physical struggle. The cyclist even mentioned in the story how many hours into the ride the land changed to “short, rolling hills,” which would have made it harder to pedal, forcing him to work harder and expend more energy. In the story, he also mentions how the sun was beating down on him relentlessly, and that would also serve as a major factor that helped deplete his hydration rapidly. Through all of the problems the cyclist faced, however, he managed to stay determined and persevere, when other people faced with his problems might not have been able to make it through. Also, in the story you notice that in the different stages of his struggle, the author's tone and anger shift from confident, to unsure, to desperate, mirroring the harsh landscape's impact on his mental state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, primarily through its physical demands. It made him tired from the long, arduous ride, thirsty under the relentless sun, and he was near exhaustion from the constant effort required to traverse the difficult terrain. The harsh, unshaded environment and the vast, empty distances between points of respite drained his energy and tested his limits. This physical toll imposed by the setting was a constant challenge throughout his journey, shaping his entire experience from start to finish.

The cyclist in the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” took the advice of older gentlemen who offered him a shortcut they knew to get to the national park. However, the land had changed long ago after these men were last here, rendering their directions nearly useless. The first town he came upon was deserted, a realistic version of a ghost town that offered no help. He laughed bitterly at how long ago those men must have been here, realizing the advice was a relic of the past. Long hours on the hot road and with depleted water supplies led to despair sinking in deeply. He lost almost all hope when he reached an old and destroyed grape juice factory, seeing it as another symbol of his failed detour. Ultimately, he had made it to a bait store for water at last, a moment of profound relief. He would never take the advice of anyone but his map again, having learned a hard lesson about trusting outdated information over reliable tools.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by letting the author have hope, which is quickly challenged by the harsh environment. When he came across a sign which read "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," his hope was faint because he was doing a water-depleting twenty miles per hour. Because of the rapid rate of the water loss, he felt life was cruel sometimes and he thought that he was at the point of losing all his water. Also when he came across the tumbleweeds and the large snake he tried to avoid them, navigating carefully past the obstacles. If he would have been bitten he would have died, a constant danger in such a remote place. Finally because of the heat he might have also died from heatstroke, with wide signs of dried sweat marking his clothing and skin. Ultimately, the setting presented a series of severe trials that pushed him to his absolute limit.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” many features of the setting challenge the cyclist. The cyclist accepts information from foreign old people which made his first mistake, leading him onto a difficult path. After realizing this, he notes, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California, in June.” The lack of water plus the intense heat in California in June would have turned to heatstroke for most people, creating a dire situation. Even further into the journey, even with all those things against him it states, “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills," so not only did he have excessive heat and no water, but he was handed troublesome roads too, adding physical strain. Although the cyclist must have been near to complete exhaustion, he continued through, pushing forward with immense effort. Fighting all odds and elements, many features in the setting of this story affected the cyclist, but he overcame them honorably through sheer determination and willpower.

The dry desert-like setting would affect the cyclist because he could easily become dehydrated from the sun, and loss of water through sweat. The cyclist states, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state” (Rough Road Ahead). The man is badly dehydrated, but in his determination he moves on, fighting through the weakness. The terrain went from being flat to short rolling hills, increasing the physical challenge. The road had been abandoned along with the town he had passed through, hoping to get water but finding none. The man goes on to say, “I toiled on, at some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake- it really did look like a diamond back- blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me" (Rough Road Ahead). The setting is obviously desert like, so it is dry, hot, and dusty, with very little shade or respite. This would definitely have an affect on his body which is sweating, which causes dehydration due to water loss, draining his energy reserves. In conclusion, the cyclist was greatly affected by the setting, which tested his physical endurance and mental resolve at every turn.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist quite drastically. First of all, he was “traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” a time of extreme heat. He was running out of water and the pump he found only produced “brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees” and “had the flavor of battery acid,” making it undrinkable. Then he came upon “rolling hills” and “Rough Road,” which demanded more from his tired body. By the end, he was exhausted, dehydrated, and in desperate need of water, his condition worsening with each mile. The terrain made the story more meaningful in proving that you shouldn’t get directions from old guys, a hard-learned lesson about preparation and trusting unreliable advice.

In the essay, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the cyclist encountered several problems. The main conflict of the cyclist in this text is the lack of water. Cycling is a vigorous exercise and can take much strength out of a rider, demanding constant hydration. Water is necessary to make sure the cyclist stays hydrated, but his supply was critically low. In the text, the old men had the cyclist take a detour through desert areas and hilly terrains, a route fraught with difficulty. Because of the hot weather and rough roads the cyclist became dehydrated faster than normal, accelerating his physical decline. For example, the text says, "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June." The author, by using vocabulary such as "tantalizing," expresses the cyclist's desperate need for water. Furthermore, later in the sentence the narrator makes a reference to the old men, giving the blame entirely to them for suggesting the path. Readers can also conclude that the harsh setting of the essay greatly affected the cyclist, shaping his difficult and perilous journey.

The story "Rough Road ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed limit" by Joe Kurmaskie was about a man traveling through some pretty difficult settings. In the article “Do not exceed the posted speed limit,” the features of the setting took a toll on the cyclist in many ways. The setting affected the cyclist in many ways. One way was the weather. In the story it said, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” That quote confirms he is in a desert, and deserts are usually warm. It also said in June, and June is usually a hot temperature month. The weather affected the cyclist because it was hot and he started to become dehydrated and had little water left in his bottles. Another way the setting affected the cyclist was the surroundings. Many of the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The most obvious and direct feature would be that this adventure took place in the “high deserts of California in June.” This passage suggests blistering heat; "high" meaning it is going to be closer to the sun, "deserts" where the world is hot, "California," which is known to be smoggy, and "June," which is the middle of summer. Also, the closest water supply was described as being “somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees,” there was a “long crippling hill” all while the sun was beating down. All of that would most obviously affect the cyclist by making him exhausted and weary, which he vividly explains by expressing his fears of losing consciousness and succumbing to the oppressive conditions of his journey.

In the story, “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One example is when the cyclist says, “I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This affects the cyclist because it makes him work harder when he is already dying of thirst, especially on a hot summer day. When the cyclist is biking it is very hot, he says it was “in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” After this quote he is explaining the difficulty of getting frustrated and there is no cold water. This affects the cyclist by making him think only about water and not bothering to think about where he is; he could be lost, a fear compounded by the fact that he didn’t have a good map to guide him.

As the cyclist goes on his trip, he is met with many dreary places and people. For starters, there were the old men he knew he shouldn’t have trusted but did anyway. In the essay, the features of the cyclist affect the setting because the readers wouldn't have thought that he was in that bad of danger if he hadn't of been going through the harsh desert environment. The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly. For instance, the terrain consisted of rolling hills that went up and down continuously, and it took a lot of strength to navigate them. The setting was an important factor in the story. It was a desert, and in a desert there is a severe lack of water and intense heat. The features of the setting affected the cyclist profoundly because he was biking up steep hills in extreme, relentless heat. This physical exertion was compounded by the fact that he also had a short water supply, which was rapidly depleting. To make matters worse, he was headed in the wrong direction, further extending his exposure to the hazardous environment. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in several key ways. The directions given to the cyclist by the elderly man were incorrect, and as a result, he got lost and his journey was prolonged.
