The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly, shaping her emotional state throughout the journey. When she biked around a bend, the landscape opened up into a beautiful, serene vista, and in that moment, she felt a profound sense of relief, as ìmy troubles, thirsts, and fear were all behind me.î The change in scenery provided a mental escape, proving how the physical environment can directly influence a rider's internal experience and offer a reprieve from hardship. This demonstrates the powerful connection between a cyclist's surroundings and their psychological well-being, concluding that the setting is a crucial element in any journey.

In the story ìRough Road Aheadî by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist set out on a bike ride in the heat of summer in California where he was staying he met some old people who gave him a ìshort cut.î As he found out, most of the places he was told about were abandoned ghost towns without a single drop of drinkable water, leaving him increasingly desperate. If he were in a different setting like by a river or spring he would just stop and drink from that, or even if he was in a more populated, industrialized area he could stop in any building and ask for a drink. But he was in the dry, hot, abandoned hills of California without any water, a setting that offered no such relief. Under these conditions he grew tired, thirsty, dehydrated, and desperate for a drink until he finally came upon a bait shop that had water there, ending his immediate physical crisis.

During the cyclist's journey he was affected by the setting frequently, with the environmental conditions directly impacting his physical state. When he was cycling it became very hot to him, but at first it wasnít so bad, as he notes, ìThe sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.î This proves that the cyclist knows it was getting hot but it did not initially affect him significantly. Another thing that affected him was the time that he was traveling in, specifically the season and location, as he states, ìI had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high deserts in California in June.î This proves that the reader was constantly drinking because of the time of day and year he was out, showing his body's heightened demand for water. All of this shows that the setting affected the cyclist on his trip, dictating his needs and actions throughout the ride.

I think that the features of the setting really do affect the way someone rides a bike because certain places have certain terrain which can pose different challenges. Some types are not always good for a bike rider because if itís bumpy then someone could fall off the bike, leading to potential injury. Also, if it is dark you might not even be able to see where you are going then you could hurt yourself very seriously, which is why riding a bike can be dangerous under poor conditions. Also, if you're in the type of environment where everything is smooth then you might be able to have a nice bike ride without such risks. Therefore, the safety and quality of a bike ride are fundamentally tied to the characteristics of its setting.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in, ìDo not Exceed posted speed Limit,î by changing him physically and mentally. He was in the California desert in the middle of June without any water left, and this harsh environment was taking a significant physical toll on him. His physical effect was making him feel hopeless as well, as he says, ìIt was a sad hopeless laugh mind you, but at least l still had the energy to feel sorry for myself." So the way he was suffering from dehydration physically effected his emotional state because he felt as though there was nothing he could do. Had he been in another place, for example a cooler, forested region, where it does not get nearly as hot so soon as California, he would not have been suffering from dehydration, nor would he have been in such an isolated place. His cycling ordeal could be compared to the climbers who were lost in the snow storm in the mountains. Instead of dehydration and heat stroke, however they suffered from hypothermia. Had they been on a different mountain, there would have been no snow storm and they would be fine. The outcome of this story and the climbers was ultimately determined by their setting, proving environment is a powerful force in any narrative.

The harsh conditions gave the cyclist no hope at some points because the intense heat and the unforgiving features of the setting were so severe he felt completely defeated. This is evident when the cyclist thinks he can only hope to make it to the horizon because there is nothing else to compare it to. He cannot tell himself to ride to the next building or a distant mail box because there are simply none in the vast emptiness. The desert's desolate features make the cyclist feel profoundly alone, convinced that no one can help him and that he will inevitably die of dyhydration. Then, the features deliver a cruel blow when he sees the Welch's grape fruit juice building, which gives him a small, fleeting hope of survival, only for him to find out that it is completely deserted. This discovery feels like the final straw, and he completely gives up. The cyclist, now almost unconscious from exhaustion and despair, then stumbles into a fishing store where he finally has a life-saving sip of water. Ultimately, the geographical features were the main reason the cyclist lost all hope of surviving his journey.

The features of the setting affect the author because it physically moves him toward a state of severe dehydration. The relentless desert sun seemed to sweat every last drop of moisture out of him, and he had no supply of water to bring that would adequately replace his lost electrolites. Also, once the author had got into the rolling hills he had lost a great deal of his energy, so peddling up the steep inclines was a tremendous amount of work. If I were the author I would also have gotten incredibly tired because you simply need water in your body to survive, and the setting provided none.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist greatly, both physically and mentally. In the cyclists opinion things began pretty well, as he embarked with a positive attitude which is stated as being “with strong legs and a smile on my face.” As the man moves on he comes to a fort of sorts, a sight he found troubling and ominous. Though troubling, he still had the residual confidence that he could continue his journey. Next he keenly noticed the significant changes in the terrain, explaining that “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This shift meant that he would have to peddle harder and with greater force in order to get over each challenging hill. The weather was not helping, growing increasingly hot as the cyclist was running dangerously out of water, and the real possibility of heatstroke came to his mind. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind”, as told by the man, emphasizing his isolation. His mind then entered a deep state of sad, and hopeless thoughts, but he tried to persevere and cycled on. At this critical point he was very thirsty and felt with certainty that his death was near, thinking “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” As he kept going, he suddenly spotted an old guy in the distance, which made him regain a spark of hope and move ahead. The features of this story thus affected the cyclist in a dual manner. Physically he was tired and worn out from the exertion, and in a like this horrible state, mentally he was becoming negative and pessamistic about his entire travel. The setting's features directly interfered with the cyclist's physical endurance and mental state throughout his arduous trip.

In this story, “No Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, by Joe Kurmaskie, I believe the setting greatly affects the cyclist's experience and morale. I believe this because when the route consists of long, downhill cool roads the journey is fine, but if it is straight uphill roads under an extremely hot sun he feels like he simply cannot keep pedaling. The cyclist gets very weary when the setting is out in the hot desert with no other people around, feeling the immense solitude and heat, so the setting has a huge affect on the overall mood in this story. Another example is the sheer monotony of the landscape, which drains his spirit as much as the heat drains his body, showing how deeply the environment influences his struggle.

A cyclist is fundamentally a bike rider, dedicated to their sport or mode of travel. They can be in groups of diffrent people, riding together for camaraderie, or they can be a solo cyclist tackling the road alone. Some cyclist go for a few miles riding there bikes, a short recreational trip, while some can go for more like one hundred miles, embarking on epic journeys. Some go over formidable hills, go trow bodies of water, and navigate various terrains; they do alot with what they do, requiring significant planning and effort. They inevitably have alot of time on there hands to ride a bike that far, which demands both physical stamina and mental fortitude for such long-distance endeavors.

The setting is oppressively hot, resembling a desert, with no one around and a very dry atmosphere. The intense heat outside directly affects the cyclist, making him sweaty and creating a desperate need for water. The relentless sun wears him down, sapping his energy with each passing mile. The profound isolation, with no one around, causes him to be unable to get the water which he critically needs for his journey. These combined factors make him weak and significantly complicate his efforts to find a place to get water, extending his suffering. Ultimately, the harsh environment proves to be a formidable adversary in his travels.

The setting can affect the cyclist because it could be a good or a bad thing for his journey. If a cyclist is able to adjust his own settings, such as his pace or route, that is good for maintaining control. However, if somebody else messes with them, perhaps by providing faulty information or tampering with his equipment, that could be bad and lead to difficulties. This dynamic shows how external interference, versus personal management, can alter the outcome of his ride. Therefore, the cyclist's experience is heavily dependent on who controls the variables of his trip.

In this narrative of a cyclist riding in California and headed for Yosemite National Park, he encounters a severe lack of water and receives bad directions from a group of old men on a porch. The setting plays a big part in his "challenge," from the initial pine trees to the later barren hills. In the beginning of his trip he passes a "ghost town" that has clearly seen better days, which presents him with his first doubt and he continues with caution. Then he sees the pines that, as he felt, "had my name written all over them," which gives him hope and reassurance. Then the discovery of a rusty pump and a "ramshackle shed" took that hope and reassurance away, making him cautious once more. The steep hills that made him work hard to get over, the snake that slowed him down, and the abandoned Welch's juice company all didn't help and made matters worse. Then he finally got some water at a roadside bathroom and his situation was all better. If the setting had been less varied the whole way, he wouldn't have had any hope or his hope would not have fallen and risen, making the story far less interesting and dynamic for the reader.

Winding hills, limited water, and poor directions are the primary troubles of this cyclist. First, he gets very bad directions from a group of old men who have not been outside of their porch in a while, leading him astray from the start. Then he goes through the first town and makes the crucial mistake of not filling his water bottles while he has the chance. Consequently, he gets lost and runs out of water, putting him in a precarious situation. His luck changes when he finds a fishing store where there is water available and people who give him a better, more reliable map for the remainder of his journey. This final assistance provides him with the means to continue his trip successfully.

The lack of water, and the absence of reliable direction, severely effects the cyclist. Water effects the cyclist because he said in the essay “I could drop from heatstroke" (Kurmaskie), highlighting the immediate physical danger. Also, having no direction is another big problem he faces. It is important because without proper direction he is going to be riding for a long time, potentially getting more lost and exhausting his limited resources. In conclusion, the dual challenges of dehydration and navigational confusion were the cyclist's central problems in the story, each compounding the other to create a significant ordeal.

The features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist because he mistakenly thought he had packed enough water. Confidently, he began on his way, but he drank most of his water less than half way to his destination. He didn’t realize how intensely hot the arid landscape was until he got down to his last couple of sips. As he started to become dehydrated, he remembered the old men had said that the next town was about eighteen miles away, so he kept on going. His hope faded when he reached the town, finding nothing to drink, just an old run down factory. Desperate, he took some rocks and sucked on them for moisture, but when he went over a bump, he accidentally swallowed one. He said to himself that next time he would just go by what the map said, as everything he had gone past on the way had been run down and abandoned. Finally, he reached a bait shop and went inside to the bathroom, where he was able to get some water and end his ordeal.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. For example, it was not just the heat but also the steep hill that contributed to him becoming dehydrated, sapping his energy as he climbed. He went down a rusty-bumpy road, which didn't help his dehydration, jostling him and making his journey more arduous. And another example would be when he found a vantage point from which he could assess a change in the terrain and find the best way to get where he was going. This demonstrates that the features of the setting had a significant effect on the cyclist and his decisions throughout the ride.

The cyclist goes through many natural settings that affect him. First of all, he rides into barren land, a desolate expanse with little life. The cyclist portrayed this barrenness by saying “it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This was in response to the first “town” he came across, which was empty and crumbling. Next, he speaks of a large snake that came close to him, which was dangerous, but luckily he maneuvers out of its way, his heart pounding from the scare. But the worst setting the cyclist had to deal with was the pervasive lack of water, a severe threat to any living creature. His thirst became all-consuming, but in the end, he found some water and the story ended fine, providing a welcome relief from the harsh journey.

In the essay “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting relates directly to how the author is feeling. At first, when the author sees the abandoned first “town,” he is not too worried about it and moves on, noting, “I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.” The author is okay right then, and still has enough water to feel secure. Next, he starts to get low on water, and he becomes more panicked; which in return makes the day seem even hotter and more oppressive. He observes, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” From that point, as the author is low on water, the day seems worse. Afterward, he continues on and runs into a rattlesnake, which makes him even more panicked, describing “a ridiculously large snake. It really did look like a diamond back—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Later, when he got to the bait store and drank from the sink, things didn’t seem so bad anymore and there was no more talk about water nor the intense heat. As a result, the description of the setting was clearly related to the author’s shifting moods throughout his difficult trip.

The features of the setting did affect the cyclist in this small story. In this story, the setting is a hot, dry terrain which can be better explained by the name California, evoking images of a vast desert. This heat of the desert climate seems to start having an effect on him about after he reaches the first ghost town. I know this by his statement: “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water supply and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down.” The summer heat is thriving now during this season and he is drinking lots of water, noting how quickly his supply diminishes. So this setting does affect him greatly; it causes him to use his water supply rapidly and it causes him to begin the process of dehydration, a dangerous situation. I know how the summer heat can affect you during strenuous activities; at times it feels like you are going to die, but that hopeful building is always just around the bend for the determined cyclist, offering a promise of respite.

In Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit, the features of the setting are devastating to the cyclist's condition. "CAPS1 through the high desert of California" is surely never an easy task to begin with, given the relentless sun and arid landscape. Without proper hydration, people often suffer heatstrokes or pass out, sometimes even perishing, and it is entirely worse for this cyclist because of the effort he is exerting, pedaling over “short, rolling hills.” Even worse, the trail a few very old, eccentric men set run on doesn’t do much in the way of helping with a depleted water supply. The first town the cyclist comes across easily splits “the traditional definition of a ghost town,” being utterly desolate and abandoned, and the only other water pump he comes to emits only sewage and incredibly hot brackish water, which is completely undrinkable. Therefore, the oppressive heat is only made worse by the lack of usable water on the cyclist's path. This combination of features in the setting causes a great deal of distress to the cyclist, severely depleting his energy and resolve and almost pushing him to death from exhaustion and dehydration.

There are many ways the setting affected the cyclist in this story, such as the weather, the supply of food and water, a wrong estimation for old people, and the road. First off, the weather was very dry and it felt like two hundred degrees, so it made you sweat profusely and made it hard to breathe in the thick, hot air. The supply of water was harsh, with not much around at all, and when he tried to get water the pumps would pump out anything but clean water, yielding only useless, hot liquid. The weather and water supply were two major affects on the cyclist, combining to create a truly desperate and life-threatening situation for him on his journey.

In the beginning of the story the author is happy, but towards the end grows upset. "I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face" (NUM1). This shows how the author is in a good mood and happy to be there, feeling optimistic and free. She is on a journey, and no one can touch her, filled with a sense of invincibility. Then the story takes an unexpected turn. “With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill,” (NUM2). After getting lost in a town that seems distant from any living things, a place of eerie silence and emptiness, the author hears people! She is extremely relieved to have found anyone of help to her, a feeling of salvation washing over her. She gets water and is forever grateful for this simple, life-saving act. The setting is horrifying to her because you will feel like you can't survive even if you live there, creating a profound sense of isolation and vulnerability. She felt alone and that she would die, a fear that was entirely shaped by the desolate landscape. If the setting was in a city surrounded by buildings the author would still feel some security even without water, but the utter remoteness of her actual location stripped away all such comfort.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist, primarily for two reasons concerning the water and the hills. One reason was water because his water supply, which he had carefully refilled all the way up, quickly cooled down and became insufficient under the harsh sun, failing to provide the needed relief. My last reason is because of the rolling hills, which demanded constant physical exertion, relentlessly draining his stamina as he pedaled up and down their slopes. Together, these two elements of the environment created a formidable challenge that severely tested the cyclist's endurance on his journey.

There are features such as blazing heat coming off the sun, “short, rolling hills,” and no water. There was also the fact that the rider thought he was in the middle of nowhere, a profoundly isolating feeling. This has a great effect on the cyclist, both physical and emotional. The heat, lack of water and constant up hill riding can take a lot of energy out of someone and make it extremely hard to ride, pushing the body to its absolute limits. Not to mention there isn’t much hope left so that eliminates the whole mind over matter thing, leaving only despair. All the features of the setting put together can lead to major trouble, creating a situation where survival itself becomes the primary and most difficult challenge.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. After about @NUM1 miles, when in desperate need of a water supply, the cyclist found a rusty pipe from which a foul, tar-like substance initially came out, followed by a trickle of brackish water that was undrinkable. While cycling, you are in need of clean water, and this failed source was a profound disappointment. Next, the terrain changed abruptly from being flat to very hilly, demanding greater physical exertion. In need of water, the last thing you need is to be challenged more by such an arduous landscape. Later on down the road, there were no cars or any buildings in sight, amplifying the sense of desolation. When you are feeling the worst, you would want someone to be near in case you fall out, but no one was in sight on that lonely, empty road. Lastly, seeing the old Welch's Grape Juice Factory would profoundly affect the cyclist. Seeing that image of a drink factory right in front of you, a place that should have been an oasis but where no business was conducted, had to make them feel like he/she will never make it through this ordeal. These distinct features of the setting collectively had a significant and negative affect on the cyclist's morale and physical state.

The features in the setting dramatically affect the cyclist. Everything was fine and the ride was manageable until he ran out of water and reached the daunting, unending hills. Now if he was in a different, more forgiving location, he wouldn't have become so severely dehydrated. But the hills, with their steep and constant grades, were sure to play with his mind, creating a mental battle alongside the physical one. The most important setting is the Welch's grape juice factory, which stands as a cruel landmark. He would have had all of the grape juice he wanted to quench his powerful thirst, but it was abandoned and provided no relief, an ironic twist as he calls it. And the last one is the bait shop that saves his life, where a kindly old man finally appears and offers him the crucial directions he needs to find civilization. This final feature provides the turning point that the other harsh settings had made so necessary.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist because he was isolated in the middle of no-where with no available water or a sense of direction. The man was also very thirsty and had no water left in his water bottle; he began to get very thirsty and fatigued. I found an example in the text to show that he was thirsty and struggling: “The speed limit was @NUM1. I was doing a water-depleting @NUM2. Sometimes life can feel so cruel”. By saying he was doing @NUM2 when it should have been @NUM1, he was indicating he was getting very exhausted and he desperately needed water to get him feeling refreshed once again. Also, the fact that there was no one in sight to give him direction effected him too because he didnt know where the next refuge or source of help was located. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” From the mans point of view, he probably thought civilization was many more miles away and he probably could not make it that far in his current state. The setting effected him by making him probably begin to stress or panic a lot, for the most part eroding his confidence and hope.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example he feels dehydrated and tired because he is riding through the stark desert and has a severe lack of water, a basic necessity for survival. I often feel this way when jogging for extended periods of time, but his situation is far more extreme. The men in the story “who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office” also add to the story by providing local, if dated, advice. Due to their role, the cyclist takes an unmarked shortcut that turns out to be horrible, leading him further into difficulty. The Welch’s factory affects the cyclist because it increases his thirst and causes him to once more think about the drink he cannot have. The sign showing grape juice looks irresistible to him in his parched state and drives him to keep forward in a desperate search for anything to drink. The terrain charge also affects the cyclist because it causes him to have to work ever harder to get up hills now, expending precious energy, rather than just ride on flat terrain where the going was easier.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, in paragraph @NUM1 it says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” @CAPS1 the intense heat the cyclist experienced, since he was in a desert in June, made him dehydrate faster, sapping his strength. The relentless heat made him drink more frequently so he ran out of his water supply more quickly than anticipated. Then he would try and conserve his remaining water by not drinking, and this would cause him to dehydrate more because he was still losing body fluid in sweat from the exertion. Secondly, in paragraph @NUM2 it says, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” These hills affect the cyclist because he would need to use significantly more energy and leg power to cycle up the slopes. This would cause him to become exhausted more quickly than he would on flat land, compounding his fatigue. If the setting had been different, such as not being in a hilly desert environment, the cyclist would not have become as severely dehydrated and tired as he did during this challenging journey. In conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, both through the environmental heat and the demanding topography.

The features of the setting directly affect the cyclist, primarily through the intense heat and lack of water. The statement, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” highlights the extreme environmental conditions. The June heat in the desert is oppressive, accelerating dehydration and forcing the cyclist to consume his water supply rapidly. His physical exertion from cycling uses energy and produces sweat, further increasing his need for hydration. The description of the location, “One ramshackle shed. Several rusty pipes and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule,” confirms the desolation and absence of a viable water source. This inability to renew his water means he must conserve what little he has left, which in turn forces him to limit his energy expenditure. Both of these factors—the scorching desert heat and the complete absence of water—combine to create a setting that affects the cyclist far more severely than cycling on a cold day would.

The cyclist in the narrative is profoundly affected by the features of the setting, which create a sense of physical and psychological distress. The extremely hot weather is a primary factor, as such intense heat induces exhaustion and a feeling of being completely drained of energy. Furthermore, the complete absence of other people contributes to a feeling of isolation. Being entirely alone in a vast, empty landscape can make a person feel small, helpless, and vulnerable, much like the common fear associated with solitude. Finally, the critical lack of available water in the surroundings intensifies her suffering. The author’s description clearly conveys a state of severe thirst, and the barren environment, offering no hope of relief, makes the sensation of thirst feel even more acute and inescapable.

The setting effects the cyclist through several distinct physical challenges. The rough roads directly impact his journey, making pedaling difficult and physically taxing as he navigates the uneven terrain. An encounter with a snake introduces a moment of fear and danger during his ride through the desolate “town,” breaking his concentration and adding a psychological hurdle. The dwindling supply of drinkable water is another critical factor; not only is he running out, but the water he does manage to find is so contaminated it tastes like battery acid, rendering it undrinkable and worsening his predicament. Ultimately, the cumulative hardships presented by the setting prove to be very rough on the cyclist, testing his endurance at every turn.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him tired, scared, thirsty, and causing him to worry. The setting was a hot California day in June, and the cyclist was riding through the intense heat over hills and difficult terrain. He describes the changing land, noting, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” and later speaks of going, “Over one long, crippling hill.” As the cyclist progresses, his doubt grows. Fear and thirst begin to overwhelm him, leading to the despairing thought, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” When he finally finds the bait shop, he has almost lost all hope, a feeling captured in his observation of “Slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” However, at the very end, the setting enables a reversal as the sight of the bait shop makes the cyclist regain his strength; he says, “Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst and fear were all behind me.” Thus, the features of the setting put the cyclist through an unsteady ride of fear, hope, and ultimately, restored confidence.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by ultimately providing him with the water he desperately needs for his thirst. This crucial resource allows him to recover and get back on the road to continue toward his destination. However, a minor inconsistency arises as the narrative does not mention him actually obtaining any bait for fishing, which is suggested by the location being a bait shop. The cyclist was also profoundly affected by the harsh conditions of the setting prior to this point, as he nearly died from a combination of extreme thirst and the apparent lack of a clear, traversable road. The setting, therefore, presents both the crisis and the eventual solution for the weary traveler.

He raced through the rugged terrain, trying to get to Yosemite for some whitewater rafting on the rushing river. The path was steep and littered with loose stones, challenging his endurance with every turn. His lungs burned with the thin mountain air as he pushed forward, the sound of the churning water a constant, motivating roar in the distance. He knew that reaching the river’s edge would make the entire grueling journey worthwhile, offering a moment of cool respite and thrilling adventure. With one final, strenuous push over a rocky crest, he finally saw the magnificent, frothing water ahead, a triumphant end to his difficult race.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. Having desert races makes you want to just lay there and not try to go any further, because you don’t know where an end will be, the vast emptiness sapping your will. As for grassy, flowery land, its more of a scenic route, and makes you want to keep going and see many things, with each new bend promising another pleasant vista. Hills and terrain make it harder to keep going but present more of a challenge, and a good workout at the same time, testing both physical strength and mental resolve. Each type of landscape imposes its own unique psychological and physical demands on the rider. Ultimately, the setting does profoundly affect the cyclist, shaping the entire experience of the journey.

When the cyclist first receives directions to Yosemite Park from the “old timers” he met, he was pretty confident that they knew what they were talking about. To his dismay, these elderly men sent him through life threatening conditions in a deserted area. As the cyclist begins his journey through the hot, June weather, he “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face,” feeling optimistic and energetic. As he continues forward, he notices that there are no buildings, cars, or people of any kind, a silence that grows increasingly unnerving. He passes abandoned towns and creeps into the desert flat land, the isolation becoming palpable. The flatland however, morphs into crippling hills with tumbleweeds and snakes awaiting, each pedal stroke a new struggle. Not only is the terrain suddenly different, but the cyclist is rapidly deteriorating, his initial energy completely spent. Tiredness and lack of water make the cyclist think “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” a stark vision of his desperation. It was amazing that through all this, the cyclist was able to reach a small fishing camp where he is quickly replenished. “Gary and Wilber’s Fish Camp” saved the cyclist from almost certain death and taught him to always just use his map from that day forward.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed posted Speed Limit,” the features of the area the cyclist rides through affect him greatly. For example when the narration says, “At some point, humble weeds crossed my path,” the mundane sight underscores a growing monotony and fatigue. The tone of the cyclist from the quote above shows despair creeping into his mind as the journey wears on. Also, another good example is when the narration says, “Over the next hill, a building came into view,” a simple line that carries immense weight. The cyclist sounds more hopeful than before, his spirits lifted by the promise of civilization or respite. That is how the area the cyclist enters affects him, directly influencing his emotional state and outlook.

In the story the cyclist is affected by many features of the desert. The main feature is the relentless, oppressive heat. “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” a simple statement that conveys the severity of his undertaking. He’s also running low on water, a critical resource, noting “The water bottles only contained a few tantalizing sips,” which only heightened his anxiety. He’s faced by extreme heat and lack of water, a dangerous combination that begins to take its toll. He’s tired and has a long way to go, the endless landscape offering no comfort. So far, all of the towns have been deserted, ghostly places that provide no relief. Finally he reaches a bait shop and his luck changes, as he refills his water and, shaken by the ordeal, promised to stick to the map in the future.

In the essay the setting affects the cyclist in different ways. For example, the course must have been tough because he was dehydrated and it says that there are rolling hills and rough roads, which made his journey physically grueling. Another example is there were dangerous animals like snakes that he came across, adding a layer of constant peril to his ride. In conclusion, these are some reasons how the setting affects the cyclist, shaping both his physical state and his overall experience on the challenging route.

The terrain described in this essay adds affect to the struggles of the cyclist. For example when the author says “there were no cars nor buildings in sight” that adds to the affect that he is really out in the middle of nowhere, emphasizing his profound isolation. Also it adds a lot of affect when he comes upon an abandoned juice factory and he is so thirsty he puts stones in his mouth to gather saliva, a desperate act highlighting his extreme need. Also when he finally finds water an “oldtimer” asks if he knows the best way to go, introducing an element of uncertainty into his difficult journey.

In the essay the cyclist is riding in the desert. It is extremely hot out because it’s June and that causes a lot of problems for him. He said that since it was so hot he was afraid of getting dehydrated, a constant and pressing concern. Also he explains that the roads were getting hilly, which would have caused him to work harder, meaning he was losing more water through increased exertion and sweat. The combination of the relentless heat and the demanding terrain created a cycle of physical hardship that was difficult for him to overcome.

The features of the setting negatively affect the cyclist. When the cyclist arrived at the first “town”, he could tell there’d be some issue. It was a deserted, run down area with no signs of life to offer help. The water was hot, providing little relief from the oppressive conditions. Down the road the setting started to change from flat land to hills, increasing the physical difficulty of his ride. There was a big snake in the road, presenting a direct danger. He was becoming very dehydrated going through hilly areas with little to no water, showing how the landscape itself contributed to his deteriorating condition.

I think it explains because they did a good job but it was not good either because they did the right thing but they did the same thing wrong too, creating a confusing outcome. The overall effort was therefore mixed, with both positive and negative aspects that are difficult to reconcile.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist. Dehydration caused by the intense heat and a lack of sufficient water caused the cyclist to sweat excessively and to feel nauseous. The author describes how “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke, caused me to laugh.” In this quote he is thinking about all the bad and horrible things that could happen to him because he is already in a bad state, pushed to his physical limits by the harsh environment. The relentless sun and the arid landscape work in tandem to create a dangerous situation for the rider. In conclusion, this is how the features of the setting, particularly the extreme heat, affects the cyclist, threatening his well-being and challenging his endurance.

The environmental features affect the cyclist in a big way, creating a series of compounding challenges. For one, the "heat beating down on him made him sweaty, hot and tired," sapping his energy over the long miles. The heat had also made him desperately thirsty which led him to drink a lot of water in a little amount of time, so he ran out of water long before reaching the next town. Also the fact he was in the desert meant there were no trees to give time off shade that he could rest in, leaving him fully exposed to the elements. There were also no people around to help him or give him water, intensifying his isolation. So in the ride he struggled more than he thought he could, as the setting presented one obstacle after another without reprieve.

Some of the things that affect the cyclist was the critical lack of water. He notes that “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips,” highlighting that water is of big importance to a person. Your body needs water to work right, and without it, the body begins to fail. The humid, dry weather of California was a major affect too, as he was cycling through “The high deserts of California in June.” The thought that “I could drop from a heatstroke” was a real danger. The sun is unbearable, especially without shade and water, and this has a major affect on the cyclist. The presence of animals was another factor, and “There was No-one in sight.” It would have been a lot easier for the cyclist if a store or people would have been around, but instead the exact company is the animals. He encounters “A large snake crossed my path,” and specifically a “diamondback- blocked the majority of the pavement.” It would have been stressful to worry about those things, and these are all things that significantly affect the cyclist during his arduous journey.

Rolling hills, open terrain, and high deserts—all are features of the setting that significantly affect the cyclist on his journey. First, Rolling Hills could take energy out of the cyclist when having to travel for miles on end, constantly battling against gravity on the ascents. The open terrain leads directly to the beating sun which also puts immense pressure on the cyclist, offering no shelter from the relentless heat. Lastly, high deserts would have an affect on the cyclist because he has to pedal for miles on end in rough, dry terrain, putting strain on him overall as he fights for every inch of progress. Each geographical feature presents its own unique physical demand, combining to create an exhausting and grueling trip.

In the case of the cyclist in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting has an enormous affect on the biker. Predominantly, the weather causes him to feel severely dehydrated. He says that he “had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly.” This is demonstrated when he tries to get water from an old well, showing just how much he needed water. The water in this pump, the owner said, was “somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” If the water has reached such a high temperature, the reader infers that it must be intensely hot outside; the author implied this when he says he is in California in June, it is a scorching day, and the sun was beating down. Another aspect of the setting, the lone, dirty, “ghost town” infested land, had a large affect on the cyclist. As he begins to see how hopeless his situation is, he cannot see any signs of modern life; “there was no one in sight, not a building car or structure of any kind.” This empty land makes the cyclist himself feel empty and utterly alone. Most literally, the fact that the setting was unknown to the cyclist affected his confusion. He didn’t know the best path to his destination and therefore relied on others for aid. Because of this, he ends up lost and aching, defeated by the unfamiliar and unforgiving landscape.

There were many different conditions that affected the cyclist throughout his arduous journey. He did not have the proper amount of water for the journey, which made it incredibly difficult to maintain his stamina. He states in the story, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Furthermore, the challenging terrain and steep hills made it difficult to maintain a steady pace. He ran into snakes and traversed very deserted country, feeling entirely alone. But his unwavering determination ultimately led to success, and he finally arrived into a town, where he could find respite.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, shaping his emotional state and resolve. When he arrives in the first “town” that the old men told him to go to, the cyclist “chuckled and moved on”, and acted just sort of indifferent, to seeing this old, dilapidated town. As he reached “the fork of sorts” twenty miles up the road, "the sight was troubling to him his water supply was somewhat deteriorating, so he became a bit uneasy and concerned. Finally when the cyclist read the sign that said “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, the author continued to move on, but with a large chunk of his confidence gone. He was dehydrated, worn out, and had lost a lot of hope after coming across all these desolate places. When he saw the sign for Gary and Wilber’s fish camp, he was as happy as could be, knowing he would drink some water, continue his journey the next day, and not listen to old men’s directions again. Many people in stories or in real life are affected by the setting they are in. In the novel @CAPS1 of champions by @PERSON1, one of the characters named @ORGANIZATION1 went on a journey to find an art exhibition, running into many problem's on the way, which in many cases, gave him a lack of hope in reaching his destination safely, mirroring the cyclist's own trials.

Some features of the environment can significantly affect the cyclist during a ride. The weather can slow them down; for instance, if it was extremely cold or hot outside, it can slow the person down and drain their energy. If the person does not have adequate protection from the elements, such as proper clothing or sufficient hydration, the journey can become far more challenging and potentially unsafe, ultimately impacting their overall performance and ability to continue.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist primarily by the road that he was on. He was on a road that had snakes and where trees had fallen all across the road, creating obstacles. The road itself was like a snake because it was waved with curves, and it had a huge hill that made you go fast, which was hard to start in the dark because the hill was steep and no one would ride that hill. If it was a more popular path, then it would have been easier to ride the hill because then there would be more people around who could help you if you got hurt. There is also no lighting there, so if you ride at night then you can’t see where you are going unless you put a light on your bike or helmet; then you can ride easier down the hill at night. That lack of light is one of the key features of the setting that affects the cyclist going down a hill where no one is there to offer assistance if it is needed.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because there was a lot of detours and distractions where the cyclist rode, demanding constant vigilance. The cyclist had to pay full attention to the road or else he could have been seriously injured by an unexpected hazard. The features of the setting also affect the cyclist because he has to navigate down steep hills and around sharp, windy turns, which tests his skill and control over the bicycle. In conclusion, the features of the setting have a huge affect on the cyclist, directly influencing both his safety and his ability to progress on his journey.

Setting can affect a cyclist in many ways. Just as I read in the story, being in a desert dehydrated him. It was hot, the road was bumpy and the dangers of poisonous snakes were ever-present. The cyclist could have died in many ways such as: heatstroke, falling off his bike, dehydration, and a bite from a snake. Say you are in the mountains of a remote region. There are many problems that face you there, including steep climbs and sudden weather changes. In conclusion, the environment presents constant challenges that can turn a simple ride into a struggle for survival.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by causing him to be hit with his water bottle regularly, the high deserts of California affected him with their intense heat and arid air. Also, “Not the miles into the next section of the ride, he noticed a terrain change.” For example, flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills which demanded more effort. Then after overcoming that, “A large highway sign jumped out at him saying or reading,” “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed Posted Speed Limit. And that was 55.” This warning signaled a new difficulty with cracked and uneven pavement. Last the author says, “Sometimes life can feel so cruel,” reflecting the cumulative strain of the journey. In conclusion there were many things that affected the cyclist, from the landscape to the official warnings on the road.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. One way is that they would drink up all of their water because it was hot and they would get extremely thirsty from all of that pedaling under the scorching sun. The relentless heat accelerated their need for hydration, quickly depleting their vital water supply. This created a dangerous situation where the cyclist's physical resources were being drained by the environment itself. In conclusion, the setting's high temperature directly influenced the cyclist's water consumption, posing a significant risk to their well-being.

In the essay entitled “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed the speed limit” the setting changes and so does the mood of the essay as well as the mood of the cyclist. For example towards the beginning of the essay, at the reserve the essay states, “At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early summer evening.” This shows how towards the beginning of the essay the cyclist is happy, just woke up and getting ready to go on a nice bike ride; however this all changes when he gets directions from a couple of “old-timers.” From that point on his trip goes down hill and the essay states, “About forty miles in to the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town’, a ghost town,” “The sun was beginning to heat down,” This also shows that the setting of a ghost town and a setting with the sun beating down is effecting the mood of the essay and the mood of the cyclist as well as when he goes another twenty miles to a different ghost town with only a few rusty water pumps containing acid flavored water. At this point the cyclist is very worried because its hot and he has no water, while knowing he has another thirty miles to go. Thirty miles of rolling hills and hot sun while seeing a “A Rough Road Ahead” sign and a diamondback snake he is sure he is going to die. However it all changes when a different sign appears, one for a bait shop, offering a chance for rescue. This is how the author, Joe Kurmaskie, uses the setting to effect the mood, demonstrating a clear link between the physical environment and the emotional journey.

The dusty, dry setting has a serious effect on the cycling author. It got so long and hot that, “Öa blues tune ‘summer time’ rattled around inÖmy deteriorating brain.” The author has spent so long cycling through heat, his brain is starting to shut down from the exhausting conditions. It’s also because there is very little water left for him, intensifying his physical struggle. Another problem is that every building and town except the last building is deserted, offering no refuge or supplies. So without any chance of being refueled and restocked, it’s the author versus nature in a harsh landscape. Plus, as the author states, the directions came from old people who, “Öhaven’t left their porches since Carter was in office.” The world has greatly changed since their time. Towns have become deserted, buildings rundown but the roads are kept in shape for traffic that no longer comes. The towns the old people mentioned are now ghost towns, and are no help to the author, leaving him isolated in a forgotten part of the country. In conclusion, the setting’s desolation and outdated information directly contributed to the author's perilous situation.

As the cyclist continues on his ride, distinct changes begin to occur in the surroundings, which ultimately affects the cyclist’s attitude. When first starting out on his journey to Yosemite, the cyclist began that morning, “with strong legs and a smile on my face.” He had received information from a few of the older locals that would help to cut the amount of time it took to arrive at Yosemite National Park. However, as he was riding, the cyclist realized that perhaps the older men’s travel advice was a little out dated. The promising shortcut led him onto a long, desolate road through an unforgiving desert landscape. The sun beat down relentlessly, and with barely any water left to hydrate himself, and being surrounded by nothing but more road and desert, the cyclist couldn’t help but laugh. “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” At this point, the cyclist was mad at himself for not just using the map that he had brought with him instead of listening to the locals. Although the cyclist remained determined to find water, he had begun to lose hope when he suddenly came across a bait store. Here he was able to rehydrate himself, and with his renewed spirit, continued on his journey, this time wisely using his map to guide his way forward.

The cyclist was riding on a rough, bumpy, and dangerous road. The uneven surface jolted his bike, demanding constant attention to maintain control. He had to be on the look out for animals that might try and hurt or even kill him, scanning the scrubland for any sudden movement. Since he had no water he was de hydrating, his throat dry and his energy waning. Also the road was not very well taken care of, covered in loose gravel and potholes, so it took more energy to get through it, slowing his progress to a grueling crawl under the oppressive heat.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it just looks like he is on the highway as in the desert riding his motorcycle or bike and it does look like he's coming or going on a vacation. The vast, empty horizon and the long, straight road create a sense of isolation. Because of the way he's riding it, it seems he's going real fast, as about to fall, with the bike wobbling precariously on the sandy shoulder. This visual tension between the open road and his unstable control highlights the vulnerability of his journey through the stark landscape.

The cyclist is out in the desert and therefore was tired, his muscles aching from the sustained effort. He was also running out of water, the last drops in his bottle long gone, so he's getting dehydrated. The relentless sun and dry air sapped his strength with every passing mile, turning his ride into a strenuous test of endurance against the harsh, arid environment.

The setting of the story affected the cyclist by changing his mood. At the start he had confidence which died once he got into the barren desert but picked up when he found a rest stop. A prime example is how he started, “with strong legs and a smile on my face” to “the growing realization that I could dropping heartstroke on a gorgeous day in June because I’d listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their perch in decades” to “I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait.” The overall mood of the story is based off how the author feels, shifting from optimism to despair and finally to relieved gratitude, all dictated by the challenging and then welcoming features of his surroundings.

The features of the setting in this story, “Do not exceed Posted Speed limit,” affect the cyclist in a huge way. The cyclist was biking through California in a desert-like area, a landscape characterized by its vast emptiness and relentless sun. It can get very hot there, like the writer describes, “wide rings of sweat circled my shirt.” The fact that the area he was biking through was so arid, and that he was out of water, put himself into serious danger. Also, since the cyclist had no water he was becoming dehydrated, a condition worsened by the extreme heat. The area he was biking through had barely any people, with long stretches of road showing no signs of life. This means there was no water available for him, leaving him with no recourse for relief. Therefore, if the setting had taken place in a cooler setting with lots of people, the cyclist would have found water. Without this type of harsh, isolated setting, the story and the cyclist's peril would have completely changed.

The setting very much affects the cyclist, primarily through the challenging terrain he must navigate. “I maneuvered down the hill,” is a statement that shows him going down the hill, a task requiring focus and control. If the hill wasn't there then it would have been a whole lot easier for him to get to where he was going, as he could have maintained a steady, efficient pace. Also, he would have had more energy, energy that was instead expended on the difficult ascent preceding the descent. If there weren't any hills to get in his way, his entire journey would have been far less physically taxing and much quicker to complete.

The setting in this story was hot and filled with rolling hills, creating a dual challenge for the rider. These factors greatly affected the cyclist, testing his endurance and resolve. The hot weather was bad for the cyclist because he had a limited water supply, which the heat threatened to deplete rapidly. The text says, “The sun was beginning to beat down,” showing the temperature was rising and intensifying his discomfort. Furthermore, the text states, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills," which introduced a new physical obstacle. The author’s battery was leaking acid so it was harder to make it over the hills, adding a mechanical difficulty to the geographic one. Seems like everything went wrong for this man with the environment against him, but he still made it through determination.

In the short story “Do not exceed speed limit,” time of year and place setting were the main things that affected the cyclist. This story takes place in the deserts of California in June, a combination known for creating severe conditions. The fact that the story took place in June, and especially in a California desert, really is what caused the cyclist’s dehydration, as this is one of the hottest and driest environments. Anywhere in this country, June is summer, and summer means that it gets hotter and more humid than usual, though in a desert the humidity is low but the solar radiation is intense. This intense heat caused the dehydration and prompted the "growing realization that I," the author, was in a serious and potentially dangerous situation far from help.

The settings in the story affected the cyclist throughout the story with its difficult geography. With winding roads and hills, peddling can already be tough, tiring, and challenging for any rider. This was compounded by the rider having little to no knowledge of the way, so the roads were ten times harder to deal with due to the constant uncertainty. And with no landmarks or places in sight, its hard to have confidence and maintain morale because there is nothing visible to keep going for, no sign of progress or destination. This psychological burden, imposed by the featureless landscape, made an already physically demanding journey even more arduous.

Don’t let anything stop you from pursuing your goals, such as going to Yosemite National Park. It takes a certain status that would put one far outside their comfort zone, off side from home. Forty miles into the journey, one comes to a small, dusty town. At a water station, you might get nothing because old men there say “the water tastes like buttery acid.” The path then leads to the hills and to remote asyl towns, a route that can be ridden without anything to drink. Tragically, people sometimes die from heat attacks because they don’t stop to sit and take breaks for necessary water and food, pushing themselves too hard in the unforgiving environment.

Features in the setting of the cyclist’s journey do in fact affect him in many significant ways. The setting in the passage includes features like having no one to be seen for miles, no buildings for shelter, a dirty and bumpy terrain, intensely hot weather, and plenty of wild vegetation. All these environmental features affect the cyclist in profoundly negative ways. For instance, the dry, hot weather directly affects the human body by causing rapid dehydration, a dangerous condition which the cyclist is severely affected by as he struggles through the barren landscape.

The setting in the story affects the cyclist a great deal, shaping his difficult experience. It is June in the harsh California desert, and the relentless sun is beating down on him without any shade for protection. Another serious problem that he faces is that there is a very rough and uneven terrain, full of rocks and ruts that jar his body. All of this together makes him drink up his precious water even faster, depleting his vital supplies. The hostile setting is making him feel very desperate, a mental state which is even worse than his physical fatigue.

Each person has a really good ability that stands out and defines their character. Someone can be good looking, smart, or naturally confident. Someone else might possess the powerful trait of never giving up, always striving to do what he wishes to do. The cyclist in the story is one such man with a remarkably strong will. He possesses a deep, burning desire to be alive. He saw too many difficulties in his way to get to the place he wanted to be. He once listened to some old guys and consequently lost his way. The sun was beginning to beat down mercilessly. He was completely out of water but he continued riding, determined to reach his goal, even as he was losing his physical strength. The weather was intensely hot. The water he remembered tasted like acid battery. Yet, he believed in himself that he could stay alive. He got psychologically stronger by believing in himself even though he was losing physical strength. Every new place that he passed by was a new experience for life. They were like levels in a challenging game that he eventually came through successfully. He never gave up. He did everything he could possibly do to avoid losing his mind amidst the hardship. He didn’t want to lose the critical battle in his own mind, and his perseverance ultimately defined his journey.

The features of the setting consistently made the cyclist more tired and thirsty throughout his ordeal. The rolling hills where he had to pedal strenuously up and coast down and the vast desert with no water in sight, just endless dry land, drained his energy. Everything in the setting was deliberately increasing the conflict in his story. The sight of the old Welch’s Grape Juice Factory, for instance, is a cruel reminder that drinks are right there but are now gone, a tantalizing mirage of the past. If the setting would have been Yosemite with its cool pines and fresh rivers he would’ve felt completely different and refreshed. The fact that there were no people in sight lacked any sense of security and hope for water, and also no buildings for respite. The tumble weeds rolling across the landscape gave you no hope of getting anywhere meaningful, and the presence of snakes and vultures seemed to promise they would just eat you after you died from exposure. Everything in the story was the absolute opposite of what he wanted and needed for survival, until he finally got to his last hope: the distant bait shop.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the setting of the story majorly affected the cyclist. The story tells us “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” The extreme heat of the summer definitely put a strain on the cyclist, causing him to have to drink lots of water and struggle against the oppressive, dry air. Unfortonatly the “towns” were very far apart and many not having good water, making dehydration a constant and serious problem. The isolation is clear when he observes, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or a structure of any kind.” None of this would have happened had he been cycling at a marathon with people handing him water when requested, or if he had been smart enough to follow a good map that accounted for such harsh, remote conditions. Ultimately, the unforgiving desert environment was the primary antagonist of his journey.

The features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist, creating a direct physical challenge. For example, on page @NUM1, Kurmaskie said “I got down on my hands working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength,” a statement that shows his desperation due to the critical lack of water. His entire physical effort was focused on this single, unreliable source of relief, highlighting how the arid setting dictated his actions and consumed his energy. This moment of struggle encapsulates the constant battle he faced against his environment, where a simple necessity like water became a monumental task.

The features of the setting been a major affect of this cyclist in the story, shaping every aspect of his difficult journey. On a normal road, the ground is smooth but this path is a lot like a rough and winding trail. The cyclist also comes across bumps and non-paved roads full of gravel and dust that make it hard to maneuver through and maintain balance. Then you add the fact that there is not really any towns for rest and he is in a blazing heat with little water, which compounds the physical toll. The setting of this passage played a key role in the story by creating a series of interconnected obstacles that tested the cyclist's endurance and resolve to the limit.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is in the high deserts of California where it is very hot so, you need a lot of water to survive the scorching sun. Then he needs more water and finds a water pump but cant use the water because it was “some where in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees," making it undrinkable and useless. Then the terrain changes when he says “Flat road was replaced” by steep, challenging inclines that demanded even more exertion. This combination of extreme heat, scarce resources, and difficult topography created a multifaceted challenge that directly impacted his physical state and his chances of success on the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the story was talking about the exceed posted speed limit and the nature of the advice he received. It discusses how the speed limit warning or where it says “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” They are trying to say is that, if you do what they say you are going to be misled, as peoples' outdated travel advice will not work in the current landscape, so you must make the right choice and do the right thing by relying on accurate, modern information. This illustrates that the social setting, comprised of locals with outdated knowledge, is just as important a feature as the physical one, as it can lead a traveler astray before the journey even properly begins.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by dictating that he or she should behave, act, or talk in accordance with the surroundings. It means that wherever they are and whatever the environment looks like, they need to fit themselves into it. They also need to align their mood and actions according to the specific location they are in. The cyclist in the story is feeling comfortable and does not require any change in the setting or location. For conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist by requiring that he needs to make improvements and personal changes to adapt to wherever he or she is located, ensuring a harmonious existence within that space.

In the beginning the cyclist was ready to go and happy, filled with anticipation for the journey ahead. By the time he got half way there he was losing hope, as the initial excitement had faded. It was very hot and he was simply alone, with no one to share the burden of the difficult trek. By the end, he was profoundly relieved because not only did he find a source of water to quench his thirst, he also discovered an easier, more manageable way to get to his destination of Yosemite. The first old group of men he encountered didn't help him, offering no assistance, but the second man did provide the crucial aid he needed to continue.

In the story “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the features of the setting affect the cyclist, and it says this because the cyclist enables us to understand what is going on around him and how he feels about it. It says, “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule greeted me.” The author goes on to say that the desolate scene troubled him. Actually, that description made the author scared that maybe he was all alone in the desert with a ghost town. The unpaved and rough roads were a concern where the speed limit was posted at 55 mph, but since he barely had any water he was only going 12 mph. This tells me he’s troubled and confused about the surrounding ways, because the entire desert seemed to highlight how the author is slowly losing hope on the travels further and further. I think it’s the same with many people that as soon as trouble comes, or when it looks like trouble is approaching, they start losing hope and their better judgment, and life seems a lot harder than it truly is.

In this story it seems as if everything is dry and devoid of moisture. The rider would be getting real thirsty under the relentless sun. He is all by himself on this journey, and that solitary state would make any man feel a sense of isolated strength, because if you have an accident then nobody would be there to help you out. He's going up and down steep hills on his bicycle, so he would have to be careful with his balance and speed to avoid a fall. This constant vigilance is a direct result of the challenging terrain he must navigate.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, both physically and mentally. For instance, if you were cycling in a very cold climate you wouldn’t sweat as much and wouldn’t need to drink as much water, but in the story the cyclist is in a very hot climate and he runs out of water, leading to distress. The quote, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, wide rings of sweat circled my shirt and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June…” explains that the setting of the cycling plays a huge role in the cyclist's experience and well-being. Also, the terrain can significantly affect a biker. If one was to ride on a flat terrain it is going to put much less wear and tear on the cyclist's body, therefore making the flat terrain much easier to manage. All of those reasons explain comprehensively that the settings affect the cyclist in many important ways.

The setting plays an important part in the author's mood, reflecting his internal state throughout the journey. When the author finds the dilapidated ghost town, he is still high spirited and amused. He thinks that it is a little funny that the old men’s “town” was now abandoned, noting that “(the town) fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled…” This shows that the author is still in good spirits because he can still laugh at the situation. When “a tar like substance oozed out of the water pump at the next stop,” the author became a little unsettled, as he was running low on water. But he was still optimistic, hoping for a better outcome ahead. Once the rolling expansive hills came into view, however, the author let out a “sad, hopeless laugh.” The author was depressed, dehydrated and had all but given up, feeling the full weight of his predicament. However he kept going, pushing through the difficult terrain, and eventually made it to some water, a testament to his enduring perseverance.

In the passage “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” the setting must definitely affects the cyclist, mirroring his struggle and isolation. When the cyclist comes to the first abandoned “town,” he searches for water but finds only that which tastes like battery acid, noting “when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” This makes his dehydration seem much worse because of the fact that he has found water, but it is just undrinkable, deepening his frustration. The rough road ahead there gives the feeling of determination because when the cyclist is on his last legs he must work even harder to get water, as “a flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This quote shows that despite his condition the cyclist must persevere against the challenging landscape. Also, the quote “tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake” evokes a feeling of desolation and of being completely alone, which is precisely what the cyclist is experiencing at this point in his arduous journey. The setting of this story directly correlates with how the cyclist is feeling, charting his physical and emotional decline.

It was a hot day in June for riding a bike in the desert. The cyclist rode off into the sun on his way to Yosemite National Park, embarking on a journey that would test his limits. The old men had told him where to go on the map even though they had not been through that way in years, offering directions that were perhaps outdated. When the cyclist started his day off, he was ready to go, filled with initial enthusiasm. He thought he would be able to stop and get water regularly, but as he found out, he was in the middle of the desert with no water around, a harsh and unexpected reality. The man pushed himself and stopped thinking about water, focusing instead on the road ahead. He even put pebbles in his mouth to suck on so he would be able to keep his mind off water, a classic trick to stave off thirst. The man was very smart in this difficult situation and knew what to do to survive. This experience, while grueling, has ultimately made him stronger and more resilient.

Flat roads, hills, and buildings are all settings that affected the cyclist profoundly, each presenting a different mental challenge. While the hills were flat, the cyclist was determined; he felt he could make it and wasn’t going to give up on himself, spurred by the easier terrain. When the hills got bigger and harder to pedal up, he began to get exhausted and tired, his energy sapped by the increasing difficulty. Lastly, the buildings were what made him want to give up, as they symbolized the comfort and sustenance he lacked. When he sees the building of the Welch’s grape juice factory and the young boy drinking, he “hung his head” in despair and envy. He was getting more tired as he went along, and the land itself was making him feel as if he didn’t want to keep moving along, each feature of the setting chipping away at his resolve.

The setting affected the cyclist greatly, creating a dire situation that tested his limits. He had no water and he was “traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” a time of extreme heat. The deserts and the lack of water could have been a life-or-death situation for him, making him stressed and unbearably thirsty. Couple that with him biking, a physically demanding activity, and you have yourself a dehydrated man in a very dangerous environment! In this story, the cyclist had to ride through the desert during the intense heat of June and with a critically low supply of water. In the story, the setting in many ways affects the cyclist. Three of those things are the heat, the lack of water, and the misleading ghost town. The heat affects him because he gets extremely hot and tired, sapping his energy with its relentless intensity. For example the text states, "I could die from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June," this shows that it was extremely hot and the conditions were deceptively dangerous. The cyclist had a lack of water and was very thirsty, which impacted his physical capabilities. For example it states in the text, "I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." This shows that he was very thirsty from lack of water, a condition that made even simple maneuvers difficult. The last way the setting affects the cyclist is when he goes into a town and finds it empty, a crushing disappointment. The text states, "on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town." This shows that he expected it to be there so he could rest but it wasn't like it was supposed to be, leaving him without the respite he desperately needed. These things all show how the setting affected the cyclist throughout his challenging ordeal.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in a couple of significant ways. The first and main way was that he was riding through the desert, an environment known for its harsh and unforgiving nature. This caused him to sweat badly and get very dehydrated, as the dry air and scorching sun pulled moisture from his body relentlessly. The second way was that there were rough roads and hilly spots along his path, which presented constant physical obstacles. This made him more tired faster, draining his stamina with every difficult mile. In conclusion, the setting did not help him not one little bit, instead posing a series of challenges that tested his limits at every turn.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, primarily through the consequences of his poor planning. The cyclist should had looked at his map instead of taking the old man's advise because all the necessary information was on the map, which would have revealed the true nature of the route. He almost died because he listened to the old men and didn’t look at his map, leading him into a treacherous and isolated landscape.
