Many things on the cyclist's journey affected him profoundly. It was in the middle of summer in California, a time when the weather is at its most extreme. The heat is unbelievable and ridiculously hot, creating an oppressive atmosphere. “I could drop from heatstroke,” he thought, and he was so badly overheated and dehydrated that he could have died any minute, his body pushed to its absolute limit. He could have also been killed by a giant snake, a sudden and terrifying danger. “look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement.” It could have easily killed him, if he wasn’t careful, presenting a lethal obstacle in his path. But with his determination and spite he pulled through and made it to a fresh supply of water, a hard-won victory. If he would have given up his life would have been over, but his perseverance in the face of these extreme setting features allowed him to survive.

When the cyclist went to ask about the road, the old men told him in all good faith that he should go that way. But the old man had not seen the land in a really long time. The man did not know that the land had changed significantly since he last traveled it. So when the cyclist went back to ride, the roads were broken and everything ended in desolate, unfamiliar terrain, leaving the cyclist not knowing what to do next in his confusion.

There are many reasons how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, and these manifest in ways both mentally and physically. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie in a very profound way. While he is riding, he sees surrounding him “no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” a description that emphasizes his utter isolation. The setting affects the cyclist because it’s very hot outside and he is starting to lose energy from the relentless heat. In the essay “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the features of the setting had a great affect on the hard-working cyclist. The weather, land, and surrounding objects really determined the cyclist's mood and physical ability throughout his ride. One example would be the statement, “cool pines, rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” The refreshing nature and cool air made the cyclist feel confident, energized, and ready to take on the challenge. Another example would be the quote, “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greet me.” There, the cyclist feels troubled and a little curious as to what lay ahead; this water wasn't the best and he was worried about its quality. The last example was, “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills...tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake.” There, the cyclist tries to stay focused through these distractions; it is deserted and he feels dehydrated as well, testing his resolve. As his route ends he comes across many more aspects of the setting which create a different feeling or ability, each leaving its mark. Therefore the nature of where his bike passed, and the things he saw, consistently affected his choices and his ability to persevere.

There are many features in the setting that affect the cyclist, one of which is that he is in the middle of California riding his bike in the sun with a limited amount of water, a situation fraught with peril. It affects the cyclist because he almost collapses from heatstroke and lack of water, pushing his body to its absolute limits. The harsh, unrelenting landscape becomes a direct antagonist to his journey. That is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, creating a physical challenge that nearly overcomes him.

The features of the setting in this essay affected the cyclist in many ways, primarily through isolation and scarcity. The description, “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me,” paints a picture of profound desolation. The cyclist was expecting a small, functioning town with people and a reliable water supply. However, he instead found a deserted ghost town where the only available pump was rusty and yielded no water. This discovery made the cyclist feel profoundly depressed, as he was running critically low on water and faced the real danger of dehydration under the relentless sun. Further compounding his struggle was the highway itself, where “The speed limit was posted high. I was doing a water-depleting crawl. sometimes life can feel so cruel.” The cyclist is painfully aware of cars passing him at high speed while he can only manage a slow, exhausting pace. This contrast probably makes him feel as if he is getting nowhere, amplifying his frustration and providing a strong reason to simply give up. Yet, despite the disheartening environment and the feeling of being outpaced by the world, a spark of determination ignites within him, compelling him to continue and finish his arduous journey against the odds.

The cyclist's situation was defined by severe hardship and vulnerability. He had very little water remaining in his bottles, a dire circumstance exacerbated by the intense, unrelenting heat. He still had a long way to go to reach his destination, and the journey was made even more difficult by the condition of the road. The surface was very bumpy and cracked, forcing him to maintain a cautious speed; going too fast risked a busted tire or a fall. To make matters worse, there were no cars in sight along the desolate stretch. This profound isolation meant that if he did break down, he would be stranded for a long time with no hope of immediate assistance, a sobering thought that underscored his complete reliance on his own dwindling resources and fortitude.

The setting profoundly affects the cyclist in many ways, and following the old-timers' advice ultimately proves to have been unwise. In the essay, he was headed to Yosemite National Park, equipped with a map and his own confidence as an experienced cyclist who knew his way around. However, he encountered a couple of men who suggested a shortcut. He trusted them, a decision he soon regretted, and set off on the recommended path. The setting was immediately rough; he was riding through a California desert, which was oppressively hot, and he was desperately looking for water. The only water he found tasted like live battery acid, rendering it completely useless. The landscape shifted from flat, barren land to rolling hills, and the next town was still many miles away. This cyclist was pushing himself to the limit. While riding through these lands, there was nothing in sight—no buildings or passing cars—it was like a dead road. Those old men had sent him through a difficult and desolate area, and once he finally made it to the next town, he understood the full weight of having endured such severe conditions based on a misplaced trust.

On the cyclist's way to Yosemite National Park, he is given directions from a group of old men, but their directions are not reliable. The deserted place affected him deeply because there was nowhere for him to stop for food or to refill his water bottle. The text notes, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” emphasizing his complete isolation. He encountered rusted water pumps, but they only offered hot, undrinkable water, providing nothing to cool him down or quench his powerful thirst. His harsh surroundings, marked by heat and emptiness, directly led him to a dangerous state of dehydration, turning his journey into a desperate struggle for the most basic necessity. This experience highlights how the physical environment became his greatest adversary on the road.

The features of the setting, including vast emptiness, hills, heat, and no water, all create significant obstacles for the cyclist. Due to the vast emptiness of the area in which he was traveling, he could not stop somewhere to ask for help or to take a proper rest. Also, there were no other travelers on the road, so he could not ask for assistance from anyone. Another major obstacle during his trip were the hills, which required more energy to pedal up, causing him to tire easily and slowing his progress considerably. There was also the extreme heat, which caused him to sweat profusely and become even more thirsty, accelerating the depletion of his water supply. In the story he writes, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips,” indicating his growing desperation. He is becoming dangerously thirsty, and if he doesn’t find water soon, he will dehydrate. He searches for a place to rest where there might be water but is not able to find one. All of these interconnected obstacles cause the cyclist to become devastated and nearly lose hope, but he perseveres, continues his travel, and eventually finds a place to rest, demonstrating resilience in the face of a compounding environmental challenge.

I really thought the story didn’t make sense; the narrative was confusing and the setting was crazy, lacking any coherent logic. I really wasn’t feeling it at all, as the characters' actions seemed arbitrary and the plot was disjointed. I don’t think it was even a good story, failing to deliver a compelling or engaging experience from start to finish. Ultimately, the entire concept felt poorly conceived and executed.

The features of the setting affect a cyclist in many ways, directly influencing the difficulty and experience of the ride. If you have a bumpy ride on a rough road surface, then the cyclist will have a harder time maintaining speed and control. Also, if it is really hilly with steep inclines, then it is harder on the legs and will take longer to complete the journey too. As the text states, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” which means it will take him longer to reach his destination, requiring more energy and effort. Furthermore, animals in the setting can also be effective obstacles. For instance, “and a ridiculously, large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” Animals can get in the way like this snake did for the cyclist, causing sudden stops. If a squirrel or some kind of animal was to run across the road right in front of you, it could startle you and you could clash, potentially leading to a fall. On the other hand, environmental features can offer benefits. Sometimes trees make it cooler by providing shade because you don’t have the sun beating directly down on your back, offering relief from the heat. If there is a fresh water stream you can stop and wash all the sweat off of you and get a refreshing drink to rehydrate. In conclusion, the setting in which a cyclist is riding can significantly help or hurt the cyclist, shaping the entire journey.

It affected him by severely dehydrating him and wearing him down both physically and mentally to the point where he was about to give up on his arduous journey. But he never gave up, pushing through the exhaustion and hardship with sheer determination. As the end, a profound sense of satisfaction and accomplishment came out of it all, making the struggle worthwhile and proving his resilience.

The trees were present in the landscape, and their autumnal foliage was making the colors a brilliant red, while the distant volcanoes and the tall pine trees covered the mountainous regions. There were a few key features in the setting that profoundly affected the cyclist during his journey. One very important feature is that the cyclist was riding through the desert, a harsh and unforgiving environment. This is demonstrated by the statement “I was travelling through the high deserts of California.” Not only was the cyclist in the desert, he was there in June, one of the hottest and most challenging months of the year. It is demonstrated that he was there in June according to the statement “I was travelling in June.” Being there at that time made dehydration a much bigger risk due to the extreme heat. It was also very hot there, with temperatures soaring. We know this because when he was at the water pump, he stated, “blackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” From this, we can affirm that not only was it extremely hot, but the available water was dirty and overheated. The water also “had the flavor of battery acid,” making it virtually undrinkable. This was particularly bad for the cyclist who was running dangerously low on his own water supply because he “had been hitting (his) water bottles pretty regularly.” The fact that he had little clean water left is demonstrated in the statement, “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips.” The cyclist was truly in a bad situation, facing multiple environmental challenges. These conditions had all ganged-up against him in his trip, creating a cumulative effect of hardship. These primary antagonistic features are the desert itself, the punishingly high temperatures, and the blackish, foul-tasting water which was completely unpalatable. The fact that he was low on his own water made it harder to fight these features, as he could not properly rehydrate to battle the desert heat and had no need to pump the bad water. Again, the defining features of the setting that affected the cyclist are the desert landscape, the extreme high temperatures, and the bad water which he could not drink, culminating in a severe test of his endurance.

In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affected the cyclist because it made it more difficult for the cyclist to survive and make it through his journey, testing his physical limits. In the story, “Rough Road Ahead”, by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist was profoundly affected by the setting, which presented a series of physical challenges. In the selection “Do not exceed posted speed limit” there are a lot of great details of the area around the cyclist that paint a vivid picture of his struggle. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the he was traveling through a hot place at a hot time of year and didn’t have much water, a combination that created a serious risk. The setting profoundly affected the cyclist because since it was the California desert, and it was in June, it was very hot and dry. In the story *Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit* the setting greatly affects the cyclist throughout his challenging journey. The towns, the terrain, the Welchís Grape Juice factory- all are distinct parts of the setting that significantly affect the cyclist. ìThis place might have been a thriving little spot at one time- say, before the last world war,î describes the cyclist, ìbut on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.î The desolate town intensifies the cyclist feeling of doubt, in that it is increasing with every abandoned building. At this part, he is really regretting taking the old guy's advice in taking the ìshortcut,î feeling misled by the empty promise. ìNot two miles into the next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing,î reveals the cyclist as the road grew more arduous. The cyclist is already very worried and very doubtful, and the rough terrain is making it worse; it mirrors the deserted town in which the cyclist had stopped at earlier to, again make his feeling of doubt increase. Then the cyclist exclaims, ì By the looks of it- had been a Welchís Grape Juice Factory.î Upon seeing this landmark, the cyclist gets very excited and gets a great feeling of hope, a stark contrast to his earlier despair. So throughout the whole story, the setting of where the cyclist is at affects his mood by giving him doubt, but by also giving him hope, ultimately shaping his emotional journey.

The cyclist was biking through the California deserts during the warm summer months, a time of intense heat. The heat and the uninhabited, lonely canal path were the biggest struggle for the cyclist, offering no respite. For example, he thought there would be many stops for water during his trip, relying on this assumption, but he was mistaken as the landscape was barren. Also he runs out of water very quickly because of being dehydrated in the scorching heat, which accelerated his thirst. The cyclist became irritated with himself for trusting someone else to give him directions for a shortcut that seemed to lead nowhere. Ultimately, the setting affected the cyclistís mood in a negative way, fostering frustration and regret on his difficult journey.

There were many features in the setting of this bike race that physically affected the cyclist during his ride. It stated, ìflat road was replaced by short, rolling hillsî (Kurmaskie @NUM1), introducing a new challenge. The cyclist was pedaling fine until these big hills came into affect and his energy was running lower as he went along, straining his muscles. Also it stated,î At some point tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snakeî (Kurmaskie @NUM2), creating obstacles. This debris and snake made him stop because he got scared and slowed him down, interrupting his rhythm. There was a lot of features in the setting that made the cyclist affected to slow him down and lose energy, proving the environment was a formidable opponent in the race.

Many things can affect a cyclist and how they ride, and in this essay, many things affected him, such as the setting of the story. One of the problems of the setting was that there were no stores or even people for many miles, creating a profound sense of isolation. Another and most important thing was the critical lack of water around him, which became a constant source of worry. The vast, empty landscape offered no respite from the harsh conditions. So many things can effect a cyclist while they are riding, including their immediate surroundings and the challenges presented by the environment, which ultimately shape their entire journey and experience on the road.

The second photograph better communicates ideas similar to the ideas expressed in the essay “A Sea Worry,” because the story is about a boy who surfs as a job and in the second picture a boy is surfing in the ocean. The author says, “my son body-surfs. He says it’s his ‘job’.” That quote was explaining that he’s a body-surfer and it’s his primary occupation, his chosen way of life. The image visually reinforces this central theme of a deep, personal connection to the sea. This direct parallel between the textual description and the visual content is the primary reason I chose the second photograph to represent the essay's core idea.

The condition the cyclist is in affects a lot of how they ride, particularly in challenging environments. One example of this is, “I was travelling through the high desert of California in June.” Due to this fact, the cyclist had went into a “dehydrated state” because of not having much water available on the long, barren route. When you are travelling in hot weather areas without much water, your body will become dehydrated from excessive sweating, leading to fatigue and diminished physical capacity. The physical state of the rider is therefore directly influenced by the external conditions. Cycling in different conditions will affect cyclists differently, highlighting how a rider's well-being is tied to the environment.

Many features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead.” First, the scorching heat of the desert in June was a major problem that had him to the brink of severe dehydration. In the text it states, “I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This shows the dangerous effect the prolonged exposure to intense heat had on the cyclist, turning a beautiful day into a potential hazard. Also, the difficult terrain posed a significant threat to his well being during the story. In the text it says “I toiled on.” This shows the increase in effort and physical strain the rugged terrain caused on the cyclist during his adventure, compounding the challenges he faced from the climate alone.

In the story “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. It being hot affected him because it made him more thirsty and drained his energy quickly. Then, him being out in the middle of the desert made it so he couldn’t get any water, as there were no services for miles around. Furthermore, the steep hills made him tired and weak, demanding great physical exertion to overcome. All of the features in the setting had an affect on him, which collectively made him feel powerless and desperately thirsty, demonstrating the overwhelming power of the environment.

The features that affect the cyclist are that he is riding his bike in the desert and doesn't have any water. That affects his journey because he is dehydrated, so he needs to find water fast, making his progress toward Yosemite slower as he is forced to search for a source. The relentless sun and the barren landscape create a significant obstacle, directly impacting his speed and physical condition. This is a feature that profoundly affects the cyclist and his ability to complete his journey efficiently. Ultimately, the lack of water becomes the central challenge dictating the pace and difficulty of his travel.

In the story, the setting has a large effect on the cyclist. After taking advice from old people, he ended up in the desert with no cars, buildings, or people. He was running low on water and had no way of getting anymore, and he was really dehydrated. He got really tired and almost gave up because of the oppressive heat and the complete lack of water. The isolation of the environment meant there was no one to assist him, leaving him entirely on his own. All this was caused by the harsh and unforgiving setting he was in, which tested his physical and mental limits to the extreme.

The setting of the place was a “ghost town” as the author said. It was a hot summer day in June, so of course the cyclist would be dehydrating quickly under the intense sun. There was no one around, so he couldn’t ask for help or directions from anyone. It was like an old, abandoned town because he ran into old men who knew nothing of the new world, as they ultimately told him the wrong directions, leading him further astray. The desolate and outdated nature of the location directly contributed to his predicament, leaving him lost and without resources. This shows how the specific qualities of the setting created a series of obstacles for the cyclist.

The setting affected the cyclist in a few different ways. At first, it helped him. “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed. The cool pines and rushing rivers” This is saying the pines and rivers helped him forget the sun and provided a pleasant environment. Later on, the setting was against him. There was no place to get water and he was becoming dehydrated as the terrain was getting rougher and more barren. There were no people around to help him, but there was a snake, adding a element of danger to his isolation. All these features were working against him, creating a formidable challenge, until he finally made it to a bait store. This bait store gave him water and a good map, providing the crucial relief he needed from the hostile environment.

In the story *Rough Road Ahead* by Joe Kurmaskie, it tells of a cyclist heading for Yosemite National Park and the problems he faced. For example, the heat was a major issue the cyclist had to confront throughout his journey. In the story, it said “Drop from heatstroke,” which shows the setting affected him in a negative and dangerous way, threatening his health. In the story, the intense heat was a major part of the setting that affected the character, shaping his experience and presenting a constant physical threat. This demonstrates how the environmental conditions were a central antagonist in his narrative.

The features of the setting affected the author’s story a lot. It affected it by making the trip seem more difficult to the reader. This was made possible by telling how hot it was and explaining how the road was full of bumps or hills. The story says “over one long, crippling hill.” This makes the reader think the trip is very hard since he has to ride up so many hills, which is physically draining. But if the road wasn’t as hilly then the trip would seem less difficult and tiring. This would also make it as if the old guys gave good directions, suggesting an easy path. But the whole point of the setting's description is to emphasize the struggle and the misleading nature of the advice he received.

As soon as the cyclist gained information about which way to go, he set off through tall, cool pines. They gave him a feeling of confidence, and physically cooled his body down from the sun's heat. As he headed down the road, he encountered various small towns—none of which looked promising—which gave him a feeling of despair, in accordance to his lack of water. Even further into the journey, he found one last town, and a rundown welcher’s factory. This increased his thirst and gave him a feeling of spite towards the old men who had given him advice, as the place was clearly abandoned. However, he soon found a bait house where he could get water and escape the heat. For this he was satisfied and grateful to the owner for the relief. It made him realize to never again trust the old men and their unreliable guidance.

The setting affects a lot in a cyclist. For example, if you are in a city you feel rushed, tired, and overwhelmed by the traffic and noise. But in a forest you are happy and a bit less stressed by the calm and shade. A setting sets the mood and also the attitude in the story, influencing how the character feels and acts throughout their journey. The environment directly shapes the emotional experience and the challenges faced by the individual.

The features of the setting affect the author’s disposition as well as his ability to complete the journey, thus creating an obstacle the author must overcome. At the end of paragraph five the author writes that “I was traveling through the high deserts of California.” This setting is important because it adds a sense of urgency to his trip when he starts to run low on water in the arid heat. This is similar to when I was backpacking and a bear got most of our food; our normal backpacking trip had become more of a game of survival. So, the water issue was clearly the main point of conflict that the author presented in the setting. He also writes that “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This aspect of the setting also affects the cyclist because it makes it much harder for him to progress than if it was a downhill road, demanding greater physical effort. In short, the setting of the story presents the main points of conflict to the author and thus was essential to the essay’s narrative of challenge.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the unbearable setting effects the cyclist with its harsh conditions. At first, in the cyclist’s own words, “things began well enough.” However, this soon changes. The road is long and filled with obstacles and the cyclist has hardly any water to sip. He does not give up, though; in the text it says, “got back on the bike, but not bothered gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth.” He does this in order to reduce his need for water and continues, ignoring the toll the setting brings upon him, demonstrating his determination to push through the adversity.

The cyclist is affected by the setting in "Rough Road Ahead" because the road itself is a place, and its condition directly impacts the traveler. If the road is rough or unknown, it presents a direct challenge to the cyclist. For instance, if the path includes a hill, then the cyclist would inevitably have to climb it. In the text, the phrase "over a long crippling hill" is used, and the description of the hill as "crippling" strongly emphasizes how the specific feature of the setting, a steep incline, physically and mentally strains the rider. This demonstrates the powerful influence of the environment on the journey's difficulty.

The various features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist, primarily through the absence of water, the presence of hills, and the expansive deserts. When the cyclist saw water, his desire to jump in was overwhelming, as his mind was completely fixated on the water that they lacked, which he compared to something as undesirable as battery acid. The hills then further impeded his progress, actively slowing him down and delaying his reach to the potential water source. The desert environment, with its arid heat, only served to intensify his thirst and his need for water even more. These are the key features of the settings that significantly affected the cyclist and his arduous journey.

There were many features in the setting that affected the cyclist during his journey. One significant factor was the extreme heat of the June sun in California. The speaker explicitly stated that he felt he could have died from heatstroke, highlighting the danger. The rough road was also a major problem for the cyclist, creating additional physical hardship. The constant bumps, the exhausting hills, and even the presence of wildlife all affected the cyclist's progress. However, the thing that most affected him was the severe lack of water. It was such a pressing problem that he resorted to sucking on stones just to take his mind off his powerful thirst. As you can see, these environmental problems in the story collectively affected the speaker's challenging journey to Yosemite National Park.

The features of the setting directly affect the cyclist throughout his ordeal. He is riding through a desert where there is little to no rain. This arid condition means that he cannot collect any rainwater to drink if he runs out of his own supply. Also, deserts are notoriously hot, and the intense heat will speed up his dehydration process, meaning he will need even more water to survive. The consequence is severe; if he runs out of water, he will die. The cyclist finds a building, but it is abandoned and empty, offering no respite. All these features of the setting affect him profoundly. Since he cannot find water, he has to carefully conserve what little he has. The heat is overwhelming and feels as though it is killing him. It does not help that the only structure he finds is abandoned, reinforcing his isolation. During this time, with death in the air, the barren desert with nothing growing and no water, the cyclist is consumed with thoughts of his own death. As long as he thinks about his death, the feeling of doom only intensifies. However, as soon as he puts the pebbles in his mouth to stop thinking about death and his thirst, he sees a bait shop which ultimately saves his life. He shifted his thoughts to surviving, and immediately found a shop where he could finally drink.

The setting affected the cyclist greatly throughout his ride, creating a series of life-threatening challenges. The quote, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke,” clearly illustrates this impact. This statement shows that because of the relentless heat, the rough terrain, and the unexpected length of his so-called “shortcut,” his water supply is nearly gone. That is the critical moment when he realizes he could actually die from heatstroke, a dire situation he attributes to having listened to the advice of a bunch of old men. This highlights how the environmental conditions directly led to a crisis of survival.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He is in the desert and has a low supply of water, which is a critical resource in such an arid environment. Without water he tired very easily, as dehydration quickly saps one's energy. On top of that he had to pedal a bicycle across the vast, sandy terrain, which required significant physical exertion. So he was thirsty and tired, a direct result of prambeing in the desert. This is how the setting affected the cyclist, creating a challenging and draining experience.

Setting affects the cyclist in several significant ways. The cyclist has to worry about the road condition, which can vary greatly. If the road condition is bad, with potholes or loose gravel, then the cyclist must reduce his/her speed to maintain control and avoid accidents. The cyclist also has to worry about if it is day or night, as visibility is a major factor for safety. If it is night, they must be especially careful due to cars not being able to see them clearly in the darkness. In the text, the cyclist was in extremely hot weather, which adds another layer of difficulty. This is dangerous to a cyclist if they are not prepared with things such as water and proper sun protection, highlighting how the environment dictates the journey's demands.

The setting affects the cyclist because the cyclist believes that he has a nice, short, flat distance to travel to get to Yosemite but instead it is a long, hilly(rough), hot journey. He only prepared himself for a quick ride, bringing only enough water for that short trip, and wasnít prepared for the reality of his ride. First of all he is riding in the middle of the day (the hottest part) in the ìhigh deserts of colifornia in Juneî I know when I go to camp here in @LOCATION1 during the summer I drink I drink six to seven liters, but the author only mentions a "few bottles of water" which aren't going to help him in that intense heat. Secondly, the cyclist believed that the old men had given him a safe path to follow but instead he came across a ìridiculously large snake. It really looked like a diamond backî That is a poisonous snake and the cyclist has barely able to ìease postî it because, of his lack of water and resulting fatigue. Lastly, the cyclist expected the old men to give him an easy path on a flat terrain when in fact it was ìreplaced by short, rolling hillsî which means you have to put more effort (using more water) to climb the hills, further depleting his reserves. The setting definetely affects the cyclist because it makes it more difficult for him to reach his destination, but without a few bumps in the road, how is he to learn a life lesson about preparation and perseverance?

The cyclist is affected by the features of the setting a lot. For example the dry hot place makes him thirsty and accelerates his need for hydration. Then the ghost towns make it hard to get supplies, leaving him without access to water or food. Also the bad road slowed him down, forcing him to navigate carefully. The bad roads even would probably hurt him and his bike with jolts and vibrations; the roads also would make him work harder, demanding more energy with each rotation of the pedals. Ultimately, the harsh environment presented a series of interconnected obstacles that significantly impeded his progress.

The features of the setting affected the cycalist in many bad ways. For example in the text it says how ìI eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated stateî. Meaning that he had trouble being in a place he didnít know well of and he was dehydrated, which impaired his coordination and physical control. The unfamiliar and demanding terrain directly contributed to his physical distress. In conclusion the setting did affect the cyclist by creating conditions that challenged his body and his ability to navigate safely.

First, the bike encounters flat roads in the desert which are very easy to navigate through, offering a smooth start to his arduous journey; when he gets to his first town he still goes on trying to get to Yosemite, then after is going low so he looks for some more water to help him go, finding only a small, nearly dry stream. Then he kept going and he experienced a fork in the road, a choice that added to his uncertainty. After the fork he kept going and he then faced another problem. That problem was an old person told him to go @NUM1 miles to the town and he didn’t trust the guy, fearing the directions might be wrong. Then the biker listened and he went on down the road, hoping for the best. He then faced his next problem. The flat road started to get very wary with short high and low hills, which began to sap his energy. These hills reduced his stamina greatly, forcing him to push harder with each pedal. Then he had to deal with a rocky and bumpy desert road, which jolted his bike and his resolve. He then had to face a snake and he had to avoid it so it didn’t attack him, swerving just in time. Finally the biker faced his last long hill and he finally found a bait and tackle shop with lots of water, a welcome sight that promised relief.

In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclist is affected by the features of the setting by making him feel worse than he does, amplifying his sense of isolation and hardship. The cyclist is lost, has only found dirty water, and is moving on rough ground, which compounds his misery. The features of the setting are “cool pines and rushing rivers,” however, the cyclist comes to find that the “rushing river” is not so refreshing, as it is either inaccessible or not what he imagined. He also encounters a terrain change, from flat road to short, rolling hills, which further tests his endurance. There is a sign, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” also the name of the passage with a limit of 55 mph, while the cyclist is only going 12 mph, highlighting his slow, painful progress. Ironically, he finds a picture of a boy drinking grape juice at the factory, which cause him to hang his head in misery due to his intense thirst, a cruel reminder of what he lacks. Finally, he comes to a fish camp, where he encounters the owner who, ironically, tells him he’d be better off using his map, a final blow to his misguided efforts.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is going to be on the road a long time, with the environment posing constant challenges. The features of no buildings, no people and no cars, affect on the rider is that he feels helpless when he is low on water, with no one to turn to for aid. The ghost town doesn’t help he because the old man told him about it and he thought he would be able to get more water, but it was completely barren. The grape juice factory affected him because he thought he would get a drink but it was abandoned, dashing his hopes for refreshment. This is how the features affect the cyclist, by presenting false promises and deepening his desperation throughout the journey.

Features of the setting would affect me if I was the cyclist because, I would be thinking I was going to die just like he did because, there is nothing to look at, no breeze, wind, he seen a snake, he had no water, creating a profound sense of dread. He went through three towns that had nothing, each empty location eroding his morale further. The sun was setting down on him, it was hot, he had no hope, and the vast, empty landscape seemed to offer no escape. Who knows, maybe if he would have just went with what the map had said, he would have been fine, but the oppressive setting clouded his judgment and led him astray, a cautionary tale about the power of environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly throughout his journey. The cyclist is running out of water and is in the intense heat in “the high deserts of California in June,” a brutal combination. The tumbleweeds that cross his path add to the desperation, symbolizing the bleak and unforgiving nature of his surroundings. Not only do the features of the setting affect the cyclist physically by dehydrating him in the heat, but also mentally, as his spirit begins to break. The cyclist encounters rolling hills, tumbleweeds, rattlesnakes and ghost towns, each new obstacle chipping away at his resolve. All of these make the cyclist start to give up hope, feeling utterly defeated by the landscape. In conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist physically and mentally, demonstrating how environment can overwhelm an individual.

The features of the setting greatly impacted the cyclist, shaping his emotional and physical state throughout the journey. First, the setting at the middle of the story was empty and offered no place to get water, a desolation that filled the cyclist with profound doubt and despair as he thought he would die. The setting also made the cyclist intensely thirsty because of the extreme, unrelenting heat that seemed to press down from all sides. Finally, the cyclist was filled with a deep sense of regret because he regretted listening to the old men whose advice had led him astray, a bitter realization as the cyclist didn’t make it where he wanted to go and was left stranded in the harsh environment.

The author thinks that the setting means he is not getting any closer to his destination, a feeling reinforced by the monotonous and barren landscape. However, he found out that there were still people around, a discovery that did not bring comfort but instead made him panic as he thought he was going to die. The places were completely deserted and he thought they led nowhere, offering no escape or salvation. He was a little scared at the fact he might die because everything around him was, in a sense, already dead, a chilling observation that underscored his own fragile mortality in the vast emptiness.

The setting really affected the cyclist, imposing severe physical demands on his body. Since he was in the desert on a bike he was going to be hot and tired, a state of exhaustion which would come from the sun coming down on him with relentless intensity. You know he was hot where it said “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt,” a vivid description that illustrated the extent of his dehydration and the physical toll of the journey through the arid, unforgiving landscape, leaving him drained and weary.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they are extreme and do not change, creating a constant and oppressive challenge. The cyclist was riding on a small road in the desert, a path that offered little shade or respite. In the desert it was very hot and because of this the cyclist was sweating a lot and getting dangerously dehydrated. Also because he was in the desert he had no clear sense of direction, lost in the vast, featureless terrain. Furthermore, the towns are all run down with nothing in them, so the cyclist couldn’t get any water to drink to rehydrate himself, a critical failure in the environment. Only when he comes to a small bait shop close does he finally get water, a moment of brief relief in his otherwise desperate situation.

The setting really affected the cyclist a lot, primarily through its harsh climatic conditions. The sun and hot weather dehydrated him, a serious problem as he had also pretty much ran out of water. In the story he says "The bottles contained only a few drops," a statement that shows he had drank almost all of his water and was facing a critical shortage. Then it says "the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke" shows the heat was affecting him profoundly, highlighting the direct and dangerous impact the environment had on his physical well-being and his fear of succumbing to the elements.

The setting was calm and peaceful as he started out riding his bike on a quiet, shaded path. He was smiling and his legs were strong, propelling him forward with ease. As he hit the first town and saw a ramshackled shed, rusty pumps, and a corral, he begun to be troubled b/c he was running out of water, the sight of decay mirroring his growing anxiety. As the flat rodes were replaced wI short, rolling hills he became even more troubled, his energy waning with each new incline. When he saw a building he became happy, thinking he had found a place to rest, but when he found out it was run down he was sad, thirsty, and tired, his hope deflating. When he finally saw an old man and told him he had a map he became a little happier b/c he was going to get to Yosemite, the simple guidance offering a new direction. As the setting became worse his mood became worse b/c he had less and less water and felt very hopeless, the harsh landscape draining his spirit. But when he saw the man he became happy b/c the map was going to help him navigate the difficult journey ahead, providing a crucial lifeline.

The setting of this story is very rigorous, testing the cyclist's endurance at every turn. At the beginning of the story the boy was fine, enjoying the morning air. He had a bottle of water with him so that he didn’t get dehydrated, a sensible precaution for his trip. When he was riding he started to feel the sun get higher into the sky, though he could barely feel its full intensity because of the pines that shaded the road, and the cool feel of the river nearby. The cyclist got to the second town on his journey and he had been drinking his water all day and was about out, his supply critically low. He had found a water pump, a potential source of relief. He got down on his knees and pulled the handle with all his might but all that came was blackish water. He just feared the water and stated that it tasted like battery acid, undrinkable and foul. He began to ride again, his thirst unquenched. Not two miles up the road the terrain changed, becoming more demanding. Not only was it rolling hills, it was also getting hotter, the sun now relentless. He was majorly dehydrated because he was out of water except for a few tantalizing sips. Dry sweat circled his shirt and he was afraid he could freeze up from heatstrokes, a confusing and frightening thought. Where he was at was in the middle of no where, with no buildings, cars or structures in sight, a vast and empty landscape. Over one of the hills he saw a building came into view. He wiped the sweat off his eyes to make sure it was not a mirage. By the looks of it had been a Welch’s grape juice factory. He is so dehydrated and tired that he could see a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth, a cruel trick of his mind. There is only the problems it is abandoned, offering no real solace. This person was imagining things, his desperation creating visions. He got back on his bike and stuck pebbles into his mouth, a classic but futile trick. This was to help take his mind off being thirsty, a small distraction from his overwhelming need for water.

I read “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” written by Joe Kurmaskie. In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist by forcing him to accept advice from “old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This interaction, born from the cyclist's encounter with the specific locale and its inhabitants, highlights how the environment directly shapes his journey and the decisions he must make along the way, ultimately influencing his path forward.

In the essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, creating a series of physical and mental challenges. First, the sun is making the cyclist hot and dehydrated, a constant source of discomfort. He states “The sun was beginning to beat down,” showing that the sun was a big factor on the affect on the cyclist, relentlessly sapping his strength. Also, the hills of the country roads posed a significant obstacle. Going up and down hills take a lot of work; you have to use a lot of energy, which was in short supply. The cyclist says “flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills,” marking a difficult transition in his route. Furthermore, there were snakes in the road, which make the cyclist timid looking out for snakes so he would not get bit, adding a layer of fear to his travel. Again the cyclist states “diamondbacks blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me,” a vivid image of the danger. Finally, there was an old factory that gave the cyclist hope and then crushed his hopes when he found it abandoned. The factory even made him more thirsty by reminding him of his need for a refreshing drink. In the end, there were many affects on the cyclist due to the setting, each feature contributing to his arduous experience on the road.

The features of the setting take their toll on the unfortunate cyclist, each element conspiring against his progress. For example, “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” The deserts of California especially in June are hot and dry and caused the cyclist to use much of his water supply, very quickly, leaving him vulnerable. As he “toiled” on, the terrain features became even more trying, the path growing more arduous. “Over one long, crippling hill…” By this time the cyclist barely had enough energy to make it over a hill from all the wear and tear his body was put through by the features of his setting, the cumulative effect of the harsh environment pushing him to his absolute limit and leaving him utterly spent.

The setting of this story has an encouraging impact on the narrative because it presents an alike ride, one that is both challenging and demanding. The terrain in the story sounds rough, as evidenced when he saw a sign marked, “Rough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limit.” He already has to navigate up and down steep hills littered with rocks and devoid of any water sources. Such a setting, combined with a really athletic ride, can be devastating, testing the very limits of his endurance and resolve as he pushes forward.

The feature of the cyclist and the settings aren’t that good, creating a series of incidents that are a significant problem for his journey. One major issue is the bad weather, with a temperature that makes it feel pretty close to @NUM1 degrees, creating an oppressive and draining heat. He stops at a water pump where water comes out, but it is really not cool and is utterly undrinkable. He takes two little sips and its taste is like battery acid, so foul that if he were to drink a lot of that water it would probably kill him or make him very ill. He desperately needs something because the next town is @NUM2 miles down the road, so he has to find a way to keep himself going. As he continues down the road he sees another sign: Rough Road Ahead, a warning that even though he is going only 12 mph he could still hit a hole and go flying over his handlebars. If he does get thrown from his bike, he could run into the snake he saw earlier and then be too weak to move, left vulnerable. There are some interesting and tense scenes in the story that highlight his precarious situation.

Heat, water supply, and energy are all critical features of the setting that can profoundly affect a cyclist. First, is the intense heat. When it is too warm out, it makes the ride more difficult, and more inconvenient, sapping strength with every pedal stroke. Second, is your water supply, a vital resource. If you are riding and begin to run low on water, you are in serious trouble, a point the author describes by stating, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” If you aren’t prepared enough for your cycling journey, it will be extremely inconvenient and dangerous when you run out of supplies. Lastly, is personal energy. If you run out of energy while cycling, you have nothing left to give; your energy is what keeps you moving and motivated. The author illustrates this, describing, “With what I believe, was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill.” When you are completely out of energy, your ride is effectively over. Ultimately, all of these aspects are fundamentally important to consider before deciding to go on a demanding cycling journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by severely dehydrating him due to the relentless heat and the critical lack of available water, even causing him to see mirages. Furthermore, he steadily loses strength and stamina from the exertion of going over the many successive hills along his route. Adding to the danger, there is a very large snake he has to ride by, a creature that could have easily bitten him and ended his journey in disaster.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly because when you have numerous hills to climb and little water available, you will inevitably get dehydrated. Also, the extreme heat from the desert is so intense that it too can quickly make you dehydrated, compounding the physical strain. If you don't carefully pace yourself and if you don't ration your water, you will struggle to reach your goal. Your rest is also a big thing, for if you don't have enough energy from proper recovery, you will simply not get far on such a demanding journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the steep hills made it hard for him to ride his bike up, forcing him to push it instead, and he was afraid of the tall grass lining the path because it was tall and scary looking, obscuring his view of what might be hidden within. The physical challenges presented by the environment directly shaped his experience and emotional state during the journey.

In the story “Do not exceed Posted Speed limit” a cyclist takes a long journey through difficult terrain to get to Yosemite. In that remote part of California there are not a lot of towns or people, creating a profound sense of isolation. The road he is riding on is very dangerous and long, with sharp curves and little shoulder. It is very dry and hot out there, with the sun beating down relentlessly on the cracked, pale earth, making his journey a true test of endurance.

The setting can affect a cyclist in a lot of ways, influencing both their physical stamina and mental resolve. One way setting affects a cyclist is when it is hot, as the intense heat makes it harder to cycle long distances and leads to dangerous dehydration. I say this because in the story the narrator says “…and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke…” Another crucial part of setting that affects a cyclist is the specific terrain they cycle on. For example, it is much easier to cycle on flat, smooth ground than it is on rolling hills with rough, rocky ground that jolts the bike. This is shown with the quote “…ride down into distances I could see over the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine.” Ultimately, the setting can have a great deal of effect on a cyclist, depending on whether it is smooth or rocky, or hot and cool, fundamentally shaping the difficulty of the ride.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed the Speed Limit” the features of the setting affects the cyclist a great deal, creating a series of survival challenges. Each feature causes the cyclist to act and adapt his plans accordingly. For example, in reaching the ‘ramshackle shed’ the cyclist finds the water unusable, which causes him to conserve his remaining water and try to head for the next town as quickly as possible. That action leads him deeper into the high deserts of California during the intense heat of June. Also, as the terrain changes from flat road to short, rolling hills the cyclist must change his speed and effort to better survive and continue in his dehydrated state. The scarcity of buildings in this dry desert terrain causes the cyclist to try every ‘shack or building he comes across for water, no matter how dilapidated. In this story the features of the setting dictates the actions of the cyclist in his quest to survive in the desert a lot, demonstrating how the environment directly controls his fate.

The cyclist in the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is about a great adventure gone bad, despite his initial preparations. He has every thing he needs but some how it turns out bad when his supplies begin to run low. He gets low on water & the setting is horrible, a vast and unforgiving desert. He is on his way from a camp ground to the Yosemite river after receiving bad directions from old guys at the camp ground. On his way he ran into two abandon towns & was running out of water; then he came to a sign that said, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” He was pedaling over hills & becoming dehydrated; when he thought he was going to die he came to a bait shop & got water & met an old guy who was going to give him direction & he decided he better stick to the map. Even though the setting got worse through the story, he stuck it out & made it to the end, completing his arduous journey through the challenging landscape.

Heat, hills and ghost towns ñ all are features of setting that profoundly affect the cyclist. First, the intense, unrelenting heat dehydrates and exhausts him, almost causing him a heat stroke under the scorching sun. He starts drinking more often to combat this, and consequently nearly runs out of his precious water supply. Next are the formidable hills. They can take massive amounts of energy and sustained effort to climb, which significantly adds to his physical strain and dehydration. Finally, the desolate ghost towns he passes through make his journey seem hopeless and isolating. Which could cause him to lose the crucial mental will to carry on through such a challenging landscape.

The cyclist is in the desert which is over @NUM1 degrees with water that tastes harshly like battery acid, making it difficult to consume. The oppressive desert environment makes him see shimmering mirages and causes stinging sweat to constantly get into his eyes, further disorienting him. This challenging setting is a central element in the story ìDo Not exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, highlighting the physical toll of the journey.

In the story, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the author tells a story about when he took advice from ìold folksî and consequently became lost on a remote road. The desolate setting greatly affected him and his journey, for example when he notes that ìtumbleweeds crossed my path, and a ridiculously large snakeÖî slithered by, and he faced a ìcrippling hillî that tested his resolve. These quotes explain that the setting was quite scary and intimidating, contributing to his sense of being lost and vulnerable in an unforgiving environment.

Heís on a very hot climate, in a vast desert, so he needs lots of water to stay hydrated, but he has only a limited supply in his bottles. Heís riding on steep, rolling hills, which makes the physical exertion even harder and more draining on his energy. Furthermore, he canít find any towns that arenít abandoned, leaving him without hope of respite or replenishment. This combination of harsh elements creates a deeply challenging and isolating journey for the cyclist.

In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way it affected him was the time it took because of the rough road; he had to go slower and more carefully, so it took him longer to get to the next town. Also, because the road was harder to peddle on, he got thirsty more quickly and found that the water in his bottle was really hot from the sun, offering little refreshment. These environmental obstacles worked together to slow his progress and increase his physical discomfort throughout the ride.

There were several features of the setting that held an affect on the cyclist in this story. For one, the cyclist was riding in a hot desert, a landscape that was relentlessly dry and sun-scorched. This condition normally prevents one from obtaining water. Seeing as how water was a necessity for the cyclist, the lack there at due to the desert created the conflict of dehydration, a physical struggle that defined his journey. Additionally, the town that was abandoned, with its empty buildings and silent streets, triggered a spark of doubt in the cyclistís mind. The cyclist now had to ride with his brain in doubt and his body in desperate hope, a combination that wore him down further. By the time he/she reaches the old factory, the cyclist is extremely dehydrated. Now his head is screaming with annoyance and his body is screaming with lack of water, a dual torment that was almost unbearable. This abandoned juice factory, a place that should have offered salvation, almost completely wiped out the cyclist hope. A man is little to nothing without hope, and his was fading fast. Therefore, this abandoned factory had a negative affect on him, deepening his despair. Now, the only reason he continues is out of his/her desperation of survival, an instinct in all of us that pushes him forward against the odds. In conclusion, the desert removed water and the abandoned homes and factory removed hope and all three created a negative affect. The cyclist is lucky to have survived such a punishing ordeal.

The setting affected the cyclist profoundly, because he didnít know if he was going to die or live, a terrifying uncertainty that preyed on his mind. He had used up all his water because it was so hot and his mouth was dry, a parched feeling that made every breath a reminder of his peril. The oppressive heat and the seemingly endless landscape created a situation where his survival was constantly in question, leaving him to grapple with fear and physical distress as he pressed on.

In the short story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, he shows features of the setting played that affects the cyclist in many different ways. A setting the cyclist faces is that its so hot he keeps taking (drinking) water, and worrying that he is going to run out, a constant anxiety that shadows his every move. Kurmaskie writes, ì I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in @NUM1). This is what the cyclist gets affected by throuout the whole story as he releizes he could die of heatstroke if he dosent watch how much water hes drinking, a real and present danger in such an unforgiving climate. Also, this is what a lot of people normally face which is a challenge cause of dehydration, a common yet dangerous adversary for anyone traveling through a desert environment. The story effectively illustrates how the harsh setting creates a central conflict centered on the body's most basic needs.

With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place things change, and landscapes are not immune to this truth. No a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist exists than to be wary. Never travel advice home old-timers who haveníth confines of use porches, for their knowledge of the world may be as stationary as they are. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills, a change that tested the cyclist's endurance and altered the journey's rhythm. Rough Road ahead Do not exceed posted speed limit, a warning that applied not just to velocity but to the pace of one's expectations in a shifting terrain. The journey itself became a lesson in adapting to the unexpected changes of the path.

Many things about the setting in ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî affect the cyclist. The terrain in this story is hilly and filled with deserts, a challenging combination for any rider. This contributes to the cyclist nagging sensation for a drink of water, a thirst that grew with every arduous pedal stroke. The ride on the hills and through the desert, also tire him out dramatically, sapping his strength and his resolve. Not to mention while he is severely dehydrated, and when he finds the water it is ìtarlikeî and "in the neighborhood of two hundred degreesî, a cruel disappointment that deepened his plight. The cyclist in this story really must want to get Yosemite National park if he is willing to go all through all this trouble, a testament to his powerful determination. The old men he asked in Lodi, California hadnít left the town in decades and gave the cyclist faulty directions that could of killed him, their outdated knowledge proving to be a genuine hazard. So he asked for directions and was given inadequet information, which made life very difficult for the cyclist, adding a layer of navigational peril to his physical struggles. The entire journey was a testament to his endurance against a hostile and misleading environment.

The setting of “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” affects the cyclist in so many ways. First of all, the cyclist is riding in a desert, in mid-June, with the heat “beginning to beat down” on him. This feature of the setting causes the cyclist to drink more water, but when his supply of water was running low, he was unable to drink much water to hydrate himself. The cyclist began to realize that he “could trap from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” Furthermore, the long distance and the significant changes in the terrain that the cyclist was travelling over affected him. The distance on which the cyclist was travelling to Yosemite National Park consisted of hours and miles of riding over vast changes of terrain. The “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” which affected the cyclist's speed and drained his energy to finish his trip, making his journey a grueling test of endurance.

A response that explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist by giving him the wrong direction involves an old man he meets. One feature occurs when he travels through a ghost town. The old people in the town didn’t know the correct way and could not tell him. It made it harder for him because that wrong direction led to more difficult roads and less opportunity for water. He almost died as a direct result of this misleading information and the harsh conditions it led him into, highlighting the perilous nature of his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly because the roads are hilly and he is old, so it is hard for him to ride up them, draining his limited strength. It was very hot and he had a scarce supply of water, which intensified his physical struggle. He was seeing things that weren’t there, a sign of his growing dehydration and heat exhaustion. When he did try to get some water, the weather was so hot that the water from the pump came out hot, offering him no relief and deepening his desperate situation on the arduous trek.

Some features of the setting like the intense heat are affecting the cyclist; for example, he was riding through the high deserts of California and was drinking too much of his water too quickly. So when he stopped at a place, the pipes and things to get water were rusty and old, rendering them unusable. Another feature was when he thought he could make it to the next town to get water there. He started his ride and the roads were hilly and short, which was challenging. Then the road turned bumpy, too. So no matter what, he was having bad trouble anyway, with each element of the setting conspiring against his progress.

The character in this short story has a mood that changes with his surroundings. Towards the beginning when he was enjoying his ride he said, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name all over them,” showing his initial optimism and excitement. As time goes on and he begins to realize nobody inhabits the path he is on, he becomes concerned and the terrain becomes rougher. This shift in the environment directly correlates with his fading morale, illustrating how his spirit is worn down by the increasing isolation and physical difficulty of the route.

There are many ways the features of the setting affect the cyclist. For instance, the desert is not a humid environment, making its lack of available water a bigger deal than normal, as dehydration sets in rapidly. Also, there are many hills making him have to use his full force to get up them, a strenuous effort that also makes water a big deal for maintaining his strength. In conclusion, if the temperatures were more level and it was flat land, he could undoubtedly go further with a much less substantial water supply, as the physical demands would be significantly reduced.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by teaching him to never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left their porches since Carter was in office. This is a crucial lesson because you don’t know if they are a real collection of reliable guides or simply what they claim to be. This is especially important after considering that some people genuinely have not left their porches for a very long time, since Carter was in office, and thus their knowledge of current routes is outdated. Ultimately, I don’t know why people have not left their porches since that time, but it clearly makes their advice unreliable for a modern journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie he accepts directions from old men for a shortcut to Yosemite National Park. He ends up cycling in a desert with no water, just barely able to push the pedals of his bike. The setting affects the cyclist by it being so intensely hot, him not having anything to drink, having nowhere to get water or food, and him maybe even seeing mirages due to his condition. In the essay it states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke.” This shows that the lack of water and the surrounding harsh environment with nowhere to go is making him give up hope to survive. It also says in the essay, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited.” The cyclist is coming out himself and stating that the desert has him thinking he's seeing something and then letting him down by it not being real. The desert setting of this essay effects the cyclist in many significant ways, impacting him physically and mentally beyond just one single hardship.

In “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, I think that the setting affected the cyclist because he was desperately thirsty and he thought he was going to die. In this case, he had no water left and he was stranded in the vast desert. He was regretting not taking the advice of the stranger and was dying of thirst, a direct consequence of his surroundings. Also, he didn't have the mind set that he wanted to live, as the oppressive setting drained his will. That is how I think the setting affected him, by creating a life-threatening situation that broke his spirit.

The features of the setting have a big impact on the cyclist. One feature is the hot weather and the arid area he is in. He says he is in the “high deserts of California in June.” Being hot in this region means the cyclist is surrounded by deserts, causing more intense and direct heat. “I could drop from a heatstroke,” he says, showing his distress. Being hot from the sun beating down on him relentlessly took away the cyclist’s energy he needs for riding his bike. Another feature that affected the cyclist was his critical lack of water. He mentions “Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This affected the cyclist by making him profoundly tired and weak. Being tired from no water, the cyclist had immense trouble going up hills on his bike. The last feature that affected the cyclist was all of the hills in his road. He observes that “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” These hills made it hard to go up on a bike, especially considering his pre-existing lack of water, and the overwhelming heat. All of these features affect the cyclist by making him lose energy and get tired and frustrated because of their combined negative impact on his journey.

Nature has an affect on everyone, even when they don’t think it does, especially for cyclists traveling anywhere or everywhere. In “Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, there is a perfect example about how settings affect people like cyclists. When you’re riding your bike as actual cross country transportation, you have to know what you're doing and where you’re going. The cyclist in this story decided to take advice from older fellows and ends up going the wrong route, leading him to a place that was not really a town anymore, a place with no water available. If you don’t have any water, like this guy did, the challenging hills could kill you. In such a case, you have to know what to do; for example, he gathered a few pebbles and stuck them in his mouth, having read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst. This guy knew a little bit of survival tips, which was crucial. If he’d gone all that way without a way to manage his thirst and the strain of those hills, he probably would have had some kind of physical crisis, such as a heat stroke. That is just one of the ways that a harsh setting could harm a traveler.

Some of the feature setting that effect the cyclist was the seal on the road was beginning to lend down, but he truly noticed it only after about twenty miles up the road when he came to a park of sorts. The cyclist was riding through the high deserts of California in June, a time of intense heat. He got on his hands and knees, working on the heated handle of a rusty pump he found there. After some effort, the pump began to shoot out a tar-like substance, and when the water finally came, it was scalding, feeling somewhere near two hundred degrees. Continuing on for two more miles, he noticed the terrain changing from a flat road to a series of short, rolling hills. He said tumbleweeds crossed his path and a large snake crossed the pavement ahead of him. To combat his growing thirst, he gathered some pebbles and stuck them in his mouth, recalling that sucking on stones helps to take your mind off thirst. After reading of his ordeal, it is clear these settings did profoundly effect the cyclist and his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. First, the “town” the cyclist first comes upon is described as a ghost town, a place devoid of the resources he needed. Although the cyclist chuckles about it, this setting sets up the long and arduous journey the cyclist has ahead of him. There were other features that would negatively affect the cyclist as he pressed on. For example, he noticed the terrain changing, as flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. Flat land is much easier for a cyclist to pedal on, so this shift in geography significantly affected his stamina and will to keep going. He really had to push himself, using immense effort to trudge up and down each challenging hill. His determination finally led him to a place called “Gary and Wilber’s Fish camp,” where he finally found hope and a chance for respite after his difficult trek.

In the story “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features had a more negative affect on the cyclist. The cyclist grew increasingly tired because of the big hills he encountered, and the scenic view was the only good thing that he had going on. His situation was dire, as his water bottle only contained a few tantalizing sips, leaving him without enough water and plagued by thirst. Furthermore, the environment presented physical dangers; at some point, a ridiculously large snake, one that really did look like a diamondback, blocked the majority of the pavement ahead of him. It is a dangerous place where he was riding, and even though he was on a bike, he could have been bitten by the venomous creature. All of these points I made clearly showed the negative affect the setting had on his journey and well-being.

The desert-like land affected the cyclist by making him tired and causing a loss of body water through the intense heat, which therefore made him desperately need water to go on. I think the psychological thought of being so thirsty, constantly on his mind, made him become even more weak and fatigued. If he wasn’t thinking about his thirst and dehydration so intensely, the mental burden would have been lighter and the ride wouldn't have been so rough, demonstrating how the environment impacts both body and spirit.

In the cyclist’s outlook on his journey through Yosemite’s park, readers can get a good feel of how it might be to be riding right along side. It seems that it is very beautiful along the bike ride, offering a vivid and immersive experience. He sees such a vast variety of scenery including rushing rivers and expansive, sandy dry deserts, as well as the cool shade of pines and trees in the park part. He said it was also breezy which probably made for an enjoyable temperature, enhancing the overall pleasantness of his ride through the diverse landscape.

The features of the bike ride to Yosemite through California in June affect the cyclist profoundly. Some of the features were it was hot high deserts, and no water, creating a harsh and unforgiving environment. This affected the author by making him dehydrated and tired, which made it hard for him to find water or to get to Yosemite, significantly slowing his progress. In this case the author says “The sun was beating down on me,” conveying the intense, relentless heat. The author is hot from the sun, and his suffering is compounded by thirst. He says “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips,” highlighting his desperate situation. He is showing how he has no water and is probably dehydrated, with his physical state deteriorating. All of those features are affecting the way he is traveling and getting to water, presenting a serious challenge to his journey.

In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” there are many features of the setting that greatly affect the cyclist. Many of these features affect him in a negative way, testing his endurance. One such feature is the hills that are present in the essay, adding a physical challenge to his trek. These probably exasperated the cyclist even more than he already was with the sun beating down on him, draining his remaining energy. Another feature was the road sign that said “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” “The speed limit was @NUM1. I was doing a water-depleting @NUM2. Sometimes life can feel so cruel.” The author/cyclist probably felt like he would never make it, his spirits crushed by the slow pace. Also, the sign advertising grape juice probably made him feel life was even crueler with its sadistic irony, mocking his thirst. Finally, the bait shop offered much relief to the cyclist, a welcome respite. “I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait,” showing his profound gratitude for this small sign of civilization. All in all, the setting affected the cyclist in some pretty bad ways until the end, making his journey a true test of will.

Many features of the setting affected the cyclist significantly throughout his arduous journey. First, the heat was the main part of nature that threw him off, its intensity overwhelming. It caused him to go dehydrated because of a lack of water and he went kind of delirious, his mind beginning to play tricks on him. He thought he was seeing things and his vision was distorted, a clear sign of his physical distress. Next, the water he had to come across in the pump was undrinkable because of the tar-like substance coming out of it and the degree of water he said it was, which was @NUM1 degree, rendering it a useless, foul liquid. Lastly, the Welch’s factory that he came across was teasing him in the way that he couldn’t have the liquids he needed, and the little boy advertised on the building was drinking his refreshed Welch’s juice, a cruel reminder of his own deprivation.
