In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie the setting profoundly affected the cyclist. It was a hot June day and the water supplies he had was running out, creating a sense of urgency and danger. He got the wrong directions from some old men so he would have to ride his bike longer than he had to, and he would need more water from pedaling all that way for nothing, a frustrating and exhausting detour. Since he was going in the wrong direction there were no buildings for him to get water from, there were no people around so he couldn’t communicate for assistance, and there would be no one to call for help incase he was over heated from the oppressive heat. In the story, the rider faced several melancholy sites that tested his resolve. With the sun beating on his back and the emptiness of the road he might have begin to want to turn back, feeling the weight of his situation. He kept on persaveering which was how he made it down, showing his determination. The lack of water also mad it difficult for him, intensifying his struggle. Traveling with his water running out and beginning to feel sick did not go well with him, marking the journey as a true test of endurance against the elements.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a negative way.
