This affects him because he cant get water from the well, which means he desperately needs water but cannot get any. Also in the essay it says the terrain is bad, with rough roads and hills, so that means that the cyclist has to pedal harder to keep moving and he has to work harder in the hot reek. So all this puts a negative affect on him from just whats around him. The old abbandon factory with the boy drinking juice was had the most effect on the cyclist because he was so thirsty and that was when he was about to give up, highlighting his desperation. In this essay the setting had alot of affect on the cyclist to were he thought he might die from the harsh conditions.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. The speaker tells us that he’s riding his bike in the middle of the desert in June, under a scorching sun. This shows the author is probably very hot and suffering from the extreme temperature. The author tells us that the road turned into hills and bumps, becoming difficult to navigate. This would make it more difficult for the author because he would have to use more energy to move up the hill, increasing his exhaustion. And lastly, the cyclist tells us that the “towns” he came to were abandoned and uncared for, with no signs of life. This would not be good for the cyclist because he would not be able to get water or supplies for his trip, leaving him without aid.

The cyclist is affected in many ways by his environment. The major thing that effects him is the lack of water, which becomes a constant source of anxiety. Throughout the story he mentions the lack of water and his growing thirst. He also continues to say to himself he should not have took that route, regretting his decision to follow bad advice. For example, he thinks, “I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in june because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off thire porch in decades, caused me to laugh.” The cyclist says things about the older gentle man throughout the story, blaming him for the dire situation he finds himself in on the unforgiving road.

Setting very much affects the cyclist and now he feels, demonstrating a clear connection between his environment and his mental state. If he was in a bad setting then he would most likely be in a bad mood, feeling frustrated and defeated. Mood is highly affected by the general setting, which can either uplift or depress a person. In the essay “rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” the cyclist feels very confiedent of himself at the beginning, and the initially promising setting helps to boost that confiedence and andorence for the journey ahead, before the conditions worsen.

The features in the setting of the essay affected the author greatly during his arduous journey. The Hills, on a hot day, with no water, or nearby town is really rough, expecially if you’ve been riding for more than fifty miles under the relentless sun. The environment of the hot June weather near a dessert area can cause serious problems, for example heat stroke and since he had no water to drink dehydration caused a lot of fear and physical distress in the author. The setting of the essay and the conditions the author were under were extreamly dangerous and hes lucky he made it out alive from such a perilous situation.

That the cyclist is steadily climbing up a totally steep incline within the desert when he begins to consider how and when to get to his destination. The town he had settled on reaching out of necessity seemed to have been taken away, its meaning lost just yesterday. The condition of the road is rough on his hands and he feels a hurry some of the time, a pressing need to move forward when he has nothing left in his body. The physical toll of the journey is immense, and the unforgiving landscape offers no respite, pushing him to his absolute limits as he continues his arduous trek toward a distant and uncertain goal.

In the short story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting greatly affects the cyclist. For example, in the beginning of the story, the cyclist is eager to get to Yosemite National Park. He listens to the advice of old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office, and quickly realized that he shouldn’t have. The author describes the setting of the first “town” as the traditional definition of a ghost town. This didn’t bother the cyclist as much as his next sight. “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the largest mule” was what met him there. The cyclist said that this sight was troubling. The profound desolation of the place saps his spirit, leading him to a point of utter hopelessness. It is obvious that the cyclist has given up hope when he says, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This short story shows how a harsh and unforgiving environment can get even the best of travellers worried about their survival.

I think the features of the settings affect the cyclist because the knowledge of the cyclist is limited. For example, the “old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office” provide advice that is outdated and no longer applicable to the current, harsh realities of the road. This means that now it is time for the older people to relax and watch the younger people, but their well-intentioned guidance ultimately leads the cyclist astray, leaving him unprepared for the severe challenges he subsequently faces on his journey through the desolate landscape.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because where he is riding it is very dry and hot. He can deal with the heat with his good water supply, but when it runs out he begins to get disoriented. For example, in the text he writes “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage.” That statement shows that the cyclist was hot, and the images around him were making him feel more hot than what he is, and his lack of water made him almost believe that he was imagining seeing a building. Another example is “A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hang my head.” This quote shows that the cyclist is in complete despair as he looks at the photo and hangs his head, a poignant symbol of his own deprivation. This shows that the cyclist was constantly being reminded how hot and thirsty he was everywhere he would go and he couldn't get a drink. This is how the features of the setting affected the cyclist.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affected the cyclist in the story. “Not two miles into this next reaction of ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie). The cyclist is travelling through hot, dry California in the middle of June without much water left. The fact that he now has to travel up and down short hills is going to make him even more tired, because going over hills requires more energy than flat riding. This energy loss, coupled with the cyclist's lack of water, causes him to become even more miserable and physically drained. The challenging geography directly intensifies his physical suffering and mental fatigue. The setting of this story greatly affected the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist's mood and behavior. First, the cyclist sees a potential shortcut and begins believing it will help him arrive to Yosemite faster, but he soon realizes it will not. Next, the harsh sun and the rough terrain, combined with a critical lack of water, causes the cyclist to give up hope that he will make it to Yosemite. This difficult experience causes him to rethink his initial judgement and the importance of taking advice from others, ultimately teaching him a valuable lesson about preparation.

The setting affected the cyclist in a harsh way. At first, the cyclist was fine and going strong, but soon after passing the first "ghost town" he was getting weak and his energy began to fade. Then the cyclist had to face a series of difficult problems. For example, he was running dangerously low on water, which heightened his anxiety. Also, he faced rough roads that jarred his body, and last, he faced the threat of snakes and a profound sense of abandonment. The cyclist had to face many obstacles that tested his spirit, but in the end, he pulled through strong, demonstrating his resilience.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist for these reasons. It says, “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me. The sight was troubling.” That shows how the features affected the cyclist because he explicitly states the sight was troubling. It troubled him deeply because he desperately wanted water and he saw the rusty pumps that reminded him of water, but he knew there was no water to be had or that it was likely nasty. This encounter intensified his feeling of desolation and thirst.

The conditions of the environment as well as the road can majorly effect the cyclist. For example, if someone was riding a bike in warm weather on flat land it would not take major determination to pedal and the journey would be relatively easy. On the other hand, if it is extremely hot with rough paths and hilly roads, the biker could dehydrate quickly and it takes much more physical effort to get up and over the hill. Those factors demonstrate how the conditions of the environment effect a cyclist greatly, determining the level of challenge and endurance required.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist, on his way to Yosemite National Park, is forced to face the rough deserts of California. As is normal throughout all deserts, the sun is blazing hot, as is the sand under his wheels. There is no water anywhere and dangerous, highly venomous creatures are abundant, adding to the peril. The lack of water almost puts him into a heat stroke as he is determined to leave the desert, riding his bike all alone with no one to help. A grape juice factory taunts him, mocks him with its unattainable promise of refreshment, but he continues on, with a steady pace despite the hardship. The desert roads are rocky and bumpy and his lousy 12 mph speed is getting him practically nowhere in the vast landscape. Until, finally, he reaches a modern area and drinks from the sink in the bathroom, finding the relief he so desperately needed.

In the story the setting plays a big role in effecting the cyclist. The terrain was very hard at times such a big hills and windy turns. The sheer physical exertion required to navigate this landscape was immense. Also, there was no one around, no houses, buildings or people which made him feel alone and like he was going to die. This profound isolation amplified his distress. The author describes the terrain in one part of the story, “Over one long, crippling hill a building came into view!” This quote shows how the hills in the setting were very big and hard to get over. It also shows the significance of a single building and how excited and relieved he was to see it, a stark contrast to the emptiness. In the story the author described many features from the setting which all greatly effected the cyclist, shaping his difficult journey through a challenging and lonely environment.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist, by putting him in unwanted places starting off with this man took advice from many older men, which don’t even know the area anymore. So riding through this, the man seems lost; he is trying to follow their advice, but comes across many unknown, unwanted areas. He starts out good, then comes to a “Rough Road” and he even says “sometimes life can feel so cruel,” highlighting his growing frustration. Then he comes to this large snake in the middle of the road scary enough he has to slow ride past this thing taking up most of the road, a direct and frightening obstacle. Coming over these things was very strong and hard on this young man, testing his resolve and physical endurance throughout his arduous trip.

The desert environment had huge effects on the cyclist. He had been drinking his water regularly and would be running out. Not realizing there would be no refills because the pump was only giving a “tar-like substance” said the text. With the lack of water, dehydration was beginning to hit the poor man, causing him significant physical strain. An effect of dehydration is poor balance that would have been useful to pass the “ridiculously large snake” he had seen, making an already dangerous encounter even more perilous. A final effect would be mirages that could loose your judgement. This man double checked his eyes, when coming in view of a building, by “[wiping] the sweat from (his) eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage,” showing his desperate hope. Through all the toughest desert obstacles the character was able to take the short cut and survive the heat, dehydration, and animals of the desert, completing his challenging journey.

I think the features in the setting of the story "Do not exceed the speed limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, highly affect the cyclist. Some implied information would be that it is very hot out, and the people in towns didn't help him. I know that it is hot because the text says, "somewhere in the neighbourhood of @NUM1 degrees." This implies that it is very hot outside, creating a harsh riding condition. I can tell the people in towns didn't help him because the text says, "Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." This shows that the people in towns didn't help him, leading him astray. Some expressed information in this text would be that there is a rough road, and a snake was in his way. I know this is expressed because it tells you right in the text. "Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit." This comes right out and tells you there is a rough road, directly impacting his ride. You know there is a snake because the text says, "a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the road," presenting a clear physical danger. I think there are many implied and expressed details in the story "Do not exceed the speed limit" that show how the setting challenged the cyclist.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in a larger way, almost resulting in a very severe situation. The cyclist was in a desert-like terrain, which was not densely populated on his trail; there was a lack of fresh water supplies, and the temperatures were more extreme. The cyclist could easily have fainted from heatstroke, due to the lack of water and excessive heat and work that he was doing pedaling, pushing his body to its limits. Had the area been more populated, he would have had more chances to stock up on water, greatly decreasing his risk of heat stroke. There was also the snakes which presented danger for him; had he been bitten then he would be at least @NUM1 miles from the closest help which could have proven fatal, isolating him in a crisis. Had the setting been, say, a city park or a populated countryside, then this setting would have provided exponentially fewer problems and dangers for the cyclist, underscoring how the harsh environment itself was the greatest antagonist.

The conditions and features of the setting caused the cyclist to be tired and dehydrated and think that he was going to die from it. For example, it says “and ther growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a georgus day in June,” which highlights the cruel irony of suffering on a beautiful day. Also, he thinks he is getting dehydrated when he says “I was doing a water depleting 12 mph. sometimes life could be so creul,” indicating his awareness of his dwindling water supply at a steady, draining pace. The physical exertion combined with the intense heat created a perilous situation. In conclusion, this cyclist started this journey without enough water and under a harsh sun, causing him to think that he was going to die from either heatstroke or dehydration.

The setting affects the cyclist because he’s in the middle of nowhere with no water. The cyclist had to ride his bike for over @NUM1 miles trying to get to Yosemite. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly.” This quote shows that he was just beginning to run out of water, having consumed his supply steadily. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” This quote shows how he really had nothing to drink at all, with the last drops being insufficient. Having no water in the high deserts of California while riding your bike for over @NUM1 miles is not a good @CAPS1 unless you have a car, as the remote and arid environment offers no relief.

In the essay the setting had every thing to do with the cyclist cause he is ridding through the desert with batey tay water. He is pedaling through the dry heat thats tough even you had water, and the journey is made more difficult by the physical terrain. Pluse there were hills and the threat of deadly snakes, adding to the inherent dangers of the landscape. Its dangerous enough with out that stuff being there, making the cyclist's ordeal a serious struggle for survival. So I would listen to the cyclist & never ever listen to old men, as their advice can lead one into such perilous situations.

On the cyclists rideto Yosemite National Park he encouters a lot of hardships due to the setting hes around and the advice given by oldmen. The cyclist riding his bike in the middle of June in the deserts of california isnt good to begin with, and this adds to the cyclist dehydration state. He first come to encouters "one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn`t hold in the lament mule." By that description oF his lecatracy it seems as if he might be in ghost town by himself, a place that could almost strand him without aid. He described the terrain with “short, rolling hils” and “over one long, crippling hill.” This shows some of the obstacle that he had to go through on a bike, just to get to Yosemite National Park. He @CAPS1 realized once he encounterd these Features oF the terrain that he was oFF track and needed to find help, as the landscape itself misdirected him. After his survival of his surroundings For as long as he could go, @CAPS1 gets help at a real camp, finally finding safety. That is how the settings of the story play role in the cyclist epidemic, directly shaping his difficult experience.

“Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is an inspiring and almost humorous essay it take the reader inside a journey in a cyxlist daily routine. In this story the author fights dehydration as he tries to make to a national park with shortcut directions from “old timers,” and the setting of this story greatly affects the cyclist and the pitty the reader feels for him. Half way through the essay, the biker had already traveled roughly @NUM1 miles; that’s extremely crazy for a single ride. The fact that he is travelling through California deserts in June is even harder to believe, given the extreme temperatures. The first time he mentions the setting, he states he is in a ghost town, two sentences after he states that the sun was beating down, yet at that point he wasn’t really bothered. Another description of his setting that probably affected his ability to peddle was when he states “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” He was already dehydrated and had already traveled so far, so the rocky roads probably didn’t help his journey much, adding physical strain. The setting basically made the story, providing the central conflict. If he wouldn’t have been peddling in the desert, it would have just been another trip in his life, but the setting makes the reader see what cyclist really go through in such harsh conditions.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist a great deal. It does so because the road is not in good condition, with potholes and uneven surfaces, and he has to travel a long distance while also contending with bad weather. This combination of factors affects him because he might get dehydrated from the physical exertion and exposure. The difficult terrain and harsh climate create a challenging journey. In conclusion, there are many things in the setting that affected the cyclist throughout his arduous trip.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly because if there weren’t steep hills and rough roads, he would have been able to get to Yosemite Park faster and with less effort. The challenging landscape slowed his progress considerably. Consequently, he wouldn’t have run out of water so early in his journey. The difficult terrain directly contributed to his shortage of supplies. Therefore, the physical characteristics of the environment played a crucial role in his predicament.

The setting was the main effect on the cyclist. He explicitly said it was extremely hot and that he was completely lost. The cyclist had no clue where he was going and it was hot outside, which compounded his problems. He seemed very stressed and the disorientation only made it worse for him. He was thirsty from all the riding and the intense heat, so he tries to get water from a roadside water pump. The water that was in it was horrible; he called it a “substance” that had a flavor of battery acid. If he were not lost and if it were cool outside he would have water and he would not be so upset. Ultimately, the setting of a hot and unfamiliar place had a huge impact on the cyclist and his state of mind.

In my opinion the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, when he was talking about the terrain changing from long straight roads to sharp windy ones and the speed limit changing, he said he was doing a water-depleting fury and sounds like he is having a hard time. The difficult landscape saps his energy and morale. It seems he doesn't want to go on under these strenuous conditions. The alteration in the road's character presents a significant physical challenge. Thus, the environmental features directly influence his cycling experience and his willingness to continue.

Due to the features in the setting, including the hot summer weather, the cyclist not knowing the area, and the California desert, the cyclist is profoundly affected. In the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist is travelling through the hot desert in June when he realizes he's running out of water, stating, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie). This is affecting the cyclist because he's becoming overheated and has a dangerously low supply of water. Also, the cyclist realizes he should have never taken the direction from the old men and thinks to himself, “The growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June” (Kurmaskie). This quote proves that the intense heat of the desert is taking a severe toll on him, both physically and mentally. The harsh environmental conditions are the primary source of his escalating crisis.

The setting of this story affects the cyclist a great deal. I think the setting was supposed to be most like a run-down, out-of-date town which didn't help him when he was lost. The town is out of date and oppressively hot, which brings another problem: the cyclist was dehydrating because he didn't have enough water. He would begin to hallucinate and see things that weren't there, a direct result of his worsening physical state. He became very tired in the hot sun, his energy sapped by the relentless heat. So the setting in this short story affected the cyclist in many ways, proving to be a significant antagonist in his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly because of the condition he is in without any water. The cyclist would likely be fine if he would have had more water for his trip. He ran out of water not too far into his journey, a problem exacerbated by the intense heat of the setting he was in. The cyclist makes this statement: "I was hitting my water bottle pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high desert of California in June." The cyclist is saying that since it is so hot where he is, he has to take regular drinks of water to stay hydrated throughout his trip. It is also implied that in the mountains, with less air and the extreme heat, he is not doing as well as he thought he would, his body struggling against the dual challenges of altitude and temperature.

The cyclist had a hard trail to bike in order to get to his destination. It is easy to bike if you are on flat, smooth terrain, but when you get to rolling hills, it makes it a lot tougher. The biker said, "I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. It was also very hot." He was sweating and getting dehydrated, leading him to recall, "I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst." He had eighteen miles to the next town without much water, a daunting prospect. The first deserted town didn't have any drinkable water, dashing his hopes for a quick resupply. It was very hard to bike in these conditions, and this experience highlights the importance of always being prepared and knowing where you are going.

The cyclist has to endure rough terrain and bad road conditions, and a lack of water in the area near him did not help the problem. There was a good possibility he could have suffered heatstroke, a real danger given his circumstances. Then his hope was still lifted by the sight of an abandoned Welch's take factory, a brief respite in his arduous journey. This momentary discovery provided a flicker of optimism, though it ultimately underscored the desolation of his surroundings and the severity of his physical ordeal.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the imagery is what sets the cyclist back. The scorching desert and sparse plant life gives him a sense of seclusion and scares him. Because the cyclist is in the desert he keeps on worrying about his water supply and heatstroke, whereas if he were in a rain forest he wouldn't worry about water or heat. I think he psyched himself out just by taking in his surroundings. If the cyclist would have pictured water all around him and arctic-like temperatures I think he wouldn't have been so worried. What’s interesting about this story is that if he would have gotten himself prepared mentally for the conditions he wouldn't have struggled so much at the end. “At some point tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake- it really did look like a diamond back blocking the majority the pavement in front of me.” (Kurmaskie). If the cyclist would have concentrated more on the task at hand and less on what was going on around him, I think he would have succeeded without as much stress, his mind proving to be as challenging an obstacle as the landscape itself.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in that the harsh, arid environment made him use up his water supply and tested his determination to its very limit. His thought, “Sometimes life can be so cruel,” strongly implies that he was having a horrible time coping with the oppressive setting he was in, a place that offered no relief. To himself he thought he was gonna die at any moment, a belief fueled by the relentless sun and the seemingly endless, barren landscape that stretched out before him. This profound sense of despair, directly caused by his surroundings, nearly overwhelmed his will to continue, showcasing the powerful influence of the setting on his mental state.

In the essay “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit,” the author is continually depressed by the bleak and discouraging features of the landscape he passes. At first he passes a ghost town, but because he has enough water at that point, this sight doesn’t bother him significantly. But the next thing he sees is a rundown old shed and a “rusted water pump,” and this troubles him deeply because he is acutely aware that he is running out of water. Then he sees a huge snake which does not help his mood at all, because the snake is intimidating and blocking his path. Then he passes an abandoned Welch’s Grape Juice factory and despairs that he will never find water, seeing it as a cruel irony. The setting and its features consistently serve to disappoint and depress the cyclist in his increasingly desperate quest to find water, each new sight deepening his hopelessness.

In the story “Rough Road ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” a cyclist is faced with many problems that test his endurance. It’s really hot out, practically a desert, and it’s in June, which means the heat is at its most intense. Just knowing that makes me want some water, highlighting the cyclist's own pressing need. Also this cyclist is running short of water and still hasn’t got to the place he needs to be, creating a race against time. The roads are hills and bumpy, which make it harder for him, sapping his already diminished energy. Those are the significant problems this cyclist is faced with, each one compounding the other to create a truly challenging journey through an unforgiving environment.

At first the narrator in “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” was energetic and enthusiastic about their journey to Yosemite National Park. After getting some helpful advice about a few short cuts, the cyclist sets out for an adventure with high hopes. First thing they encounter is a ghost town. The gentlemen they had taken advice from had assured them it was a booming, prosperous town, so this discovery set the first wave of doubt through the cyclist's mind. Then the lack of water began to be a serious issue. They were travelling through the high deserts of California in June and were slowly running out of water, which increased their anxiety. Flat road was soon replaced by short, rolling hills which only increased the cyclist's state of deliriousness and physical exhaustion. After a few more disappointments, such as the non-functional water pump, the cyclist decides there is no hope and they are going to die. The reader is partly drawn in, believing that this is the end for the cyclist, so invested in the narrative. All of the disappointments set the stage for the end of the cyclist and you can’t stop reading because you have to find out what happens, proving that if it weren’t for the pervasive hopelessness of the setting you wouldn’t care as deeply about the outcome.

When the cyclist is going on his trip, he is riding through a vast and empty desert. All he sees the entire journey is a flat road and dirt, a monotonous and draining vista. He is riding on the road, hopelessly hoping for some form of life or respite. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” a description that emphasizes his profound isolation. The author is trying to be positive but it’s hard, because all this scenery is doing is bringing his hopes down with its unrelenting barrenness. How would you like it if you were riding a bike and had no water in the middle of a desert, a truly terrifying predicament. Now, if the setting had been a nice, green forest, he wouldn’t be that worried, as there would be water and shade readily available. He has none of that in the desert, only exposure and scarcity. This whole journey was all mental, a test of his spirit. He always kept in his mind that everything would be ok, a mantra that provided a sliver of comfort. That is what helped him survive the ordeal, his unwavering mental fortitude. This is an inspiring story, to anyone who needs a push to stay optimistic even when circumstances seem dire.

Poor directions, intense heat, and a critical lack of water profoundly affect the cyclist in the story. At the beginning, the cyclist is supremely confident in the directions which promised to, “slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park.” As the story progresses, however, the cyclist is no longer so confident, his assurance eroded by the harsh environment. The oppressive “heat of the California, June day causes him to be fluent in drinking water.” He notes, “I had been hitting my water bottle pretty regularly, and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” This escalating lack of water becomes a monumental problem, so severe that he was near heat stroke. “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” He braved the elements and forced himself on, with hopes that any source of water would reveal itself to him. His perseverance ultimately paid off. “Then , as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.” The cyclist had found a barst shop and recteved water, a discovery that marked the end of his ordeal and the restoration of his hope.

The distinct features of the setting directly affect the cyclist throughout his journey. I say this because the setting is in the hot, arid deserts of California. Under the relentless sun, the cyclist becomes sweaty and tired, his energy sapped, and he finds himself with almost no water left in his bottles. This severe lack of water, combined with the exhausting heat, makes the cyclist desperate for any source of sustenance, for food and water to keep him going. The setting, with its unforgiving climate and isolated landscape, has a lot to do with how the cyclist reacts to what happens, dictating his desperation and his ultimate drive to survive the challenging conditions.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, compounding his difficulties at every turn. First, because there was no one in sight across the vast, empty landscape, he couldn’t ask for any help or direction, leaving him entirely alone in his struggle. Also, because of all the poor road conditions it was hard to ride a bike through all the rocky, uneven roads; he was already very tired and dehydrated so that didn’t help him and it just tired him more, draining his remaining strength. Another reason is because of the threat of poisonous snakes; if he disturbed them they could harm him, adding a layer of constant danger. Also, if he had fallen off his bike on the rough terrain, a snake could have biten him and then he wouldn’t be able to make it anywhere because of the venomous bite. Those are the key features of the setting that significantly affected the cyclist and his perilous journey.

The features of the setting in the story affect the cyclist both physically and mentally, creating a dual burden. It affects him physically because of the relentless rolling hills he has to trudge over and the critical lack of water he has. The rolling hills make him tired and weak, along with the challenge of the rough terrain that jars his body with every turn. The lack of water doesn’t help any when he’s thirsty and exhausted because of the hills, deepening his physical distress. The features affect him mentally because the farther he goes the more delirious he gets from heat and exhaustion. Each more mile he keeps telling himself, if I can just get there I’ll be fine, clinging to a fragile hope. He also blames himself for listening to the old men who gave him the faulty directions. And with this also came profound doubt. He was doubting that he could make it alive. In the story it says, “it didn’t really matter: I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean," a thought showing how mentally he couldn’t make it, his spirit nearly broken by the oppressive setting.

When the rider was riding his bike in such harsh day settings, he started to desperately need water as he was running out, so his whole adventure narrowed to the singular goal of finding water. Being thirsty was very hard because it made him not want to keep going, as he was so tired and his body was weakening. It made the journey harder on him, testing his physical limits. But it also, in a way, got him more strength and belief in himself, forcing him to dig deep and keep on pushing through the adversity. This internal resolve became his key asset, allowing him to persevere until he found the relief he so urgently needed.

“Do not Exceed the posted speed limit” tells a story of learning and determination, as one cyclist bikes through the deserts of California, encountering obstacles such as snakes and a lack of water along the way. The descriptive features of the setting greatly affect the protagonist along his journey. The essay takes place in the early summer. As the cyclist prepares to retire for the day, he takes particular note of “the serenity of an early summer evening,” and ends the day feeling calm and at peace. The next morning he is excited and rejuvenated, ready to bike again with fresh energy. The heat rises as the day goes on, and by mid-day the cyclist begins to worry seriously about his dwindling water supply. He boldly continues forth reaching new terrain, the challenging rolling hills. Here he begins to lose hope, and is deeply disappointed when he sees the “town” he hoped to find is merely an abandoned juice factory. The cyclist thinks he is going to die due to the oppressive heat and lack of hydration, but gathers his last reserves of strength to turn the final bend, and reaches a bait shop where he can stop and get water, where he is finally relieved. In conclusion, as the cyclist continues his journey through the California desert, the change in both weather and terrain coincide and affect the cyclist’s change in physical and mental strength to continue traveling.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the story states, "I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth." This quote explains that the setting was very dry and had pebbles scattered about. The setting ended up benefiting him by taking the thirst off his mind for a short while. If there weren't any pebbles near the cyclist he would not have made it through that difficult stretch. The pebbles helped him produce saliva, which provided a temporary relief from his desperate thirst. In conclusion, in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclist was ultimately benefited by the features of the setting.

The features of the setting affect any cyclist over a long period because if a cyclist passed much time on the bicycle, they could develop problems with their back later in life. When they become an older person and they have passed many years on the bicycle, they will likely have serious physical problems and also they will not be able to walk very well anymore. The constant strain and posture required for cycling can lead to chronic pain and mobility issues. This shows how the physical demands of the setting and activity can have lasting consequences. In conclusion, the physical features of cycling can negatively impact a person’s health in their later years.

The setting in the essay “Rough Road ahead; Do not Exceed the speed limit” affected the narrator in many ways. The first thing that affected his ride was the intense heat. At first he didn't really notice it much but then it began to slow him down significantly. Then the nature of the roads began to affect his ride, as the roads went from flat sheet to short, rolling hills which were more difficult to pedal across. The road change and the accumulating heat made him say “I could drop from heatstroke,” showing his growing desperation. Then because of the old towns he went through he was unable to get any drinkable water. The water pumps were so old and unused for so long that the water was of very poor quality and not safe to drink. These environmental challenges tested his endurance throughout the journey.

The complex features of the setting affect the cyclist negatively throughout this story. His trip goes from bad to worse as he progresses toward Yosemite. After taking directions from the “old codgers,” the author attempts the shortcut, but is quickly disappointed. He arrives at the first town but it is completely deserted and offers no respite. He rubbed it off though, and kept “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,” as his primary motivation to continue. He pedaled on, but began to run out of water; when he arrived at a well, he found the water to be inedible, and continued his journey parched. Just as if things couldn’t get any worse his trail was getting rougher, and his water supply was critically low. The cyclist was becoming dehydrated, and began to lose hope of finishing. He became even more of a pessimist when “a ridiculously large snake… blocked the majority of the pavement…” creating a dangerous obstacle. He kept going, and excitedly pedaled toward a building, but found it to be abandoned and useless. He even put rocks in his mouth to help his dehydration by stimulating saliva. When he finally found the fish camp, he was profoundly relieved. All the obstacles he prospered through were worth it in the end, as he achieved his goal.

The journey of a solo cyclist is a lonely one. The cyclist in “Do not exceed posted speed limit” had a particularly hard journey, as made even worse by the setting. His main opponent in the battle of staying alive was the heat, a relentless force in the California deserts on a day in June. It was no surprise that the sun would be beating down particularly harder than it would at another place anytime, baking the asphalt. Also, as the terrain became hillier, his journey became even harder. There is nothing hard about biking in a flat straight line, but constantly pedaling yourself up steep hills and around winding roads is no picnic. Just like the buildings around him, the cyclist’s water supply deteriorated as did his state of mind, as his trip which started out very joyful became increasingly more morbid. “It didn’t really matter, I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This cyclist was fighting against strong forces of nature, a battle where the environment itself was his greatest adversary.

In the short story, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting plays an extremely important role. The story takes place in sunny California, where the cyclist was pedaling around 12 mph through a vast, arid landscape. The intense, dry heat made his dehydration situation much worse, sapping his strength with every rotation of the wheels. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” The cyclist was losing hope, yet he was still determined to find water, pushing forward against the oppressive conditions. This setting was very important to the story, for if it had taken place in a cooler, shaded location, it would not have made sense for the central conflict. The setting contributes to the story by raising the intensity of the situation, creating a palpable sense of danger and urgency that defines the cyclist's ordeal.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they started to mess with her mind. She didn’t know where she was and on top of that got lost, her sense of direction failing her. Whether you see nothing around you or a lot around you, you’re going to feel scared; isolation and overwhelming stimuli can have the same alarming effect. In the author's case, she was cycling and didn’t have any water, a terrifying reality. This is an overwhelming feeling because you can die from dehydration, a fact that preys on your thoughts. She then kept cycling and saw nothing. “no one in sight; not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” That is alarming—no water or people around, as if you are going to be just left to die. These settings would affect anyone who came across them. They definitely affected the cyclist because she was by herself, and on her own. Plus, all she had was a map, her bike and an empty water bottle, tools that felt useless in the face of such emptiness.

The features of this story tend to affect the cyclist very much, shaping his entire unfortunate experience. Because he took a shortcut, he ended up with an even longer and more arduous journey than before. He was in the middle of nowhere with barely any water left, and on top of all that he’s exhausted from all the hills on the terrain, his muscles burning with the effort. So because he took a shortcut it ended up costing him in the long run, turning a simple ride into a desperate struggle for survival against the elements and his own poor judgment.

The features of the setting in the essay affected the cyclist because first of all he listened to old folks that haven’t left their front porch in about ten years, relying on their outdated advice. Then he didn’t ask someone else’s opinion on where to go and how to get there, failing to seek a second perspective. His worst mistake though was not trusting the map he had with him the whole time, a reliable guide he foolishly ignored. If he would have just trusted his map and not went with what the old fella said, he wouldn’t have almost died of heat stroke, a direct consequence of his misplaced trust in the unfamiliar setting.

In the essay, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects him negatively because he was on his bicycle and he was in a hot area and no water whatsoever, like in this quote, “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar like substance oozed out.” In the quote, the cyclist finally thinks he has found a water pump but he really gets nothing, a moment of profound disappointment that deepens his distress. Also, another negative thing is that he thought he was never going to get to where he was going, but in the end, he got there and he got some water, a resolution that came only after enduring the harsh and unforgiving landscape.

The setting in the story affects the main character greatly because of the heat. The main character is biking through a desert in the summer with little water, a journey that becomes increasingly perilous. The heat of the setting provides a problem because the main character is at risk of dehydration and heatstroke. The main character knows that if he passes out in the barren desert he will surely die, a fear that haunts his every pedal stroke. The main character says, “The growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.” The main character is faced with a problem of man versus nature and the heat is winning. Heat and dehydration sap the main character's energy while he is biking through a desert, desperately trying to make it to the next town. In summary, the main character's biggest problem is the oppressive and dangerous heat of the setting.

The setting around the cyclist affected him in one main way. “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town’” (Kurmaskie). The cyclist put the word town in parentheses because it was actually a ghost town; no one lived there, it was completely abandoned. Around the cyclist was desert, and more empty towns, creating a landscape of isolation and false hope. The farther the cyclist got, the more he realized the old men were wrong as he was running low on water and there was nowhere to stop, a dire situation born from misguided advice. He finally found some water and vowed to never listen to old men's directions again, a hard-learned lesson about the treachery of the environment.

All the features of the area have a big effect on the cyclist. It is a hot June morning, and he is on his bike, pedaling hard, going many miles through an unforgiving landscape. He can't find any water, because all the towns along the road are deserted, leaving him without hope for replenishment. He is getting dehydrated, and losing strength, his physical condition deteriorating with each passing mile. It seems like he might have collapsed if he hadn't thought he was going to make it, and if he hadn't gotten some water at that store just in time. All in all, the setting seems to have the intention of testing his very limits for survival.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road: Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie affects the cyclist in a very negative way. It begins slowly with the “ghost town.” The narrator “chuckled, checked my water supply and moved on,” he wasn’t especially worried, but the fact he checked his water suggests that he’ll need to ration it for a while, an early sign of the challenges ahead. The decline continues when he reaches the fork and the “ramshackle shed.” The description of the place shows you he did not like it, and he confirms that with the words, “this sight was troubling.” He wouldn’t be replenishing his water here, another hope dashed. Any more of this and he’d be dead, either from dehydration or from pessimism. Eventually he reached the road sign which declared that going over 55 mph was a bad idea. This is ironic, as he was only going 12 mph; to put it in his own words, “sometimes life can be so cruel.” He quite obviously hates the setting, and his entire difficult experience is a direct result of the hostile environment through which he travels.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he had limited water, he had to peddle harder to get up over the hills and he was getting dehydrated from the heat. For example, he had limited water because he had taken the directions from the old men and probably didn't bring as much as he would have if he would have taken a longer, more established route. Furthermore, to get up the rolling hills he had to peddle faster and harder, which drained his energy more quickly. That affected him because he would have been more exhausted from the strenuous peddling. Moreover, it was a June day and in June the days are hot; with the lack of a good amount of water the cyclist would have started to get dehydrated from the combined effects of the sun and his exertion. This is how the specific features of the setting affected the cyclist throughout his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For one, his body heat raised a good bit from the intense solar exposure. They don't come out and say it explicitly, but they do say, “The sun was beginning to beat down.” We all know that if you're outside when it's hot, you get hot too, and this would have been directly felt by the cyclist. It also probably added to his dehydration as the heat increased his sweating. As a long distance runner, I know what the sun will do to you during a hot day, sapping your strength and fluids. That is how the setting, particularly the relentless sun, affected the cyclist and his physical state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a major way, defining the very challenges he encounters. For one, if the desert was not a deserted mountainous area in California then the cyclist would not have the same problems with isolation and difficult terrain. By changing any of the features of the setting you would change how the cyclist would behave and what resources he would need. Thus changing the entire plot of the story and the nature of his struggle. If the cyclist was say in a city or a merely developed area then he would not face the same dangers, like dehydration and exhaustion, as if he were in a remote, mountainous region. The settings features have a huge affect on the cyclist, ultimately shaping his entire experience.

In the story “Rough Road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie the feature of the setting seem negative to the cyclist, creating a series of escalating difficulties. The setting seems to start worrying the cyclist two miles after he said that he could make the next stretch of miles easily. For example the cyclist says “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills,” and the cyclist seems worried at that point that things aren't going to be as easy as they seemed they were going to be. From that point on the setting seemed to get worse for the cyclist as the hills grew and his water diminished. Later on the cyclist ends up saying “It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” That was when the cyclist began to notice his intense fear of dehydration and the severity of his situation. The cyclist ended up making it and he realized what a big effect nature can have on you, both physically and mentally.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by unexpected things happening that complicate his journey. His water supply got drank quickly in the heat and he couldn't find a town near to replenish it. He was in the desert-like California, and the sun was beating down on him relentlessly. When he did find one town, it was more of a “ghost town”, and had rusted pumps that yielded only a battery-oil tasting liquid, which was undrinkable. Every person he asked told him the next town was near, but from dehydration and fatigue, it took him longer to reach than anticipated. The roads got windy and small hills occurred, slowing his progress further. There was a large snake in the middle of the road, as tumble weeds blew by, adding to the sense of a harsh environment. He finally saw a town that had a bait shop and was able to get fresh water and cool down, ending his ordeal.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit” definitely affected the author. The cyclist states, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This change in terrain meant the cyclist probably found it more difficult to navigate through the "hills" as opposed to the "Flat roads," making him more quickly tired and expending greater energy. The speaker states, “I could drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie @NUM2). The speaker is implying that it is so hot outside that he could faint from a ‘heatstroke’ which could slow him down and pose a serious health risk. The speaker also states,"water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees"(Kurmaskie @NUM3). The author did not have any good water to drink, because it was so hot outside that his water became undrinkably warm, which affected him in that he was dehydrated and his performance suffered. Many aspects of the setting, from the topography to the extreme heat, significantly affected the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because if the old men didn't give the boy advice then he probably wouldn't have run into all the trouble he ran into, leading him down an unfamiliar and difficult path. At the same time, the boy made his way to where he was going, demonstrating resilience despite the challenging circumstances. Next time though he will just use his map so he doesn't have to go through the scare of death again, learning a valuable lesson about self-reliance from his environmental experience. This shows how the setting, through the people and paths within it, directly shaped the cyclist's ordeal and his subsequent resolution.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist by the road’s condition being rough as the cyclist rides further along the road. This increasing roughness makes the journey more physically demanding and difficult to traverse, requiring greater effort and concentration from the rider. The deteriorating path forces the cyclist to adapt his pace and technique to navigate the challenging terrain safely. Consequently, the setting's physical characteristics have a direct and cumulative impact on the cyclist's experience and endurance throughout his ride.

The setting of this short story has a big affect on the cyclist. Since the story takes place in the desert, the temperature is very hot and the environment is harsh. The cyclist only packed enough water for the intended trip, underestimating the demands of the landscape. Since he made a few wrong turns, he ended up needing more water and found his supply insufficient. There were no signs of civilization so he could not stop any where and buy water, leaving him completely isolated. He came to a “run-down” rusty faucet and tried to drink water from it, but it was hot and tasted like battery acid, offering no relief. If this short story had a different setting, then the story would not make much sense, as the conflict is built upon the desert's unforgiving nature. For example, if the story would have taken place in @LOCATION1 he could have just stopped and bought water, completely altering the narrative's tension. The setting is one of the most important elements in a story, fundamentally driving the protagonist's challenges and the plot's development.

The features affect the cyclist in many ways. For example the road, the rocks, and everything close to his path present constant hazards. The cyclist needs to know everything about where he's going, because if not then he can run into some problems along the way, for example like snakes, rough terrain, or rocks in the way, all of which can cause injury or delay. That is why its important for a cyclist to never listen to anyone but themselves when planning a route through such an environment. That is why when you see cyclists you see them around a road where there's cars around, just in case they get into trouble and need assistance, highlighting how the setting dictates their necessary precautions for a safe journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they give the journey more life and meaning, making the narrative more engaging and fun to read. A well-described environment adds depth to the experience, allowing the reader to visualize the path and feel the challenges and triumphs alongside the rider. This connection to the setting ultimately enriches the entire story, making the cyclist's adventure more vivid and compelling for the audience.

At times when the features of the setting are bad it can have a great impact on the cyclist. For one if it’s too hot the cyclist is going to need plenty of water if he/she doesn't want to be dehydrated. There are also the dangers of heat strokes and deadly snakes, which a cyclist would certainly want to avoid. The harsh environment presents constant physical challenges that require significant endurance. When you're a cyclist times can be hard, so it is essential to be just prepared for the long run and its many potential hardships.

The setting in the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” really goes against the cyclist and his journey. This is because in the places he goes there is no water and if there is it is really hot or bad water. For example, on the page it says, “a tarlike substance oozed out, but the water wouldn’t cool down.” This quote explains how bad the water was when the cyclist was there, highlighting the hostile and unforgiving nature of the landscape that actively hinders his progress and well-being.

During this essay the author is talking about his journey, detailing the various challenges and observations he encounters along the way. He reflects on the changing landscape and how it influences his physical state and his morale. Through his descriptions, the reader gains insight into the demands of such a long-distance ride. The narrative serves as a personal account of perseverance, ultimately conveying the profound experience of traveling through diverse and demanding environments on a bicycle.

The features of the setting included nice cool pines and then a ghost town and it being hot out and banners and poisonous snacks and hills that were getting harder to go up. When he first started the pines were nice and cool but when he scanned the ghost town he got disheartened. Then it started to get hot and he saw the snack and thought that it was a dimmed baby and was nervous, and then he was scared of dehydration. Finally, the hills started to make it harder and harder to pedal, illustrating the cumulative difficulties presented by the setting throughout his ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he has to use more energy to pedal up steep hills and through rocky, uneven terrain. This increased physical exertion caused him to sweat more and his body to work harder. Therefore he drank more water to stay hydrated. When he couldn't find a refill for his bottle, his situation became increasingly difficult and his progress slowed considerably, highlighting the direct impact of the environment on his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in several ways. The first was the terrain, which started out flat, then turned to hills. The cyclist was growing tired from all the pedaling. "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This tired him out faster, since going uphill is harder than riding flat terrain and requires greater effort. The heat definitely affected him, because it made him thirsty and dehydrated. He was "travelling through the high deserts of California in June." This is a very hot time of year, and when a person gets lost without conserving water, which he had not done, a person gets extremely thirsty. Not to mention the "sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth," which would remind the body of its thirst and taunt him with what he lacked. So the setting most definitely affected the cyclist, shaping his physical state and his entire experience.

In the story, the cyclist is greatly affected by the features of the setting. For example, the setting has nothing for miles. Just ghost towns, which makes it impossible to find any water or help. Also it’s a desert-like setting, adding to his thirst with its dry, arid air. Another example is the hills, that made him even more thirsty from the exertion of climbing them. It was June in California so it must have been pretty hot and also the town that he came to had no water because they seemed deserted and abandoned. Another example is the state he put under his tongue, a small stone. It’s a trick that lets you survive a lot more effectively by stimulating saliva. Therefore the settings affected his journey profoundly and made him wish he didn’t take the old man's advice, leaving him in a dire situation.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. Three features I found were the lack of the water, the heat and the conditions and limits of the road. The lack of water really affected the cyclist. When he was tired and dehydrated he/she didn’t have anything to drink. The essay stated how he/she would say she/he would save the water til the end, but it was not enough. He /she was so tired so the lack of water really affect him/her, slowing him down. The conditions he/she was in really affected the cyclist also, primarily being lost. From the beginning he/she was told the wrong directions. That was the reason why he/she was lost the entire time, unable to find a correct path. Finally the limits of the road affected the cyclist. Hills and different grounds did not help the cyclist, making the ride more strenuous. In conclusion, the cyclist had many factors affecting him such as lack of water, limits of the road and his/her conditions, all combining to create a challenging ordeal.

I think that the features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. First, I think the weather conditions affect him. I think this because in the passage it says, “I could drop from heatstroke”. Meaning, its really hot and the extreme temperature is a genuine threat! Also, I think the fact that he has no water left is affecting him because it says in the passage, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state”. This has a big affect on him, because he’s very thirsty and his physical coordination is suffering. Also, I think the fact that there is nothing around him is affecting him, increasing his sense of isolation. I think this because in the passage it says there were no cars or people to offer assistance. I think all these things affect him, creating a cumulative and overwhelming challenge for his journey.

In Joe Kurmaskie's "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the setting profoundly affects the cyclist. The cyclist takes advice from some old guys and ends up wishing he never did. He finds himself on an empty road, flat and dry, under the oppressive June sun of California's high deserts. He ends up drinking all of the water he has, having been hitting his water bottles pretty regularly, and desperately needing to stop for some more. He stopped to get more water from an old pump, but once, all that came out was some tar-like stuff, and then he couldn’t find another place for quite a while. The flat road was soon replaced by short, rolling hills and he came to a sign that said “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit.” He passed tumbleweeds and a large, menacing snake, all of which impacted his journey with fear and caution. When he finally reached a place to get a drink, he was finally satisfied. Because it was hot and the landscape was empty, he was more thirsty, and therefore the setting directly affected the cyclist's physical and mental state.

He feels profoundly alone; there is no one around him to push him, and yet he keeps going, trying to push himself to the end to win. The fast roads are rough and unforgiving, and the hills are tall and demanding, but he is a determined individual, steadfast in his resolve to finish the arduous journey he has undertaken, proving his endurance to himself.

Heat, abandoned roads, and snakes are all reasons that affected the cyclist. The intense heat made him get dehydrated faster while he was using energy pedaling through the desert. The long, abandoned roads further increased his doubt of surviving the whole bike ride, amplifying his sense of isolation. He used up all of his water, so when he got to the old pump, only hot, dirty water came out. The snake in the story made the journey for this guy perilous and deadly, introducing a real physical danger. This all happened because he listened to the old guys, a decision he clearly came to regret. When another old guy was about to tell him where to go, he wisely said no, having learned a difficult lesson about trusting such advice.

The features and the setting affect the cyclist a lot. One reason was that he was in the desert, as indicated in the quote “through high deserts of California.” This means that it was extremely hot and he was at risk of passing out from a heat stroke. Then he couldn’t even get any clean water. The quote about “the rusted water pump” describes how old and decrepit it was; the cyclist got some water out but it tasted like old battery acid, making it undrinkable. Therefore, the harsh features and setting directly affected the cyclist by threatening his health and impeding his progress.

The features of the setting intensely effect the cyclist over a period of time. Destined to reach Yosemite National Park from Lodi, California, a determined cyclist rode strongly through the gentle evening. When the setting changed, so did the effect it had on the cyclist. When the man reached the first town, which was deserted, his energy began depleting because the sun began to rise, bringing intense heat into the picture. Next, he came to a shed desperate for water only to find rusty pumps with tainted, unsafe water. When the flat terrain turned to rolling hills, the man was entirely exhausted. With what he believed to be his last burst of energy, he maneuvered down the hill. That quote directly describes what the man was feeling and how the hills effected him, draining his final reserves. When the man stumbled across a fish camp with fresh water, he became reloaded and replenished, regaining the confidence he had before when he “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile,” completing his transformative journey.

The setting affected the cyclist in many ways, shaping his journey and his state of mind. For example, he was riding in the desert, a vast and empty landscape, and all the towns he was going to were abandoned, which increased his sense of isolation. The month was June, a notoriously hot month, and the sun was beating down on him relentlessly. And he was cycling with very little water, a situation that made the harsh environment even more threatening and dire for his survival. This combination of factors created a profound physical and psychological challenge that defined his entire experience.

In the essay “Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit,” the setting effects the cyclist in many ways, directly influencing his emotions and resolve. When the cyclist arrived at the first town, he described it as a ghost town, a place of eerie silence and decay. This effected the cyclist because he started to have serious doubts about the directions he received, but he was looking foward to the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite so he persevered, clinging to that hopeful destination. The setting of the next land mark was similar to the last, offering no respite. There was a shed, a few rusty pipes and a corral that "Couldnít hold in the lamest mule," a description that underscored the complete desolation. This made the cyclist more werry of the path ahead because he was running out of water, his anxiety growing with each empty landmark. The next place was also similar, deepening his despair. There was an abandoned @ORGANIZATION1, another sign of a place that had not survived the harsh environment. The cyclist was running out of water and now thought he was going to die because everything was deserted, leaving him feeling utterly alone and hopeless. Then, finally, the setting changed, offering a miraculous turn of events. There was a store that was actually opened, a beacon of life and civilization. The cyclist then felt happy and relieved, his fears immediately washed away by this simple sign of human presence. That is how the different settings effected the cyclist, each one dictating his emotional state from doubt to fear to ultimate relief.

The authorís setting described a difficult terrain and harsh weather for bike riding, creating a formidable challenge for the cyclist. The author said that it was early summer which means it could be hot and uncomfortable weather for the cyclist, a time when temperatures begin to soar. The author also noted that when the cyclist reached the first town, the sun began to heat down, intensifying its glare. That means the temperature is going to rise since the sun is getting stronger, compounding the physical strain. Riding a bike in hot weather is very difficult because it takes a lot of effort and makes your body dehydrate faster because the heat makes you sweat which lowers your water retention, a critical problem for a long-distance rider. Another feature of the setting that the author described was the cyclistís location, which provided context for the severity of the conditions. He was traveling through the high deserts of California, a region known for its arid climate. This gives you a sense of how much hotter it is since heís traveling through deserts during early summer while the sun is high, creating a perfect storm of environmental hardship. After the first couple town, he starts to ride on short, rolling hills, introducing a new type of physical obstacle. Hills take a bigger toll on a personís body because it takes more effort to pedal up a hill, demanding greater strength and endurance from the already fatigued cyclist. The combination of heat and difficult geography thus presented a relentless test of his limits.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly, testing his physical and mental fortitude at every turn. From the ghost town to the bait shop, it was all a challenge for him, a series of obstacles in a desolate landscape. A misleading challenge, but a challenge nonetheless. In the desert is were water grew short and he tried everything to push himself, employing various tactics to maintain his will. From staring at the horizon to get to a place to another from sucking on pebble stone to not focus on water, he used every mental trick to manage his thirst and despair. And when he arrive at the bait shop, his perseverance was finally rewarded. A sense of relief came to him, like that shop was his safe haven, a sanctuary in the wilderness. But yet he would never get directions from any old-timer again, having learned a hard lesson about trusting such advice. Luck was not a factor in this story; his survival was not a matter of chance. Rather it was drive and overal climate of the story that determined the outcome. When it was two-hundred degrees left, and no water left, he pushed himself to the light, relying on sheer determination. And also when he saw a building he was determined to get to it, his spirit refusing to be broken by the harsh setting. His journey was ultimately a testament to human resilience in the face of environmental adversity.

The cyclist was trying to make it to Yosemite National Park, a goal that motivated his entire arduous journey. The cyclist was in Lodi, California when he decided to ask for directions from old codgers so that he could take a short cut, a decision he would soon come to regret. He followed their directions and little did he know that he should have stuck to his original directions, as the new path led him into severe hardship. The cyclist was traveling through the high deserts of California in June, a time and place known for extreme heat. The cyclist became very hot and thirsty from traveling in the desert, the conditions rapidly depleting his resources and energy. It says in the text “when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid,” a vivid description that shows that he had no water left to kept him dehydrated throughout his travel, and what little he might have found was undrinkable. Also in the text it says “with what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill,” a statement that shows that he had no energy left, pushing his body to its absolute limit in the unforgiving landscape. His experience underscores how the physical setting directly created a life-threatening situation that tested his endurance to the brink.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, he goes through all kinds of settings where the going could get better or worse. He writes, “I noticed the terrain changing, flat roads was replaced with short rolling hills” (Kurmaskie). This shows or explains that the going could get a little tougher now because he will have to be riding up hills and he is almost out of water. The physical challenge of the landscape is compounded by his dwindling resources. Furthermore, he observes, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind” (Kurmaskie). This explains that the man could not get water or a ride from anywhere around, because there was nothing out there to assist him. The isolation of the setting intensified his predicament, leaving him entirely reliant on his own dwindling strength. This is how the setting features affected the cyclist, creating a situation of escalating difficulty through both terrain and solitude.

Almost all the features of the setting affect the cyclist. For instance, the fact that it is hot causes him to drink a lot of water and need a lot of water. In the story it goes on about how thirsty and sweaty he is, describing his physical state in detail. He notes, “The water bottles contains only a few tantalizing sips. Wid rings of sweet circled my shirt.” These description suggests that he is very hot since he is sweaty and hes been drinking so much, highlighting the direct impact of the climate. Another feature of the setting is the rolling hills that make him feel like he is never going to reach the next town, creating a psychological barrier. He states, “I began breaking the ride down into distances I could make it test for.” He is making the ride seem like a lot of short rides so he could make it, a mental strategy forced upon him by the relentless, repetitive landscape. Thus, both the heat and the topography work in tandem to challenge him physically and mentally.

The setting is described by the author as very challenging for three reasons: distance, water, and the heat. All of these only served to multiply the effects of the others, creating a compounded hardship for the rider. As time had went on, the cyclist grew increasingly tired from the relentless heat, which sapped his energy. In one sentence the effect of the heat were clearly described by the cyclist, who conveyed a sense of being physically drained and overwhelmed by the environmental conditions. The great distance he had to cover seemed even farther without a reliable water source to combat the scorching temperature. Ultimately, these interconnected elements of the setting formed a triad of adversity that tested the cyclist's endurance to its limits, demonstrating how environmental factors can converge to create a singularly difficult experience.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in many ways, primarily influencing his emotional state. The scenery makes the cyclist turn worried, unconfident, and in the end an ironic hopeful. The cyclist came upon the first “town”, and described it as only having “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral”. I believe this is when the cyclist realized the men were a little off, and began to worry; he also couldn’t refill water supply, so fear of dehydration also kicked in. Already tired, the cyclist became unconfident when he came upon the sign reading, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”. Knowing that this was going to be a long and slow journey, the cycles becomes unconfident that he can make it, feeling daunted by the official warning. Finally, when passing the sign saying, "Gary and Wilber's fish camp – If you want bait for the big ones, we’ve your best bet," the cyclist reached a hopeful stage, because he knew he had found civilization once again, a sign of life and potential aid. I believe your atmosphere and surroundings can effect your general mood, and that stands true today with the cyclist, whose spirits were directly shaped by the landscape and signs he encountered.

The way the features of the setting affect the cyclist is by either making the ride easy for him or tough for him, with the narrative focusing on the latter. This means that the way he had to go was tough and making it hard for the cyclist to stay focused, as the constant ascents and descents demanded more effort. The setting affects the cyclist because the pass is on a road with a lot of hills, which would affect him by making him tired. The setting affects the cyclist because it can provide landmarks and directions. The setting affect of a cyclist can be petty complicated. So many things has to be prepared for you to be a successful cyclist. First up have to be prepared for the weather. The setting of where cyclsit takes there journey effects the cyclist. The reason I say that is because in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclsit came upon a conflict with the setting.
