The setting in the short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed speed Limit” greatly affects the cyclist, testing his physical endurance and mental fortitude. The rough terrain and blazing sun test him and make him suffer in ways he never imagined, pushing him to his absolute limits. One point, after the cyclist has been going for hours he notes, “Over on long crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage…” this setting has caused the cyclist to become so dehydrated that he can’t think clearly, his vision blurring and his mind clouded with exhaustion. The cyclist knows the dangers of the setting around him, the vast emptiness offering no respite from the oppressive heat. As you can see the setting has a very strong affect on the cyclist, fundamentally shaping his arduous journey.

The cyclist was profoundly affected by long hours of riding the bike into the remote and unfamiliar areas where he had never been before. The isolation of the landscape compounded his physical fatigue, leaving him entirely reliant on his own dwindling resources. Each turn in the road revealed more desolate scenery, which weighed heavily on his spirit and heightened his sense of vulnerability. This challenging journey through unknown territory pushed him to confront his own limits in a harsh and unyielding environment. Ultimately, the unfamiliar and demanding setting was a central factor in his difficult experience.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist is affected by the setting mentally and physically, with each element of the environment contributing to his ordeal. For example, the setting affected the cyclist mentally because it all was desert and sand with no water, a barren vista that offered no hope of immediate relief. He thought he was going to die, he said “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” a vivid expression of his deep despair. If he had some water he would not have thought this, as his physical need directly fueled his mental state. Also the cyclist was affected physically because the road was rough and it looked as it could go on forever, each bump and incline sapping his strength. He was losing energy and was getting tired from riding up all the hills with little water left in him, his body pushed to the brink of collapse. It was hot and it seemed hopeless but if he was riding through the evergreen forest I don’t think he would have felt this way, the contrast highlighting the setting's specific cruelty. In conclusion the cyclist was effected by the setting physically and mentally; if he had not been riding in the desert he would not feel this way, proving the environment's powerful role.

In the essay, “Rough Road ahead" the character sees many settings through his ride, all of which affect his mood and physical condition in significant ways. For example, when the author describes one place he came to as, “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mute greeted me. This sight was troubling”, this was the turning point where the cyclist began to worry that he would not find the supplies he desperately needed. He was running out of water, a critical situation made worse as “The sun was beginning to beat down” with increasing intensity, and he was probably tired of pedaling for hours without a clear destination. But, to make matters worse, he came to rolling hills that demanded even more from his weary body. This affected him because he had to work harder and had less water to pick him up, his energy reserves nearly depleted. When he finally got to a “modernized” town his spirits were lifted by the sight of civilization, and he was able to get water to cool him down and replenish his strength. This gave him more strength and will-power to continue his trip to Yosemite park, demonstrating how a positive change in setting could immediately reverse his declining condition.

The setting of the story has a huge affect because it was such an empty terrain that made him rely on only himself because of the complete lack of others to help. The vast, silent desert stretched out in all directions, offering no signs of life or assistance. For example, if he was riding through a city for hours he could stop and take a break in a store or get water from about any where, simple comforts that were entirely absent from his current reality. But being in the desert it really tested his inner strength to go on and get to safety, forcing a profound internal struggle against the elements. The isolation was absolute, making his personal resilience the sole determinant of his fate. In this way, the harsh setting was the primary antagonist of his journey.

In the essay I can conclude that there were many features of the land that affected the cyclist. For example in the text it states “ridiculously large snake…blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” If you are greatly afraid of snakes that could ruin your whole trip, causing a significant delay and mental distress. The cyclist was scared but over came the fear and moved on, demonstrating resilience in the face of an unexpected obstacle. Also another thing that changed the cyclist was the lack of water. Not having enough water could be bad, leading to severe physical consequences. As stated “I could drop from heatstore on a gorgeous day in June…” This highlights the real danger posed by the environment. There are many features that effected the cyclist and his journey, each presenting a unique challenge to be overcome.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s, “Rough Road Ahead Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” there are several features that effect the cyclist. “..and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie) Deserts in June are extremely hot and dry and caused the cylist to become dehydrated quickly, sapping his energy and increasing his physical discomfort. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” The change from flat lands to hills made the ride more strenuous on the cyclist, demanding greater physical exertion and altering the pace of his travel. These conditions directly affect the cyclist, shaping his experience and testing his endurance throughout the journey.

The cyclist was trying to get to Yosemite National Park, a destination that required a long and arduous journey. The cyclist barely had water at the end of the stony, leaving him in a state of severe thirst and vulnerability. A lot of buidings were abandoned, right when he needed water, which added to his desperation and highlighted the unforgiving nature of the landscape. That is how the setting affected him, creating a series of physical hardships that directly challenged his ability to complete his trip.

In the essay rough road ahead the setting does effect the cyclist because he has been pedaling for so long and he is becoming dehydrated “I had been hitting my watter bottles pretty regularly. I was in the high deserts of California”. This constant need for water illustrates the physical toll of the environment. Another reason the setting effects him is because he is starting to see mirages “A sandblasted picture of a boy pouring a refreshing glass of grape juice into his mouth could still be seen.” This mirage, a trick of the mind induced by heat and exhaustion, shows how the harsh conditions were beginning to affect his perception and mental state, making the journey even more challenging.

The features like not enough water not enough sense of direction, effect the cyclist because he needs water to keep on peadiling and maintain his physical strength. The features of the setting are that it is hot and dry, creating a harsh environment for the journey. The way that it affects the cyclist is that he gets very hot and he drinks almost all of his water, leaving him with only about @NUM1 sips remaining when he finally gets to the other town. It also effects him because he had one key advantage on his side. The advantage that he had was he left before the sun came up, so then he had a brief time to get cool before the intense heat of the day set in. Another part of the setting that affects the cyclist is when he gets to the top of some of the hills he gets a little bit of the wind, which offers a momentary relief. Also when the cyclist was desperately thirsty he put pebbles into his mouth to stimulate saliva. These environmental factors collectively shape his difficult experience on the road.

Setting plays a crucial part in the cyclist’s mood and energy, directly influencing his physical state and mental outlook. For example, in a cool @DATE1 day riding gently downhill, the rider is happy and energetic, feeling a sense of effortless progress. However, “traveling through the high deserts of California in June is not the best environment for laughs and ease.” The cyclist in the story was hot, exhausted, and dangerously dehydrated. He thought, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” a grim reflection of his despair. Where the cyclist rides can have a huge effect on the cyclist himself, proving that the landscape is a powerful force in any journey.

The cyclist was riding his bike and was trying to get to Rosemite, pushing forward despite the significant challenge he faced. He had a severe lack of water, a critical problem in the arid environment, but he went on anyway, driven by his determination to reach his destination. During his arduous trek, he had to go past a snake coiled on the path and got scared, a moment of sudden alarm that broke his rhythm. This encounter with the wildlife, combined with his physical strain, tested his resolve as he continued his journey through the demanding terrain.

All the features of the settings affect his rhythm, determination and will to win because it sets him off his goal a little bit when he should just try to ignore stuff the best as he can. The various distractions and hardships of the environment, like the heat and the difficult terrain, can disrupt his focus and mental stamina. Instead of thinking about it and letting the negative conditions overwhelm him, he should maintain a stronger mental approach. If I was him I would just ride my bike and think about one thing: winning! This singular focus would help him push through the adversity and stay committed to his ultimate objective.

To a cyclist, the surrounding setting can either cause triumph or despair, acting as the ultimate determinant of success. The cyclist was given very old directions, which led him onto a challenging and unforgiving route. He was given back roads that are abandoned now, paths that offered little assistance. These towns had no people in them; normally that would not matter, but he “was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (@NUM1), a time of extreme heat. If there was shade, a breeze, and @NUM2 weather, he would be fine, but he is pedaling a bike in a desert during the summer, a truly grueling endeavor. A “ghost town” with no good water could have killed him, highlighting the life-or-death stakes. A cyclist needs to know their surroundings and be prepared for what nature throws at them, as failure to do so can have severe consequences.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. First of all I think that when the cyclist came across the “ghost town” he felt alone and discouraged, surrounded by empty, silent buildings that offered no refuge. Also the long hilly highway with nothing but desert on either side basically gave him the discouraging feeling that that road was never going to end and there was no way out of what he had started. I think it made him feel trapped and it was so dry that there was no water in sight and it made him feel so much thirstier than he was, amplifying his physical discomfort. Overall I think that it had really physical and psychological effects on him, draining his spirit as much as his body.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist runs into a couple obstacles and they affected him in many ways. The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist. Some of these features include the heat, dangerous animals, not a lot of civilization, and the terrain. In the essay, each of these features were spoke of and they all affected the cyclist in a negative way. For example, when the cyclist headed from the intense heat, he needed to find a town. The first “town” he found he described as a “ghost town” which offered no relief. It took a while to find another town and he had been hitting [his] water bottles pretty regularly and [he] was travelling through the high deserts of California in June so he was getting really dehydrated and ready to collapse. The terrain really affected the energy he had to exert in order to keep going, along with being dehydrated the cyclist had to deal with dangerous animals. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. First, the heat made the cyclist overheated, bearing down on him without reprieve. For instance, the weather was sunny in June, creating an oppressive and relentless environment. Also, the hills made the cyclist very tired, demanding constant physical exertion. For example, the cyclist was losing energy and had to keep pushing, his muscles straining with every incline. Lastly, the setting had no places that could have helped the cyclist, leaving him isolated and without support. For instance, the cyclist had trouble finding a place with water to drink, which intensified his struggle. In conclusion, the setting affected the biker in a very negative way, creating a journey defined by hardship and endurance.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist in the way that it is so hot that he is quickly becoming dehydrated, with the sun draining his energy and moisture. Another feature is that all the building seem to be either abandoned or in despair, presenting a landscape devoid of life or aid. This desolate environment contributes to a feeling of isolation and difficulty, as there are no resources available to assist him on his arduous journey. The combined effect of the heat and the crumbling structures creates a significant challenge for the cyclist's progress and well-being.

The features of the setting strongly affect the cyclist. Now the setting is in the California desert on a hot day in June, which causes the cyclist to drink all of his water, which later makes him dehydrated. The barren desert, with its vast expanse and no distinct landmarks, causes the cyclist to become lost, which is the main problem he faces. The relentless sun and the monotonous terrain offer no respite, compounding his dire situation as he struggles to find his way. Ultimately, the unforgiving environment proves to be the central antagonist in his journey.

The setting of this story plays a huge part in the final outcome. The author makes a mention that he is travelling through the high deserts of California in June. This sentence alone tells the reader that it is hot. And not hot by normal standards, where it gets to a high temperature, maybe, by noon. That means that the day starts at a very warm temperature. By noon, it's past extremely hot. Also, the author comes to a sign marked "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit." He makes note that he’s only going 12 mph. Before he reaches any sort of civilization, he has already drunken most of his water, his last "tentalizing sips." This is his main problem, his lack of water. He drank most of it in the beginning of his ride, thinking he’d be okay, but he regretted it later on when the intense, dry heat continued to bear down on him. The setting, therefore, directly orchestrated the central conflict of his narrative.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist was in the middle of almost nowhere dehydrating. Because he is dehydrated, the setting makes him worse. He’s biking, in California, in the desert. It’s not a mild climate and the sun is probably scorching, beating down without mercy. The heat plus all the biking he’s doing, is making him even more thirsty and tired, creating a vicious cycle of physical depletion. The arid air saps the moisture from his body with every labored breath, and the shimmering heat haze on the horizon disorients him further. In this way, the hostile setting actively exacerbates his already critical condition.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many was. The cyclist went through many different obsticales travilng, triying to get to Yosemite, each challenge shaped by the environment. The features of the setting affect cyclists greatly, presenting challenges that can make or break a journey. Elements like the relentless weather, difficult terrain, high temperature, and thin air at altitude test a rider's limits. In this essay, the intense heat and the endless hills on the road challenge the cyclist profoundly. He just keeps going through the adversity, pushing past each obstacle, and eventually he gets to civilization, where the harsh environment recedes. This hard-won arrival lets you know that you can’t let mother nature control you, but must persevere against its forces.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist, imposing a severe physical toll during the journey. The author is getting worn out by the conditions and is rapidly running out of his vital water supply. He was traveling through the high deserts of California in June, a time of year known for its extreme and unforgiving dryness. This specific setting, with its vast, arid landscape and scorching sun, is causing him to become greatly exhausted, sapping his energy with every mile.

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist tremendously, directly challenging his initial confidence. The setting of “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” was the very hot, arid deserts, a place of stark isolation. On a bike ride through such an environment, there are not many places to stop for food or water, making preparation critical. On a bike ride you can't bring a lot of luggage with you, only the most important materials and a big enough jug of water to sustain you. An example from the text shows how desperate it was out there: “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted pump with all my strength.” He was so thirsty and tired he didn’t know how else to get some water, revealing the sheer desperation induced by the setting.

In the setting, the young man is faced by some challenges that make him as an individual a stronger person, forging his character through adversity. For example, he was proud of himself at the journey's end; he made himself happy by saying, "yes sir! I own a very good map." This statement reflects his triumph and acquired wisdom. He knows that he got through the oppressive heat, the dry air, the potential snakes, and a low supply of water to get to where he was determined to be, which was Yosemite, proving his resilience.

The setting in the story "Do not exceed posted speed limit" affects the cyclist because it’s a dry area in California in June. In the essay the features of the setting affected the cyclist. In the story, "Do not exceed posted speed limit", there are many features of the setting that affect the cyclist. First, in the beginning of the story it says that, "The sun was beginning to beat down", the temperature was beginning to rise, but it had not really affected the cyclist because he had plenty of water supply. Next the story says, "I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June", California’s temperature is really high and June is one of the hottest months of the year. The temperature was very high and the cyclist did not have much water left. This was affecting the cyclist because he was tired, hot, and getting dehydrated. In the short story “Rough road ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist faced many difficulties. These difficulties were the direct result of the harsh setting. The story takes place in “the high deserts of California in June.” Because the month of June is very warm, and the climate of that region is typically hot and dry, the cyclist quickly ran into problems. Not only did this affect the cyclist physically, but he was also travelling through a vast and unforgiving desert landscape. The setting also included several abandoned towns along the way, which significantly contributed to the problem. The cyclist soon ran out of water, and to his dismay, discovered the towns that lay before him were completely unoccupied and offered no respite. He had no choice but to continue with his arduous journey through the desolate terrain.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. One primary way is that the hilly terrain makes him work harder and consequently wears him out more quickly. Since the cyclist is getting worn out from the constant exertion, he needs to drink more and more water to stay hydrated. Now that he’s drinking more water, he is running out of it faster and wanting more and more of it, creating a vicious cycle. Then, when he starts to use less water in an attempt to conserve it until he gets to the next town, he begins to become dehydrated and even more tired, and he starts to feel progressively weaker. Also, because the terrain is consistently hilly, his legs are working much harder to go up the steep inclines and his legs become sore and tired. Furthermore, as the day progresses, it also starts to get hotter and he gets thirsty more often. That is how the various elements of the setting collectively affect the cyclist.

In the poem “Do not exceed speed limit” the setting is described as very rough and dry. The man on the bike says he was running low on water, which immediately establishes a sense of scarcity. At one point he says “At some point tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake.” This detail makes the setting sound particularly dry and empty, with the added threat of a harmful snake around, increasing the feeling of danger. This man also mentioned a sign which read “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit,” and this warning also made it hard for the man to ride smoothly and maintain his pace. These are the specific settings and details that affected the biker in the story and shaped his challenging experience.

The feature of it is the landscape, which establishes the physical world of the narrative. Another key feature is the characters, who drive the action and provide a human element. The plot is also a central feature, outlining the sequence of events and the conflicts that arise. Furthermore, the beginning of the story sets the stage and introduces the initial situation. Finally, the end of the narrative provides resolution and concludes the sequence of events. These components work together to form a complete literary work.

The setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limits” affects the mood of the cyclist in that every time the setting changes, the mood of the cyclist changes accordingly. In the beginning of the story, the cyclist is riding through the “cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite.” At this time the cyclist is enjoying his trip and is in a positive and cheerful mood, refreshed by the pleasant surroundings. As the story goes on, the landscape shifts dramatically, and “there was no one in sight, not a building, a car, or structure of any kind.” At this point in the story the cyclist has exchanged his positive mood for a desperate and lonely one as his water begins to run out and the isolation becomes overwhelming. The evolving setting directly dictates his emotional state throughout the journey.

The setting in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” makes the biker's travel a very difficult challenge that he has to overcome. When the “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” the biker must use significantly more energy to pedal up the steep inclines. This made it hard on him to overcome his exhaustion and test his limits of physical endurance. Also, he states that he was “traveling through the high desert of California in June,” and this weather is very hot and dry, therefore causing him to quickly run low on his precious water supply. And, because he was in the vast, empty desert, there was no sign of towns or people or salvation of any type for many miles. These conditions made it hard on the biker because he knew with certainty that if he dropped from severe dehydration, no one would be around to save him. In conclusion, these hard and unforgiving conditions challenged the biker a great deal.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist was on a very long bike ride to Yosemite National Park. However, on the way there, he had to cross through a desert-like terrain that was harsh and uninviting. The blistering sun had been beating on his back for many miles, sapping his strength. All the intense heat built up a powerful desire for him to get a cool drink of water. He had been very tired from the exertion. The terrain and climate had made him drenched in sweat, dehydrating him further. If it wasn’t so hot, then he wouldn’t have had that much of a hard time on his journey. The desert contains a very high temperature, which makes it harder to endure strenuous physical activities. Even if you are to have a high endurance level, the relentless heat will make you very tired, and you will lose a lot of energy quickly. Also, it didn’t help anything, that the elderly men had given him terrible directions, leading him further into this difficult landscape. That is why I think the setting affected the cyclist so profoundly.

The setting in the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” affects the author in a big way. The features of the setting are that “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The fact that there was nothing around him, just empty isolation, made the author lose hope and trust in his situation. After the author saw the old juice factory, he felt a surge of optimism like something was finally happening in his favor. Then he saw with dismay that it was completely abandoned and he lost all hope once more. He shows his loss of hope again when he talks about how he’s going to die out there alone. He shows that he’s lost trust in the old men when he talks about never accepting advice from “old-timers who haven’t left their porches since Carter was in office.” In conclusion, the features of the desolate setting caused him to doubt the directions he was given and lose any hope of surviving.

At the beginning of the ride, the cyclist is feeling good and strong and the day as well as the journey, is just beginning with promise. The sun begins to beat down on the cyclist but he remains upbeat, still feeling good and barely noticing the growing heat. When he arrives at an old rusty water pump, he feels disappointed and tastes a foul liquid that resembles “battery acid,” which does nothing to help him. The terrain begins to feel like more of a constant hill, which makes the physical struggle even worse for his tired legs. The cyclist is drinking water more frequently now, and is becoming genuinely tired and weary. He comes to a rough road and says, “sometimes life can feel so cruel,” which lets the reader know he is feeling the negative effects of what he presumed to be a nice bike ride; further on, a snake blocks his path and he becomes dangerously dehydrated. The cyclist feels a wave of refreshment and relief at a sign for a fish camp, and his thirst is finally replenished when he takes a satisfying gulp of water in the restroom. The water is a feature of the setting that refreshes the cyclist, while the hot sun, rough terrain, and unknown area are features that make the cyclist feel lost and tired.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the sand and the intense heat are two big parts of the setting, which make him incredibly thirsty. “... followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees”. This is a quote that explains the intense, oppressive heat that the cyclist is feeling from the environment around him. The sun is another big feature that affects him, beating down relentlessly and contributing to his dehydration and fatigue. The combined effect of these harsh elements creates a formidable challenge for his journey. This is how the setting affects the cyclist throughout his arduous ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he wants to go somewhere spectacular and amazing. He is searching for a place that matches a specific ideal in his mind. For example, he said he was thriving on this one spot forever and he finally got there and it was a ghost town; he chuckled and rode away because it wasn’t what he was looking for. I believe that this guy is judging every place he goes by the way it looks and not by what it has to offer. It is like he doesn't believe in getting direction from an old map, but yet he still took it, showing his conflicting nature. I believe that he wants to get where he wants to go and not let anybody get in his way no matter what. It's like he is looking for a perfect spot and he thinks when he finds it he will be filled with stories, a belief that drives his entire journey forward.

The setting can affect a cyclist in many ways; if it were hot out, he would be thirsty and sweaty, his body straining under the sun's intensity. If there were hills the cyclist would be tired as well as thirsty, his muscles burning with the effort of each ascent. The cyclist, although thirsty and tired, is determined to get through and find a town, a goal that keeps his legs pumping. The cyclist said, "I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine." By saying this, he knows that he can make it that far as well as being determined to do so, using small victories to fuel his spirit. With the terrain causing even more trouble for him, it would make it more difficult, but he knows that he must overcome his challenging activity. He still keeps a strong spirit, and with that, he can do just about anything because he has the encouragement he needs from within himself.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making his mood change throughout his arduous journey. In the first location, where it’s nice, shaded, and cool, he feels fairly good and his optimism is high. He’s excited and ready to take on the adventure of a new path, feeling invigorated by the pleasant surroundings. His spirits are still in a good mood when he comes to the first town, hoping for a respite. As he moves on, and his water supply depletes, his mood sinks lower and he becomes more frustrated, the physical lack mirroring his emotional state. In the ironic twist of fate that he finds a Welch’s Grape Juice factory, he is about to quit, the cruel juxtaposition pushing him to his limit. He is dejected and almost ready to admit defeat, his resolve worn thin. But he forces himself to go on, and when he finally reaches a place with water, his relief is mixed with wariness of the old man sitting on the porch. He will never take water for granted or advice from old men ever again, a lesson hard-learned from the setting's tests.

The features of the setting only drain the cyclist's willpower, offering him no solace on his difficult trek. The desolation begins to wear away his hope of finding a building or town; sometimes the things are psychologically damaging, eroding his mental fortitude. "In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it – had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen." For someone who is quickly running out of water, this irony could make one lose their resolve to continue, the taunting image a final mental blow. The snake and rolling hills slow him down, and make him use more energy, while the heat dehydrates the cyclist even faster. The environment is a hostile one for a cyclist, presenting obstacle after obstacle to break his spirit completely.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, each one presenting a new challenge to his journey. During the cyclist's trail there are many factors that play out to be disadvantages to him/her. The setting affected the cyclist profoundly because of the bad condition of the roads. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind”. The main features that affected the cyclist were the ruff terrain and the hot sun. The rough terrain, with its potholes and jagged rocks, made it harder to pedal and it tired the cyclist out faster, sapping the strength from his legs with every rotation. The features of the setting in the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted speed limit” affect the cyclist significantly. As the cyclist rides to his destination, he encounters obstacles and views his surroundings with a mixture of awe and apprehension. The author gives the starting setting in the second paragraph as “a reservoir campground outside of lodi, California an early. Summer evening.” The reader is informed that the temperatures are not mild in summers in California. This gives the cyclist his main conflict, the pervasive and growing lack of water. With temperatures being high, it is easier to become quickly dehydrated, a constant threat on such a journey. The author stated, “The sun was beginning to beat down and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. Also, the cyclist encounters a ridiculously large” snake in the middle of the rode, a sudden and startling danger that halts his progress. The reader is aware that there are many conflicts which one can encounter while cycling, from the environmental to the unexpected. There are finally many features of the setting that let the cyclist know where he currently is, and the place where he wants to be most, the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite.” @CAPS1 the essay, the cyclist is determined to reach Yosemite, and although he faces troubles, he doesn't give up and is profoundly relieved when he finally receives water, a moment that underscores the harshness of the setting against the power of human resilience.

The features of the desert profoundly changed the way the speaker thought about his journey. When the road began to change, the speaker's determination did too, as "flat roads were replaced by short hills." The increasingly difficult terrain made him doubtful of the old man who had directed him towards the supposed shortcut. He thought, “I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades.” The oppressive heat in the desert made the speaker desperately thirsty, causing him to drink all of his water prematurely. With no visible source of water, he decided to suck on a stone, recalling, “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst.” However, the bumpy terrain did not allow him to do this safely; he hit a bump and accidentally swallowed the stone. This incident caused the speaker to panic, thinking, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Luckily, his desperate thoughts changed after he fortunately found a supply of water, demonstrating how the desert's features affected the cyclist very much.

The desolate setting affects the cyclist in a very negative way. Due to the complete lack of buildings, people, and cars on his so-called “shortcut,” he was filled with great doubt about his survival. The overwhelming isolation intensified his fears, leading him to think, “I was going to die, and the birds would pick me clean.” He became convinced he wouldn't find any water because there was nothing around him, and he believed he would ultimately die of dehydration or the intense heat. This is captured in his “growing realization that I would die of heatstroke.” The barren landscape thus directly fueled his despair and sense of impending doom, leaving him feeling completely vulnerable and hopeless.

The setting of the story had affected the bike rider in many ways, primarily through the harsh environmental conditions. It was extremely hot when he was riding, which made him profoundly thirsty. For example, the text states, “The sun was beginning to heat down,” indicating the sun's exhausting and dehydrating effect. Another detail provided is that he was “traveling through the desert of California in June.” California is a relatively hot state, and June is one of its warmer months, which compounded the heat's intensity. Furthermore, the terrain itself did not favor the rider, as “flat roads had turned into short, rolling hills.” These short rolling hills are physically harder on a biker's body than flat terrain, demanding more energy and increasing fatigue. This combination of extreme heat and difficult terrain is how the setting profoundly affected the rider during his journey.

The setting significantly affected the cyclist primarily because the journey took place in June when the temperatures were starting to get dangerously hot. In the book, it specifies that he was going through the desert, an environment known for its harsh and unforgiving climate. The author did not have enough water to survive in the desert while the sun was relentlessly beaming down on him, leading to a severe risk of dehydration and heat exhaustion. These environmental factors created a life-threatening situation that directly impacted his physical state and his chances of survival on the journey.

In this paragraph, I will explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The features of the setting in this story give the cyclist determination. Since the desert landscape is vast and unforgiving, it demands immense physical and mental fortitude to traverse. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it is very hot and is summertime. The features of the setting are very important for a cyclist. If the setting is wrong, they could be in many dangers, such as getting lost or facing extreme weather. The features of the setting affected the cyclist horribly! For example, he ran into the worst problems and couldn't really do anything about them. Throughout his journey, the protagonist in the story encounters obstacles in the setting. First off, he is cycling in the hot, dry desert. The cyclist must have lost hope in finding civilization after he found multiple abandoned examples of it. The features in the setting would affect the cyclist because they would want to have towns with water so they can restock they’re water supply, which is essential for a long journey. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because of the intense heat and the fact that he had no water to drink. The hot, dry, desert setting affects the cyclist in many different ways, as he states, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The cyclist is very hot and suffers from the relentless sun. He was thirsty but found that “A tarlike substance ooted out, followed by brakish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of zoo.” The water was barely even water, so he didn’t have much to drink until the next town, which prolonged his discomfort. He was thirstier and more tired after biking on hills, and his spirits were low. He saw “A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth could still be seen” on an old welchs grape fruit factory. This makes the cyclist envious of the young boy and his apparent refreshment. It also discourages him, highlighting his own lack. In conclusion, the water being bad, the terrain change, the picture of the young boy, and the fact that the cyclist drinks a lot makes him tired, hot, envious, and generally exhausted from his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because when he has water and plenty of it, the setting seems to be smooth, easy riding, which boosts his morale. This means that he doesn’t have to use much water, but he still uses some because anyone that rides many miles on a bike will need plenty of water no matter what the terrain is like, just to maintain basic hydration. The features of the setting affect the cyclist toward the middle and end of his trip greatly because it gets rough and hilly and so he needs more water that he doesn’t have. And since he was planning on being able to get water at the first stop he didn’t conserve it as well, so this left less water for him to have when he really needed it for the difficult stretches. He then became dehydrated after his first stop, and he didn’t get any more water there so it caused him to dehydrate further, weakening him. So it seem that the features of the setting affect the cyclist because when he has plenty of water and doesn’t really need it the terrain is smooth and easy to ride but as he drinks his water the terrain gets rougher and worse, creating a cruel irony. So the features of the setting affects him greatly in that they don’t help him they just get worse when he needs it to get better, making his journey a struggle against the environment.

There are many ways that the features affect the cyclist. One is that he is already scared to go up this really big hill, which looms intimidatingly before him. Another is that as he is going up this big hill it's hot, there are snakes around, he's scared and tired from the relentless climb. Almost all of his energy is gone, drained by the steep incline and the harsh conditions. He just wants to stop and rest, yet he is determined to go up this hill and see it through to the top. He also knows that it cant be that bad because he can just relax all the way back down, a thought that provides a small comfort during the arduous ascent. This mixture of dread and determination defines his experience with the challenging terrain.

After reading "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit," I noticed that the setting of this adventure profoundly affected the narrator. First of all, the intense heat caused the narrator to be physically uncomfortable and significantly thirstier. While on the move, he refers to the trip as a "water-depleting" one; this quote clearly shows that he was critically lacking water and that this was a major problem for his survival. Also, it refers to the road as "rolling hills," and this description shows the reader that the terrain seemed to go on forever without end. This endless landscape lowers the narrator’s hope of getting to his destination quickly, creating a sense of mental fatigue. Also, the vast, empty desert gives the author low hope of ever reaching his destination, amplifying his despair. The setting thus affects the narrator both physically, through dehydration and exhaustion, and mentally, by diminishing his morale and optimism.

The setting of the story affected the cyclist because it kept him going precisely because he was all alone and had absolutely no help from anyone else. First, just the fact that he was by himself kept his determination high, as he had only his own will to rely on. If he would have had a partner, they could have stopped and took a break or shared the dwindling water supply, providing mutual support. Next, the fact that there were no buildings, houses, or anything in sight for miles deeply affected him. He got a sudden bolt of strength just from seeing a single building ahead in the distance, a rare sign of civilization. If there had been buildings consistently, he could have stopped and asked for more water and rested safely. The fact that he was in a desert in California in the middle of June, with its extreme heat, really affected him. He had no determination there because there was nothing he could actively do to better the situation in his cause, feeling utterly powerless. He even at one point felt with a chilling certainty that he might die from the ordeal. In conclusion, the setting really affected the cyclist because it fundamentally determined his level of endurance and his will power to continue.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. For example, he asks the older guys, "that haven't left their porches since Carter was in office," where the next place was to get water, highlighting his desperation and the isolated nature of the locals. Also, he was out in the middle of nowhere, with no immediate sources of aid or comfort. It was also in June where the weather was particularly warm, and he didn't have a lot of water, which compounded his physical struggles and heightened his thirst. These environmental factors collectively shaped his difficult and draining journey through the landscape.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. First, he was in the "high desert of California in June." This affected him in many ways, primarily through the extreme heat. It makes him become very dehydrated, a constant and pressing concern. He had to carefully conserve his limited water and even chew on pebbles just to get any spit to collect in his mouth for temporary relief. Also, the road became very rough and unforgiving. The new, difficult terrain made him has to push himself harder and lose energy much quicker than on a smooth path. The last significant feature would be the immense distance he had to cover. He had to travel a lot further then he had originally planned to, which was disheartening. This again affected his energy and spirits with dark thoughts of possible death, and not be able to make it to safety. Those are how just some of the key features of the setting critically affected the cyclist throughout his arduous trip.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. Since the cyclist was in the middle of nowhere, he couldn’t get any water from any source, leaving him completely reliant on his own dwindling supplies. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst,” he thought, showing he was so thirsty that he barely had any energy left to keep going and was resorting to desperate measures. “The growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke,” further illustrates the danger; it was extremely hot out and he had no water, so this affected his energy levels and his very will to continue, creating a life-threatening situation. These environmental challenges directly shaped his physical state and his mental resolve during the journey.

The features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist. The harsh, unforgiving terrain proved a significant challenge, especially when his water supply was critically low and all the towns he passed had been completely abandoned, leaving him with no opportunity for a refill. The oppressive heat was also a major factor, quickly creating a weary and tired state as he pedaled onward. On the bike ride, he had a glimmer of hope upon discovering an old water pump, but was quickly disappointed when the hot liquid that emerged tasted strongly of battery acid, making it undrinkable. Ultimately, the hostile setting established the central conflict and helped achieve the desperate, weary tone the author was looking for to truly affect the cyclist's journey.

The setting affects the cyclist primarily through the roughness of the ride. First, they might go over a bunch of sharp rocks and uneven ground, where a tire could easily pop or become damaged. Next, the path could sometimes be smooth and easy, offering a brief respite from the physical strain. Also, the route could be far away from any towns, making it difficult to get back to safety or find help. Furthermore, there could be a complete lack of available water sources, making you dehydrate quickly under the sun. That is how the various elements of the setting around the cyclist could significantly effect him during his journey.

The setting described in the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” would be a genuine nightmare for any biker. This biker is riding in the middle of a vast desert on a scorching summer’s day. The constant sweat dropping down his body is just speeding up his dangerous dehydration. This is clearly shown when the narration states, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that i could drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie). This quote powerfully shows how intensely hot the desert was, and how he genuinely feared he could drop dead. The desert is also completely deserted, marked only by rolling tumbleweeds and the threat of giant snakes, as he passed numerous abandoned towns and derelict factories. The overall dangerousness for a biker in this isolated area is very high, and the biker was ultimately lucky to have made it out of those harsh surroundings alive.

The arid desert area of California was aggressively making him dehydrated. The trip was long, but he initially had enough water to get him there, but only if he had strictly taken the map's prescribed way. The old men, who he thought “haven’t left the confines of their porches since carter was in office,” told him about a tempting shortcut that he foolishly followed, and this decision ended up almost killing him due to severe heat stroke and dehydration. If the cyclist would have simply followed the original map, he could have safely stopped off at a store for more water even if the setting was that bad, thereby avoiding the life-threatening situation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many critical ways. The setting was a dry California desert, for if it had been a bustling city, the perilous events in the story would have simply not happened. The author asked a group of old men for directions to Yosemite National Park, and, “like a foolish youth,” blindly followed their questionable advice. Everything started out fine until he reached the second town, where he was almost completely dehydrated and “in an ironic twist” he reached an abandoned grape juice factory that offered no relief. Almost all hope was lost for him until he finally rounded a bend and came across his new hope: a sign for “Gary and Wilber’s Fish camp—if you want bait for the big ones, we’re your best bet.” In the end, he learned a vital lesson to stick to a reliable map instead of relying on old people who “haven’t left the confines of their porches since carter was in office.”

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because first he realized that getting advice from people that no longer drive or even leave the porch would be useless. When the author refers to the “old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” he is explaining how their perspective is outdated and irrelevant to his current journey. He then says, “I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face,” referring back to how he is on the road alone, riding the bike with not a car in sight anywhere around him. The curves of the turns were so sharp that only a bicycle could navigate them as safely as he did. When “he whipped the sweat from his eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage and tried not to get too excited,” it shows that in this situation, the long, lonely cycle by himself would have made many people excited, yet he maintained his focus and composure throughout the ride.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making his way to Yosemite National Park a longer, more difficult, and dangerous route to travel. He dismisses the awe of going that way expressed by some old folks that he says “haven’t gotten off their porches since Carter was in office.” I think that there would be a reason not to listen to them, though they may possess a certain kind of wisdom; their lack of recent experience means their advice is not practical for the challenges of the actual journey, which required current, firsthand knowledge of the terrain and conditions he was facing on the road.

In the setting there are no cars and no buildings, meaning no help was available for the cyclist. He was tired and dehydrated because he had run out of water, and no one was around because it was the desert. The cyclist, despite being dehydrated, kept going toward his destination. The road was mostly straight, but almost at the end there were many hills that posed a significant challenge. Along with having to bike up the steep hills, he almost ran into a snake, adding a sudden element of danger. The weather was intensely hot, he had no water, and under these harsh conditions, he could have died, highlighting the severe risks presented by the isolated and unforgiving environment.

The features in the setting of the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affect the biker. For example, the relentless heat is constantly drying the biker out, exacerbating his thirst. Also, at the first town, the old water pump proved to be a hopeless cause, as the water tasted like “battery acid,” leaving him without a viable source of refreshment. Even after that, more problems arose. There was a sign that posted a maximum speed limit, which the biker was doing about one-fifth of, and this stark contrast affected his mood, making him realize that it would be a long and arduous ride. The pebbles that he found helped him out somewhat, as he remembered reading that sticking pebbles in your mouth can calm your thirst. Finally, the bait store at the end of his trip gave him the relief that he desperately needed. In conclusion, the setting makes the rider's journey a challenging one, but in the end, the bait store had just what he needed to recover and continue.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist significantly. For example, there were no towns close by, which created a sense of isolation. One reason this affected the cyclist is because if the towns were nearer to each other, he could have easily reached a store if he ran out of water. In addition, he was at risk of a heatstroke in the remote area, and with no one around to get help from, he could easily have died from such a medical emergency. In my point of view of the reading, I believe the remote location where he was cycling is what affected him the most, as the lack of nearby resources and assistance defined the perilous nature of his entire journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist on how the nature of life he was hydrated or not. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist from the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie had many obstacles to overcome. When he first showed the old men his map he was probably thinking to himself, “my gosh, what did I get myself into?!” Because the cyclist trusted the shortcut the old men told him about he had a lot of doubt, anger and determination later on during the day as the path grew more difficult.
