The setting where the cyclist is at is in a desert, and it can affect him because he could get a heatstroke. The text states that he is lacking water and if you get too dehydrated it's not healthy and you can die from it, making his situation perilous. However, when the wind is against his face, it can cool him down, along with the sweat that evaporates from his skin. As long as he has some liquid left in his body to produce sweat, it should be enough to manage for a short while, though the threat remains ever-present.

The setting of this story is a dry, hot desert in the middle of June. These features of the setting effect the author, because it shows how he starts off strong and determined and is left weak and doubtful. In the beginning of the story, the author says, “Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” This is showing the readers confidence he has with himself before starting his trip under the cool morning air. Later on in the story, he describes the setting as “the high deserts of California in June.” He is describing the heat and what he is facing, a brutal and unforgiving landscape. It goes on to tell how he is dehydrated and worn out, his initial optimism faded. But he comes to a town, "cool water drippen from my head as I slumped against the wall." He is relieved, the harsh setting finally giving way to a place of respite. As the setting changes, the authors attitude changes as well, moving from hope to despair and back again.

Different features of the setting affect a cyclist; for example, temperature really changes everything. If it’s too hot, you’re going to get tired really easily and can become dehydrated quickly. Then again, if it's too cold, breathing gets really hard and your muscles can stiffen up. The biker in the story was in a desert area in June, so it was really hot, tiring, and the sun was relentless. Also, the terrain affects a cyclist significantly. If the road is filled with hills, getting up those steep inclines is difficult and requires great effort. If it’s all downhill, it’s really easy and you can gain speed, but all uphill is hard, while level terrain is fairly easy to navigate. The cyclist in the story was initially in level terrain, which allowed for steady progress, but then it turned into a lot of hills which tired him out and drained his energy. Ultimately, the various features of the setting really affect a cyclist's performance and endurance on a journey.

The setting profoundly affects the cyclist because he is faced with unfamiliar roadways he is unsure of, the weather is intensely hot and dry, and there is the constant presence of wild animals. Navigating unknown paths requires extra caution and can slow his pace considerably. The text states that the harsh, arid conditions lead to rapid dehydration and exhaustion. Furthermore, the potential encounter with wildlife, such as snakes or coyotes, adds an element of danger and stress to his ride. These combined factors of the environment create a challenging and hazardous experience for the cyclist, impacting both his physical state and his mental focus throughout the journey.

The setting has a great impact on the condition of the cyclist, shaping his entire experience. First, it is a very hot and dry climate in June, which saps his strength and fluids. The cyclist is maneuvering his way through the high deserts where he comes across many hills that he must climb over and carefully maneuver his way down. The ascents are grueling, and the descents require control and focus. With all of these obstacles and the oppressive heat slowing him down, he will need water frequently but is already running dangerously low on his supply. This scarcity of water in the arid landscape compounds his physical struggle, making his journey a true test of endurance against the elements.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the narrator is faced with the challenging and perilous desert he must cross, a vast and unforgiving landscape. He wasn't traveling in a car; he was riding a bike, and crossing a desert on foot is tiring enough let alone on a bike, which offers little protection from the elements. "The speed limit was quite high. I was doing a water depleting pace. Sometimes life can be so cruel." In the horrible, extreme degree heat the narrator gulps down his water bottles at such a rapid rate that he’s at a severe risk of running out completely. Not only that, but he’s been pedaling for such a long time that he could pass out from exhaustion or, as he fears, "I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades." So I would say the narrator was pretty hassled by his surroundings, his journey defined by a constant battle against the heat and his own depleting resources.

The setting affected the character in ways that would usually affect people traveling through a harsh environment. When he got into the first town he had ran out of water to drink, but the town's water he was in now tasted like battery acid, so that’s not safe to drink, leaving him without a viable source. As he started to head out, the scenery changed noticeably. “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This is hinting at the fact that maybe this town he is going to would be abandoned or not used, a desolate place. He saw a huge rattlesnake and tumbleweed, which are usual signs of a desert ecosystem. It was hard for him to keep his balance, as he says, “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state,” making every pedal stroke a struggle. He ended up getting to the point where he had to put rocks in his mouth to trick his mind that he wasn't thirsty anymore, a desperate measure highlighting the severity of his situation. This shows how the desert setting directly challenged his physical well-being and resourcefulness.

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist significantly because at first he had to carefully watch out for the snakes that usually crossed the roads, forcing him to remain constantly vigilant. Then the streets themselves were crooked and bumpy, so the difficult road structure threw him off a bit, disrupting his rhythm and balance. Furthermore, he was riding his bike in June when it was very hot, and due to his lack of water he began to think he was going to have a heatstroke. These challenging things collectively affected how the cyclist performed on his bike, ultimately diminishing his endurance and focus.

The cyclist is riding through the vast, high deserts in California, a landscape where everything looks the same for miles, creating a disorienting and monotonous experience. The cyclist is dangerously dehydrated and his condition is getting worse because he has no protection from the relentless sun. It is hard for the cyclist to keep in good spirits because he is not even coming across any towns or sources of water, deepening his sense of isolation. The cyclist says, “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town.’ This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time- say before the last world war- but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This desolate discovery made the cyclist doubt the old timer's directions profoundly. In the wide open desert, the cyclist was only coming across any notable landmark after at least twenty miles of empty travel. The oppressive heat, the critical lack of water, and the complete lack of civilization made the cyclist think he was “going to die and the birds would pick [him] clean.” When the cyclist finally spots the abandoned Welch’s factory, he says they used what seemed to be their last bit of energy to reach it. The harsh desert conditions profoundly affected the cyclist's physical state and morale.

The setting affects the cyclist by showing that he is a little angry and frustrated with his situation. He states that “don’t remember the saying don’t take candy from strangers,” so we know he is upset about something and regretting his own naivete. He is mad about the fact that this one older man tells him directions on how to get somewhere, and it’s wrong, a realization the man figures out halfway through the story. He also said that “the old man hasn’t been off his porch since Carter was in office,” so he feels the man needs to get his directions up to date, highlighting the source of his irritation. So the beginning of his journey is marked by a distinctly negative attitude born from this misguided trust.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the settings affected the character deeply because he thought he wouldn’t make it to the park because of the way things looked around him, which appeared hostile and endless. Because of the intimidating rolling hills and the ever-present threat of snakes he didn’t think he would make it anywhere and genuinely thought he was going to die in that desolate place. The overwhelming and dangerous nature of the environment filled him with a sense of hopelessness. That’s how the setting affected the character, shaping his fears and challenging his survival.

While the cyclist was trying to get to Yosemite National Park he listened to some old men who gave him directions for a supposed shortcut, which he initially trusted. When he began his trip everything was fine and the riding was manageable. But then he found that along the “shortcut” there was no building or sign of life for miles. By the time he figured out that the old men were mistaken he had almost run out of his precious water supply. There was nothing around that he could drink, and he was getting very thirsty and desperate. The fact that he was in the deserts of California in June didn’t make his task any easier, as the heat was extreme. About halfway through his ride he ran into rolling hills, which made his trip even harder by adding physical strain. Towards the end he found a building and he used all of his strength to get to it, just to find that it was an abandoned juice factory, which was a cruel disappointment. This made going without water much harder as well as he gazed at the picture of the boy who was drinking juice, taunting his own thirst. In the end he finally made it to a paint shop where he guzzled all the water he possibly could, bringing his arduous journey to a close.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly, shaping his resolve and his methods. For example when he was riding on the long, empty road he would pick a destination and ride to it with singular focus. Then he would take a brief break to recover. If this destination was a building, a clear mark of civilization, he would be strong willed and determined to reach it. If it looked like their was nothing ahead but endless, rolling hills, he would just ride on with a sense of fatalism and wait to fall over dead without a care in the world, surrendering to the landscape's demands.

One ramsackle shed with a sagging roof, several rusty pumps that looked long abandoned, and a corral that couldnít hold in the lamest mule greeted me upon my arrival. This desolate sight was deeply troubled, offering no solace. There was no one in sight, not a single building, car, or man-made structure of any kind beyond this ruin. With any luck, Iíd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat to end the struggle. Rough road lay ahead; if he didnít take the old mans advice about the route, he would have enjoyed his bike ride far more, but now he desperately needed a new map to find his way out.

The features in the story affect the cyclist profoundly, primarily by not having anything to drink for many miles. The person was going to a place far away with out any food or water for what seemed like an eternity, a dangerous situation. He could have died from the severe lack of provisions. There is anther feature the effects the cyclist, and that is the utter isolation, for no one is around for miles in any direction. If he died out there, collapsed on the trail, no one would no know for days, perhaps even weeks. I know this because in the story he said ì There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind. ''That says it all, confirming his complete solitude. The last feature is that it was oppressively hot, a relentless sun. I know this because it says ''I was travelling through high deserts of California in June.'' It is hot is June, and it is even hotter in the California desert, baking the earth and the traveler upon it.

People who travel will almost always encounter difficulties of some kind. For the main character in this story, thus a very true and challenging reality. His first crucial mistake was when he took directions from the ìold-timersî on the porch; by doing that, he travelled extremely far out of his way into desolate territory. In the story he talked to the old men on the porch and later reflected, ìwhat I shouldnít have done was to let them see my map," revealing his regret. Another serious problem he faced was when he began to run out of water in the heat. This caused a dire problem to him because of the threat of severe dehydration. In the story he said, ìThe water bottle contained any a few tantalizing sips,î highlighting his desperation. Furthermore, another problem he encountered was the vast, empty desert area that he was riding through. This caused problem for him because there wasnít anybody around for miles to help him if he needed it or if he faltered. In the story he says, ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, cars, or structure of any kind,î emphasizing his isolation. By reading this story, weíve realized that people encounter problems everywhere, however any problem, no matter what size, can be overcomed with perseverance and careful planning.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly because on page @NUM1 it talk about how the cyclist had to go down a steep hill and then hopefully find a factory for some juice to replenish himself. Like if the cyclist donít find any building or source of aid, he would of kept riding over the next hill and wasted the little bit of energy he had left for actually surviving, leaving him completely depleted and stranded in the harsh environment.

Since the cyclist was really thirsty, the setting was not very appealing considering it was a desert, a vast and sun-scorched landscape. You could tell she was stressing because she was sweating heavily and having a trouble time trying to pedal against the loose sand. The relentless heat and the complete absence of shade made her journey feel endless and particularly grueling, amplifying her desperate need for water.

The setting effects the cyclist in away that most people can’t tell cycling forty miles on maybe a gallon of water is hard expecialy in California. The cyclist recalled, ìI had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high desserts of California in June.î The effect on his body would be rather devastating, leading to severe dehydration and physical exhaustion. The intense, dry heat of the desert environment rapidly drained his energy and resources, making the simple act of pedaling a monumental task.

In the story the Features of the setting affects the cyclist is that when he is riding he has very little water, which becomes a critical problem. Also he takes advise from old men and he meets up with an @CAPS1 Snake and he goes down an dirt Road where he has no water at the time there, a decision he soon regrets. The conclusion is that he comes of the dirt Road and @CAPS2 the main Road that he travels, a much safer and more manageable path. Also he promised to stick to it in the @CAPS3, learning a valuable lesson about preparation. That is how you should stick things at in the future, by staying on a proven and reliable course.

The biker has many features in his story that make it vivid. For example he has discriptive words that put pictures into my head, creating a clear mental image. For example ìOne long, crippling hillî I can picture it in my head, a steep and exhausting incline. ìThere was no one in sight.î All of these parts of the story put pictures in my head, building a sense of isolation. Thats a good thing, for example you want the reader to understand it, and by having discribing words help to fully immerse them in the narrative experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly. One way is that the ìrolling hillsî @MONTH1 let the rider get more tired, constantly challenging his stamina. Another way is the lack of water from severe heat, which poses a constant threat to his well-being. And finally the path you take along the way and how many stops you make along the way can either help or hinder progress. The heat, lack of water, rolling hills, and the advice you get can result badly by affecting the outcome of the entire journey. A rider should make a plan and use determination to get to where they need to go, ensuring they are prepared for the challenges of the environment.

The setting in the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit” profoundly reflects upon the cyclist's journey and the lessons he learns. In the story, a cyclist is riding his bike and takes directions from some old men he meets along the way. Later he realizes the old men probably had no idea that things change overtime, such as roads and landmarks. He says, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left their porches since carter was in office.”(Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist takes the old-timers “shortcut” and it takes forever to reach his destination, leading him through a long and arduous path. At the end he reaches his campsite and another person askes him for directions. This time the cyclist says, “Yes, sir! I own a very good map,” and “I’d always stick to it in the future.” The cyclist’s message is to follow a map, something you know is right and reliable, not a person that @MONTH1 be lying or irresponsible based on outdated knowledge.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him dehydrated and hot, creating a physically demanding ordeal. He was in deserts on a bicycle with his water support running low and rough road with plenty of hills to make it hard for a bike to out come. The harsh, unrelenting sun beat down upon him as he pedaled. he kept going though the heat was outrageous and dehydration beginning to overcome him, pushing his endurance to its very limits in the challenging environment.

I think the boy should ask you directions for the place were he is going to ensure he takes the correct and safest route. He can reach the place without water but that is not a good thing to do, as it would put his health and safety at significant risk. It is always wiser to be prepared and informed before embarking on any journey, especially one that could involve potential hardships.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist’s mood throughout the essay, charting a clear emotional journey. Joe @CAPS1 starts with being happy and confident to determined yet help helpless and then to relief. Joe writes, “Things began well enough… flat roads…” This quote suggests that in the beginning, everything was okay and his spirits were high. He started out with a “smile on the face.” (@NUM1) @CAPS2, things start to change @CAPS1 hits changing terrain, which begins to wear on his optimism. He writes, “…I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This quote states the changing terrain was the first sign of difficulty. He starts to lose water to keep him going, yet he pushes himself determinedly to the next “town”, feeling increasingly helpless. Finally, when the author reaches “Gary & Wilber’s fish camp” he is relived when he sees an old guy sitting, a sign of civilization. The two men say, “know The best way to get There? “Yes sir! I own a very good map.” This reveals that Joe didn t ask for more directions which was his first mistake, and he has learned from his earlier error. In addition, changes in setting can chang a persons mood and attitude, as clearly demonstrated by this cycling experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it is in the desert and it is in the summer, creating an extremely hostile environment. It affect the cyclist because he is riding a bike, which offers no protection from the elements. For exsempl in the story he is running out of water, a critical resource in such a climate. He is starting to git dehyjradid, which severely impacts his physical condition and ability to continue his journey under the scorching sun. The desert setting thus poses a direct and dangerous threat to his well-being.

The setting profoundly affected the cyclist because of the mood it created and how every environmental change happened. For instance, when the setting changed from one location to another, the cyclist felt different, and it really affected his emotional state. Like if the setting was all sunny in a nice, welcoming town then he would feel good and optimistic, but if he was in a dark, foreboding town he wouldn’t feel very happy or safe. So the setting, through its inherent atmosphere, really affected him and his journey's morale.

After some time into his trip he mentioned, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” I believe that this harsh, arid setting had initially gotten him determined to keep on pedaling so he could live and overcome the challenge. But then he started to think he might die from the ordeal, but he wasn't sad or upset about it, he was surprisingly happy and at peace. He had sort of chuckled to himself, because of the absurd fact that he might die simply because he listened to some old men's directions. In my opinion I think he was having the time of his life, finding a strange joy in pedaling through this severe and beautiful setting of California, embracing the experience fully.

Where the cyclist was gave him more disadvantages, then advantages. The few advantages were that their were hills to go down, which provided moments of rest. The disadvantages were far more numerous: hills to go up, his water running out when he is in the middle of no where, the weather being very hot out, and being lost in the vast desert, where he doesn’t have much hope until he see's the factory in the distance. The biggest disadvantage is he is on a bike, and not in a car. So he has no protection from the elements and has to peddle constantly to keep going. But being in the desert on a bike with no water, and you are last, is quite a bad and dangerous situation. He is very lucky that he made it up the final hill or else he would’ve died out there from exposure. And he thought he was seeing things, but it was a good thing he checked it out and found salvation. I think for future reference, one should ride in a car, don’t use a bike in the desert, its not too smart and far too perilous.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist because when all the cyclist is worried about is finding a place with water, all he’s doing is getting scared and panicking, which is directly influenced by his surroundings. In other words, when he’s looking around, the setting he sees is barren like a desert with no buildings or signs of life. The story says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” and when he sees that endless, dry landscape he panics and thinks he’s not gonna make it, which affects him mentally by filling him with dread and desperation. The oppressive environment thus plays a key role in his psychological state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in different ways, often creating perilous situations. The woman who had listened to the older men to get where she was going had made her run out of water and almost died of thirst in the unforgiving landscape. As she was going to this place she had seen a snake, “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake it really did look like a diamondback” which heightened the sense of danger. The harsh conditions and her deteriorating state caused her to start seeing things that wasn’t there, showing how the setting’s features directly impacted her perception and physical well-being.

He was affected by the crippling hills, the rough condition of the road, a snake blocking his path, and a critical lack of water. His water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, which were insufficient for the journey and intensified his thirst. The hills were steep and relentless, draining his energy with each difficult climb. A long snake stretched across the road presented a significant obstacle, causing him to stop and ponder how to get past it safely. Furthermore, the roads were so rough and poorly maintained that traveling over the speed limit of 55 mph was not advisable, adding to the difficulty of his progress. So he was affected in a lot of different ways, not just one, with each challenge compounding the others to make his journey arduous.

The features of the barren desert path make the cyclist quite nervous, but they also fuel his determination to escape them. He passes through ghost towns and abandoned buildings, encountering diamondback snakes along the way. These are images traditionally associated with being lost in the deserts, and they would be enough to instill fear in most anyone travelling alone. The author even remarks that sadists are probably finding his story pleasing. He often mentions fears of dropping dead, being eaten by vultures, and, at one point, even wishing death upon himself via choking, albeit jokingly. And yet he was determined to live. In spite of the odds stacked against him, he moved on, even after losing what he believed to be his last burst of energy. He even maintains a sense of humor throughout, writing of a diary entry that would be left behind, one that remarks on the wisdom of old men. In the end, when he finds a place to rest, he turns the entire harrowing experience into a lesson he’ll surely abide by for the future: always follow the map.

The cyclist is profoundly affected by the intense heat, the challenging hills, and the complete lack of people. For example, the cyclist was growing dangerously short on water and had wide rings of dried sweat on his shirt, clear signs of severe dehydration, and he feared he could drop from heatstroke at any moment. The steep and numerous hills must have forced him to use significantly more energy, slowing his progress and increasing his exhaustion. Lastly, the land was devoid of people; the towns he passed were empty and silent. If the towns still had people, the cyclist wouldn't have been as affected by the setting, as he could have sought aid, directions, or at least the comfort of human presence.

Features of any setting affect what you do and how you do it, and in this case, the features affect the cyclist through water scarcity, the absence of help, and concerns for his safety. The quote, “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirsty by allowing what spit you have to circulate,” shows his desperate need for water, revealing he resorted to sucking on a rock to stimulate his own saliva. The rough terrain and the abandoned road the old men sent him on, which was out of date, made him unable to ask for directions and left him uncertain if he was even travelling correctly. Along the road he meets a snake, a dangerous encounter. Being so far away from civilization, if he was to have gotten bit then he would have had no one to help save him from dying on the side of the road. Also, if he was to have a heatstroke, he had no water and no one to call for help. Safety, help, and water are all critical factors which contribute to the features of the setting, and they profoundly affect the cyclist's journey and his chances of survival.

The features of the setting make the ride for the cyclist very hard and dangerous. It has a lot of hills, which would make him use more energy with every arduous climb. Also, it is a desert, so it is very hot and dry, with a relentless sun beating down. This makes the author need more water than he normally would, a resource that was in short supply. The author stated, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” a time known for extreme heat. The author knew that it was very dangerous to travel there without sufficient water, as he said, “I could drop from heatstroke,” a real and constant fear. If the setting had been cooler and less arid, there would not have been so much danger, making the environment itself his greatest adversary.

The cyclist’s features around him affected him negatively. He was cycling through “the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1), a landscape defined by its harsh, arid conditions. His water bottle was slowly running out, and the only town he came to that had water had water that tasted like battery acid, offering no true relief. Events seemed pretty bad, until the speaker became elated when they saw a @ORGANIZATION1 factory, a beacon of potential salvation. The author was thirsty and the side of the building had “A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth” (Kurmaskie @NUM1), a cruel and tantalizing mirage. The building was abandoned, dashing his hopes for sustenance. The speaker then states “Somehow  I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope” (Kurmaskie @NUM3). He lost hope after that landscape, and he pretty much gave up, defeated by the environment. The landscape or features affected the author very negatively due to the lack of water, demonstrating how a setting can directly shape a traveler's morale and physical state.

The setting affects the cyclist because there were lots of hills and very little water. The challenging terrain of the hills demanded constant physical exertion, sapping his energy with each difficult ascent. Combined with the scarcity of water in the arid environment, these geographic features created a situation of extreme physical distress. The relentless climbs under the sun intensified his thirst, making the lack of a reliable water source even more critical. Ultimately, the combination of these harsh features—the demanding hills and the severe dehydration—profoundly impacted his ability to continue his journey.

The cyclist in the story "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, is heavily affected by the features of the setting in the story. First is the ‘shortcut’ that is suggested to get to @CAPS1, which naturally just ends up separating him from all other people and putting him in the middle of nowhere with a limited supply of water, isolating him in a vast, empty landscape. His water shortage is the second thing that affects him because it makes him despair and feel that he is about to collapse and die, a feeling compounded by his solitude. In the story, he says: ‘It really didn’t matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.’ This shows that the features of the setting made him feel hopeless, as the unforgiving environment convinced him of his impending demise.

Many features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie. One feature that affected the character was the heat of the sun, which intensified the harshness of his journey. The narration states “The sun was beginning to beat down” (@CAPS1), signaling the start of an increasingly oppressive and draining day. This relentless heat would have accelerated his dehydration, making his physical struggle more severe. The rising temperature thus acted as a key environmental pressure, directly influencing his deteriorating condition and adding to the overall challenge of his ride through the desert.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”. In the story it says, "I was traveling through the high desert of California in June." This is telling the reader that the weather was hot and you need a lot of water here to survive, especially if you are riding a bike or working, highlighting the inherent danger of the location. Later on in the story it says, "I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." This quote gives the reader information and tells us that the cyclist is having a hard time surviving through the harsh features of the setting, as his physical coordination is failing. In California deserts I know from prior knowledge it is hot and dry, especially in the summer, creating a perilous environment for any strenuous activity. If you are working outside, like the cyclist in this story is, and you do not have water to drink, you will get dehydrated which eventually leads to death, a real threat the cyclist faces. The author does a good job showing the readers how the setting affects the cyclist by illustrating the direct link between the arid landscape and the protagonist's physical decline.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One significant thing is the water, or rather the lack of it. There is little water to be found, and what little he encountered was boiling hot. He took a small taste of it, and he said “It tasted like battery acid,” which was completely unpalatable. To me, if the water is that hot, one should not even consider tasting it. Another impactful thing is the land itself. The land went from being straight and flat to becoming increasingly hilly and difficult. That change in terrain started slowing him down considerably, making his progress a struggle. Last, is the factor of day time. It started turning dark while he was still biking, and he was determined to get as far as he could before nightfall completely halted his journey. These environmental challenges collectively shaped his difficult experience on the road.

The features in the setting profoundly affected the cyclist, who found himself getting tired very easily because he was biking across the desert in the intense heat of June. There are no rivers or streams in that particular desert, so he couldn’t get any water to cool down or rehydrate, which worsened his fatigue. It is so exceptionally hot out there that his vision was impaired; he couldn’t see very well because of all the sweat that persistently dripped into his eyes, stinging and blurring his sight. Also, there are no other people anywhere out there because of how oppressively hot it is, leaving him completely isolated in the vast, empty landscape. This profound solitude and the harsh climatic conditions made his journey an immense physical and mental trial.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting deeply affected the cyclist both mentally and physically. When the setting was pleasant and the surroundings were nice, he naturally had a positive outlook on his journey and was full of energy, feeling motivated to continue. Later in the essay, however, as the setting grew less appealing and became more treacherous with difficult terrain and harsh conditions, the cyclist correspondingly grew weary and increasingly distressed. This direct correlation shows how the external environment can dictate a traveler's internal state, ultimately shaping the entire experience of the journey from a hopeful beginning to a grueling test of endurance.

A cyclist always has to face many problems that are dictated by the environment, such as the weather and the condition of the road, among other external factors. Inclement weather, like heavy rain or extreme heat, can make a journey dangerous and exhausting, while a poorly maintained road with potholes or debris presents a constant physical challenge to navigate. These elements are ever-present concerns that require constant adaptation and resilience from any rider. Therefore, overcoming these persistent obstacles is a fundamental part of the cycling experience, demanding both preparation and fortitude from anyone who undertakes a long-distance ride.

The features in the setting affected the cyclist in many ways during his arduous journey. The first way the features in the setting affected the cyclist is that the whole trail was completely deserted, leaving him entirely alone with no access to water or supplies. In the story it says, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time – say, before the last world war – but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This quote effectively explains that he was profoundly alone and that the first town he visited was utterly deserted, offering no respite. The next example of how the features and the settings impacted him further illustrates the profound challenges of his solitary trek through the barren landscape, where every mile presented a new hardship to overcome.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist profoundly; the pervasive lack of water made him deeply tired and a bit delusional, his mind beginning to play tricks on him. The complete absence of shade from the relentless sun dramatically increased the rate of his dehydration, sapping his strength with every passing mile. The rough, uneven road surface made it incredibly hard to maintain his balance, demanding constant physical effort. And the meager snack he had consumed earlier seemed to have slowed him down rather than providing energy. In his weakened state, he genuinely thought that he was going to die, a terrifying conviction born directly from his harsh environment.

The setting of the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" is very important to the events that occurred in the story. For example, the story was set on a long, open highway where the posted speed limit was set at a high velocity which the cyclist was only able to do a fraction of on his bicycle. This is significant to the events of the story because since he was pushing himself to maintain this considerable speed, which by the way is a lot for a cyclist, it led to him almost reaching a state of severe dehydration. Plus, the route was hilly, adding to the physical strain. This grueling combination of factors ultimately led to the extreme exhaustion of the cyclist, so one could see that the setting is very important to the outcome of the story.

The setting is in a California desert, which isn’t really the coolest of places to be, especially in terms of its extreme temperature. The heat is a constant, oppressive force, bearing down on the landscape and anyone traversing it. This intense warmth defines the atmosphere and the challenges faced there, making it a central feature of the environment. The sheer heat of the location fundamentally shapes the experience within the narrative.

At the beginning of his journey, the cyclist is relaxed and appreciative of the features of his environment. He says, “I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening,” indicating a peaceful state of mind. At a campground in the foothills, the setting is calming and relaxing, offering a gentle start. At the first deserted town, the setting becomes shocking, but still humorous to the cyclist, though he starts to get a little nervous. After looking around he says, “this sight was troubling.” The cyclist's trip gets decidedly worse when he reads the description for the next town and finds that the “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This more demanding part of his journey affects him the most, draining his energy. His environment and the features of the land have made him tired and thirsty, proving that the setting has a major role in determining a cyclist's experience.

In the essay "Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting is integral to how the cyclist feels and behaves. The cyclist feels a growing desperation as the setting around him gets progressively more bleak and unforgiving. In the beginning of the trip, the cyclist encounters a ghost town and remarks, "I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on." The cyclist is still thinking positively and with humor at this point in the essay. A while later, the cyclist comes across another abandoned set of buildings, and he feels that this sight is "troubling." While the cyclist is now worried, he is not yet fully depressive and pessimistic. Farther down the road, the terrain changes drastically, and he sees the sign that gives the essay its name. "The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water depleting 12," he notes, adding, "Sometimes life’s road can feel so cruel." The cyclist’s surroundings get progressively worse as he rides on, but eventually he finds a lone building with working water. He is so overjoyed by this discovery that he wants to find the owners and kiss them out of sheer gratitude for the relief it provides.

Some features of the setting that affect the cyclist is he is riding a bike through the desert. He says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” So he was scorching hot pedaling a bike under a relentless sun. The road became bumpy and curvy, a challenging surface for any rider. A sign had said “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted Speed limit.” The speed limit was @NUM1 and he was going @NUM2 so it must have been hard to get over all the bumps, jolting him with every turn of the wheel. The lastly he comes across a poisonous snake that blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. So him, dehydrated and fatigued, trying to get around a snake would be terrifying, a final obstacle in a harsh landscape. So on his @CAPS1 the setting doesn’t help him much, presenting one difficulty after another.

The cyclist ran into many issues in his/her travel to @LOCATION1. They had to endure many hardships such as a profound lack of water, the disorientation of being lost, and the immense desert heat, plus minor things like snakes and poor road conditions. The setting of the California desert in June was the most intense hardship, an unyielding adversary. That and the lack of water created a desperate situation. Though the heat started playing with the cyclists’ brain by making them see mirages, etc., distorting their perception of reality. The heat and entire setting made the cyclists’ travel much harder, testing their physical and mental limits to the extreme.

The setting affect the cyclist because in the hot heat of California in June which nobody wants to be outside, the environment was inherently hostile. But first, was the heat which took a lot out of his body while trying to keep it cool, sapping his energy with every passing mile. Then came the factor of which he had very little water when he reached the first town and in the story it said, “A tar like substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” So now he has no cool water to drink when he says, “Not two miles into the next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” So the cyclist has very little water and is now having to endure the hardest part of the ride, a cruel combination of challenges. Then later on he makes a mention to change a paragraph if he loss consciousness, showing his deteriorating state. Also he talked about him might getting a heatstroke, a real and dangerous possibility. Hinting to the fact that the setting he was in was affecting him in many different ways, from his physical stamina to his very sense of awareness.

The setting of the essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit," is very dry, sandy, hot, and deserted, a vast and empty landscape. On his way to Yosemite he takes a “short cut" from so he do me through the desert, a decision that would define his journey. When he first leaves its in a hot and flat part of the desert. His mood is high and her has confidence, feeling optimistic about the ride ahead. “Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile of my face.” With this he arrives at the first “town” but hes wasn’t worried he had bad plenty of water he moves on, still feeling prepared. The terrain starts working against him in his search for water, becoming more difficult and demanding. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills a large high way sign jumped out at he. It read: Rough Road Ahead : Do not Exceed posted speed limit.” This lowers his confidence, especially because everything is deserted and if he has a heat stroke no one would he around to find him, a lonely and frightening thought. He keeps up his determination we he sees the factory yet he moves on, pushing through the adversity. When he see the first comp he is overwhelmed with relief and the terrain flattens out again, offering a brief respite. When asked if he need direction he say he has his own map so he can keep stick to the terrain he knows is rest, regaining a sense of control. He can keep his hopes for himself and follow a true set of directions, concluding his arduous trek with hard-won self-reliance.

Anyone who has ever rode a bike knows how relaxing it can truly be, but when you are forced to ride miles and miles on @CAPS3 terrain without any water, relaxation feels like an oasis, a distant dream. @CAPS1 through beat-up roads with dryness all around you really puts a damper on your experience, transforming a pleasurable activity into a grueling test. @CAPS2 it extends your need for thirst by enhancing the amount of dryness in the air and the amount of energy you are having to expend just to keep moving. The ability to block all of that out and trying to focus on something easier to handle is exactly what you want to do in these situations, a necessary mental trick for survival. @CAPS3 terrain can really build character into a cyclist, forging resilience through adversity, but adding the fact the amount of water he had and the dryness around him, it sounds like torture, pushing the limits of human endurance. I can only hope that if I ever become a cyclist, I never have to endure this kind of situation, a journey defined more by suffering than by scenery.

The cyclist, Joe Kurmaskie, had a rough time traveling to Yosemite National Park. Granted he was misled, but if the conditions of the terrain and if the climate were working for him it would have made life a whole lot easier. Not only was it hot, being in a desert in California in June, but he only had one water bottle. One water bottle might have lasted a little longer if it was a straight shot through, but it wasnít. The roads went up, down, there were hills, there were towns-ghost towns at that, offering no supplies or respite. The only water he could pump from the pump was scalding hot and tasted acidic, making it undrinkable. Also, he wouldnít have lost as much energy if it was a straight shot, but the constant elevation changes were draining. Itís easy to say that he literally roughed it, having to resort to putting rocks in his mouth to circulate saliva in a desperate attempt to stave off thirst. All in all, he was very determined to work through the very unfortunate conditions he had working against him, and very lucky to survive it.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the fact that he is pedaling a bike through the high deserts of California in June, make the intensity level of the story very high. The oppressive, dry heat of the desert sun significantly increases the physical challenge and danger of the journey. If it would have been a cooler month and there was a nice breeze it would be different, transforming the arduous trek into a potentially pleasant ride. The harshness of the environment is therefore a central element that defines the entire experience for the rider.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by the lack of water, a poisonous snake, and the condition of the road. For example, the lack of water affected the cyclist because he couldn't make it without water; he could have passed out from severe dehydration if he didn't have any. Another example of how the setting affected the cyclist would be the poisonous snake; if he would have gotten bitten he could have died, cause there would be nobody around to help him in the remote location. And the last example of how the setting affected him would be the condition of the road because it made it tougher for the cyclist to get to his destination with its steep hills and windy rounds. This is how I think the setting profoundly affected the cyclist and his difficult journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that if itís hot and you're riding a long way you need a lot of water so you donít become dehydrated and suffer from heat exhaustion. Also, the bright, glaring sun can affect your vision cause you are looking directly at it or its reflection on the pavement for long periods. Another way a cyclist can get affected by the setting is because what if the road is all bumpy and just not in good shape; it can affect the way they ride their bike, causing physical strain and making it harder to maintain control and speed. These environmental factors combine to create a significant challenge for any rider.

The story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie had some statements that were kind of pointless to put in. One of the sentences in the essay had a couple of words that donít need to be used. In the sentence, "about forty miles into the pedal, I arrive at the first ìtown,î" I donít think the phrase ìinto the pedalî needs to be in there because its not describing anything crucial and the sentence would be clearer without it. This kind of unnecessary wording can slightly disrupt the flow of the narrative for the reader. While the overall story is engaging, such minor edits could improve its conciseness and impact.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, primarily through the harsh desert environment. The cyclist is out in the desert, in two-hundred degree weather with very little water, which creates a severe physical challenge. Also, the cyclist didn't have a map and he asked for directions from someone that hasn't left their porch since Carter was in office, leading him astray. The quote, ''Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn`t been off their porch in decades,'' powerfully illustrates how the setting, with its extreme heat and desolation, can endanger him. This experience shows how the physical landscape and the unreliable information from isolated locals directly impacted his journey. In conclusion, that is how the features of the setting affected the cyclist, putting his health and progress at risk.

The setting of the story is very desert-like, characterized by intense heat and vast, arid landscapes, which forced the cyclist to push himself to his physical limits. The conditions on the road are very rough, with sharp turns and challenging terrain that test his endurance. At one point in the story, he gets a boost of energy and pedals as hard as he can down a hill, enjoying a moment of speed and relative ease, before he eventually relaxes and coasts, finding a brief respite from his exertions. This cycle of strenuous effort and momentary relief is dictated entirely by the setting. This description of the setting and its demands provides a summary of the story's central physical conflict.

The setting affected the cyclist profoundly because of the condition of his surroundings. The intense heat caused him to become dehydrated more quickly, so he needed more water and had to carefully manage his limited supply. Furthermore, there were a lot of steep hills, which forced him to pedal harder and use significantly more energy to reach the top of each ascent, draining his stamina. In contrast to these hardships, the setting also offered a positive aspect; there were no cars, buildings, or smog, just pure nature. This provided a peaceful and relaxful ride on the bike at times, offering a mental reprieve. That is how the setting, with its mix of physical challenges and natural tranquility, affects the cyclist throughout his journey.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist in a great way, as his journey would not be as difficult if these factors had not crossed his path. Climate, location, and population all have a significant effect on him. In the story, it is told that the cyclist is in the dry climate of California, in the heat of June, with a severe lack of water, so he must pace his sips carefully. There are also very few towns, making it hard to get good advice and supplies. The cyclist also comes across a snake, showing he is affected by the native wild life. The dry climate and lack of water affects him by seeding doubt; he is constantly worried about passing out and dying of dehydration. He also gets doubts when he sees the road signs reminding him how slow he is going. The snake also has a depressing effect, highlighting the dangers on his journey. All of these things in the setting affected the cyclist, challenging him mentally and physically. His journey does teach you, though, that through determination you will be rewarded, as you have to want things bad enough and put the effort into it. The author also teaches you to always maintain a positive attitude to achieve success despite the obstacles.

The features and settings affected the cyclist because of all the inherent dangers of his undertaking. He initially took advice from old people who encouraged him to do it, but even though it started out good, almost nothing lasts forever. He's riding his bike in the middle of summer with little water and in the harsh desert environment, which poses a constant threat. He runs into towns that are abandoned, and a sign warns him that the next town is only a few miles away but that the road ahead is literally going to be rough. His situation seems dire when he gets to another town that was also abandoned, testing his morale. However, he eventually found hope upon seeing a man in a chair, a sign of life that renewed his spirit and showed that perseverance can lead to a breakthrough.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by not being in town, creating a sense of unfamiliarity and isolation. I say this because the cyclist talks about “old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This statement implies that the local advice he receives is outdated, which means he doesn't really know where he's at or what to expect from the remote landscape. The unfamiliar terrain, far from any urban center, directly challenges his journey and his sense of direction, ultimately shaping his difficult experience.

In the cyclist's journey to Yosemite, several factors hinder him from reaching it. The first is obviously the false information given to him by the elders, which misdirects his route. The second is that because the information wasn't true, the cyclist had an insufficient amount of water for the actual distance, and this shortage made him dehydrated and weak. The last is the fact that the route given to him included obstacles such as snakes, rocky roads, and old ghost towns and abandoned buildings, which made the cyclist less confident in his ability to proceed. Those are the key features of the setting which affected the cyclist and his progress toward his destination.

The setting affects the cyclist significantly, primarily because he should have stuck to his own map instead of deviating from his planned route. He also should have packed an extra bottle of water to prepare for the unexpected challenges of the arid landscape. Ultimately, he learns a crucial lesson about not taking any advice from people that haven't left the porch in years, as their knowledge of the area is limited and unreliable. This reliance on poor guidance, combined with his own lack of preparation, is how the setting directly impacts his journey.

The setting affects the cyclist's mood in the story as the cyclist takes a shortcut with many abandoned towns and buildings as well as a bumpy terrain. When he came to a fork in his path that had a water pump, he immediately began to pump it, but the water was not good for drinking. He was determined to make it to the next town, stating, “I could make that.” Because of the ghost town and the old pump, he had to continue on without relief. When the cyclist came to a sign in the road warning him about the road ahead, he began to get depressed, recalling, “I was sad.” Finally, when he reached the more welcoming locations of Fish Camp, he was thankful and wanted to show his gratitude. The setting can affect a cyclist by his mood; at first the cyclist is determined, but as the setting gets worse, his mood and hopes go down the drain. At the end, when the setting is bright and hospitable, so is his mood, concluding the journey on a positive note.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was thirsty and it was hot, and he was almost out of water. The harsh environment nearly led to a dire outcome when, while he was drinking the last of his water, he hit a bump and a bit of spit got lodged in his throat, causing a moment of panic. Furthermore, the tiring hills of the landscape seemed to never end, sapping his energy and prolonging his exposure to the difficult conditions. This combination of heat, thirst, and exhausting terrain created a severe challenge that profoundly impacted his physical state and his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he was not prepared in the beginning. The cyclist got directions from an old man who had not left his porch in years, so he would not know what had changed in the landscape. Then the cyclist starts his journey with not a lot of water, which was a critical oversight. When he got to the second town, he notes, “I notice the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This quote means that he was not expecting hills, as he thought it was going to be a flat way the entire journey. Also in the high degree heat with a limited water supply, he could not easily ride up and down the hills, which required more effort. Going down the hills gave him a brief break from the strenuous climbing. That is how the cyclist was profoundly affected by the settings features, learning a hard lesson about preparation.

A lot of factors affected the cyclist throughout his journey. Temperature, terrain, and directions all gave the cyclist doubt and challenged his resolve. The intense temperature through the high deserts of California left the cyclist feeling hot, parched, and irritable, sapping his energy. Through the story, he had all but a few sips of his water left, which heightened his anxiety. Knowing you are running low on water leads one “to feel sorry for himself,” as the text states. The cyclist had biked so far that the terrain started to change from flat to “rolling hills,” a significant shift. This could impact someone greatly who has never biked on different levels before, demanding new physical adaptations. Lastly, the feeling of hopelessness could have affected him the most, as morale is crucial. Not believing in yourself is the hardest thing to overcome on such a demanding trip. Having just leisurely taken instructions from an old man who was out of touch cost the cyclist hours of mental and physical torture. The author did a great job using hyperbole to exaggerate the cyclist's feeling of lost hope, emphasizing his despair. He also used very detailed text to paint the reader a vivid picture of the harsh environment. These literary elements made it easier for me to understand the profound effect of the temperature, terrain, and hope had on the bicyclist, illustrating how setting shapes experience.

The features of the setting really affect the cyclist, shaping his experience and leading him into danger. He is led into false pretenses by the immediate surroundings, which appear more manageable than they truly are. Little does he know that the deceptive landscape would bring him into serious peril, testing his limits. When he comes to a rock in the road and finds that the water pumps are not working, he realizes he is in serious danger, with his resources failing. In the reading it says, “The sun was beginning to heat down, but it hardly noticed. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” This shows how the setting, specifically the appealing idea of his destination, let the cyclist's mind wander so much that he did not even realize the immediate, oppressive heat, demonstrating the power of mental escape. This disconnect between expectation and reality ultimately underscores how the environment dictated his ordeal.

In the short story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the author expresses how the features of the setting, like the pervasive lack of water and the inability to find help, affect the cyclist profoundly. During his time of need, the cyclist says, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men and their wisdom.” This shows the cyclist confronting a severe lack of necessities in the features around him and is letting his pride fall away, completely giving up on hope. When the cyclist later finds hope at a crucial moment, his perspective shifts, “And drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait.” The cyclist was astonished by what he had stumbled onto and deeply appreciated that he was still alive after his harrowing experience. The cyclist should not have taken the old people's advice for granted, but he will now look onto people’s sense of directions with much greater caution and skepticism, having learned from his misadventure.

Setting affects many things in stories, establishing the context for the characters' challenges. For example, he said he was doing 55 miles, but the oppressive heat made such a distance feel insurmountable, demonstrating how the environment directly impeded his progress and shaped his entire experience.

The setting in the story was the "high deserts of California in June," a place known for its intense, dry heat. The cyclist was running low on his water supply, so he stops and pumps water from an old water pump, but all he gets is this acid taste, which was undrinkable. So he is on his way to the nearest town which is @NUM1 miles away and he thinks he can make it, clinging to that hope. During this time the cyclist starts loosing hope, his initial confidence shattered. He thinks that he is going to die of dehydration and the birds are going to pick him apart, a grim and vivid fear. He ran into the shop and took long, desperate drinks from the sink in the bathroom, quenching his terrible thirst. When he went out of the store an older gentle men asked him if he needed help and he said no I have a really good map, perhaps still trying to maintain a semblance of control. The features of the setting where the cyclist is traveling affect them very drastically, as the environment is harsh and unforgiving. They need a consistent water supply and if they donít have one they might dehydrate or even die, which is a constant danger in such a climate. They need shade trees because it keeps the sun from beaming down on them so hard, offering a crucial respite from the heat. They also need to cycle when its not as hot outside, perhaps during the early morning or late evening, so that just incase there water gets low there is a better chance of survival by reducing fluid loss. It would be great if there was someone with you to help if you get hurt, providing both practical aid and moral support. There should be buildings near by just incase of an emergency, such as a shop or a ranger station where one can find shelter and supplies. It might even be good to carry a cell phone for calling for help if one becomes stranded or injured, a modern safety precaution in a primitive landscape. Ultimately, being prepared for the setting's challenges is essential for a cyclist's safety and well-being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in more than one way, each element contributing to his mental and physical state. The first features were a ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold in the lamest mule, all presenting a picture of abandonment. These items gave the cyclist a feeling of doubts about his location and the accuracy of his directions. They made him begin to think he had taken the wrong route when he saw these things were outdated and no longer in use. Then, he couldnít get any cold, clean water out of the pumps to save his life, which was a severe disappointment. This was the first obstacle which affected him, deepening his anxiety. The next features of the setting which caused a problem were the tumbleweeds and "a ridiculously large snake," adding elements of surprise and potential danger. They made the cyclist scared and caused him to go around these things cautiously. You can tell he wass scared because he quoted ìI eased past,î indicating a careful and fearful movement. When the flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills, the cyclistís journey became exhausting, never ending, and difficult, sapping his remaining energy. Two more things affected the cyclist significantly. These two things consist of the signs he encountered. One of which read ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" and the other ìGARY AND WILBER'S FISH-IF you want bait for the big ones, weíre your BEST BET." The first sign affected him in a negative way and caused him to become a little angry and frustrated because he was tired and dehydrated and the rough road ahead gave him no hope for an easier path. The second sign led him to water which was the one thing that would make things better so it had a positive affect, offering salvation. These are the various features that had an affect on the cyclist throughout his challenging journey.

The setting affected the cyclist profoundly, primarily due to the changes in terrain that he encountered. The author wrote, ìI tolld on" (Kurmaskie @NUM1), suggesting a slow, laborious struggle. The cyclist had experienced some hard obstacles on his ride to Yosemite, making his journey far more challenging than anticipated. Where they said there would be a bustling town it was more like a ghost town, deserted and offering no resources. This meant he was running out of it fast, and since the old men had given him directions through places that were no longer open he couldnít get more water, leading to a critical shortage. The cyclist also had to go over roads that were in bad condition, @CAPS1 slowed him down even more, adding physical strain to his mental distress. Those features of the setting affected the cyclist a lot on his trip, turning an adventure into a fight for basic necessities and a test of survival.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. In the beginning, he cannot get water from the arid environment and becomes dehydrated, then, he goes on a rough ride over uneven terrain and loses more energy. Then he finds the bait left by the roadside and gets a small amount of water. All of these environmental factors greatly affect the cyclist's physical condition throughout his journey.

The setting of the cyclist’s journey effected him because it was a hot desert in california. The bicyclist was riding to Yosemite National Park and on the way ran out of water. "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." In the story “Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affected the cyclist a lot. At first, when the cyclist set off in the morning, the conditions were great. It was breezy with shade from trees and rivers providing cool water. Then, after a few hours, the cyclist was in the exposed desert with bumpy hills. In the story, the speaker states, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they introduce significant obstacles that doubt or lessen his chances for survival, creating a constant state of peril. The harsh environment, with its extreme heat and desolate landscape, constantly challenges his resolve. However, the cyclist is fueled by a powerful determination, a will that pushes him to persevere through each hardship. This inner strength allows him to overcome the external threats, and so he ultimately survives the ordeal, proving his resilience against the unforgiving setting.

In the essay, the features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist, primarily through the oppressive heat and scarcity of resources. One feature that significantly affects him is his critical lack of water, as described: "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." The lack of water made him very desperate, especially when he came upon the Welch’s grape juice factory. The building—abandoned years earlier—had been a Welch’s grape juice factory and bottling plant, a cruel irony that deepened his thirst. This desperation, after he had come to the abandoned factory, was followed by profound disappointment and a vague sense of hopelessness expressed by the phrase, "I hung my head," after he had found the empty building. These environmental details are some of the key features of the setting that affect the cyclist, shaping his emotional and physical journey.

The cyclist faces numerous challenges that explain why he isn't doing so well on his journey. I said no water because he is clearly dehydrated but needs to conserve his remaining water, creating a terrible dilemma. Also, he could easily die from heat exhaustion under the relentless sun. I also cited the rough terrain because he could fall on the jagged rocks and get seriously hurt with no one around to help him for miles. And to top it off, he took navigation info from old people that didn’t know what they were talking about, leading him astray. These are all concrete examples from the essay that support my writing about the difficulties imposed by the setting.

In the story by Joe Kurmaskie, it tells about a cyclist's formidable challenge through the heated deserts of California in June. The cyclist had started out with confidence, followed by a stubborn determination, then a fleeting sense of relief upon finding any landmark. The setting deeply affected the cyclist both physically and mentally throughout this trial. First, listening to the old men was a stupid miscalculation, then taking the trip without being certain if he would have enough water was a grave risk, and lastly, traveling through the desert in June was inherently dangerous. He started getting a little doubtful with himself as well, and that mental state won’t help much with bringing success to the trip. Once he had made it to a fish camp, an old man even older than the men who gave him the false information told him he knew how to get to Yosemite, but the young man did the best thing and told him he already knew how to get there, refusing to be misled again. He didn’t need to be traveling out in the desert heat for hours; that’s just unhealthy and a testament to the extreme conditions he endured.

A cyclist is affected by many things when riding, most being features of the setting that create constant physical demands. One feature of the setting that can have a major affect is the terrain itself. If the terrain is rough and uneven, then the cyclist could have a more difficult time maintaining control of the bike, especially if he is not a professional rider with extensive experience. For example, the author of the essay had a hard time on the rougher roads, partly due to his level of experience, which made the journey more perilous. Another aspect of the environment that can have an affect on a cyclist is the climate and weather. Most people who go cycling regularly know how to dress for it to keep their body at a comfortable temperature, but sometimes the weather plays tricks on us, changing without warning. The cyclist could get caught in a sudden heat wave or an unexpected drop in temperature, each posing a unique threat to his endurance and safety.

The features of the setting enhance the cyclist’s desperate spirit. Throughout the whole journey the cyclist is by himself and there are no people, cars, or buildings around, creating a profound sense of isolation. This made him much more desperate because if he would fall from dehydration there would be no one to help him and he would just die, alone in the vast emptiness. Also, he came upon things such as “Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant” which got his hopes up for potential aid or resources, but would soon crush his spirits upon finding it abandoned and useless. These events made him much more desperate because he had no support from anywhere and nothing to fall back on in a life or death situation, highlighting his complete vulnerability.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. First of all as he was riding about @NUM1 miles up the road, he saw that the terrain was changing and that scared him, he says “This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly” (kurmaskie @NUM2). He is saying that as the things around him began to change the more he got scared, and the unfamiliar landscape fueled his anxiety. And he kept drinking a lot of water just to bring down his fear, using it as a psychological crutch. Another example is after he had left the sign that told him not to pass. He says “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (kurmaskie @NUM3). This is also an example of fear that started over coming him, when he saw even more changes presenting new, unknown challenges. He wasn’t going to stop because of the road changes and the fact that his water was almost gone he still had the courage to go further, driven by a determined will. The setting brought him fear but he made it through, demonstrating his resilience against the intimidating environment.

In the story the cyclist had ran out of water, a critical situation in the harsh environment. He had mentioned it tasted like battery acid, indicating the poor quality of his last reserves. Now if you saw that you would think of no water or shade or nothing because the desert is put to image when you hear those descriptions, a place defined by its scarcity and extreme conditions that test human limits.

The features of the setting, in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affects the cyclist. The setting affect him both physically and mentally, creating a dual burden. An example of this is when he sees the abandoned Welch's factory and sees the picture of a boy "pour a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth". This made him hang his head as he rode on, the cruel irony deepening his sense of deprivation. He is also thinking to himself that he will die out here, a thought born from the relentless mental toll of the landscape. This is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, intertwining his physical decline with psychological despair.

In the passage DO Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit the desertís feature did not have any positive affects on the cyclist. The desert contained "rolling hills." The features of the settings effect the cyclist by obstacles in the settings. A obstacle is a object in the way of you and were your trying to go. In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit”, the setting affects the way that the cyclist rides. In this story, the setting is out in nowhere with no water, and all he can see is roads. This affects the cyclist because he is hungry, thirsty, and now he's about to go down a really steep hill with fear of crashing and seriously injuring himself with no one around to get help from. The setting of nowhere, with its vast emptiness and absence of any signs of life, creates a profound sense of vulnerability and danger for the cyclist, intensifying his physical discomfort and mental anxiety as he faces the treacherous descent alone.

The features in the story tell me that it was in a very dry, not populated area. It says that there were rolling hills, in a desert of California, and that it was dry. I think those things affected the cyclist by dehydrating him. Going up and down hills can be very tiring, especially when you don’t have a lot of water left, and need to save some. The quote “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” tells me a lot about the story. In a desert in California in June during the summer is a very brave and stupid thing to do. It is twice as hot during the summer, and the relentless sun and dry air would rapidly sap his strength, making the challenging terrain even more exhausting and perilous for a cyclist with dwindling water supplies.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist by not having good directions from old timers.
