Because the road might have changed and the old timers do not know because they been sitting on their porches all the time. This misguided advice directly impacts his journey, leading him to rely on outdated information in an unfamiliar landscape, which is why I think the setting affects the cyclist so significantly.

In the essay entitled “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” It talks about a gentlemen who is riding a bike to “Yosemite” and he does not know exactly how to get there. So he stops and ask some old folks and he says “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This means they are not familiar with the changes to the roads. After he leaves the old-folks he continues on his long hot journey. He begins to run out of water and so he begins to panic. Next he comes to the sign that said “Rough Road Ahead,” a warning that underscores how the isolated and unforgiving setting, combined with his poor directions, has led him into a difficult and hazardous situation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it is so hot the cyclist keeps drinking and sweating water so he is really worn down from dehydration and fatigue. Also just the feeling of how unsafe it is out there contributes to his distress. Like how he saw a ridiculously large snake or how it just keep getting hotter, these elements of the harsh environment compound his physical exhaustion and amplify his sense of isolation and danger throughout his journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting had a significant affect on the cyclist. The setting and the various features affected him not only physically, but mentally as well. The harsh environment caused him to doubt himself and the men who gave him directions, and it also kept him from having the energy needed to get to where he was going. Where the cyclist was riding, in the California desert, affected him physically. It was intensely hot, and he had no water. This caused him to become profoundly tired and deeply frustrated. The setting affected him emotionally as well. He started off fine and determined, but as he went on, and as the road slowly changed to steep hills, he began to get frustrated and angred that he had listened to the men. As he saw no buildings in sight for many miles, he began to lose his determination as well as his hope. Lastly, when he saw the sign for “Gary and Fish Camp” he started to regain a small amount of hope and become less frustrated. The setting and features of the essay affected the cyclist not only physically, but mentally as well. He started off determined, then as the setting changed he became doubtful and frustrated. In the end, he turned out satisfied as the setting finally seemed more hopeful and his goal appeared within reach.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways throughout his difficult journey. The text first mentions that, “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or a structure of any kind.” This profound isolation shows that the cyclist felt in saccure and was starting to upset him, amplifying his loneliness. Another example from the text that describes the cyclist's experience is, “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me.” You can see through the cyclists eyes that he was frustrated that the water from the pumps were lame and undrinkable. This also could have sparked fear in the cyclist because he was running out of water, a critical resource. He was terrified that since the water tasted like, “battery acid,” that he wouldn’t last much longer in the oppressive heat. In conclusion, the features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, from his emotional state to his physical well-being.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” many of the features of the setting affect the cyclist on his arduous journey. The rusty water pump, the ominous highway sign, and the abandoned juice factory all seemed to make his trip more difficult than it already was. First of all, when the author stumbles along a “ramshackle shed” surrounded by “several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lames mule”, he is anylous to check the pump for well-needed water. When he finds that he is out of luck and cannot drink the bitter tasting water, his hope droop a little. It is as if the sun were taunting him, telling him that he can’t make it through the desert. Secondly, he passes a large road sign reading “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”. Once again he begins to feel hopeless, but then turns his angst into a fierce determination to finish his journey. He says “sometimes life can be so cruel” as he notices the speed limit to be high, but he continues on, pedaling hard against the challenging terrain. Lastly, the author sees a lone building in the distance and almost doesn’t believe his eyes. It turns out to be not only his last hope for water, but an abandoned grape juice factory. He reflect on the irony of his position by saying that his situation “should please all sadists” reading about it. Therefore, the features of the setting affected the reader by highlighting the negativity of his situation, which in turn drives him to continue pedaling toward his destination.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” the features of the setting affected the cyclist in a few significant ways. One way it affected him was that the temperature was very hot and by it being hot outside his water wouldn’t stay cool, becoming warm and unappealing. This is a problem because you need nice, cool, refreashing water to stay hydrated on a long, strenuous ride. Another way was when he hit a fork in the road. He didn’t know which way to go, feeling lost and uncertain. All he saw was one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule greeted me. The sight was troubling and offered no clear direction. Last but not least this water pump wasn’t working very well so he got down on his hands and knees and started pumping with effort. The water wouldn’t cool down and was scarce. He tried a drop or two and the water tasted like battery acid, making it impossible to drink. Those are some features of the setting that affected the cyclist on his journey, each posing a unique challenge to his progress.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in several distinct ways during his journey. First the rolling hills make it hard to pedal over the land, demanding great physical exertion. "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills," shows that the terrain was changing into a more difficult course for the tired rider. "One long crippling hill," also shows how the hills had a draining effect on the cyclist, sapping his strength. Another feature of the setting was the vast desert and the high temperatures. This caused the cyclist to become dangerously dehydrated. "Trying to keep balance in my dehydrated state" and "I could drop from heatstroke" show me how hot and desperate the cyclist was becoming. One final feature that has on effect on the cyclist was the old abandoned factory. The sight of the boy with a refreshing glass of juice on the sign makes the cyclist lose hope and he doubts he will survive this ordeal. "I hung my head" and "abandoned factory of juices and dreams" tell how the cyclist lost all hope at the sight of the building, symbolizing his crushed expectations. All of these features of the setting have negative affects on the cyclist, both physically and mentally.

The setting of the area where the cyclist was biking effects him because it makes him weaker. Since the cyclist takes the long route, he is in the desert for a longer period of time. Being in extreme heat can cause a person to suffer from major dehydration. We know this was the case for the cyclist because he says, “but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst…” This detail is saying that the cyclist put stones in his mouth to get his mind off of how thirsty he was. I think this action is explaining exactly how dehydrated the cyclist actually was. If he was willing to put filthy stones in his mouth to help him get through his dehydration, he was pretty thirsty. Another thing that effected how thirsty the cyclist got was how hard he worked which was also a feature of the setting since during the end of his trip, he met rough terrain, he exerted more energy which made him sweat even more than he was. This made him significantly more dehydrated. This story is explaining how the features of your environment can either make or break you, demonstrating the profound impact of physical surroundings on an individual's endurance and well-being.

There are several features of the setting which affect the cyclist one is the fact that he is traveling on a hot day in June. “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” The heat was getting to the cyclist and he was scared he might get heatstroke. The terrain was also not very ideal for a cyclist on a hot day. “I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” The cyclist was tired and the hills were making it worse, demanding greater physical exertion. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” The cyclist was running out of water quickly and there was nowhere close to get more, amplifying his distress. These glitches in the setting affected the cyclist because it was extremely hot, he was running out of water and there was rough terrain. The setting was not in the cyclist's favor, creating a series of obstacles that challenged his journey at every turn.

According to the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit'' the features of the setting affect the cyclist a lot. The features of the setting affects the cyclist because in the story the character makes it seem like horrible weather for example when he said “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt” this is one way the setting affects the cyclist because it almost like your in the story and you can imagine what the character is going through because everything is written in details. The setting, therefore, is not just a backdrop but an active force that shapes the narrative and the character's ordeal.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it makes it hard for him to get to the national park. He took advice from some old men to take a shortcut to get him where he wanted to be. On his ride there, he stopped at a town, which was, to him, considered a ghost town, emphasizing the isolation of his journey. Then he got to a Welch’s Grape Juice Factory, but it was abandoned years earlier and he was becoming weak and dehydrated. He thought he would drop from a heatstroke, a fear compounded by the desolate surroundings. At the end of his ride, he reached a fish camp where he found water to drink. A man asked him where he was going and the cyclist told him. Then the man asked him, “Know the best way to get there?” The man was much older than the other old men that gave the cyclist advice. So the cyclist told the man “yes, sir: I own a very good map”. The man realized throughout the setting on his journey, that he would never accept advice from old-timers again, learning a valuable lesson about self-reliance from the challenging landscape he traversed.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed posted Speed Limit” the setting profoundly affected the cyclist's sense of direction. The cyclist initially knew where he was going and how to get there, but his journey was complicated when the old men told him their “short-cut.” This advice ultimately ruined his own sense of direction because he was attempting to follow out-dated directions from “old-timers that hadn’t left their porches since Carter was in office.” Their guidance, rooted in a landscape that had long since changed, created confusion and disorientation. That is how the specific setting and its inhabitants affected the cyclist's experience in the essay.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. I say that because when there is peace and calmness in the environment, then it motivates you more and allows for clearer thought. Steep mountains, rolling roads, jagged rocks – are all reasons why the setting is significant for the cyclist. What I believe is that the features of the setting affect the cyclist is that, “The old guys in the story remember things back how they used to be but as they say in the book the world is a fluid place and things change all the time.” Their memories were fixed in the past, while the actual roads and paths had evolved. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because you wouldn’t put the setting in heavy rain or he wouldn't be able to ride the bike effectively. Another one is you wouldn't have the setting in a city when the narrative describes nothing around but trees and rivers; the environment must be consistent with the action. The specific details of the location, such as weather and topography, are therefore crucial as they directly enable or constrain the cyclist's journey, defining what is possible within the story.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist is that on his way he had to deal with so many things. Like for example he had trouble with the flat roads that was replaced by short, rolling hills, which demanded more effort and drained his energy. The next thing was there was a sign that was posted he could not ride at the speed he wanted; he had to go much slower and that made him disappointed. Then a large snake blocked the majority of the pavement in front of him, forcing him to stop and wait cautiously. He became dehydrated under the relentless sun. He became sad and hopeless but still had a small reserve of energy to feel himself moving forward, a testament to his enduring will.

There are several features of the setting that greatly affect the cyclist. One feature is the desert he is biking through. The heat of a desert in June can easily dehydrate someone, sapping their strength with its dry, oppressive air. When exposed for a long time, exercising, and running out of water, the effect is even greater, leading to dizziness and a deep, pervasive thirst. In addition, the change in terrain and road surface would have an effect on the cyclist. Traveling on a flat road requires much less effort then climbing hills, which strain the leg muscles and the lungs. If the road is also rough, the biker has to work even harder to push up the hill, battling against the loose gravel. There is also the mental effort of not tipping the bike on the uneven surface, requiring constant focus. Finally, there are not any buildings in sight, just an endless expanse of sand and scrub. When someone is dehydrated but has no water, they are desperate to find some, scanning the horizon for any sign of help. However, if there is nothing they know of nearby, they will start to lose hope, a feeling that is as debilitating as the physical exhaustion. Once they lose hope they won’t try as hard to keep going and they will lose some of their strength, their pace slowing to a weary crawl. Considering all of the things negatively affecting the cyclist, it is amazing that he managed to push through and reach a source of water, a true feat of human resilience.

The setting in the short story “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie is troubling to the cyclist. The description, “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the tamest mule greeted me,” made him troubled that he was in the middle of nowhere, a desolate and forgotten place offering no real refuge. The quote, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing, flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” shows that he was troubled by having to go over the hills, a physical challenge that compounded his sense of isolation. As you can see the setting was very influental to the cyclist, shaping both his physical journey and his mental state throughout the narrative.

In the essays the features of the setting affect the cyclist by giving him hope, however fleeting it may be. The cyclist takes directions by a few old men on a porch, whose vague gestures point him forward into the unknown. The directions seem incorrect at first, leading him down a path that appears just as barren as the one he left. The remains of a Grape Juice factory make it seem like he will never find civilization, its crumbling walls a monument to failed enterprise and a stark reminder of his own precarious situation in the vast, empty landscape.

The features of the setting around the cyclist affected him to the point of exhaustion and dehydration. The cyclist being exhausted and dehydrated, or tired and thirsty, was beginning to wear down as the setting went from being flat to many ups and downs, a constant physical trial. The cyclist explained the change by saying, “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills” (Kurmaskie). The cyclist’s idea presented here is that he was to find new challenges when riding the hills of this Californian desert roller coaster, each ascent a test of his diminishing stamina. His water supply was thinning from the heat and the hills were tiring him beyond reason, each pedal stroke becoming a conscious act of will. All this cyclist could hope for was the blessing of a water refill and the shade of a puffy cloud, small mercies that would make his arduous journey bearable.

The harsh desert setting affected the cyclist severely. Biking through the arid expanse while following outdated directions nearly got him killed, leading him dangerously off course. He also came across several broken down factories and desolate, abandoned towns, their skeletal remains causing him more dismay and a deepening sense of isolation. However, his fortunes changed when he came across a last stop, a small outpost that provided vital water and shelter, which ultimately saved his life and allowed him to continue his journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist is profoundly affected by his surrounding environment. At first the man starts out at a reservoir camp ground, his spirits high and his water bottles full. His confidence is high, and he is ready to continue his adventure with optimism. As the day went on and all he could find was abandoned buildings, silent and decaying, he began to worry a bit, his water running low as the sun beat down relentlessly. He come upon “one ram shackled shed, several rusty pumps” with no sign of life, a sight that crushed his hope of finding aid. He realized that his trip was going to be rough and unforgiving. The environment and the very real risk of death gave him the determination he needed to push forward, a primal will to survive. Although he was fearful of death from dehydration, his throat parched and cracked, he knew that “travelling through the high deserts of California in June” meant his only chances of survival was to keep going, to keep moving. The man's surroundings, both its threats and its vast emptiness, were what had pushed him to keep biking until he finally found the fish camp. If he had not been so aware of his surroundings and the dire stakes, he might have given up, but the thought of not making it out of the desert to “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite” would be too devastating a failure to accept.

The setting affects the rider in several critical ways because it is very hot, which makes him thirsty and physically drained. The immense length of the road, stretching endlessly toward the horizon, affects his mind state, fostering a sense of hopelessness and mental fatigue. Lastly, the fact that no help is in sight and that the landscape is barren affects his morale, making the journey feel insurmountable and isolating him in his struggle. These environmental factors collectively challenge his resolve and physical endurance throughout the ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they directly change the cyclist’s mood and perception towards the ride. For example, in the essay “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” it states, "There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon." The cyclist had to do this because they were having trouble riding since they were desperately thirsty and the monotonous ride was very boring. This mental tactic makes the ride seem larger and more daunting, so it also makes it harder to ride from a psychological perspective. Also in the essay it states, "One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps," which affected the cyclist because after seeing this and later realizing he couldn’t drink the water, his thirst intensified since he was running out of water and the disappointment was crushing. Conversely, when the cyclist notices the Welch’s grape juice factory in the distance, he became determined to get there, his spirits lifting with a new goal. In conclusion, the cyclist in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie finds that his mood towards the ride is strongly affected by the setting’s features, which alternately dishearten and motivate him.

The setting affected the cyclist in many ways, both physically and mentally. When he was going up a steep hill, the incline made it significantly harder for him to pedal, sapping his strength. The hot summer day was breaking him down, the relentless sun leaching his energy and will. He was getting dangerously dehydrated because he had only a little bit of water left in his bottle, a constant source of anxiety. It said he was trying to keep his balance in his dehydrated state, a difficult task that required immense concentration. He felt like giving up, his resolve weakened by the cumulative hardships of the environment, but he pressed on despite the overwhelming urge to stop.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, primarily through the intense heat. For example, in paragraph @NUM1 it says, “I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” Knowing that California is often called “the sunshine state”, one can infer that the temperature was very high. Another feature that significantly affected the cyclist was the poor quality of the available water; when he finally found some, it was hot and tasted like battery acid, as described in paragraph @NUM2. These harsh environmental conditions directly impacted his physical state and his journey, demonstrating how the features of the setting affected the cyclist throughout his ordeal.

The setting features affected the cyclist by creating a significant conflict for him. It was a conflict primarily because of the oppressive heat and the fact that he was lost. The heat presented a conflict because it increased his need for water, yet he had only a limited supply, which he could not replenish because he did not know where to find more. The heat causes people to get thirsty quickly, but he was unable to drink freely due to his limited water reserves. Another major conflict was that he was lost, which was a problem because he needed to be somewhere specific and his inability to find his way exacerbated his dangerous situation. These intertwined conflicts created by the setting posed a serious challenge to the cyclist's well-being and progress.

The features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist as he rode through the heat-scorching desert of California. He rode over @NUM1 miles on his bike to get to Yosemite, a journey defined by the harsh, arid environment. The extreme conditions led to him almost running out of water, which was a constant source of anxiety. However, what kept him going through this difficult trek was the vivid thought and eventual sight of the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite. This envisioned destination served as his motivation, providing a mental refuge from the physical hardships imposed by the desert setting and ultimately driving him forward.

There are many ways the cyclist is affected throughout the essay by the setting. As he first enters the “short cut” that the old men give him, he is filled with confidence. When he arrives at the first town and sees that it is like a ghost town, he does not fret but continues on his journey with that same initial confidence. As he got to the second stop, his lack of water began to set in, illustrated when he says, “I got down on my hands and knees working the handle of the rusted pump with all my strength.” This shows he will work hard and is in desperate need of water. After the cyclist passed another place with no hope of water, he placed stones in his mouth because he once heard it helped get your mind off thirst. When he had just about lost hope from travelling through the hot @CAPS1 desert with no water, he found one last drive in him when he saw a store with water. Though this was a hot, harsh setting, it ultimately created inspiration for him to keep going and push through the hard times to survive.

The cyclist in Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit was greatly affected by the setting. There were no buildings or people in the town anywhere, creating a profound sense of isolation. This emptiness meant that there was no help available from anyone, and he could die without anyone knowing. Also, the setting seems to be very dry and have desert-like conditions; without water, the cyclist would become dehydrated and could potentially suffer from a heat stroke. Furthermore, the setting seems to be very hot. The heat also makes the cyclist physically dehydrated and causes him to mentally consider the logic and very real possibility of a heat stroke at the time, impacting both his body and his mind.

The features of the setting had greatly impacted the cyclist, creating a series of obstacles that slowed him down throughout his journey. The oppressive heat had been a major factor, slowing him down because he didn’t have enough water to keep his body moving normally, leading to dehydration and fatigue. The animals he encountered also posed a problem, as he said he had to slow down and sneak around a snake so it wouldn’t bite him, causing delays and requiring cautious movement. Furthermore, the hills had significantly affected the cyclist because it takes a lot of energy to pedal up an incline, especially when he said he couldn't see anything in sight, which added a psychological burden to the physical challenge. Each element of the environment worked against his progress, demonstrating how a harsh setting can directly impede a journey.

The arid, bare, and rough terrain of the desert profoundly affected the cyclist during his arduous journey to Yosemite in the story “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit.” The cyclist’s expedition was consistently hindered due to many formidable obstacles presented by the landscape. The extreme dryness was a huge and persistent problem during his journey, as the quote, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1), effectively illustrates the hot, arid climate he was cycling through. This unforgiving climate substantially decreased the rate of travel the cyclist had intended to exert, sapping his strength with its relentless heat. Since the cyclist was riding through the vast desert, there weren't many towns present to offer respite. When the cyclist did finally approach a town, it was invariably abandoned and desolate, offering no relief; “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me” (@NUM2). After riding for hours through the barren desert, the cyclist would have desperately wanted a nice rest stop, but all he found were ghost towns that deepened his isolation. To compound his difficulties, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (@NUM1). Cycling for hours in a hot desert with limited water wasn't enough of a challenge on its own; now the flat land was replaced with energy-sapping hills. The cyclist, already exhausted from all the other obstacles that the desert confronted him with, found that the rough terrain further affected his journey since his pace was drastically reduced by the arduous climbs. In conclusion, many interconnected factors negatively affected the cyclist's expedition to Yosemite, as the dry, bland, and hilly terrain of the desert collectively hindered his journey at every turn.

I believe the setting of an area can profoundly affect the mind when a person is put in certain situations, shaping their emotional state and perception of safety. In the reading, the man is cycling and he sees no one for miles; he is almost out of water and can't see a house or a person as far as he can see, which creates a profound sense of vulnerability. This isolation is inherently scary and gives the feeling of helplessness, as there is no immediate source of aid or comfort. However, if he would be in @LOCATION1 and go past cars, people on the street, and buildings, he would undoubtedly be calmer, knowing help and resources are readily available. He could easily get water at any building along his ride, and the cooler temperature there would mean he would drink less and potentially travel further without the same level of distress. This stark contrast in environments would have completely changed his mood, proving that the physical setting is a powerful determinant of psychological well-being during a challenging endeavor.

Well in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limits” by @PERSON1, the setting affects you psychologically because if you can't see anything for miles and you are running out of water, it has a profound psychological effect on your state of mind. You can start to panick, just like he did when he stopped at the old house and all that came out of the rusted water pump was battery acid, dashing his hopes for relief. Also, you don't know exactly where you are, so that also affects you because you don’t know where to go or if you should turn back or what decision is the safest. The uncertainty and isolation feed anxiety and fear. If I was this person, the desolate features around me would have a lot of effect on me, influencing my thoughts and actions significantly. The environment's emptiness directly creates a sense of dread and confusion that is hard to overcome.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, primarily by dictating his emotional journey from optimism to despair. In the beginning of the essay, she was happy and optimistic that she was getting a shortcut, stating, "I followed their device and launched out at first light along a ‘shortcut’ that was to slice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park.” He thought he knew where he was going, a confidence reflected in the line, "I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on." However, when she entered the first deserted town, the sight was troubling, signaling the beginning of his troubles. The narrator describes getting “down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength,” showing she was beginning to get worried as she started to run out of water, pinning her hopes on the next town which was “only eighteen miles down the road." He was now entering a dehydrated and fatigued state, as “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips," intensifying his desperation. Then he saw a building, but it was no longer open, so he got back on his bike, but his thoughts had changed dramatically; he was now upset and genuinely expecting to die in the harsh landscape. His salvation came when he then saw an open store, “Gary and Wilber's fish camp,” where he went in, drank cool water, and regained his composure. He then wisely decided to use his own map for the remainder of the journey, rather than relying on the advice of the old guys, learning to trust his own resources over shortcuts through unforgiving terrain.

There were many features of the setting that had affected the cyclist. One of the features was the lack of water, which was a constant and pressing issue. This had made the cyclist dehydrated and not think right, clouding his judgment. It had also made the cyclist have less energy, slowing his pace considerably. An example is, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Another significant feature is the heat. The intense heat had made the cyclist thirsty and sweaty, exacerbating his physical strain. An example is “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage…” A further example is, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The features of the setting had affected the cyclist in many ways, creating a challenging and arduous journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, there were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. The first feature that affected the cyclist was the desert terrain, which was very hot and there were no trees to provide shade from the relentless sun. This affected the cyclist because he got very hot and thirsty, leading to significant physical discomfort. So he drank more water than usual, depleting his supply at a faster rate. Secondly, he was running out of water because he was drinking more than usual so he had to conserve his water, which was making him became dehydrated and weak. That all the towns we past through were ghost towns with no running fresh water, so this extremely dissapointed him, it also furthered his dehydration and sense of isolation. Just when the cyclist was losing hope he found a small bait shop and got into the shade and finnaly got water to drink, which was a tremendous relief. So after all those dissapointments he found hope, in the small bait shop, which gave him the strength and mental boost to continue on with his journey to Yosemite national park, restoring his determination.

The features of the setting made the cyclist’s journey even longer and more strenuous than it otherwise would have been. The reason it being in such a remote area did not help, as services were scarce. For example the people who still lived in that remote area were probably as old as the cyclist grandparents and the directions they gave were horrible and confusing. Also, the fact that their were no new shops or areas or rest for the cyclist to go to; the water pump he found was old and nasty and the only building he saw was abandoned, offering no real refuge. Another major factor was the rough terrain. It being difficult for the cyclist who was already very fatigued by lack of water and tiredness the terrain was long, bumpy and just horrible all together, demanding constant effort. Finally, the last factor was where he was bicycling in California on a hot summer day and he being on a bicycle which had no air conditioning (but which bike does) did not help at all, adding to his discomfort. These are how the features affect the cyclist journey, compounding the difficulty at every stage.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the rougher the terrain got the more the cyclist had to strain to make it through each section. For example, when the terrain turned to steep hills, the cyclist had to struggle to climb the hills which caused him to use more of his energy and strength. Also, if the terrain was flat and smooth, the cyclist had less problems making the long journey and could maintain a better pace. For instance, if the cyclist had less strain on him then he would not be as tired and would not drink as much water, conserving his vital resources. In conclusion, that is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist, directly influencing his physical exertion and resource consumption.

He wouldn't know what challenges he would be facing while riding on the road; perhaps something bad might happen to his bike or one of his bike’s wheels could break. Alternatively, he might fall off his the bike, or he would get so tired that he can’t go any more and he might give it up entirely. These unforeseen difficulties posed a constant threat to the success and safety of his journey, making it a truly unpredictable endeavor.

The setting affects the cyclist by defining the need and comfort of riding. When there is no infrastructure around and no people, he can ride down in the best mood; it is nice and calm with no cars, and it is just him and the beautiful sky to ride with. In contrast, if there is infrastructure present, he must watch for people and cars and pay attention to streetsigns and act accordingly. So that outing illustrates how the specific features of the setting would affect the cyclist's entire experience and state of mind.

In the adventures of the cyclist the setting is not only what develops the character but also what affects how he pushes himself to not give up, even when he feels helpless. This is one example of how the cyclist is affected, "I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high desert of California in June." With that information you can observe how this harsh setting creates problems for him physically because his body desperately needs water, a resource of which he is extremely limited and doesn't savor it very well. These issues create the problem of dehydration, and when mentally you think you are going to die without water, you start to panic and lose control over yourself. This demonstrates the powerful and direct impact the environment has on both his physical condition and his mental fortitude.

The features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist. There were many elements in his environment that shaped his journey, from the quality of the roads to the availability of essential resources like water. These conditions directly influenced his physical stamina and his mental outlook, creating challenges that he had to constantly navigate. Ultimately, the setting was not just a backdrop but an active force that dictated the pace and difficulty of his ride.

In ''Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit'' by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting most of the time disappoint him. You can tell that the features of the setting disappointed him because every time he got to a town he couldn’t get water. In the text it states, ''I got down on my hands & knees working the handle of the rusty water pump a for like substance oozed out followed by brackish water that tasted like battery acid.'' You know the setting disappoints him when he sees the terrain he has to cross as well. You can tell when he says ''At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path a ridiculously large snake.'' The narrator was disappointed that he listened to the directions of the elder rather than use his map. Joe Kurmaskie does a great job of making one narrator face these challenging settings and showing how he felt about them, conveying a consistent sense of letdown.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the route that the cyclist was taking had a rough road for him to travel. The cyclist took bad advice from some old men that hadn’t left their porches for decades. Also, as he got into his long journey he began to notice that the advice the old men had given him was bad advice; the cyclist was headed to Yosemite and he had gotten some advice from these locals which led him astray. This poor guidance, a feature of the human landscape, combined with the difficult physical path, significantly complicated his trip and affected his progress.

When the cyclist first set off, he was doing fine, as he had plenty of water to sustain him. As he kept going, and sort of got off course, he began to come into the vast and barren desert region. He was hot under the relentless sun, and he was running out of his precious water supply. This depletion was making him dangerously dehydrated, weakening his body. Also, seeing the endless tumbleweeds rolling across the landscape, and the complete lack of vibrant vegetation probably made him even worse mentally, because he was maybe thinking he was never going to get free from that desolate place. When he saw the fish bait shop though, he was probably profoundly relieved, believing that he was finally going to be saved from his dire circumstances. This sequence of events clearly illustrates the profound impact of the environment on his journey.

There are many ways that a cyclist will be affected and one of these are the setting. The setting affects them because if it is a short smooth path the ride will be easy and enjoyable. But if it is a long journey on bumpy, rough roads it will be significantly harder to control the bike, demanding constant physical effort and focus, which means that the cyclist’s job will be hardened considerably. This is how a cyclist is fundamentally affected by his or her settings, with the terrain directly dictating the difficulty of the ride.

The cyclist ran into a series of rough settings on the way to the park. The first challenge was that the town he came to was a complete ghost town, empty and silent. Then he was running out of water when he rode past dry tumbleweeds, and encountered a large snake coiled in front of him, blocking his path. He had no more water to drink and there were rough roads ahead of him, straining his endurance. He then came across a juice factory, a potential source of relief. However, no one was there to help him and he was out of water, so he did not know how much longer it would be until he came to another town. That is why I say that the specific features of the setting critically affected the cyclist throughout his difficult trip.

The features of the setting have a very negative effect on the cyclist. According to the old men, the cyclist would pass by a few towns if he took the route they told him. But every town the cyclist came to was completely deserted. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” Because the towns were deserted, the cyclist’s water supply was dwindling rapidly because there was no place where he could get more water to replenish it. He became severely dehydrated and kept pushing himself forward, desperate to find a place where there was fresh water. “Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Once he found some pebbles and thought about sucking on them because it helps to slow down dehydration. But he didn’t because he thought he would choke on them. The setting around him also made him have profoundly negative thoughts. “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Because the setting was a hot, deserted, and arid desert it had a very negative effect on the cyclist’s physical and mental state. If he hadn’t been running out of water I don’t think that the effect of the setting would have been as bad. But because he did run out of water it made the harsh effects of the environment much worse, pushing him to his absolute limit.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in several key ways. One reason I say this is because he ran out of water and he could dehydrate, which posed a serious health risk. Also, the constant searching for water slowed him down more, delaying his progress. Another reason I say this is because the man at the start gave him the wrong directions, which got him lost and confused, leading him into a difficult and barren area. That is how the various elements of the setting ultimately affected the cyclist’s journey and well-being.

It is said that, "experience is a good substitute for instinct." This means if someone knows how to deal with the environment they're in they can survive even if they weren't born with the animal instinct that come with the territory. However, even the most experienced person can be overcome by the extreme weather conditions they live in. In the essay, "Rough Road Ahead," by Joe Kurmaskie, the experienced cyclist decides to take a long, difficult, and dangerous trip. His ride will take him along the long desert paths of California with a limited water supply. This is the major element that hinders him in the story. Because he listened to some old men he went without water for most of his trip. Between his constant exercise, extreme heat, and lack of water, dehydration hit him fast. A common side effect of dehydration is hallucination, which the cyclist knew. It says in the essay, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn`t mirage.” This represents his knowledge and experience in the matter, and showed that he was adept at recognizing the signs of his environment through experience. A similar story to this is Jack London's, “To Build a Fire” where the man is also pitted against extremes of nature through the Yukon, but the elements still overtook him. Both stories represent man's quest for adventure, and also the constant struggle for survival that people face, demonstrating that nature's power can overwhelm even the prepared.

The features of a setting can affect a cyclist's energy. In a setting with steep hills and rough terrain, it can wear the cyclist out. The constant effort required to climb and navigate such a landscape drains physical stamina and mental resolve. This exhaustion is a direct result of the environmental challenges, which demand more from the rider than a flat, smooth path would. Ultimately, the difficult setting saps the cyclist's strength, leaving them fatigued and struggling to maintain their pace.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist most in the fact that it strained him out of his hydrated state. The relentless heat and arid conditions rapidly depleted his body's moisture, making him unable to operate at his full power and efficiency. This physical depletion was critical; the environment actively deprived him of the little energy he had in him to begin with, accelerating his decline. That is how the setting affected him, by directly attacking his physical resources and diminishing his capacity to function.

The setting affects the cyclist very strongly. The desert heat with no available water causes him to get dangerously dehydrated. Furthermore, the rolling hills and rough, unforgiving terrain physically tire him out, compounding his distress. In the story it says “and growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This shows that the intense heat and demanding terrain could cause him to overheat and suffer a heat stroke. The combination of these environmental factors creates a severe threat to his well-being, demonstrating the powerful influence of the setting on his physical state.

The temperature of the place that the cyclist was riding through affected him very much. The high temperature caused the cyclist to sweat profusely. This affected him because he would get intensely thirsty and eventually he ran out of water, leaving him without a way to replenish his fluids. For example, in the text he says “the water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips” and then it goes on to say, “I could drop from from a heat stroke.” This showed how it affected him because he genuinely feared he was going to collapse from the oppressive heat, highlighting the direct and dangerous impact of the temperature on his body and mind.

The features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the harsh and hot climate and the unforgiving terrain. The author clearly wrote how "the sun was beating down on him" and how he "almost died from dehydration," emphasizing the relentless heat that sapped his energy and the arid landscape that offered no respite. This combination of environmental factors created a severe challenge for his journey, pushing him to his physical limits. Ultimately, the setting proved to be a formidable adversary that nearly cost him his life.

The features of the setting do significantly affect the cyclist, demanding constant preparation and awareness. If the road is rough, you have to have the right bike to handle the uneven surface. Then, if you get a flat tire, you have to know to look out for dangerous and poisonous things like snakes or thorny plants while making repairs. If you were in a real bad accident, you’d have to be prepared with supplies just in case they don’t find you in time. You would also have to know what nights were like in that environment. For example, if it got real cold at night after a hot day, you would need to find a way to keep yourself warm to survive. This constant vigilance is essential for safety in such a demanding setting.

The desert and the hills had a huge effect on the cyclist, presenting multiple physical challenges. The desert in June must have been very hot, and going up those steep hills had to be hard, requiring immense physical exertion. The road was also very rough, as indicated by the sign, “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The narrative confirms the location with, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” The cyclist was very thirsty because of the hot weather, his water supply insufficient for the conditions. I think the setting had a huge effect on the cyclist, testing his endurance at every turn.

The cyclist’s condition was greatly influenced by his setting because he was lost in the high deserts of California in June. The heat crippled him as he traveled in search of Yosemite. He became lost and ran out of water, making his desperate situation worse. Being lost in seemingly the middle of nowhere in the hot heat, he became exhausted, dehydrated, and began fearing heat stroke and loss of consciousness. This is shown in the essay by, "the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke" and, "It looked like I was going to lose consciousness for the last time." These fears highlight how the environment directly threatened his very survival.

How the features of the setting affected the cyclist in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Limit,” were very dangerous to his life. The cyclist was traveling to the Yosemite National Park on a hot summer day. The cyclist traveled miles after miles on his bike only to pass by deserted towns, noting, “This place might have been a thriving little spot...a ghost town.” The terrain was threatening because after twenty-two miles or so, the cyclist had to overcome “short rolling hills,” which would use more energy and make his thirst for water even stronger. The cyclist was out of water and the hot day was not helping, intensifying his dehydration. After a grueling journey, the cyclist used all the strength he had to go to a local bait shop and drank from the sink after the treacherous environment he was exposed to. The features of the setting in the story were life threatening and almost killed the cyclist, due to the lack of water and the difficult terrain he had to overcome.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by teasing him in a cruel progression. First it was the rippling streams glimpsed from the road that taunted his thirst with their inaccessible flow, then the old faucet that stood as a silent mockery of relief, and last the Welches grape factory, a monument to past abundance. The streams were the beginning stage, simply provoking a deep thirst, then came the faucet, which was broken and yielded nothing. The faucet made him realize fully that he was dehydrated and without a ready source of aid. And last the abandoned Welches grape juice factory, with its faded signs of juicy refreshment, had him almost abandon hope entirely as he passed by. The setting was profoundly effecting his mood, pushing him toward despair with each successive landmark.

The features of the setting directly affect the cyclist in the story, primarily through the scarcity of water and the isolating landscape. In the story, it says, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. I could drop from a heatstroke.” This statement clearly says that where the cyclist was riding, water was very hard to find and scarce, highlighting a critical threat to his survival. He is talking about how he will die if he doesn’t get water, showing his desperation. Another example is that there are no buildings around and the area is deserted with no one around and many hills and roads, which deepens his solitude. In the story it says, “the terrain changing flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” This means that he was partially all by himself in a challenging environment and he had no one to go to for assistance, making his journey a solitary struggle against the elements.

In this story, the features of the setting heavily affect the cyclist, creating a complex experience. Certain features portray that this “journey” to Yosemite National Park was dreadful, but at the same time enjoyable in brief moments. "I would come to along this breeze jaunt." The word breezy shows that the cyclist can occasionally enjoy riding the bike because there is a cooling breeze. Another feature of the setting is very old and dirty, which directly impacts his well-being. The water that the cyclist is drinking is drying his mouth out even more, as described by, “A tar-like substance oozed out followed by brackish water feeling.” This shows the dirtiness of the water and its unsuitability for drinking. Also this setting shows the cyclist had to use all he had just to survive the harsh conditions. It says “working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength,” which portrays the sacrifice and bravery of the cyclist in the face of adversity.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting greatly affects the cyclist, shaping both her physical and mental state. The setting around the cyclist led her to drink a lot of water because of the dry, desert conditions. “I was traveling the high deserts of California in June” This shows that most likely she was hot, sweaty, and a reliable source of water was not near to her. The rough terrain also led to her using her own strength to get up and down hills, and to navigate past plants and animals. The settings in the story led the cyclist to become dehydrated and weak; she was forced on a low supply of water and had to dodge numerous hazards, with no sign of living people near her. “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time say, before the last world was" This suggests a ghost town, where no people were currently living, confirming her isolation. There was nobody around her to help, which intensified her struggle. The setting led to her deteriorating health, as her physical state was in danger because of her dehydration and her lack of energy. Her mind was also starting to ware, evidenced when she had to shake her head to make sure what she was seeing in one part of the story was real.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist throughout his journey. Because the man didn’t have a lot of water and he was going into the California deserts in June, the heat was an immediate and pressing danger. Another reason is because the flat road was changed into rolling hills, increasing the physical demand, and up ahead there was a sign that said “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” where the speed limit was notably low, warning of the difficult path to come. One more thing is to make sure you don’t listen to a gentleman that is old and hadn’t been off his porch in decades, as his advice may be outdated and misleading for the current conditions. That is some of the things that can affect the cyclist, demonstrating how the environment and its elements directly challenge his progress and decisions.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist since it is affecting her physical condition. She needs water to survive, and the next town is very far away. So she could possibly pass out without a break, and the hot temperatures exacerbate her dehydration. ìWhen I tried a draper I was, it had the flavor of battery acidî (Kurmaskie @NUM1). If she doesnít find water soon, it will affect her condition severely. Also, the features of the setting affects her mental determination. When she knows that she needs to find a town, she works harder. "i would conserve my water go inward for an hour or so atleast or my inner spirit"(@NUM1). As the author of the story goes on her bike trip, the landscape around her becomes less and less welcoming and more desolate. The features of the surrounding setting affect the cyclist from his/her performance in several ways. For example, In the essay ìRough Road Ahead. Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the setting is full of hills, twisting, rising and desending constantly. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, such as the oppressive heat, the lack of available water, and the challenging hills. The features of the setting affect the cyclist by hurting his ability to keep going, presenting a series of demoralizing challenges. In this story the cyclist was faced with many setbacks or problems that tested his resolve. At first he took advice from a very old man who had out of date directions, leading him astray. Then the cyclist thought he could keep going on a very limited water supply, a miscalculation that soon took its toll. His spirits were briefly lifted when he found an old building which raised his hopes, only to drop them once he found out it was closed and rundown, with no help to be found. I think features affect the cyclist because when you undertake a bicycle journey you need to consider the environmental conditions you will face. The terrain and climate are not just background details but active elements that can dictate the success or failure of the trip. A cyclist must constantly adapt to these features, which directly influence their stamina, route choices, and overall experience. Understanding this relationship is crucial for any successful journey, as the setting is an inseparable part of the cycling adventure.

In the story ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî, by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist has a very long journey that is affected by a variety of things, and problems that test his initial confidence. The cyclist is confident with himself at the beginning but after a few moments he feels really bad, and learns a really good lesson about his own limits. ìI eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state," the cyclist shows that it is really hard for him to move without water, his body weakening with every pedal stroke. This quote shows that he is not only thirsty but dehydrated which is severe for a human being, impairing his physical coordination. The cyclist also had a really bad time, because he had to taste stones in order to make his thirst go away, one example of that is when he succumbed to a desperate, ancient trick, finding only dust and disappointment. This entire ordeal underscores the profound impact of the setting on a traveler's well-being and decision-making.

In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î a cyclist is confronted with a troubling setting on his journey to Yosemite, which shapes his entire experience. He is led away from the steady road as a result of taking mislead advice from an old group of individuals, a error that compounds his difficulties. In this essay the setting plays a crucial impact on the cyclist, dictating his struggles. In the essay, the author sets up the story describing the day as, ìtraveling through the high deserts of California in June,î immediately establishing a harsh environment. Because of the amount of heat the cyclist was enduring, he became weary and dehydrated, his energy sapped. Along with this, the cyclist had to work much harder because the man noticed, ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,î demanding greater physical exertion. This setting is a major setback to the cyclistís journey, and required him to persevere through the unexpected hardships. In my life there have been numerous obstacles which I have had to persevere through, mirroring this cyclical struggle. One of which had been when I was out camping, and suddenly, as in the essay, the setting changed, and a storm came, altering our plans completely. Though the other campers and I did what we needed to to make the best out of it, adapting to the new conditions. In the essay, the cyclist is affected greatly by the setting, which was the same in my experience as the setting affected myself and my companions. In both situations, perseverance led to a final satisfaction of the journey, proving that overcoming environmental challenges brings its own unique reward.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the roads are bumpy and uneven, causing a jarring and uncomfortable ride. There are a lot of curved roads which always slows down his speed, forcing him to brake frequently and expend more energy to navigate the constant turns. These combined elements create a demanding and strenuous journey for the rider, testing his endurance and control over the bicycle at every stage.

In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist significantly. The setting is described as a rough terrain, which makes it harder for the cyclist to travel, with rocks and ruts jolting his bicycle. Also it’s hot, with a relentless sun beating down, and there are no buildings or people around to offer any respite. This also makes it hard for the cyclist because he runs out of water, leaving him dehydrated and fatigued. The feature of the setting affect the cyclist because the surrounding is so negative and bleak. Everything around the cyclist is perceived negatively, so naturally the cyclist feels like the task is harder and more challenging than it really is. For example, nothing is surrounding the cyclist but sand and the hot temperature; since the setting is so empty and no one is around, then everything seems harder than it really is. The vast, monotonous landscape offers no visual relief or encouragement. Also the cyclist feels like he can’t go on and is weak because there is no living thing around him, intensifying his sense of isolation. Furthermore, if the cyclist was in the park with the sun shining and people around and in sight, his attitude would change and everything would seem easier, highlighting how profoundly the environment shapes his mental state and perceived effort.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making it hard for him to control his bike down on the rough road, with the constant vibrations straining his arms. Also there wasn't a building in sight so he could not get anything to drink, leaving him without any source of replenishment. Also he did not know where he was going, as the featureless landscape provided no landmarks for navigation. The setting affects the cyclist in many grueling and harsh ways. First, the lack of civilization contributes to an uneasy feeling of isolation and an inability to refill his water bottle. Second, the heat and uphill battles are taking their toll on both the cyclist's physical and mental strength, sapping his energy with every pedal stroke. Third, his water bottle is emptying at an alarming rate due to his thirst and the relentless heat, compounding his physical distress. In paragraph four the exhausted cyclist reaches the first "town." This place might have been a thriving spell but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. He came to a house with a rusty water pump, which spewed out brackish, near boiling water, which did not support the parched cyclist, physically, or mentally, dashing his last hope for relief and leaving him in a state of complete despair as he faced the continuing journey alone.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he learns to never accept travel advice from strangers without verification. The environment, with its misleading paths and isolated terrain, teaches him a hard lesson about self-reliance. This experience fundamentally changes his approach to navigation and trust in unfamiliar places. Ultimately, the cyclist's ordeal underscores the importance of preparing for a journey with reliable information, ensuring he is never again led astray by well-meaning but inaccurate directions.

In the story ìDo not exceed posted speed limit," the features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways. In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Kurmaskie, the cyclist went through hard times, trying to get to Yosemite National Park. A cyclist is someone who tried their bike mostly all the time to get somewhere. First off the cyclist asked old men for directions to get to Yosemite National Park. Well, some features of the setting might have had a greater impact than others, and the cyclist might have been more affected by certain challenges. In the passage “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” there are many features from the setting that affected the cyclist. One feature that significantly affected the cyclist was the snake he encountered on his way. For example, in the text it says, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake,” and “I cased post, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This proves that the snake was a feature that affected the cyclist by presenting a sudden danger, giving him a critical point where he had to stay calm and maintain composure even in the debilitated state he was in, being dehydrated and suffering from all the other effects he encountered from that challenging environment.

There are many things that could have made his bicycle ride much more enjoyable; one primary thing is if he wasn’t in the middle of nowhere and if he actually knew where he was. For example, the text states, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” emphasizing his profound isolation. Furthermore, he had almost no water to get him through the day, which is illustrated by the instance, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Consequently, he did not know where he was going, so navigating the unfamiliar terrain was much harder for him. In conclusion, these are some of the key things that made his trip particularly hard and unenjoyable.

The features of the setting do affect the cyclist in such ways, making him hallucinatory and severely dehydrated. He saw the idea that a juice factory was working, when in reality it was completely abandoned. He saw only rusty pipes, and this sight intensified his thirst because he knew on a rational level that those old, corroded pipes could never produce water. This cruel juxtaposition of his desperate need and the barren reality deeply affected his mental state during the arduous journey.

In the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the settings of the story profoundly affect the cyclist. They make him think he will die and overall make him extremely worried. In the story, the cyclist takes two old men’s advice on the best way to get to Yosemite mountain and gets himself lost in the middle of nowhere. He finds himself in the California desert without water, and he lets this desperate situation go to his head, as shown by the line, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” which was from the last page of the story. The biker was taking an unfamiliar route and he let himself believe he would die. He knew he was in the desert without water; the setting makes him nervous precisely because he was in a vast, arid desert. He wouldn’t have been nearly as nervous if he was in a forest where there are streams and shade. He lets the desert and the intense heat convince him that he is going to die. By coming across ghost towns, he believes he will never see another person again; he gets more disoriented and fearful because of where he is. He becomes convinced the heat will kill him. Thus, the setting affects him psychologically and tricks him into believing he is going to die.

The features of the setting, including the terrain conditions, weather, and amount of water, can critically decide the life or death of the cyclist. The conditions such as steep hills and rocky roads can decide a future for a cyclist because if the rocky roads turn you off balance you could fall down a hill and give yourself a serious injury or possibly die. For example, in the short-story it says, “over one long crippling hill, a building came into view,” which shows the arduous conditions in which the cyclist had to deal. In addition, the extreme weather and amount of water can also decide the future. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.” This shows us that if the cyclist gets dehydrated enough he could pass out from heat exhaustion and no one would find him in the vast desert. In addition, the oppressive heat isnít helping him out any once he could die without anyone knowing. These reasons show us a cyclist needs to make sure they have enough water and the conditons and weather is right so they don't make a life-threating choice that could end their journey permanently.

When the cyclist is at his low point, he is in an abandoned ghost town, looking for water that tastes like battery acid. The cyclist feels completely hopeless in the abandoned town, a feeling amplified by the desolate surroundings. When he first reaches the old water pump and the abandoned juice building he has a little hope, a brief spark of potential salvation, only to be let down cruelly. This is because the building has no juice and the water pump’s water is too hot and the water is not any good, leaving him in a state of profound disappointment. The setting is the primary reason his mood changes through out the story, shifting his spirit from determined optimism to utter dejection as each potential resource proves useless.

I am going to write a response that explains how the features of the setting affects the cyclist. In the begining of the story, a young cyclist sets out on a long journy to Yosemite national park. Along his ride he meets some old but confident men who seem knowledgeable. They tell him a new rout wich “was to slice away hours” from his ride; the setting was excedingly hot on that particular day. He was supposed to encounter a few thriving towns along the way, but the first was a “baren ghost town,” the next had water with “the flavor of battery acid,” and then he came to an abanded welches grape juice factory, finding no relief. In the essay “Rough Road ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist had many changes due to the setting of what was around him. The cyclist was lost in the dessert, a vast and unforgiving landscape. This affected him a lot because the desert is very hot and exposed. He could have died from either severe dehydration or sheer exhaustion. Also, in the desert some animals can be very dangerous; on the cyclist journey, he saw a poisonous snake slithering across his path. It was a good thing that he was cautious around the snake because if he wouldn’t have been, he might have gotten bitten and there would be no one around to help him. The desert that he was in also happened to be completely desserted and there was no one around to help him with the directions or offer assistance. The worst thing would have to be that he ran out of water, his most vital resource. Without the water, he could become very weak and dehydrated and could have even died from the harsh conditions. The setting of where the cyclist was affected him greatly, dictating his every struggle.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him desperately thirsty and leading him to believe he is lost and might perish in the heat. Following outdated information from an old man who had not left his porch for years, the cyclist felt his hope dwindling. Just when the cyclist thought he was irrevocably lost, he saw the sign for “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp—if you want bait for the big ones, we're your best bet!” The cyclist went inside the camp, where he gratefully obtained water to quench his thirst. The old man inside offered him directions, but this time, having learned from his previous misadventure, the cyclist wisely declined the offer and continued on his own way.

In the short story “Do not exceed the speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting has a great impact on the cyclist. In the beginning of the story he describes the scenery as a vast, arid landscape. As he continued following the old men's outdated advice, it led him through more barren and desolate lands. When he came to the first "town" he described it as a ghost town, empty and silent. The second setting he arrived at was “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule.” He continued moving to the next town, which was many miles away, and he came to what he thought was a Welch's Grape juice factory and bottling plant, which turned out to be another disappointment. This took a toll on his confidence because he said, "I hung my head," feeling defeated. He moved on and had finally arrived at an abandoned building called “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp.” This is where he drank water and became replenished. The setting had a great effect on the cyclist because, depending on the location, it decided whether he would live or die in the hot deserts of California, making his journey a matter of survival.

One of the main things that affect the cyclist is the oppressive heat. Due to the intense heat, he drinks all of his water supply very quickly, leaving him vulnerable. Another feature of the setting that effects the cyclist is the rough road, which includes steep hills and uneven surfaces. Since he is so tired from the journey, he has a difficult time riding on these hills and navigating the other hard road conditions, which further saps his energy and slows his progress through the challenging environment.

In the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” written by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting reflects how the cyclist is feeling. For example, “Flat roads were replaced by short, riding hills,” and as the terrain was changing, so was his attitude. When he first started the journey, he was happy and carefree, and the land was flat with no hills. However, once he noticed that everything was not as the men had said, he seemed to grow a little angry and upset. Just like the land seemed to reflect this, he soon found himself on a bumpy and unpleasant road. The setting also seemed to give the man more obstacles to overcome on his adventure; “tumbleweeds crossed my path [and] a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the movement in front of me.” The land seemed to be teasing and tormenting him, especially when he started to figure out that listening to the old men was a mistake, creating a direct parallel between his internal state and the external world.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie the features of the setting affects the cyclist by draining him of energy. In the book “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting was in the small, dusty town of Codi, California. The author went on a challenging journey through this arid landscape, embarking on a bicycle trip that would test his endurance and resolve as he pedaled across the sun-scorched terrain.

Throughout the rider's long journey, the setting greatly affected him. In this story the cyclist was affected physically and emotionally in many ways. One such way was the setting around him. In the short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit,” a lot of things affected the cyclist. All the features of the environment through which the cyclist is riding affect him greatly. The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because depending on how the setting is, is how much skill they need. Like if they're going down hill then they really only need to know how to control the bike and maintain balance. Usually if they're riding in a shady area then they wear clothes to keep them cool, as the environment is more forgiving. But if they're going to be in the sun then they need to wear light clothes to protect themselves from the heat and sun exposure. The setting affects the rider very much, dictating not only the required technique but also the necessary preparations and gear for a successful and safe ride.

The setting in “Do not exceed posted speed limit” affects the cyclist in many ways.
