The features of the setting affect the cyclist for many readers after another. Here are some examples why the cyclist was bike riding down a windy road. He is in a hot place similar to a desert. It is very hot there and is affecting him during his travels, as he states, "I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." Another thing that affected him because of the setting was that the desert had rocky roads and windy paths because he followed the old man's direction, which made his journey more strenuous. The "Rough Road Ahead" sign is a final example of the challenging terrain. Furthermore, he was in the desert so he saw a snake come out of the tumbleweeds, which startled him. "A large snake it really did look like a diamond back." These are three examples how the cyclist had been affected due to the setting of the story, showing the direct impact of his environment on his experience.

The features in the settings, like hills, make the cyclist use more energy as he pedals against the incline. The more energy that he uses, the more water he will want to drink to replenish himself. This is difficult because he states, “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Therefore he was in trouble, facing the harsh reality of his dwindling supplies in the demanding landscape.

In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, he is in the desert and it is very hot outside, which drains his energy. Also he is running out of water, a critical resource. This is bad because he could become dehydrated, impairing his ability to continue. Another example is when he comes upon the building he thinks it is a mirage at first because he’s pretty much dehydrated and his vision is unreliable. The rough terrain also makes it hard for him to pedal and he is already weak from lack of water, creating a cycle of hardship. In conclusion, all these elements of the desert affect the cyclist in some way, compounding the challenges of his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist’s mood towards the journey. At first, he is confident that the old men’s knowledge of the land is accurate and he is excited about what lies ahead for him. However, his excitement soon turned into dismay and slight doubt as his journey drags on through the unforgiving heat. The intense heat of the weather and his lack of water makes the cyclist develop an uncaring matter about his own well-being. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps…with any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat.” The verbal irony in this passage delivers a negative feeling to the reader and it is here that it is clear that the cyclist doesn’t care what happens to him, showing his profound despair. When he finally reaches a sign of civilization, the cyclist becomes himself again and decides that his own knowledge is best, marking a return to his confident self.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” while riding his bike the author Joe Kurmaskie has a long ride. Where he is riding there is up and down hills, testing his endurance, and also the road is very rough, jostling him constantly. He was running out of water in the desert, a serious predicament. “I stopped at a rusted water pump to get water and a tar like substance oozed out.” Now that he is off his bike he least worries about the poisonous snakes of the desert, as his immediate concern is his thirst. He found Welch’s grape juice factory but it was abandoned, offering no respite. Ultimately, the author found a bait shop and got water, finally securing the resource he so desperately needed to continue his arduous trek.

In the short story “Do not @CAPS1 the Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting of the story profoundly affects the cyclist in many ways. In the story the cyclist experiences many drastic changes in temperature and climate, from the cool shade of pines to the oppressive heat of the desert. He also experiences significant changes in land structure, such as encountering steep hills and rough terrain, which makes it extremely hard to pedal and get where he needs to. From my reasoning, this constant physical challenge imposed by the environment is why the setting @MONTH1 so powerfully affect the cyclist and his progress.

The hot sun and the desert features in the setting are affecting the cyclist in ways that could potentially stop him from making it to his destination. The sun is beating down on him relentlessly and is making it harder for him to reach his destination, as illustrated when he observes, “The sun was begining to beat down...wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt.” By him being so hot and tired from the sun, he thought that he would die from dehydration before arriving. This would very likely stop him from making it to his destination, Yosemite. His lack of water supply didn’t help the situation either because he could only go @NUM1, was “water depleting @NUM2,” leaving him vulnerable to the harsh conditions.

The various features of the setting does significantly affect the cyclist during his journey. For example, if it is hot outside then he would need more water than normal to avoid dehydration under the scorching sun. Also if it was raining he would have to drive more careful to navigate slippery roads and maintain control. The physical landscape itself, whether flat or mountainous, directly influences the effort required to pedal. That is why the setting would affect the cyclist in these fundamental and challenging ways.

The environment around people in certain situations can affect them in many ways, both positively and negatively. For instance if you are hot, a tree could provide shade, or if thirsty, a river neer by could help your thirst. If you were hungry and hot, but nothing was near you this could make you hot and desperate. In this cyclist case the environment affected him in many ways, from bumpy roads, “ghost towns, and trees. For example he said, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barley noticed,” this is because of the "cool pines" around him as he explains in the next paragraph, offering a temporary respite. It also says in the text that the terrain changed and he even came upon a snake, which added to his thirst and anxiety. So then making it harder for him to go one. From reading the the text on can see how environmental features can have direct and powerful effects on a person's physical state and morale.

The features of the setting stronger, effect the cyclist's journey to Yosemite in multiple ways. The features of the land;in, and hills, the fact that it is desert, and the setting in the middle of june also effect this story and its protagonist. The dry and hills land is a huge factor for the main character. Because if is hilly, he has to work twice as hard to climb each incline. The land is dry, so he his thirsty and has no where to get anything to drink, exacerbating his physical strain. The land is also desert, so there is no where he can go for help or to get food, water, or civilization, leading to isolation. He believes that he is not going to make it, a feeling captured in the text which explains in paragraph !!, " the growing realization that i could drop from heatstroke on a goregous day on June simply because i listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh" The setting plays a huge role in the story. It is hot, dry, and deserted this out effects the main character and his entire journey, defining the central conflict.

The cyclist in the essay "Rough Road Ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit" feels discouraged and dehydrated because of the setting. Near the beginning, after viewing the first stop which consisted of a few broken buildings and some rusted pumps, he states, “This sight was troubling.” He also feels dehydration when he reaches the pumps and finds they produce “A tar like substance oozed out, followed by blackish water,” which deepens his sense of despair. Also, as he is pedaling through the barren landscape, he sees a sign that says do not exceed 55 miles per hour, a speed that feels cruelly ironic given his slow, arduous pace. He is thus profoundly impacted by the desolate environment surrounding him.

In this quick passage by Joe Kurmaskie, the many conditions of the road and the area around it determine how he acts and what he feels. “The sun was beginning to beat down,” (Kurmaskie) and he is starting to get tired because it is becoming hot and sunny, so he is feeling less confident about his journey. He was traveling through the high deserts of California in June (Kurmaskie), a time known for extreme heat. Not only is he very tired and hot, but where he is riding is barren and open, and there is no one around him to give him help or to find water, increasing his isolation. Through the passage you can tell that the temperature and weather around the cyclist can change how and why he does what he does, ultimately dictating his physical and mental state.

The essay explains how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The features of the setting are significant because the cyclist's experience is directly shaped by them. The support for this conclusion is found in the cyclist's own reactions and descriptions throughout the text. The setting, therefore, is a powerful force that influences the cyclist's journey from start to finish.

The scenery makes the cyclist happy. He is so happy as he rides through the beautiful landscape, feeling a sense of joy and freedom. The pleasant surroundings lift his spirits immensely, making his journey a delightful experience. Woohoo! He is truly happy.

In this story the setting has a profound affect on the cyclist's trip and to him self. It is hot and over one hundred degrees and he is going down hill with a lot of turns, which adds physical strain to the oppressive heat. The cyclist is getting so hot that his water is no longer cold, offering little relief. Being in this desert is killing him and about to make him have a heatstroke, pushing him to his absolute limit. All the things in the desert, from the relentless sun to the isolated terrain, are doing a lot to affect the cyclist, demonstrating the environment's powerful role in his ordeal.

The setting of a situation can affect a person both mentally and physically. This is evident in the story "Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit." The cyclist is unaffected, for the most part, until the directions he was given by “a collection of old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office” takes him over terrain not suitable for biking. Prior to following the men’s directions, the setting was enjoyable and made for an easy ride; a reader knows this because the cyclist is confident. For example, he says “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.” This confidence begins to deplete as the cycling gets harder. For example, the cyclist says “sometimes life can feel so cruel” after he hits rolling hills and a sign warning of rough road and not exceeding the speed limit. The cyclist became disappointed and wanted to give up because he couldn’t even reach that limit. However, he’s determined and pushes through to reach a shop, which gives a sense of satisfaction and renewed confidence. So in conclusion, the setting can have a powerful affect on a person's mood or motivation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him feel isolated and weary, which are evident in scenes like when he rode through that ghost town. The setting is a big part of this story, and that is all the narrative seems to talk about. The descriptions of him getting water or how the tumbleweeds are crossing the road emphasize the harshness of his journey. He was always thirsty and rode his bike a long way, and there is no paint on the old, weathered signs he passes, showing the desolation of the area. These environmental details consistently work to shape his difficult experience on the road.

How the setting changes the mood of the cyclist is that what he sees pretty much describes how he feels. Like he starts off with strong legs and a smile on his face, full of optimism. Then he comes to the first town which was a ghost town; that didn't really dampen his spirits because when he sees it he just laughs it off. Also when the setting changes so does his confidence in the old men's direction giving. At the first town he still has confidence in what they told him. Then he notices that it is starting to get hotter, but that doesn’t change his mood much. Several miles later he comes to a fork in the road with rusty water pumps and a rundown car; all that makes him less confident in his water level. Then he realizes the next town is a long way away, so he loses more confidence and gets more worried about his water supply. Then the flat road is replaced with rough road, so his mood goes down more as the physical challenge increases. Then at last he goes to a fishing store and gets water, so his spirits go way up with this relief. This progression clearly shows how the setting directly affected his mood throughout the trip.

The features and setting in the story affected the cyclist because they made his journey to Yosemite even harder. In the story it says that it was so hot he could drop dead from heatstroke, which illustrates the extreme conditions. Also his lack of water made him extremely tired as he pedaled, sapping his strength. Next the sun was beating down, so not only was he tired due to his lack of water but also because of it being so hot out he was losing water and energy from his sweat. The combination of heat, dehydration, and physical exertion created a vicious cycle. That is why the features and setting made his journey to Yosemite so difficult and taxing.

In the short story, “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist experiences some difficult times due to his environment. When starting the journey he had very little water to begin with, which was a major problem. Because it was so hot and dry his water went quickly, leaving him with very little for the rest of the trip and causing great concern. The rough roads also made him tired, making it harder to make the journey as the difficult terrain demanded more effort. These environmental challenges combined to test his endurance and resolve throughout the ride.

Features of the setting that affect the cyclist are “the cool pines and rushing rivers”; they affect the cyclist by keeping him cool and energized by the scenery and the temperature, providing a brief respite from his arduous journey. Another is the juice factory, and it was old and shut down, showing that he would die alone, a stark symbol of abandonment. The ghost town which was completely and utterly deserted shows that the place is barren and unlivable, offering no refuge or resources. These are some of the features that affect the biker, shaping his experience through both refreshing and desolate landscapes.

The cyclist is very discouraged by the dry and hot settings around him. A feature is something specific about some thing else. In “Rough Road Ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit” the cyclist takes the advice of a few old men that seems to be somewhat outdated, and gets him lost as he is running out of water and energy. The cyclist says “Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). He is greatly affected by the heat and was so tired he wanted to make sure the building was not an illusion, a testament to his growing exhaustion. Also, the changed terrain affected how much water he drank and how hard he had worked just to get up that one long hill, draining his remaining strength. The dry climate and tough terrain greatly affected the cyclist, compounding his physical struggle with mental despair.

Heat, desert, humidity – all are things that affect the cyclist as on his journey. First, heat because the heat is making him thirsty for water @CAPS1 he is running row on. For example, the narrator describes, “… water bottles only had a few tantalizing sips.” This means that the day is hot and running out of water, intensifying his desperation. Second, desert because the narrator is the only one around and deserts are usually deserted. For example the narrator exclaims “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, structure of any kind.” @CAPS1 clearly states that he could be in a desert where no one wants to be, emphasizing his profound isolation. Lastly, humidity, because it can be hot but then the humidity comes into plan and makes the sky more dry and seen hotter than it usually is, adding another layer of physical discomfort. This is why heat, dessert, and humidity all are things that affect the cyclist as he is on a journey, each element contributing to his ordeal.

The features of the setting greatly affect this cyclist. At first he is fine riding along the old-timers “shortcut” as he states that “things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” But what he didn’t know was this was the beginning of a very rough day. He arrived at the first “town” which was a ghost town. He wasn’t overly worried yet but at about sixty miles in on his journey he came to a ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a broken down corral. The cyclist explains how he had drank a lot of his water and was in need of some. He tried the pumps but he explains how “a far like substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” A couple miles later he came to a highway sign that read ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The cyclist continued on desperate for water. He even came across a snake, heightening the sense of danger. He was now fearing a heat stroke, his body pushed to its absolute limit. He came to an abandoned grape juice factory and hung his head in defeat. The cyclist then was almost completely dehydrated from the long, tiring bike ride. The cyclist was sure he was going to die from dehydration or a heatstroke that this terrible ride had caused. He finally came to a shop a drank from the sink, saving himself from collapse. So this ride was torturous due to the setting, a harrowing journey shaped by the unforgiving environment.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in positive and negative ways. At first, there were the two old men who gave the cyclist the out-of-date information. They affected him negatively because if it wasn’t for them, the cyclist would have never gotten lost. When the cyclist arrived at the first town, the water pump affected him, the cyclist was running out of water and the water from the water pump tasted like battery acid and was about @NUM1∞, dashing his hopes for relief. The cyclist was becoming more and more dehydrated and the small, rolling hills didn’t help his dehydration, he also used a lot of energy in order to go over the hills, sapping his remaining vigor. Finally, he found Gary and Wilber’s fish camp where he was able to get water, a fortunate turn in his fortunes. This whole experience in a way, affected the cyclist positively even though, at the time, he was affected negatively. The cyclist learned to not take advice from really old people who “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” gaining a valuable lesson from his ordeal. The cyclist was affected positively and negatively by the features of the setting, ultimately emerging with a hard-won insight.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit” the cyclist is on a journey to Yosemite National Park and stops for advice on a quicker route. When he asks the old men he says, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since carter was in office.” Along with using their advice he faces abandoned ghost towns that they said were thriving spots, finding only dust and silence where bustling life was promised. The cyclist overcomes the rolling hills of terrain and mirages and the heat of a day in June in the California in deserts, pushing his body and his bicycle through the unforgiving landscape. Finally he sees bait and tack shop and when he sees that the men who own the place are older than the other guys he just stares at them in all, a look of weary recognition on his face. Based on the quote you can infer that the cyclist will ignore their advice about having the best map, having learned a hard lesson about trusting those who are out of touch with the current state of the roads.

The features in the setting affect a cyclist in many ways. One of which is being only to carry so much equipment which may be needed for a long and arduous journey. For example, you can only take so much water with you and once you run out of it there are no buildings or anything around, meaning that you are out of luck and in a perilous situation. Also, you can only take so much food, which limits your energy and stamina over a long-distance ride. Finally, when you are ready to go to sleep you can’t just pull over; you have to ride until you find a hotel or get home, a reality that adds significant pressure to the trip. I know that I would not make it through such demanding circumstances. So those are just a few reasons on why the setting affects a cyclist, imposing strict physical and logistical challenges that must be carefully managed.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him dehydrated, troubled, and relieved. The cyclist is dehydrated because of the horrible, oppressive heat. He says “the growing realie at von that l would drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This means that the heat is a threat to him and would cause him to become dehydrated and have heatstroke, a dangerous condition. The cyclist is troubled by the scarce sourroundings and the evidence of abandonment. "a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule." He is getting worried because there is no one around and his directions are starting to sound wrong, increasing his sense of isolation. The cyclist is relieved by the water from the sink, a simple but life-saving resource. He had the “overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them.” This means that that he is so profoundly relieved that he has finally found water and he wants to thanks the owners of the bait shop for providing it, a moment that highlights the intense impact of the setting on his emotional state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie. The downhill land format helped him in a way because he wouldn’t have to use as much strength and pedal as hard without having as much water left in his body, offering a brief respite. When he came to a pump hoping for relief, it was rusty with tar oozing out followed by hot brackish water flavored like battery acid, a cruel disappointment. The dryness of the dessert had a bad affect on the cyclist because he wasn’t able to get to the Yosemite water until the very end of his ordeal, prolonging his suffering. The breeze of the wind had a positive affect because it helped to cool him down slightly, a small mercy in the vast heat. The features of the setting in the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie thus affect the cyclist in both helpful and harmful ways throughout his journey.

Many things that involve settings can affect other things, shaping experiences and outcomes. In the “Do not exceed the posted speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist is affected by the setting as he travels to Yosemite National park. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day….” (kurmaskie @NUM1). The setting from the day is affecting him very much and it is hard for him to continue under such brutal conditions. He is very tired and almost sick from the intense, unrelenting heat. The settings of this place are hurting the cyclist and he wants to go home and away from the heat, a desire born of sheer exhaustion. The setting of this place effects the cyclist very much, demonstrating the powerful role environment plays in any physical endeavor.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. One way that the features affect the cyclist is that it is summer time, and it is harder for the cyclist because the intense heat of the season leads to increased physical exertion and fatigue. The high temperatures can cause discomfort and sap the cyclist's energy, making the journey more challenging than it would be in cooler weather. This demonstrates how the environmental conditions directly influence the cyclist's experience and physical state. Ultimately, the summer setting presents a significant obstacle that the cyclist must endure throughout the ride.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way could be if the setting was in, like, a place with a lot of water, then the cyclist wouldn’t have to worry about dehydration, as water sources would be readily available. Another reason would be if the old men were never outside in the first place, then none of this would have also happened, meaning the social environment is a direct factor in the events that unfold. These examples show how both the physical and human elements of a setting can shape the cyclist's journey. Therefore, the specific characteristics of the environment are crucial in determining the outcome of the narrative.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist physically. The heat of the California desert causes the cyclist to become tired and dehydrated. For example, the narrator states, “I raced past, trying to keep my balance, a dehydrated star.” The setting is the main factor which causes the cyclist to become dehydrated, as the arid climate and relentless sun drain his body of essential fluids. This physical toll is a direct result of the harsh desert environment through which he is traveling. Consequently, the setting acts as a powerful force that directly impacts the cyclist's physical well-being.

One part of the setting that is affecting him is the sun, which is mercilessly overheating the biker. Another problem is the terrain he is on, which is a number of small hills that is wearing him out through constant climbing and descending. There are also apparently no trees for shade and no clouds or wind to cool him off, leaving him completely exposed to the elements. This combination of extreme heat and demanding geography creates a profoundly difficult challenge. In the end, these environmental features work together to exhaust the cyclist both mentally and physically.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because as the terrain got rougher, things for the cyclist got harder. In the text, there is a sentence that says, “It read: Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” In the next paragraph the cyclist comments, “sometimes life can feel so cruel,” because the road ahead got rough and to the cyclist life was cruel. All the features like the snake, lack of water, and rolling hills are all obstacles in life that people have to experience. We might not like it, but the reward at the end is wonderful, showing how challenges lead to growth. Thus, the setting's difficulties serve as a metaphor for the broader struggles and eventual triumphs in life.

The features of the setting that affect the cyclist are the harsh conditions of the road and the severe weather. At one point, he hit some bad and nasty water, a deep puddle that soaked him and threatened his balance. Along with other hazardous things, he also tried to ride through a vast desert where he had already drank all his bottles of water and had nothing left to drink. He was very dehydrated and had to drink from a bottle of Neslé water he found, which was warm and unsatisfying. It was hard for him to keep going, being dehydrated so bad but he had to push through the pain. At one point a big snake almost took up the entire road, its coiled body blocking his path, and he had to just ease his way on by it cautiously. His riding conditions were so bad, he thought he was going to die, and he morbidly said the birds were going to eat him. The weather was so hot it was hard to go on, the sun beating down relentlessly. He finally found a bathroom, went inside it, drank water from the sink greedily, and yelled to a man outside who then told him the direction he wanted to go, providing a small but crucial respite.

The features of the setting do indeed affect the cyclist profoundly. First in the story when describing the setting it says “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” basically giving a hint or foreshadow that something bad is going to happen because he is entirely alone and vulnerable. This isolation creates a sense of impending danger. Another description of the setting when it affects the cyclist is when it says “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” a sign that is pretty much saying danger lies ahead, something bad will happen to those who are not cautious. These environmental cues directly shape his experience and the challenges he must face on his journey, building tension throughout the narrative.

The setting affects the cyclist in many ways throughout his journey. How? Because there was not a posted speed limit sign up there on that particular stretch of road, the cyclist went right through and over the rough terrain, going faster then he was supposed to without any warning. This lack of signage led directly to a loss of control on the dangerous path, showing how the environment itself dictated the perilous nature of his ride. The absence of critical information in the setting thus became a hazard in itself, impacting his speed and safety on the road.

Poisonous snakes, mirages, rolling hills, and dry dead tumbleweed—these features in the setting that the cyclist was going through have the greatest effect of all. They vividly showed the treacherous path he took, the immense obstacles he had to surpass, and his ultimate will to prevail against them. The purpose of including some features of the setting like the poisonous snakes, mirages, rolling hills, no signs of life, and no water is to show and directly impact how truly bad the conditions were for his journey. If the story had left out these specific details, the audience could say or think he was traveling through any old trail; for all they know, the cyclist could be traveling along a windy river passing through nice developed towns. So you see, the features in the setting help set the grim mood and also reveal the true conflict and severity of the story, grounding the narrative in a specific and challenging reality.

When you do something really often you get used to it, and well, I think the same thing applies to how sitting affects the cyclist's physical features. It might make their butt flat from the constant pressure on the saddle, or their back might develop a different posture and with a different shape. By a different shape I don’t mean that they are deformed, but every person is different so their back can either have a curved “C” shape from hunching over, or a straight “I” shape from good posture, or perhaps a “D” shape from developed muscles. This illustrates how the very act of cycling, a product of their environment and activity, can subtly alter their physical form over time through consistent habit and position.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in these ways, primarily through the oppressive heat and the desolate environment. The cyclist was very hot, as evidenced by the description that "wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt" and his growing fear "that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June." Furthermore, the towns that he passed through, which were supposed to have people, were in fact deserted, increasing his sense of isolation. This combination of extreme heat and profound solitude meant his ride ended up being even harder than it would have been, both physically and mentally. This is how the features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist, compounding the difficulty of his journey.

There are many features of the setting that would affect the pedalists, chiefly the challenging terrain and the extreme climate. The fact that "Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills" (kurmaskie @NUM1) clearly shows the change of terrain. Hills must be traveled up to get to the other side and that takes much time and energy, especially for bike riders who must exert tremendous effort. Additionally, the "high deserts of California in June" (kurmaskie @NUM1) shows the intense heat. Heat makes it harder for most people to concentrate and causes people to become overheated when exerting much force at once. These two conditions together create a formidable environment for any cyclist, testing their endurance and resolve.

The different settings of the cyclist affected him by how he felt when he rode the bike on the road, creating a journey of intense emotional shifts. He was well excited and happy that he is going on the ride and how he truly felt about how he rode the bike real fast through the short cut, experiencing a sense of freedom. And how he came over a long, crippling hill he was riding real fast, which tested his limits. So unfortunately he was riding fast non stop and how he came through the whole road with relief after the strenuous effort. He felt so free and how he when he came over hills that are tall and large, but he mostly believed he could find his way at the end. He said it himself he always stuck in the future, so he’s keeping his future and his wisdom to himself. He thought he was gonna die but all he had to do is ask for a little push, showing his internal struggle. But different things did affect the cyclist by doing the impossible of his very bright future, ultimately shaping his character and perspective.

One of the biggest problems that the author faced in his essay was his surroundings, which presented a series of relentless challenges. The setting of the story in Yosemite provided many obstacles such as the vastness of the park, the summer heat, and the fact that many places had been abandoned. The summer heat was the biggest problem for the cyclist, exacerbating his physical strain. He had to bike many miles, but he only had limited supply of water, a crucial resource in the desert climate. Eventually, his water supply began to run low, which increased his determination to find the next town before he collapsed from dehydration and exhaustion. It is this determination which moves him from ghost town to ghost town and keeps the story moving, driving the narrative forward. Another big problem was the vastness of Yosemite National Park, which he was biking through, creating a landscape of disorientation. Any wrong turns (which he took, thanks to the direction he was given) could get him lost and thrown off track for a very long time, highlighting the precariousness of his journey. It was his confusion as to where the next town was that kept him biking, with difficulty and made for an interesting story of perseverance. An example of the vastness of the park was when he quotes, “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town.’ This place might have been a thriving spot at one time-say, before the last world war-but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This quote shows that even after many miles, he hadn’t seen a sign of anyone living, which would have increased his desperation to keep looking for civilization and underscored the immense scale of his solitary trek.

In 'Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,' by Joe Kurmaskie, the author depicts the vivid details of the setting and how they contribute to the cyclist’s deteriorating condition. For example, the author wrote “Over one long, crippling hill, a building come into view. I wiped the sweat from my eye.” The way the author described the hill as “crippling” shows how much energy it was taking away from the cyclist, emphasizing the physical toll of the landscape. Another quote that contributed to the cyclist’s journey was, “that smoky blues tune 'Summer time' rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain.” This expressed how dehydrated the summer heat was making him, illustrating his mental and physical decline. I believe the author used these modifying details to support the description of the cyclist’s condition, painting a clearer picture of his struggle. I think the description of the setting enhanced the reader’s perception of the cyclist’s journey, making the challenges he faced more tangible and visceral for the audience.

The terrain the cyclist faces don’t help very much considering he is almost out of water. He came across hills that tired him out a lot and made him even more thirsty, draining his already low energy reserves. Also, when he came across the juice factory he used a lot of energy to get there because he was excited by the prospect of refreshment, and that exertion made him even more thirsty. Therefore if he didn’t have any energy left after all of that, he wouldn’t have been able to get to the bait shop, leaving him stranded without supplies in a difficult environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. First of all he is in the middle of nowhere, a vast and unfamiliar landscape, and he doesn’t know the direction of where he is going, and he also doesn’t know the people who live there, which adds to his sense of isolation. The other thing is that he doesn’t have any food, or a drink, so without eating or drinking he can’t get energy, so he can’t ride the bike and is left immobile in a harsh and unforgiving place.

The features in the setting in the story affects the cyclist in many ways. For example in the story it said, “At same point, tumbleweed crossed my path.” This is saying that he is in the desert or somewhere very hot because I know that you usually only see tumbleweeds in very hot places. Thus, being in the desert affects the cyclist because he is already low on water then being in a place as hot as the desert made him get even more dehydrated from the relentless sun. Another feature in the setting in this story that affected the cyclist is the hills he had to climb. This affected him because he was already dehydrated and climbing hills made him have to work more which caused him to lose more sweat and become even more dehydrated. Those are two clear examples of how the features in the setting of this story significantly affected the cyclist.

The setting in this story is very hard for the cyclist. His main problem is the lack of water, a critical resource in the heat. If you deprive the body of water all of your major organs will bake in the hot sun, leading to severe physical distress. Another problem was the condition of the terrain, which was dry and uneven. It is very hard to cycle on bumpy dry land, as it requires more effort and saps one's strength. These are just a few of the significant problems the cyclist encountered in this challenging environment.

The feature in the setting affected the cyclist a lot. It was a hot summer day and he was running out of water, a dangerous situation under the intense heat. With all the heat he could have had a heat stroke, which would have been a serious medical emergency. Another problem was the hills, which presented a formidable physical challenge. He didn't have a lot of energy, and the sun was steadily tiring him out and sapping his remaining strength, making his journey incredibly difficult.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because it was hot and was a tough terrain. The oppressive heat of the environment directly influenced his physical state, making the journey more arduous. The difficult and uneven ground of the path posed a constant challenge to his progress, slowing him down and demanding greater effort. These combined environmental factors created a cycle of exhaustion that was hard to break. Ultimately, the setting's harsh characteristics significantly impacted the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because as he gets closer to the nearest town the ground becomes rougher to ride on. Like when he sees the sign saying not to exceed the limit. That shows that the ground is going to be rough and requires caution. The changing terrain forces him to adjust his speed and handling of the bicycle. This physical challenge is a direct consequence of the landscape through which he is traveling. Therefore, the environmental conditions directly dictate the nature of his ride.

The features of the setting in, “Rough Road Ahead” negatively affect the cyclist. In the California desert, water is everything. If you run out of water then you might as well have run out of life. Without water, dehydration kicks in and it affects not only your body, but your mind too. The cyclist only had a limited amount of water with him when he started. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” Through the deserted towns he came across, he searched for a source of water but found none that were useable. “When I tried a drop or two ,it had the flower of battery acid.” Another feature was the heat. It began to mess with his mind and take toll on his body quickly. “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage.” He worried about heatstroke and his body's need for water throughout the entire trip. Finally, in the deserts of California, wildlife can affect you. The cyclist was using a path that nature had claimed and was not traveled often by people “crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement.” These elements of the desert environment created a series of severe challenges. As you can see, the cyclist was negatively affected by the features of the setting in, “Rough Road Ahead.”

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist because if there is a rough road ahead you're just going to have to be able to handle the ups and downs and the bumps. The author was scared that he was gonna die and that the birds were gonna pick his bones clean. This fear was a direct result of the isolated and unforgiving nature of the landscape. The difficult path not only presented a physical obstacle but also a profound mental challenge. His anxiety about his fate was heightened by the desolate surroundings. Thus, the rough road impacted both his journey and his state of mind.

In the story the cyclist faces many issues that could stop him from not finishing his journey. First, his water supply could cause him to become dehydrated and he could pass out. Another issue is the hot weather in June, which could cause him to have a heat stroke and literally die. The rough terrain could stop him from finishing the trip because he could pop a bike tire and would have to walk. Each of these dangers was a direct product of the harsh setting through which he traveled. The cyclist faces many problems that could end his trip and maybe even life, but pushes through and survives the formidable challenges.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that the cool pines keep the sun from beating down on him and from getting heatstroke, offering a brief, shaded respite from the oppressive heat. Another way is that the towns he went to had either bad or no water and he was becoming dehydrated, his thirst growing with each passing mile. The heat from the sun was make him feel funny, he was hoping he wasn't seeing mirages as the road ahead shimmered with illusory water. Ultimately, the environment proved to be a formidable adversary on his journey.

The cyclist does not really like the setting of the road. It is messing up big time, presenting one challenge after another that saps his energy and morale. The relentless sun and the unforgiving terrain conspire against him, turning his ride into a grueling test of endurance. He finds little to appreciate in the harsh landscape that stretches out before him, a constant reminder of his difficult situation. This setting, therefore, significantly hinders his progress and dampens his spirits.

The setting is a desert in California in June, this affects the cyclist because it is very hot and he only has a couple drinks of water. There is no place for the cyclist to stop and get more water, a fact that fills him with growing anxiety. He says, “there is no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” As you can see that kind of setting would definitely affect the cyclist, leaving him isolated and vulnerable to the elements. The vast emptiness itself becomes a source of psychological strain, compounding his physical distress.

Some features of the setting that have affected the cyclist was the fact that he was running out of water and when he pumped water he said he pumped with all his strength at first a tar like substance oozed out followed by brackish water he said the water tasted of battery acid, making it utterly undrinkable. Also in this setting the cyclist notices a terrain change from flat road then turned into short hills, followed by a snake that looked like a diamond back, adding a new element of danger to his journey. These environmental challenges collectively shaped his difficult and perilous experience on the road.

In the essay “Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist because he was on a bike and it was hot; he ran into bumpy roads, and hills. For example he says, “Not many miles into the next section of the road, he noticed the terrains changing. Flat land was replaced by short, rolling hills.” Another example is, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that he could die from heatstroke.” These examples show that it was not easy and how the features affected the cyclist physically and mentally. In conclusion this story shows that you should never take directions from an old person, especially if it is hot and you are riding a bike, as the journey can become far more arduous than anticipated.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. To start with, the terrain of the road turned from flat to bumpy, which caused the cyclist to have a difficult trip. In the story it said, "Rough Road ahead do not exceed posted speed limit." Since the cyclist had to use a lot more energy on the rough roads and his water supply was limited, he became very thirsty. When he finally saw an old town ahead, he stopped and it looked like it was abandoned. He began to pump water out of the water pump, and no matter how long he pumped for, the water that emerged looked like battery acid. The quote from the story said, "when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid." These are the challenging features of the setting that affected the cyclist throughout his journey, ultimately leaving him dehydrated and desperate.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in this story greatly. The cyclist is cycling in a desert, as stated, “...I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” The environment was intensely hot and the sun beat down on the cyclist, with the text noting “the sun was beginning to beat down...” The location was remote and there was no one to offer help or assistance, fitting the description of a ghost town. There were no natural water sources for the cyclist to refill his bottles, putting him at serious risk of dying from dehydration. His desperation is clear when “I got down on my hands and knees and worked the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength, but only a tar-like substance oozed out.” Furthermore, there was a poisonous snake on the road which could have bitten the cyclist. Additionally, there were hills that required more energy to climb. Since the cyclist had to use more energy to get up the hills, he became more tired and thirsty, compounding his physical strain.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist’s attitude towards the old men. Since the cyclist listened to the old men's directions, he was furious with himself when they proved faulty. Seeing that the last attempt at following their direction had caused the cyclist to become nearly delirious, the setting had added severely to the problem. The beating sun and high deserts of California in the middle of June made the cyclist dehydrated and tired. When he came to a rusted water pump from which “black tar oozed out,” you can picture the cyclist as furious and anxious and, of course, terribly thirsty. The rough terrain and tumbleweeds had caused the cyclist to feel skeptical of his decision to follow the old men's directions, filling him with regret and frustration over his predicament.

The cyclist in “Rough Road; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” starts off in the “serenity of an early summer evening” taking road advice from old-timers. At first when the sun was beating down on him, he didn’t mind; the thoughts of Yosemite kept him determined. Later however, his determination was fading as he realized that his “short cut” was not so short after all. The “high deserts of California in June” and the changing terrain furthered his dehydration and need to find water. The emptiness of his surroundings with “no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind” made him focus on the horizon and tell himself that if he made it there, then he’d be alright. Finally, a building came into view. The hope he got from this gave him strength to move on. Ironically it was an abandoned building which the cyclist describes as a “Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant.” Upon seeing this he had lost hope and hung his head. Believing he was going to die, the cyclist got back on his bike. Driving away from the factory, he saw a sight of a fish camp and immediately regained hope. Going there, he regained his strength and learned his lesson, resolving never to take road advice from other people again.

The setting in the reading affected the cyclist because it was hot, dry, and nothing was around. Being hot was one part of the setting that affected him because he had to drink water a lot, rapidly depleting his supply. It was dry everywhere around him so he couldn’t stop anywhere and cool off, with no shade or respite from the sun. Also when things got hard there was nothing around but ghost towns and abandoned buildings, which offered no real aid and only deepened his sense of isolation. This hostile and barren environment is how the setting profoundly affected him, challenging his endurance at every turn.

The features mentioned in the story's setting made the journey significantly harder for the cyclist. The oppressive lack of water during a summer in California created a harsh environment, making it very uncomfortable for the cyclist to go through the vast, arid deserts. His physical state deteriorated under the relentless sun, and his desperation grew with each passing mile. The worst part of this ordeal was when he tried to suck on pebbles to stimulate saliva in his parched mouth, a tactic that ultimately backfired when he accidentally ended up swallowing one, adding a new layer of discomfort to his already dire situation. This series of environmental challenges tested his endurance to its absolute limit.

The specific features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist because his body has a tremendously hard time adjusting to his life-threatening situation. The intense heat and the dry desert atmosphere are constantly draining his body of its essential water, yet he needs to keep pedaling on through the unforgiving landscape. His muscles ache and his throat burns with thirst, but stopping is not a viable option. Also, the terrain itself is completely stripped of any visible water sources, so he doesn't have anything natural to refuel with, leaving him in a state of perpetual dehydration. This combination of environmental factors creates a cycle of physical depletion that is difficult to overcome.

I think that if we were to enforce stricter punishments on those who speed, then there would be significantly less car crashes on our roads. This is a logical step toward improving public safety for all drivers and pedestrians. Furthermore, really those that have demonstrated bad road rage should be required to attend mandatory anger management courses. Such measures would address the root causes of aggressive driving, not just the symptoms, leading to a calmer and more secure driving environment for everyone involved. This comprehensive approach is necessary for meaningful change.

There were many environmental features that negatively affected the cyclist during his arduous journey. One significant feature included the first ghost town that he came by, which was described as fitting "the traditional definition of a ghost town." This discovery had to affect him psychologically because he realized then that the people who told him about the shortcut hadn’t been out there for a long while, casting doubt on their advice. Another critical feature that affected the cyclist was the severe lack of water in a "desert in California in June," a combination known for its extreme dryness. The cyclist now understood that it might be a very long while before he would get any more water to drink. The steep hills also had a major affect on the cyclist because he knew he was going to have to work exceptionally hard to reach the next town, all while consuming very little water. The abandoned Welch’s building also had a disheartening affect on him since it was empty and no drinks were left for him to find. In conclusion, the cyclist had to battle many formidable features on his difficult way to the National Park, each one presenting a unique and draining challenge.

The cyclist sees his journey affected by a succession of events that will make his travel progressively more difficult and challenging. One of the first errors he makes is taking advice from people that have no real clue of where they are at, a mistake he later regrets, thinking, "I shouldn't have done was let them have a peek at my map." The extreme temperature of the desert also heavily influenced him, as he was "travelling through high desert of California," a place known for its scorching days. The cyclist also finds himself wrestling with a combination of conflicting emotions; at times he thinks he is going to pass away from exhaustion and thirst, and at other times he believes he will be fine and make it through. His spirits lift momentarily when he stumbles into a rather modern bathroom and drinks deeply from the sink, a moment of relief that gives him an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and continue his quest. This emotional rollercoaster is a direct result of the harsh and unpredictable conditions he faces.

The features of the start affected the cyclist by going listing to so dyhrate who have not left town pours in this instead of following his name got him going in the middle like the start sites on the sreach make right site at the fork. He realized what he had stolen inside himself, that "I reached myself right then that I'd always asked to ignore the proper path." He would find on the last stretch is the bitter truth. This is said as he did not comprehend the sight and felt he was walking, not making progress, about to fall on the rough ground and get dust stuck to him. Did he truly want to happen again so he would be forced to always look at the map for guidance.

In the story, the man has a very hard time trying to get to some water. He faces many obstacles in the story, which test his endurance and will. For example, he has gone about many miles without water, a significant distance under the harsh sun. Also, there are a lot of hills and turns within the story which slow him down, each ascent draining his energy further and each bend offering no relief. He is having a hard time getting to water because of many obstacles, culminating in a profound physical and mental challenge.

In the story the cyclist is on a bike ride to a specific location. He has a new map and is doing very well, until he asks these old men the best way to get there taking less time and by getting there faster, a.k.a. a shortcut. He takes their directions and feels good about it, confident in his choice. But soon things change, he experiences new terrain and it becomes much harder, testing his resolve. The type of setting that he faces are steep hills, speed limits that he can’t exceed, dry hot temperature, and he has no water. All these features combine together to make the situation worse, each element compounding his distress. While he is experiencing these things he feels like he is going to die and feels like giving up, his initial optimism shattered. But eventually he finds someone and doesn’t ask for directions, having learned his lesson. So the lesson is don’t take directions from a stranger unless you're willing to face the unexpected consequences that may follow.

The features affected the cyclist because of the rough roads. This affected him because it slowed him down, I know this because in the story it said “Rough Road Ahead Do not Exceed Posted speed Limit”, which this means slow down or you will have an accident, forcing a cautious and arduous pace. Another feature was that it was hot which means he was losing water because it either evaporated or he was drinking it, leading to severe dehydration. I know this because it said “The water bottles contained water a few tantalizing sips” which means it was few left, highlighting his precarious situation. These environmental factors directly hindered his progress and well-being.

The settings affect the cyclist in many ways on the way to Yosemite. Well for one when he took the shortcut, one thing that already made it difficult was that it was June, and he’s out in the desert, a time and place of extreme heat. Also it says how he went to a couple towns that were deserted so there was no way to replenish his water, increasing his desperation. It says, “I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn’t cool down. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” Another thing about his setting that changed was the hills, introducing grueling physical challenges. But once he came to a bait shop, the old man asks him if he knows the best way to get to Yosemite, and he responds, “yes- sir: I own a very good map.” By this he’s understood that the best way to travel anywhere is the path or road he knows because he’ll know what to expect, a hard-won realization. This is how the setting changed his perspective and approach to his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One of the ways it is affecting him is that the description of it makes it seem hotter than what it really is. He says “neighborhood of two hundred degrees,” which is a clear exaggeration meant to emphasize the intense heat he is experiencing. He is saying that it is really hot, and this perception influences his physical state and his morale. The features of the setting affected him because the oppressive atmosphere made it seem hotter, and he was taking the difficult conditions to an extreme, feeling overwhelmed by the environment. This demonstrates how the setting's characteristics can profoundly impact an individual's experience and perception.

In the essay the features of the setting affected the cyclist. The cyclist used words to describe the setting like “flat road” and “short, rolling hills,” which convey a sense of the journey's topography. There were also more examples of such descriptive language throughout the text. The way the cyclist described the setting gave the reader a clear visual picture of the landscape he was traveling through, making the environment feel tangible and real. I think the cyclist was affected by the setting because these physical features directly influenced the difficulty and nature of his ride, shaping his overall experience on the road. The connection between the cyclist and his surroundings is therefore a central element of the narrative.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, depending how the main character feels, that’s what the setting is like. When he got to the next town and left, he was feeling well because nothing was going wrong, and this positive mood was reflected in his surroundings. The setting was very tranquil and inviting during this part of his journey. The narrator says, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them” (Kurmaskie), which vividly illustrates this harmony between his internal state and the external world. This setting was very happy and pleasant just like the narrator's mood, showing a direct correlation between his feelings and the environment’s description. Thus, the narrative effectively uses setting to mirror the protagonist's emotional journey.

Some things that affected the cyclist was the terrain changing into a flat road that was replaced by short, rolling hills, altering the rhythm of his ride. Then he came to a rough road, which presented a new physical challenge and discomfort. Another obstacle for the cyclist was the tar-like substance that came out of the rusted water pump followed by brackish water feeling somewhere of one hundred degrees, making it utterly undrinkable. Every time he pumped it, the water wouldn’t cool down and it tasted like battery acid, worsening his thirst. He was hitting his water bottle regularly to dislodge the air bubbles, which is why he needed new water so desperately. The cyclist was travelling through the high deserts of California and the sun was starting to beat down, so he was becoming severely dehydrated. Furthermore, a snake blocked the pavement in front of him that looked like a diamondback, creating a sudden and dangerous interruption to his journey. These cumulative hardships from the setting significantly impeded his progress.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The setting of the story is “a reservoir campground outside of Bakersfield, California” during the early summer. Being the early summer in southern California, the temperatures are going to be hot and arid. And the main character, who is a cyclist and is doing a lot of physical activity, is going to sweat a lot under these conditions. The temperature and excessive sweating cause the cyclist to drink a lot of water, depleting his supply quickly. The water runs out and we are now into our central conflict of his desperate thirst. The setting also leads the main character to his resolution of the conflict. Being by a reservoir, fishing is going to be a popular activity for the local community. A bait and tackle shop would be the perfect business to have nearby, and since there is one at the reservoir, the cyclist could go inside and quench his thirst, finding a solution to his problem. Therefore, the setting of the story affects both the conflict and the solution, driving the narrative forward.

The cyclist decided to ride to Yosemite National Park during a hot summer day in California. His first instinct was to use a perfectly good, up-to-date map he had brought along. Then he started having a conversation with some old men who decided to tell him about a shortcut they had taken back in the day. The cyclist decided to take the old men's shortcut through the desert with only one measly bottle of water. It was really hot outside, and the sun was scorching down on his back while he was riding his bike. This made him hotter than he had anticipated, and there was no shade or place for him to stop and get some more water. This made the trip much harder for him because now he was entirely focused on finding water and not on enjoying his ride. The setting of the course affected the cyclist in many ways; he was not prepared for the harsh route, and the route he took was not biker friendly. If he had taken the route that was on the map, then he would have known where he was, and his ride would not have been affected by desperate thoughts of slowing down to put rocks in his mouth to reserve saliva or by the constant, consuming thoughts of finding water. His journey serves as a clear lesson on the importance of proper preparation.

The cyclist had a very rough time, as the elements were completely against him. It was exceptionally dry and hot, and he had no water left. In the text it says, "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." This shows that he had hardly any water, and what little he did have would only make him thirstier. The quote, "weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake," makes it obvious that the setting was a harsh desert, and it allows you to visualize the isolated, barren landscape. There was no one in sight—not a building, car, or structure of any kind. He was saving up his energy and his water, but he was starting to go a little crazy from the ordeal. The hills were killer for him; in the text it says "over one long, crippling hill." This shows how rough the conditions were, especially since he told us in the beginning that he is an experienced cyclist. The biker had a very rough time, and the setting definitely was the cause of this immense struggle, ultimately defeating his spirits.

The weather can significantly change the course of action a cyclist will take. If it is cold outside, then the cyclist will bring heavier, warmer clothes to combat the chill. If it is hotter outside, he would most likely bring lighter clothes to stay cool and prevent overheating. Furthermore, if he was riding a farther distance, he would bring more supplies like water and food to sustain his energy for the long journey. Conversely, if he was going on a short ride, then he wouldn’t bring so much stuff, traveling light for convenience and speed. The way the weather is fundamentally changes the way a person will prepare, dictating their choices in gear and provisions to ensure their safety and comfort throughout the trip.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the different aspects of the setting affect the cyclist in several ways. When he first begins his journey, he doesn’t even notice how hot it is, and he says, “the sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.” His mood starts to change very quickly as the conditions worsen. Soon he drinks most of his water and becomes increasingly tired and weary from the heat. He finds a water pump which irritates him when he realizes the water tastes like “battery acid,” offering no relief. As he continues, he sees a snake which he could swear was a diamondback, so he slowly goes by it, his anxiety rising. When he notices a factory in the distance, he uses his last bit of energy to reach it, only to be deeply discouraged when he finds it completely abandoned and silent. His spirits finally rise when he eventually finds a small store and is able to drink a good amount of clean, refreshing water, which revitalizes him and highlights how his environment dictated his entire experience.

Multiple parts of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly. When he arrives in a town with a water pump, this part of the terrain initially offers hope, but the pump does not have good water; as noted, “when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid” (Kurmaskie). This disappointing discovery shows the setting's direct effect on his morale and physical state. His situation worsens when he becomes very dehydrated, described as “in my dehydrated state” (Kurmaskie), which impairs his judgment and physical capabilities. Another part of the setting that affected the cyclist was when he arrived at the juice factory, a potential oasis, and found it closed, which deeply depressed him and crushed his last bit of hope for an easy respite. Each element of the landscape presented a new challenge, demonstrating the powerful role setting plays in shaping a journey's outcome.

The cyclist in this short story was greatly affected by the harsh desert setting. He was riding under an intense, baking sun in a vast desert which is very hot, with little civilization to help him. The isolation was profound, and the road that he was driving on was not very smooth, being cracked and uneven, which gave him considerable troubles. The local wildlife also had a significant impact on him. He once went by a big, coiled snake that he cautiously had to ride around, giving it a wide berth. Furthermore, he thought he was going to die from exposure and that the circling birds were going to pick him off, a grim thought that weighed on his mind. The desert itself, with its oppressive heat and emptiness, was what really got to him. Deserts don’t have much water which is precisely what he desperately needed, and he couldn’t find a proper town to stop at, at least one with some people any way, only finding abandoned shacks. So the setting in which the main character was riding had a huge and debilitating effect on him, testing his physical and mental limits at every turn.

The cyclist was completely exhausted as he was laboriously going up a steep hill. The setting of the story affects the cyclist a lot, shaping his entire experience. This is because while in California it is often really good to be cycling, his particular journey was far from ideal. The weather was warm, which could be perfect, but the destination was not. It had one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a coral that could not hold in the lamest mule that greeted him, a disappointing sight. Besides that, after riding twenty miles ahead, there was a significant terrain changing. The flat road was abruptly replaced by short, taxing rolling hills. After he crested the first few of these, a large, unexpected highway sign jumped out at him, startling him. The rough road was the time where he had to be really careful and not to exceed the speed limit, requiring his full concentration to navigate safely and avoid an accident on the difficult path.

The setting of the essay greatly affected the cyclist, imposing both physical and psychological challenges. These harsh settings discourage him profoundly, although he tries valiantly to keep hope alive. Seeing nothing but dry desert, watching the hills begin to heighten before him, and observing that nothing man-made is in sight for miles, all contribute to a sense of despair. These elements subconsciously affect the cyclist and his growth of thirst, which becomes an overwhelming obsession. To one point the cyclist's original objective, perhaps a destination or a personal goal, became completely invalidated, overridden by his intense thirst pangs and total exhaustion. His journey thus became not about reaching a place, but merely about surviving the brutal conditions imposed by the landscape.

Being a cyclist is not as easy as it sounds; it demands resilience and preparedness. Sure, riding a bike might be easy in a park, but being a true cyclist on a long journey is so much more difficult. Cyclists have many obstacles to over come while riding, which test their skill and endurance. One common obstacle would be a rough terrain, which can be punishing. Cyclists are often used to riding on smooth, paved roads, so going off-road or riding on a rugged dirt road might be a real challenge. In the short story “Do Exceed posted Speed Limit”, by Joe Kurmaskie, there is another critical example for an obstacle cyclists have to be careful of, and that is running out of water, as illustrated by the quote, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state”. The cyclist went on in telling how he needed to try to keep his balance but it was hard because he was dehydrated, and balancing is incredibly important when riding a bike to prevent a fall. In conclusion, when it comes to something perceived as easy as riding a bike, you need to take precaution in what might lie ahead on the open road.

The setting affects the cyclist in many profound ways, dictating his emotional state throughout the journey. It makes him feel hopeful, determined, alone, and completely exhausted at different points. The desert-like terrain, with its relentless sun, leaves him feeling very tired and desperately thirsty. The bumpy road is hard to pedal over, sapping his strength, and the endless stretches of land make him feel as if the next town is years away. While travelling, the cyclist recalls a pivotal moment: “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake… blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me”. The tumbleweeds are a stark symbol of dry desert death, rolling freely in the wind. They remind the cyclist he is completely alone in a vast, unforgiving stretch of sand and rocks. He realizes that were the snake in the path to poison him, he would lie under the beating sun until some other unfortunate cyclist found him. However, later on when he sees the sign for Gary and Wilber’s fish camp, a flicker of hope is restored back to him. He is yet again determined because waiting somewhere near is the water he needs to keep him alive, a basic necessity that has become his entire world. In the end, the challenging setting helped him to safely feel the hope deep inside of him, proving his resilience against the elements.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, "not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This affected the cyclist because he had to pedal harder to go up the hills and he got short of breath due to this increased physical exertion. Another example is, "At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me." This affected the cyclist because he had to wait cautiously for the snake to move so it didn't bite him while he crossed its path. One last example is, "As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out @PERSON1 and Wilber." This had an affect on the cyclist because he was now happy to have found water and to have finally reached his destination, which renewed his spirits. These environmental elements directly shaped his journey's challenges and his ultimate relief.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in several distinct ways because he saw “short, rolling hills,” “tumbleweeds” and “a ridiculously large snake,” and he thought that he was not getting anywhere. The hills forced him to exert more energy, slowing his progress and contributing to his fatigue. The sight of the desolate tumbleweeds and the dangerous snake blocking his path heightened his sense of isolation and the perilous nature of his journey. These combined elements fostered a growing feeling of frustration and the disheartening belief that his efforts were not yielding the forward movement he desired. Ultimately, the setting's physical and psychological challenges converged to create an overwhelming sense of stagnation.

Each area the author entered changed what he felt and experienced. At first, he is lent courage by his surroundings. When he passes through the first town, abandoned and empty, he is still confident he can go on, spurred by the lush green trees and the cool rivers around him that belied the hot sun overhead. They are basically the reason he continued to go on, providing a sense of vitality. Later on during his trek through the desolated empty desert, his bleak surroundings make him feel hopelessness as well as despair, as the landscape offered no relief. Even in the small details, such as the ghost town or the pump, this is proven, as the ghost town brings him the first vestige of despair, and the useless pump only amplifies it by dashing his hopes for water. The scenario and scenery reflect and alter the author's mood throughout the story, demonstrating a profound connection between environment and emotion.

The rider was affected by two men giving him wrong directions during his journey. The rider followed their advice, but instead of taking the right way, he ended up taking a much longer and more arduous route. He was getting very thirsty and fatigued as a result of this detour. He also came face to face with a snake, which further heightened his anxiety and delayed his progress. After these successive setbacks, he finally found the nearest town and got the help he desperately needed, bringing his difficult ordeal to a close. This series of events shows how external interactions with people and wildlife can significantly alter a traveler's path and state of being.

Some features of the setting that affect the cyclist are the hills that the cyclist has to go over and the intense heat. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, influencing his confidence, his energy, and his determination. In the story “Rough Road Ahead; Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is profoundly affected by the features of the setting.
