The cyclist was riding in the hot, desert, an environment that posed immediate physical challenges. This made him thirsties and less active, sapping his strength and slowing his pace. The story provides clear evidence of this, saying, "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt," illustrating his severe lack of water and the intense physical exertion caused by the heat. This desperate situation created by the setting directly impacted his ability to continue his journey effectively.

My point of view is that several factors affect a cyclist, including the need for people to recycle more often. Sometimes people are seen throwing away a trash can with a soda bottle still inside of it. Cyclists nowadays sometimes need to advocate for changing that behavior. My conclusion is that people need to save and recycle stuff to make some new things, which helps to create a good quality world for cyclists and their environment.

The cyclist decided to listen to the geologists' advice about the route. After a while, he starts to get tired from the arduous journey. After the scenery changes to a harsh desert, he starts to get mad at his situation. He criticizes himself bitterly for accepting advice from those old-timers who haven't left the town in years and whose knowledge was clearly outdated.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways throughout his journey. He always kept his head up and was determined to make it to his destination no matter what. The first problem was when he came to the fork of sorts, as he put it, and found his path unclear. He needed more water desperately, but the pumps he found were rusty and all he could get out of them was a tar-like substance followed by blackish water. He tested a small amount, hoping it was better than it looked, but it was not. It tasted terribly like battery acid. He was very thirsty, but had to move on, looking for another water supply. Another problem that occurred was, while he was becoming dehydrated more and more by the minute and unsteady on his bike, a huge snake lay across the road blocking his path. He had to slowly maneuver around it, though it was hard in his weakened state; he was successful and continued down the road. The third obstacle he ran into was when he was so thirsty and finally had a chance for a drink, when to his great disappointment, he found only an old abandoned Welch's grape juice factory. As nerve-racking and upsetting as it was, he continued to move on, still determined to make it to his destination. He finally came up to a fishing supply store where he was able to take a break and get a nice, refreshing drink! Even though the setting was tough, teasing, and ironic, the man made it through and still had a smile on his face at the end of his ordeal.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist primarily because of his endurance levels. The challenges directly test the amount of time he can ride without stopping for a rest. They test however long he can ride up a steep hill without giving up, and however many bumps he rides over without losing control. Furthermore, the setting challenges however long he can ride without a drink of water under the scorching sun, pushing his physical limits to the extreme.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by the changes that occur while riding his bike through the landscape. The cyclist began his journey well with a smile on his face, but then his mood changed because the condition of the road deteriorated and the weather became unbearably hot. Also, there was not any signal or signpost to show him where he was going and to confirm it was the correct way he was taking. Furthermore, his bike tire went flat and needed to be replaced, adding another delay to his difficult trip. Despite all these setbacks, he persevered and continued on his path.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by forcing him to contend with the roads and the heat. He was traveling through a desert in June which made it really hot for him, and he noted that the road was bumpy and that made him have to pedal harder. The cyclist had to put more effort into it because the roads were long and he had the spirit and determination to get to Yosemite. He then ran into a snake which told him that he was getting deeper into the desert, a sign of the increasing dangers and isolation of his journey. This encounter underscored the challenging nature of the environment he was pushing through. Ultimately, the physical demands of the landscape tested his resolve at every turn.

The setting of the cyclist clearly influences his mood. From the beginning to end, the outside world reflects the turmoil in his head. This is evident in the beginning reservoir, empty desert, hills, the Welch factory, and finally the fish camp. The reservoir is a haven, a safe ground that contains everything the man needs. He is feeling optimistic, ready and eager to follow advice of old men. He first hits a ghost town, which is foreshadowing a dangerous future. He passes through still with a level head. He comes to a water pump that gives him battery acid. This is where the mood shifts. He suddenly describes his setting as “the high deserts of California.” The sun is boiling down and water is running low. His hopes start to drop. When the “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” it reflects the turmoil in his head. The terrain is harder and the chances of his survival lessen. When he crosses a snake, it suggests even more despair. It finally climaxes at the Welch factory. How ironic, it is an abandoned juice factory. This is lost hope. When he finally arrives at the fish camp, he is relieved to be alive and is uplifted. The cyclist has made it. It is clear the setting has affected the cyclist by mirroring his internal state throughout the entire arduous trip.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He is riding his bike along the road and encounters a dilemma. “Weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake blocked the pavement in front of me.” He had to stop and wait by the snake which showed him down and freaked him out. He had problems with thirst already and had to deal with a snake that “really did look like a diamondback.” Later, he sees a building up ahead and discovers that it’s a Welch’s Grape Juice factory. He thought that it might have some water but realized it was abandoned. Relating to his thirst, before he left he grabbed some pebbles. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps takes your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate.” Finally, he came across a fishing camp and received instructions on how to go on. This affected him because he finally got to a secure place and got proper directions and will learn from his mistake of listening to the older men at the beginning. The features of the landscape thus presented a series of obstacles that culminated in a hard-won lesson.

The feature of the setting affect the cyclist by giving him hope that the finishing line is not far, yet the vast emptiness also presented a psychological challenge. There was nothing in sight—no cars, building or structure of any kind—which made the distance seem endless and his goal feel perpetually out of reach. This stark, featureless terrain tested his optimism, forcing him to rely solely on his own determination to continue. The absence of any landmarks made the journey feel longer and more solitary. In the end, the very emptiness that offered hope also became his greatest trial.

The author was affected in many ways by the conclusion of his journey. He was tired from the blazing heat, didn’t have much water, and got lost. Water simply was limiting and as he went farther and farther it seemed like things would get worse and worse for him. A man had given him the wrong directions and he probably hadn’t been off his porch in decades, the author said. This misguidance led him into a dire situation, amplifying his physical exhaustion with the frustration of being lost. The entire experience served as a harsh lesson about the reliability of advice and the brutal reality of the desert. He ultimately learned to be more self-reliant after such a taxing ordeal.

In the story the cyclist explains how the road goes from good to bad: An example, "Rough road ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed limit." Also, the dry, cracked pavement gave way to loose gravel and potholes, making the ride jarring and unstable. The cyclist had to slow down considerably, gripping the handlebars tightly to maintain control on the deteriorating surface. This transition highlighted the importance of heeding warnings and adapting to changing conditions. The journey served as a clear reminder that the path is not always smooth and requires constant vigilance.

In the story, there are many elements that affected the cyclist in his journey. The first features of the setting that affects him is the old water pump, which did not work, and when it did the water from it tasted horrible, like metal and rust. The next obstacles on his journey was rough terrain. "Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills," was how he described it, which sapped his energy and slowed his progress. When the narrator finally finds a building, it turns out to be abandoned, with broken windows and no signs of life, deepening his sense of isolation. Eventually he finds a town and rest after his long journey, and learns his lesson from before not to take advice from people he doesn’t know, realizing the value of self-reliance.

Well the features were rough desert like features. For a cyclist this terrain is difficult. For example the lack of water, and the battery acid flavor of what little he could find made his thirst unbearable. The relentless sun and the barren landscape offered no shade or respite, draining his strength with every turn of the pedals. These affected the cyclist in a major way, testing his physical limits and mental resolve in the harsh, unforgiving environment. The desert proved to be a formidable adversary on his path.

'Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills' (Kurmaskie @NUM1). When the cyclist realized the terrain was becoming difficult he become more ignorant and hopeless. 'Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt; and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades caused me to laugh. it was a sad, hopeless laugh' (@NUM1). He wasn't going to die, but even though he was struggling, he made a big deal out of it, amplifying his own misery. Unfortunately, the man lived. He would live on, telling people not to listen to old men. 'Never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since carter was in office' (@NUM3). He was on a long, hot road, and he started taking stabs at the old men, 'I made a mental note to change that paragraph' (@NUM4). The man was not forced to take direction from the old man. In his selfishness to cut back on a trip of only a few rough terrain, heat, and dehydration caused him to be hopeless, angry, and he felt sorry for himself, a lesson learned through unnecessary hardship.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that the cyclist is traveling through the high deserts of California in June, where the heat is intense and oppressive. Another affect said in the story was that the cyclist made it to a town where the water pump was all rusted and with all his strength, he worked the handle and got a tarlike substance followed by brackish water which he couldn’t drink, leaving him parched. Also, the cyclist had been hitting his water bottles regularly, depleting his precious supply much faster than anticipated. Lastly, the old-timers said the towns would be close when really they were far apart, stretching the distance between hope and reality. These environmental and social factors combined to create a challenging and disheartening experience for the traveler.

There are many things that can affect a cyclist's journey, and this particular cyclist seemed to have bad luck from the start. He begins by mentioning his plan for a trip to Yosemite, and the men who hear this offer him a tip about the route. The cyclist is pretty confident in what they tell him, so he follows their suggestions without question, but he ends up getting lost as a result. Compounding his troubles, the cyclist is travelling through the high deserts of California in June. That means he is riding in the summer with extremely dry air and intense heat. When he finally reaches the first so-called "town" he sees, he cannot get the water he desperately needs to rehydrate his body. He also runs into a snake while travelling through the desert, an encounter that startles him and slows his progress. Because it is so hot and he is so tired, he begins to see shimmering mirages on the horizon that further disorient and affect him. All of these environmental features combine to force the cyclist into one long, tiring journey through the unforgiving desert. Ultimately, these features also taught him the valuable lesson to not take advice from old men who have not left their porch, because their information may be dangerously out of date.

The setting for this event involved a little boy who was riding his bike when he met an old man. The man told him about a shortcut that would save him time on his journey. So, trusting the old man, the boy took this unfamiliar road, and I guess something went wrong along the way. The path was not what he expected, leading him into difficulties he had not anticipated and turning what was meant to be a quicker route into a problematic detour.

In the piece “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting profoundly affect the main character, the cyclist. After he first journeyed from the house where he met the old men, he rode over vast stretches of flat desert terrain, where the relentless sun beat down and dehydrated him rapidly. Soon, though, the terrain changed dramatically. As Kurmaskie writes, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This new topography tests his endurance even more, as he now has to carefully maneuver his bike down the hills while already being severely dehydrated and ready to collapse from exhaustion, pushing his limits further.

Hot, dry, and isolated—all are the key features of the setting that significantly affect the cyclist. First, there are the intensely hot days with not a lot of water available to drink, which causes him to become dangerously dehydrated. Also, there is no one around to help him if he gets lost or encounters trouble. As Joe Kurmaskie explains, “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This profound isolation amplifies his vulnerability. Finally, a creature, a large snake, came along the road directly in his path, presenting a physical obstacle so he had to carefully move around it, adding another layer of difficulty to his arduous journey.

Setting is one of the most important needs for a cyclist; if the terrain or weather are bad, the journey becomes far more difficult. For a cyclist, the hotter it is, the more demanding the ride becomes, as the extreme heat saps energy and increases the risk of dehydration and heat exhaustion, fundamentally shaping the entire experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the cyclist faces a challenging problem. For example, I noticed the terrain changing. The flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills, which made the ride more strenuous. After I had erected the first few things, a large highway appeared. That shows when he arrived, the road was not good and also the large highway had a high jump that was difficult to navigate. The cyclist's journey was directly impacted by these difficult physical features of the landscape, making his progress slow and arduous.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by it being so hot outside that he could have passed out and died from heat exhaustion. The intense sun beat down on him relentlessly. Also, he saw a snake that scared him to death, but he managed to pass the snake without incident. Furthermore, he saw a building that could probably help him, but it was abandoned; it was a Welch factory, offering no refuge. Then as he ran further down, he saw a fish place and went to the bathroom to get some water to cool down. Then somebody asked him where he was going and they tried to talk to him, but he still had his map so he decided that he was going to use it instead of listening to other people, trusting his own resources over potentially misleading advice.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead,” a cyclist takes some out-of-date information from a couple of old guys. As he went along following their directions, he found out that their directions were out-of-date and at points dangerous. Also, the setting didn’t help because he was in a desert with ghost towns and it was very hot; it didn't help him believe he was going to make it out alive. For example, in the story when he enters the fork in the road it says he found “several rusty pumps,” and “one ramshackle shed.” This probably didn’t help him because he didn’t have a lot of water left and it was really hot and he was losing confidence in himself that he would get out; the rusty pumps meant he couldn’t get any good water. Also in the story it says that “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind” and that setting affected him because at this part in the story he has cycled for a while and he has no water left and he is getting very exhausted and almost has no energy. Also it decreased his hopes because it says there wasn't a building, or a car, or anything, so it was pretty much an empty desert that he was stuck in and he thought he wouldn’t get sent out of the desert alive. In conclusion, in the story “Rough Road Ahead,” the setting didn’t help the cyclist in his hope or confidence of getting out because the setting was very abandoned and also it was very hot and it didn’t help that he was in a desert.

Well, since the cyclist is in a desert and out of water, he is probably not going to be happy or confident. The "ghost towns" he passes through aren't really a boost of confidence either, as they are empty and desolate. The rugged hills made him angry too, as they required more effort to climb. Ultimately, the oppressive heat affected him the most, draining his energy and spirit as he struggled through the barren landscape.

The features of the land affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the first two buildings that he came to were abandoned, so he could not get any food or water from them, which was a great disappointment. Also, he noticed that the terrain was changing from flat to rolling hills, and this change will put more strain on his legs, making him tire more quickly. Finally, the land was hot and dry, which was making him dehydrated and sapping his strength as he pedaled onward. This is how the various features of the land negatively affected the cyclist during his difficult journey.

In this story the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. He tries to get directions but the people he asked really didnt know what they were talking about, leading him further astray. Thats why you have to be careful on who you ask. Then he needs a drink but that dosent work out to well because the water ends up tasting like battery acid, leaving him more parched than before. Then the cyclist begins to be on his way again and finds same difficulty in the road. The same difficulty in the road. The road is in bad condition, full of potholes and cracks, and must do slower then the speed limit. At this point it felt like he was gonna die from the exhaustion and despair. Lucky he found a bathroom and drank from the sink, a small but crucial relief that allowed him to continue his arduous journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways. Early in the essay, the syclist states he ìenjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers.î The cyclist was enjoying himself and the  atmosphere, but then the mood changed quickly to doubt when he didn't listen to the ìcollection of old-timers who havent left the confines of their porches since Carter was in officeì and his depleting water source quickly became a cause for concern. Doubt was soon followed by @CAPS1 when he saw the sign for Gary and Wilberís Fish camp and was able to get a drink from the bathroom foucets, a moment of pure, life-saving relief. @CAPS1 was then followed by satisfaction when he ìpromised himself right then that he'd always stick to [the very good map] in the future, learning a valuable lesson about preparation and trusting reliable sources over casual, misguided advice.

The setting had a bad affect on the author in many ways. One reason is that the heat of the setting caused the author become dehydrated. Dehydration is when your body begins to shut down due to lack of water, leading to dizziness and fatigue. The setting also affected him by draining his confidence and making him seek out water desperately. ìI hung my head,î means that he was depressed and defeated by his circumstances. This proves that no matter who or what you follow there is always a possibility of death from any circumstances, especially in a harsh and unforgiving environment. Therefore this is how the author was affected by the setting he was biking @CAPS1, a profound experience that highlighted his vulnerability.

I think the settings made it little more challenging to not letting give up also, pushing the cyclist to his physical and mental limits. The relentless sun and the desolate landscape tested his resolve constantly. Also shows that you do better in life when challenged, as overcoming such difficulties can build character and resilience. The entire ordeal served as a powerful reminder that perseverance in the face of adversity often leads to personal growth and a greater appreciation for one's own strength and capabilities.

The setting affects the cyclist because it is in a warm dry climate, causing him to sweat profusely, and requiring like to drink more water to avoid dehydration. When no one else was around, it is more difficult for him to continue, if thereís a chance that he is on the wrong path, and no body available to tell him otherwise, amplifying his sense of isolation. With only abandoned buildings, if any, water was unavailable, which made the journey more tiring and physically straining as his energy reserves dwindled. If the setting were different, this story would not have been as traumatic, as a more hospitable environment would have provided the resources and reassurance needed for a far less harrowing experience.

THERE ARE VAST FEATURES IN THE SETTING THAT AFFECT THE CYCLIST. IN SEVERAL WAYS ONE FEATURE WOULD BE THE “SUN BEGINNING TO HEAT DOWN,” AS THAT MADE THE CYCLIST HOT AND THIRSTY. THE THIRSTINESS REDUCED HIM TO USING HIS LIMITED SUPPLY OF WATER, WHICH WAS DWINDLING RAPIDLY. SO THE SUN WAS ABLE TO AFFECT HIM IN A COUPLE OF WAYS, BOTH THROUGH DIRECT HEAT AND BY INDUCING DEHYDRATION. ANOTHER FEATURE THAT CAUSED SOME PROBLEMS FOR THE CYCLIST WERE THE RUN DOWN “GHOST TOWNS” THAT CONSISTED OF “RAM-SHACKLE SHEDS” AND “SEVERAL RUSTY PUMPS.” THESE FEATURES LED THE CYCLIST TO FEEL HOPELESSNESS, AS WELL AS THE PROBLEM THAT THEY DIDN’T HAVE ANY WATER FOR HIM TO FILL UP WITH AS HE BECAME INCREASINGLY DEHYDRATED. OBSTACLES SUCH AS “TUMBLEWEEDS” AND “PAVEMENT BLOCKING SNAKES” ALSO PLAYED A ROLE IN AFFECTING THE CYCLIST AS HE MOVED ON THE @NUM1 ROAD ONLY DOING “12 MPH,” FORCING HIM TO SWERVE OR SLOW DOWN. ONE FINAL, AND LAST OBSTACLE WAS THE TERRAIN HE RODE ON. THE OBSTACLE BEING A “LONG CROPPING HILL,” THIS MADE THE CYCLIST EXHAUSTED, AS HE USED MUCH ENERGY TO SUMMIT THE HILL, LEAVING HIM COMPLETELY SPENT AND STRUGGLING TO CONTINUE HIS JOURNEY.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The features of the setting affect a cyclist, and the major problems that a cyclist encounters are some rough road, the constant inspection of the bike, putting on necessary equipment, and the need to not exceed the posted speed limit. For a cyclist to be doing all this, I don't think there is going to be any features of the setting that would not affect a cyclist. For a cyclist to be maintaining the speed limit of @NUM1 on a challenging route or dealing with a water-depleting @NUM2, sometimes life can feel so cruel and demanding. At some point, tumbleweeds are caused by too much speed, but for them to be using the necessary equipment, they won’t get seriously injured, which highlights the importance of preparation. Forget that old saying about never taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be “Never accept a journey without being fully aware of the setting's features and their potential impact.”

The features of the setting really affected the cyclist. The author wrote of rough terrain and extreme isolation, describing how “flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake.” After reading this information and the vivid descriptions, I inferred that the author was alone in the desert facing awful conditions. I also inferred a tone of resentment and frustration in his account. He seemed to wish he hadn’t taken the “shortcut” that landed him in this harsh desert environment. The hot weather was another significant factor that affected the author, as he described trying to keep his balance in a dehydrated state. He seems to have not really planned how long the ride would be and how to properly conserve his water supply. Ultimately, the combination of rough terrain, utter desolation, and scorching temperatures seemed to have profoundly affected the cyclist and author, teaching a harsh lesson about preparation.

The features of the setting that most affected the cyclist were the water pump, the Welch’s Factory, and the fish camp. The pump affected him because he was very thirsty, and at first he thought he would have a chance to get water; he was excited and he pumped the water out, as he wrote, “with all my strength.” Yet @CAPS1 he had to go on thirsty, a very risky thing to do while cycling, because the water “had the flavor of battery acid,” making it completely undrinkable. Next, the Welch’s Factory affected him by killing his spirits. He was already feeling bad from the lack of water, but seeing the mocking, ironic image of “a sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice” made him feel even worse. It reflected his own desperate situation, a reminder of refreshments in the past when there was nothing left for him in the present. The last thing that affected the cyclist was the fish camp. It saved his life, as he arrived and "drank deeply from the sink." He was so happy and relieved that he wanted to kiss the owners of the camp, showing how a single positive feature could completely reverse his desperate circumstances and allow him to continue.

The story that I am doing the most was going to talk about what happen in the story. I was not sure about the details, but the name of the story sounded pretty good. If I was in the story, I would not be good because the story is really crazy and challenging. I would need to be really good to even start and write about such an intense experience, and it would require a lot of effort to understand all the events that took place within the narrative.

In the setting they are in Lodi, California, a location that is part of the vast desert. The desert environment effects the cyclist real bad, presenting a series of harsh challenges. For one, it is really hot, with the sun beating down relentlessly. Two, the intense heat is making him increasingly thirsty, and he is rapidly running out of his limited water supply. Then last, he is near no towns, isolated in the arid landscape, so he can’t get anymore water. The profound isolation and extreme heat combine to create a desperate situation, so the setting does effect the cyclist profoundly, threatening his entire journey.

The cyclist is most affected by the oppressive heat, which drains his strength and resolve. He is exerting all his energy and will to get to Yosemite, pushing through the grueling conditions. The hot sun and lack of water makes him very tired and causes him to use his energy inefficiently, leading to a state of exhaustion. At one point, he has to make sure the building he sees is a mirage and not a real source of help. It is so hot his mind could be playing tricks on him, creating illusions that highlight his deteriorating physical and mental state in the unforgiving environment.

The conditions that the cyclist was in was very horid, creating a severe test of his endurance. As he continued on his ride he got hotter and hotter, the heat intensifying with every mile. He was hoping to find water after he finished off his last bit, a desperate wish that grew more urgent as his supply vanished. Taking advice from an old man was his last decision he made, a final attempt to find a solution to his dire predicament. This choice represented his last hope for survival in the face of the overwhelming and hostile desert setting.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly because sometimes, it made him lose some courage and optimism. “and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day” This is an example of how he lost courage, as the beauty of the day contrasted sharply with his internal fear. I wanted to be brave and be strong, pushing forward with determination. But the hot day and all the sweat made the author feel weak, sapping his physical and mental fortitude. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear” This is an example of how the author lost some optimism, envisioning a grim end. He didn’t want to die, but he kept telling himself that he was going to, he should have thought to himself that he was going to make it, but the setting was just too rough. There were bumps along his ride, and the sun beating down his thirst, he became less courageous and less optimistic, his spirit worn down by the relentless environment.

The features of his journey are cruel, each one adding to his hardship. The “rolling hills” make him work harder to get over them, demanding extra physical exertion. The more he works, the more he sweats and therefore he needs fluids to do so, creating a dangerous cycle of dehydration. The lack of water he has does not help, making his struggle even more precarious. Poisonous snakes don’t really bother him if he leaves them alone, but they are a constant reminder of the dangers present. The condition of the roads adds on to the challenge of the hills. Rough roads make him work hard to get through and then over the hills, jolting his body and draining his energy. So this guy is getting it pretty rough from every aspect of the punishing landscape.

Some of the features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the rough terrain and the hills. It says in the reading “flat road was replaced by short rolling hills,” and this constant change in elevation would wear a person out without a good supply of water. Furthermore, the disorienting nature of the landscape made it difficult for him to be sure in what direction he was travelling. And another thing that affects him is the hot June weather in California, which intensifies the physical strain of his journey and contributes significantly to his exhaustion and dehydration.

Throughout “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The cyclist was traveling through a very dry area, where it was very hot, dry, and dangerous. There was no water to be found and the terrain was rough and bumpy, making for a jarring and difficult ride. The speaker stated, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake...” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist faced land blockings and dangerous animals, which caused him to slow down a little bit and proceed with greater caution. It was extremely hot out in the setting he was in, as the cyclist was in the deserts of California in June. The speaker stated, “@CAPS1 rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on gorgeous day in June...” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist was experiencing the high temperatures of the setting, which posed a direct threat to his health. Ultimately, the cyclist witnessed the intense and hazardous features of the setting, which shaped his entire experience.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in many ways, primarily through physical hardship and mental strain. He becomes delusional when he said that if he were lucky one of the stones would be lodged in his throat, a stark indication of his deteriorating mental state. Also he is dehydrated because he uses all of his water and is having to push hard to make it to the next town, a situation exacerbated by the unforgiving environment. These combined factors demonstrate how the setting directly impacts his physical endurance and psychological well-being.

The features of the setting started out easy like a road that's flat, with cool pines to keep him cool and not hot. Then it got harder with a lack of water, the road is not flat anymore but instead filled with challenging inclines, and there are snakes to watch out for while the cool pines are gone, leaving him exposed to the harsh sun. This progression from a manageable to a difficult environment clearly shows how the changing setting increased the physical demands and dangers of his journey.

In the story "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit," the features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. As he was riding, he was passing through desert during June, a very hot month. There is not much water present in a desert, and so, particularly in the even-hotter-than-normal June sun, he was at risk of running out of water. Had he been driving through, say, a forest or perhaps rolling grasslands, he might not have been in such danger, and could have merely looked for a river or creek for water if he was desperate. Another thing that might have affected the cyclist would have been the effect of the desert on his mind. When people think of deserts they often think of dry, barren wastelands, complete with buzzards and maybe a dead cow skull, as in movies. Deserts are intimidating; they have a bad reputation and so, as he was riding through and was low on water, thoughts of death and how he was "going to die and the birds would pick (him) clean" ran through his now-terrified head. Had he been in a city or in rolling farmland he might not have been as terrified, for there are people in those places and places to be safe. But, in his desert, he had neither, allowing him to give way to despair. Setting does a lot to influence stories, so it is important to keep that in mind when reading, as it shapes both the physical challenges and the psychological turmoil of the characters.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was out of water in a desert-like environment and there was no one around for most of it, so he was down on his own. The cyclist was affected in the story when he says, "I got down on my hands and knees, working the water handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar-like substance oozed out followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees." That affected him because he had been drinking a lot of water before he got to that point in his trip and was almost out, so he desperately needed to fill up with more, but he did not have a reliable place to get it. This encounter with the broken pump underscores the harsh reality of his situation. That is one of the key features of the setting that profoundly affected him, leaving him vulnerable and desperate in the unforgiving landscape.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by getting dehydrated, getting tired, and by getting lost. After the cyclist was on the road for a while, he had drunk almost all of his water, but he still had a considerable distance to go before he reached his destination. He was going to try to find somewhere to stop so he could pick up more water, but there was nothing around for miles, no stores or houses in sight. He also got increasingly tired because he was out in the relentless sun, had barely any water left to drink, and he didn’t know where he was going, which added to his mental fatigue. One last example was that he was completely lost. There were no cars, buildings, or people anywhere in the desolate surroundings. So if he were to get hurt or sick, no one would have been able to help him, highlighting his isolation. In conclusion, being dehydrated, tired, and getting lost were the features of the setting that significantly affected the cyclist during his difficult journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he runs out of water while trying to traverse the difficult terrain. In the setting, there is a desert in California that he is riding through on a bike, as noted when he states, "I was travelling through the high deserts of California." The word "high" means that there were hills which would make the journey even more strenuous and demanding. The hills appeared later in the story as the cyclist said, "flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." When the speaker says "replaced," he is trying to show a distinct and challenging change of terrain. Another feature of the setting is the tumbleweed that he crosses on other hills, described as "tumbleweeds crossed in path." The tumbleweeds made him remember he was in the desert because tumbleweeds are strongly associated with arid landscapes, which vividly brought up the thought of dying and being picked apart by birds, intensifying the psychological toll of the environment.

Well, if the setting relates to the theme, then the story will make sense and feel more cohesive, like if it’s a sad story and it’s an ugly, rainy day then the atmosphere will match very nicely, enhancing the emotional impact. The setting establishes the mood and provides a backdrop that reinforces the narrative's core ideas. That’s how the setting makes the story better and more immersive for the reader, creating a unified and powerful experience.

If it is hot out, you can dehydrate quickly, which is a major risk for any cyclist. Also, if the terrain is long and hilly, you use a lot of energy, making the ride much more demanding. It can be rough on your equipment, body, and mind, testing your endurance on all fronts. Make sure you dress appropriately for the conditions and carry lots of water to stay hydrated. Next, make sure your tires are properly inflated and all your equipment is working properly before you set off. Then, plan a good route that allows you to stop at places and catch a breath or drink some water to recover. Also, make sure you eat well, as food provides a lot of the necessary energy to complete your journey safely and effectively.

In the setting of the essay "Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the sign had a great affect on the cyclist, reinforcing the challenging nature of his journey. It made him even more determined to finish because the terrain was so hard to ride through, presenting constant physical tests. For example, the author writes, "At some point, tumber weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamond back—backed across the majority of the pavement in front of me, I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." The author fully explains how no matter how bad the obstacles are he comes across he keeps trying to ease on by, demonstrating his persistent resolve. The terrain affects the character by keeping him determined to overcome each new difficulty. This happens to many people in their sports, where external challenges fuel internal drive. For example, in football, players often take any problems, like a tough opponent or an injury, and use them as reasons to push themselves harder to finish the game, showing a similar spirit of perseverance.

In the story the cyclist was affected by several key factors. The cyclist was significantly affected by the directions of the old man, which were intended to help him. It says that they gave the directions to him to help him out, suggesting it was a supposed shortcut. However, I think the cyclist believes the directions are out of date and unreliable. The reason I think this is that in the second sentence of the story it says, "never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since carter was in office," indicating his skepticism. Furthermore, the feature of the setting also affected him because he had to ride up and down through what he thought of as rough terrain, a direct result of following the questionable advice. The combination of misleading directions and the difficult landscape created a challenging situation for the cyclist, which is what I think affected him the most.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the features of the setting affect the cyclist a lot, primarily through the physical environment. The terrain has a great deal to do with it, as does the oppressive heat. First, the terrain affects the cyclist significantly. It affects the cyclist because there are a lot of hills, requiring constant exertion. The text says, "With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill." In order to go down a hill, you had to have gone up a hill first, which demands even more effort. So, having to use the energy to pedal up steep hills affected the cyclist a lot, draining his stamina. Next, the intense heat affected the cyclist profoundly. I know this because the text says “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke,” highlighting the danger. This proves it is extremely hot outside, creating a hazardous condition. Heat would affect the cyclist because it prevents you from functioning at your greatest ability and leads to rapid dehydration. That is how the features of the setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist; the terrain affects him because of the exhausting hills, and the heat because it drains your energy quick, creating a doubly challenging journey.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed posted speed limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, creating a series of obstacles. One way it affected him is that the towns were old and deserted, offering no respite. In the story he said “This place might have been a thriving little spot… but it was a ghost town.” Because of this, he could not get any water or any reliable directions, leaving him isolated. Furthermore, the features of the setting affected the cyclist because the roads were bumpy and there were many hills to climb. The text states, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,” and the cyclist had to use all his power to maneuver over these hills, which was physically taxing. The third reason why the setting affected the cyclist was the weather and the fact that it was a desert environment. He notes, “I was traveling through the deserts of California in June.” Consequently, he was hot, sweaty, and terribly thirsty from the arid heat. He was also tired and desperate to find water and a town that was not deserted, his journey defined by this need. Ultimately, the features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit,” through the difficult roads, the deserted towns, and the critical lack of water.

In the story “Rough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limits,” the setting is established as a long, isolated road with “no one in sight not a building, car or structure of any kind.” This profound isolation contributes to the cyclist's experience. The cyclist could be affected by the rough road that he has to ride down, as such terrain demands constant physical attention and effort to navigate safely. The absence of any signs of life or support along this desolate path would only amplify the difficulty of the journey, making the challenge both mental and physical as he presses forward alone. This combination of a rough road and extreme isolation defines how the setting impacts his ride.

In the essay by Joe Kurmaskie, he describes his experience of bike riding in the desert. The setting affects the cyclist in many ways throughout the writing. At first, Kurmaskie is confident as he listens to a group of old codgers giving him advice. The setting is calm and happy and Kurmaskie writes that he “enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening”. The word “serenity” gives the affect of calm and peace, establishing a positive and hopeful beginning to his journey. However, as Kurmaskie proceeds into his journey, the setting changes. He is troubled by the “ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule” in a ghost town that he meets in the desert, a sight that sows the first seeds of doubt. Even later, the terrain changes and he sees a sign stating “Rough Road Ahead”. Kurmaskie’s confidence turns into even deeper doubt and worry as his water supply runs low, amplifying his sense of isolation. Finally, Kurmaskie sees a sign for a fish camp. Here, his hope returns as he finds a “rather modern bathroom” where he can stop to get a drink, a simple amenity that feels like a lifesaving oasis. As the setting changes, Kurmaskie’s confidence is followed by determination and then relief, completing his emotional journey through the landscape.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is in a desert-like place with a water shortage and he could have gotten very tired. The harsh environment posed significant physical dangers, including the threat of dehydration and exhaustion. I would never have asked old people for directions in such a situation; he should have asked someone that was in charge of a store, because those people get asked many times and might have provided more reliable, current information about the route and conditions. Also, he could have died if that snake had bitten him or from what he described as “heatstroke,” highlighting the severe risks presented by the desert setting. The cyclist's ordeal underscores the importance of preparing for and respecting the power of a natural environment.

The story begins as the author, a cyclist, has taken directions from several very old men to reach his bike-ridden destination of Yosemite National park. He starts out confident enough and then reaches the first town the gentleman described. It is a ghost town and amuses the author; still believing he’s perfectly fine he sets out again, this time arriving at a place with “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule”. It is at this point that the author starts to worry as his water supply is low and the promised resources are nonexistent. He proceeds past rolling hills, snakes, tumbleweeds and different land-marks. Each one rips his confidence and excitement to shreds, especially the juice factory as the author is currently very dehydrated and losing all hope, a cruel irony in his parched state. Finally, he arrives at the water he seeks in the form of “Gary Wilber’s fish camp,” and refreshes himself and his dried-out hope. Each time the author passed a land-mark his confidence took a beating, and even though he was in dire physical health, not having any hope for his sunny breezy vacation can drain a person even more from the inside out, demonstrating how the setting shaped his mental state as much as his physical one.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist negatively because he was in the desert in the summer with little water and no sources to get a drink at. The isolation was a major factor in his distress. For example, he says “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind's”. This explains how his setting affected him because he had no where to go or get a drink, leaving him completely vulnerable to the elements. The complete absence of any sign of civilization intensified his feeling of being stranded. That is my reason why the cyclist's settings were negative, as the environment offered no relief or assistance in his time of need.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in bad ways. The rocky road and steep hills made him peddle harder, draining his physical energy rapidly. The old people's directions made him go through the rocky way, a route that proved to be more challenging than anticipated. The temperature from the desert made him thirsty so he ran out of water fast, and the little he had was unpalatable. He said “When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” The heat could have killed him anytime, a danger he was acutely aware of. For example, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from the heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” This ride this man took to Yosemite was a very dangerous ride, where the setting itself became an antagonist testing his limits and threatening his well-being. The cumulative effect of these harsh features created a perilous journey through an unforgiving landscape.

The setting can greatly affect the cyclist, as the specific place can change what happens and how the events unfold. For example, if the story had taken place in Alaska, the cyclist would not have had "wide rings of sweat circling my shirt" and instead would have been fighting off hypothermia in the frigid cold. The setting is very important because it affects all of the details in the writing, from the physical sensations to the very challenges the character must overcome. Ultimately, the environment is a powerful force that shapes the entire narrative experience.

At first the terrain was fine and he felt confident on his bicycle. But when he reached the first town, it looked like one of those ghost towns in the movies, completely deserted and silent. The next town didn't come up when he was told it would, leaving him alone in the vast emptiness. The terrain was that of a desert with no water for miles, the sun beating down relentlessly. But he stayed determined, pushing through the harsh conditions. And he made it to some water though, a small oasis that saved his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by presenting harsh, physical obstacles. For example, he finds a "ramshackle shed" and tries desperately to find water within it. It affected him profoundly, because it says, "I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees." The quote meaning that he was determined to find water and perhaps anything to sustain himself, showing his will to survive the unforgiving landscape.

The setting affected the cyclist by depriving him of hydration and weakening him considerably over the course of his ride. The large hills and rough roads ebbed away every bit of his strength and wore him down both physically and mentally. The narration states, “Over one long, crippling hill,” a description that reflects the writer’s feeling about his arduous adventure. Words like “long” and “crippling” show that the trip was a horrible experience, emphasizing how the difficult terrain directly contributed to his exhaustion and struggle. This demonstrates the profound impact of the physical landscape on his journey.

Pride, determination, relief – all are things that the cyclist felt during his long bike ride. First the cyclist started off riding on fresh legs and with good directions, but after a while down the road he started to doubt the old men, writing “a diary with my last entry in place of old men, their wisdom, and their been a sense of direction, I made a mental move to change it.” After feeling that the direction might be rough, he rode on out of pride to get to his destination. Next the rider had great determination to get to his destination and did many things, noting “I gathered – a few pebbles and stock them in my mouth to take my mind off of thirst.” This quote shows that he would do almost anything to keep going forward. Finally the cyclist was fatigued when he arrived at the shop because he then knew the old men were right and he would reach his destination, stating “As I stumbled into rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink,” a moment which shows he was relieved to finally get water but also to know the men were right all along, completing his emotional journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist when he was thirsty. A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth could be seen. This proves that the rider was thirsty because in the paragraph before this, it talks about him having a last burst of energy going down a hill. He was also sweating a lot from the physical exertion and was wiping sweat from his eyes, which intensified his feeling of dehydration. The advertisement directly appealed to his physical need, highlighting how the environment can trigger a deep sense of thirst. This connection shows the setting's power to influence his physical state and focus.

I work better when I can feel the environment. I think the same goes for cycling in the mountain, where the fresh air and no worries on your mind can make the activity enjoyable. The pleasant climate and the easy pace, combined with the fresh air and the fine trees, contribute significantly to the experience. The surrounding environment, with its natural beauty and tranquility, makes him feel better and more connected to the activity. For a cyclist, therefore, the environment plays a vital role in enhancing performance and overall enjoyment, proving that our surroundings are integral to our well-being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a major way. The setting affected the cyclist's performance directly. For example, the harsh temperature started to make his pedaling sluggish and labored. The settings also made the cyclist a little frightened; for instance, the cyclist came across a snake on the path that he was terrified of, causing his heart to race. Again the settings affected the cyclist by tempting him with its features. For example, the clear, cool river tempted the cyclist to stop riding and go get a drink of water to quench his thirst. In conclusion, the setting had a major affect on the cyclist, influencing his energy, emotions, and desires throughout the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For one, a lot of the settings discouraged the cyclist. This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. As soon as the cyclist hits this town he realizes that the old man's advice might not have been so great, filling him with doubt. The dry desert affects the cyclist the most profoundly. This hot climate makes the cyclist extremely thirsty, hot, and sweaty. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke... The cyclist's tone here is sarcastic but he is still deeply concerned about his health because of the oppressive heat and lack of water. The fact that there is nothing living around the cyclist also affects him mentally. Since he talked to the old men for directions he has not seen a glimpse of life, or buildings or anything encouraging. So this definitely discourages the cyclist and makes him lose his will to continue his difficult journey. In conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, from his physical state to his morale.

The cyclist tracked through a barren land trying to get to a land of rivers and valleys. Tracking through the first town, the cyclist saw a ramshackle shed, rusty pumps, and a corral located in the desert of California. The cyclist was very angry that the old men led him into this barren town, however he kept a small hope and traveled to the next destination. There, he found an abandoned fruit juice factory and bottling plant, and how discouraged the cyclist was, he started to give up completely. I was going to die, he claimed with all hope lost. The man feels like there is nothing left for him and it is the old men who caused this dire situation. Then finally, he came across a bait shop which he found on his own, giving him a huge relief and a renewed sense of possibility. The features effects his attitude because in a barren land you lose hope as did the cyclist. Therefore, what is around us affect us profoundly, as in education, friendship, and survival, shaping our journey and its outcome.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist is affected both emotionally and physically by the features of the setting. At the start, when he came to a deserted shed with rusty pumps, he began to feel discouraged. “[The] sight was troubling,” (page @NUM1) he noted, a feeling that deepened his existing fatigue. Further on in the essay, the terrain changes from flat land to short, rolling hills and tumbleweeds began to pass. The cyclist is definitely affected by this change in terrain. He is now exhausted but continues to pump his legs and ride on, his muscles straining with the new effort. Before the end of his ride, the cyclist reaches an abandoned @ORGANIZATION1. The setting now includes a large picture of a young boy drinking a refreshing glass of juice, which serves as a cruel reminder of his own thirst. The author seems almost defeated by this. “I hung my head” (page @NUM2) he confessed, overwhelmed by the sight. In the end, once he finds an old fisherman's store, he is profoundly relieved. Seeing the store from a distance excited the author, because he could finally have a drink. The author's mood and body were greatly affected by the features of the setting throughout his arduous journey.

The features of the setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie show that as the day goes on the cyclist becomes tired and worn-out from his long ride through rough terrain trying to find his way back home. The harsh environment, with its relentless heat and difficult paths, steadily drains his energy. His struggle culminates when he then saw some buildings down a hill and said “With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill” (kurmaskie @NUM1), a statement that highlights his physical and mental exhaustion. After the rider finally gets home, having endured the challenging journey, he says he is going to do it again, demonstrating a resilient spirit that persists despite the hardships faced.

The main effect of the setting is the cyclist's lack of water. It is in June, while he is riding his bike in California. Therefore it’s going to be very hot and he’ll need a lot of water to stay hydrated, a basic need that goes unfulfilled. When he sees the abandoned Welch’s Grape Juice factory, it just makes him think of his thirst even more, taunting him with the promise of refreshment that is no longer available. Also the terrain he is riding is not the easiest, which compounds his physical strain. He starts out riding on flat ground but then is riding on hills and not so flat terrain, which requires greater exertion. This doesn’t help his dehydration, accelerating his fatigue. That’s why you should always carry a lot of water with you if you’re riding a bike during the summer, as this narrative clearly illustrates.

The effects of the settings were how hot it was and the cyclist's road he was on. The rider said it was June in the summer time, which meant it was very hot, causing him to sweat and yearn for a cool drink. And the roads were not smooth; they were very old and raggedy, full of cracks and uneven surfaces that jolted his bike and tired his body. This combination of intense heat and poor road conditions created a physically demanding and uncomfortable journey for the cyclist, significantly impacting his ride and overall experience on the path.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” a cyclist is going against heat, a lack of water, and rough hills trying to maneuver around. The oppressive summer sun beats down on him, intensifying his thirst as his water supply runs low. Meanwhile, the rolling, uneven terrain of the hills demands constant physical effort, testing his endurance and resolve with every pedal stroke. This challenging combination of environmental factors creates a formidable obstacle course for the rider, pushing him to his physical limits throughout the narrative.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is trying to bike up hills and down hills, which can be very tiring and physically demanding. Also, the hot air can dehydrate him quickly, which can cause him to pass out from heat exhaustion. Along with the dry air, there is dry land, which means there is no place to stop for water or take a break in the shade. The rough terrain makes the biking more arduous because it involves more energy and concentration than biking on a smooth path. Finally, the snake in the middle of the road made it hazardous for the biker to go around, forcing a cautious detour. If the snake would have bitten him he could have died from its venomous poison, ending his journey tragically.

The setting in the essay "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" was very hot and dry, with very little shade or moisture, at some point maybe even none at all. This weather affected the author profoundly because he had no water at all so he was getting more dehydrated the further he went, his thirst growing with every mile. The relentless sun beat down, offering no respite from the heat, which sapped his strength and increased his discomfort. The arid environment, devoid of any streams or sources of liquid, intensified his physical struggle. His journey became a test of endurance against the elements, where the lack of hydration was a constant and dangerous companion.

How the features of the setting affected the cyclist. The feature was that you should never take advice from old people that never get out of the house, as their knowledge of the area is outdated. For example in the story it says, “Never accept travel advice from collection of old timers who haven’t left confines of their porches since carter was in office.” This affecting the setting because if it weren’t for his map and let them take a peek at it, that would of saved him a load of trouble and misdirection. Their well-intentioned but incorrect guidance sent him on a more difficult path than necessary. Ultimately, relying on his own resources would have been the wiser choice for navigating the unfamiliar terrain.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie the setting of the terrain was hot and water draining, posing a significant challenge. In the text it says “Followed by blackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two-hundred degrees” this proves that the cyclist is exaggerating about the very hot temperature of the high deserts of California, emphasizing the extreme heat. The setting is also water draining and had to stop in the desert town to refill his water bottle as in the text says “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of a rusted water pump with all my strength.” This proves that the cyclist had to stop for water and using much power to pump it out, highlighting the scarcity of resources. In conclusion always prepare for the worst but hope for the best, as the harsh environment demands respect and foresight.

In the story, there are many features of the setting that affect the cyclist. One setting feature is the rolling of steep hills. The hills make the cyclist exhausted and even more desperate for water, draining his energy reserves. For example, in the story it says, “Over one long crippling hill, a building came into view”. This shows that the hill was very hard and strenuous to get over, a major obstacle. By using the word crippling it informs us that the hill was brutal and very hard to get over, pushing him to his limits. Another setting feature that affects the cyclist is the absence of any civilization on his cycling path. While he was riding he notices that there is nobody around to help him if he gets in trouble or needs water, increasing his isolation. The absence of people makes him feel stressed and worried about his journey, amplifying his vulnerability. It shows this in the story when he say, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind”. Also it says in the story “I was going to die and the bird would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive out door gear and a diary with the last entry on the parse of old men". This shows that there was nobody around to help him and he knew it, leading to a deep sense of despair. He thought he would die alone and that birds would eat him, a vivid fear born from the complete emptiness of the landscape. He was obviously worried about the absence of people and the dangers of such profound solitude.

Usually the features and setting have a major affect upon the cyclist. The features and setting relate to and describe the harsh, and eventually relieving, condition of the cyclist. The setting relates to the person and plays a role, which the cyclist can observe and interpret. One reason how the features of the setting affects the cyclist is it shows the various problems that are being faced by the cyclist. For example, the cool pines and no one in sight emphasize that the cyclist is alone. The way this interprets a clear meaning is that the cyclist needs help getting home, and eventually by traveling, he needs water to fill his thirst. Prior to this, the features show the weakness of the cyclist. For example, with that he believed it was his last burst of energy, as he constantly maneuvered down the hill. The features and settings affect the cyclist by showing how he was facing his troubles, thirst and fear, which all lead behind him at the end. These features and settings develop a clear understanding for the cyclist, and what is to be expected by him on his arduous journey.

The features of the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist. When he started that ride, he was confident that the “old timers” were right about which directions and roads he had to take to get to Yosemite National Park. Though the sun was bearing down, he refused to give up, just as he says, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I hardly noticed.” He came up to places that were worn down and deserted, so he knew he was alone if anything happened. The desert heat had made him drink his water pretty regularly, so he tried to get more, as in, "I got on my hands and knees. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid." He was so thirsty that he would have drunk the hot water. Then he thought he had only a few miles to go, so he kept going. He was weakening as he pedaled along the changing terrain, trying to keep his balance in his dehydrated state. With what little energy he had left, he had passed an abandoned well by a Grape Juice factory, which probably tested his patience and sanity. He had resorted to gathering up a few pebbles and sticking them in his mouth just to keep his mind off his thirst. He was losing hope when he came upon “Gary and Wilber’s fish camp best bet,” and then he felt relieved after he was able to get cool water. By then he had learned his lesson, to stick to his map and be better prepared.

In the author's recollection of his long and tiresome bike ride he talked about the struggles he had to face. When he set out that morning he asked some old guys on a porch for directions to a specific location. They told him that they knew the way and that they knew a shortcut. He chose to take their advice but later regretted it. When he found the towns that they spoke of, all he found was ghost towns. He concludes, "Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." He does eventually reach a town where he finds signs of life. There he asks another old guy if he knows the way to Yosemite, and the guy says he has a good map. All along his ride he was plagued by the sun and lack of water. The sun made him hot and thirsty which forced him to drink a lot of his water. When he reached his last few sips he resisted from drinking it and began losing consciousness, fearing he could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June. This experience underscored the perilous nature of his journey.

A cyclist can only travel as fast or as slow as he pedals, and the setting dictates this pace significantly. If the setting is a humid, sunny day he can’t go too fast due to his lung capacity and the strain of the heat. If it is a warm but windy day he has to watch his speed to keep from getting hurt or losing control. Basically, unless the weather is nice or safe enough he will not be able to go very fast. But his safety comes first so it depends on the weather mostly, but also the time of the day. If it is night and dark, reflectors must be put on to keep from getting hit by passing vehicles, ensuring a safer ride under those specific conditions.

The features in the setting are affecting the cyclist because of the heat and the difficult terrain. I say this because in the story it describes all the hills that he has to go up and down with the horrendous heat beating down on him. The heat also makes it hard because it makes you drink more, and throughout the story he was trying desperately to find some water. The water he did find was about “two hundred degrees and tasted like a battery acid,” which was nearly undrinkable. If you have no water that makes it very hard to bicycle that far of a distance in that much heat, demonstrating how the environment directly challenges his endurance.

The cyclist is affected by many features in the setting. The long, arduous hill is one example, presenting a significant physical challenge. The snake and the uneven dirt road are two more obstacles that demand his attention and energy. The oppressive heat of the desert is another formidable element, and his depleting water supply, which causes growing concern, are all examples of features that directly affected him and his journey.

There were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. One page @NUM1 paragraph @NUM2 there is a sign that states "rough road ahead," warning him of the difficult terrain to come. One page @NUM1 paragraph @NUM4 it says "over the long onpiling hill," describing the exhausting climb he faced. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in this story. First of all, in the story it says “and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke” (@NUM1).
