The setting affects the cyclist by creating a desire to go longer and continue riding the bike to discover what is up ahead. However, by riding a bike in the intense heat, you can have a heat stroke and die from dehydration and the extreme temperatures. That is why you are supposed to have a lot of water with you when you are riding a bike, as the environment directly dictates the necessary precautions for survival and success.

The cyclist's settings hinder him in the essay “Rough Road Ahead.” The cyclist is in the desert in the summer time with hardly any water, which creates a constant physical strain. He is trying to find his way to Yosemite, but he gets lost along the way because some old men gave him bad directions, adding to his challenges. During this time he is riding his bicycle for miles and miles in the scorching heat of the summer. His overwhelming thoughts of thirst get in the way of him trying to continue on to find Yosemite, breaking his concentration. I believe that if the cyclist was in a cooler environment then things would have been different because his settings were sort of a distraction to him and his ultimate goal.

The cyclist became profoundly tired, and the harsh desert area he was traversing in June offered no relief at all. The day was scorchingly hot, and every town he had come across was completely abandoned, devoid of any source of water. The terrain was also relentlessly hilly, which made the arduous physical work of pedaling even harder and more draining on his depleted energy reserves. The combination of the extreme heat, the unforgiving landscape, and the complete lack of resources created a truly formidable challenge for his journey.

The features in the setting of "Rough Road Ahead, Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" critically affect the cyclist because they determine how easy or hard his ride ultimately is. For example, the land being intensely hot would enable him to die of heatstroke without water, while the land being dry means he does not have a place to refill his dwindling water supply. Furthermore, the land being barren means to the man that if he did not succumb to heat stroke, there is a significant chance he would not be found and would not survive. Another example of how the features of the setting affect the cyclist is in the story when the road gets rough and he sees the speed limit sign; his thoughts are about how he is going a water-depleting 12 mph. This shows that the features of the setting, namely the contour of the land and the roughness of the road, make the journey a lot harder on the cyclist. The features of a setting could possibly be the biggest arrest on a cyclist, and they determine whether they have a long, hard journey in which they have to push themselves to the limit like in this story or a nice, leisurely ride.

The cyclist in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" was definitely affected by the setting in multiple ways. He was cycling in California—which is a hot place to begin with—in June, which made it even hotter as he came upon a hot desert. When you are doing a strenuous physical activity like that, the last thing you want is to be in the oppressive heat. The narrator only brought one bottle of water, which at first he was drinking regularly. Then it started to get unbearably hot and he was completely out of water. This affected his body by making him dangerously tired, and his mind because he started doubting himself and his ability to continue. Then there was the abandoned juice building where they had once made juice. He said, “In an ironic twist abandoned years earlier had been a Welch’s grape juice factory and bottling plant.” He was dying of thirst and then he found the bottling plant, a cruel reminder of his need. The cyclist was definitely affected by his surroundings both mentally—by thinking “I’m going to die.”—and physically by becoming severely dehydrated from the harsh environment.

The cyclist was riding in some rough, dry, and abandoned terrain that made his journey almost fatal. He described it as being “In the high deserts of California in June.” It was dry, lifeless, and intensely hot. The sun was beating down on him relentlessly and he needed to frequently drink water, but he was running out quickly. The empty towns were what he was counting on for fresh water, but they had been long abandoned, leaving him without hope for resupply. This made his journey very dangerous, as he could have fallen off his bike at any time because of heat stroke. He would have died right then and there in the isolated landscape. His sweat was drying instantly in the heat and there was no way for him to cool off in the lifeless desert, which was both lifeless and dry. He had to endure these extreme, ironic conditions for miles on end, just to find some life-saving water. It was everything that a desert is and all that a person should not have to go through on such a demanding trip.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, creating a series of formidable obstacles. The hills are too long and steep, making the climb exhausting. Every town he passes is completely abandoned, offering no shelter or supplies, and the roads are rough and difficult to navigate. The intense, unrelenting heat also affects him significantly, bearing down without mercy. He is affected health wise, as the physical strain and environmental conditions take a severe toll on his body and well-being, pushing him to his absolute limits. The cumulative effect of these harsh setting features creates a profoundly challenging and hazardous experience for the lone cyclist.

When you are doing any sport or anything where you sweat, your setting is everything. If you are sweating in a harsh setting, you can easily get sick from factors like extreme heat and a lack of resources. The setting from the story "Rough Road Ahead" demonstrates this clearly, as the cyclist had no water and the setting was very hot and unforgiving. That is why the cyclist was tired and sick, because he was sweating profusely in the heat and had no water to replenish his fluids. That is precisely how the setting negatively affected the cyclist, showing the critical importance of environment on physical exertion.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. The features include old abandoned towns and hot temperatures, along with dilapidated and abandoned buildings. This desolate environment makes the cyclist think all hope is lost, reinforcing his despair. The essay says this: “Over one long crippling hill, a building came into view [...] I hung my head that smoky blues tune 'summertime rattle around.'” Then, in an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building, by the looks of it, had been a Welch’s grape juice factory and bottling plant. The sight initially deepened his melancholy, as noted by the line, “I hung my head that smoky blues tune summertime rattle around.” Then, his mood shifted to a happy one when the text states, “As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them.” This shows how the setting's features directly triggered a shift from despair to relief and gratitude.

With no one around and a rough road ahead, not to mention severe dehydration, the cyclist began to feel he was going to die. Because of this dire situation, he began to doubt himself and his ability to continue. However, each time he saw something on the horizon, a building or any sign of potential respite, he tried to get there, pushing forward despite his overwhelming fatigue and despair. This cycle of doubt and determination, driven entirely by the features of the setting, defined his arduous journey and his struggle for survival.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. For one, he was biking through the high deserts of California in June, a time of intense heat. This caused the cyclist to become overheated and sweaty, so he drank from his water bottles frequently. Unfortunately, since there was, “no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” he had nowhere to fill his bottles and thus became dangerously dehydrated. To make matters worse, the terrain changed from a flat road to “short, rolling hills.” Normally, this would not cause too much struggle, but since he was dehydrated and overheated, each hill seemed “crippling” and insurmountable. My thoughts are that if the setting had been a bit cooler and perhaps existed in the time period the old men had lived in, with more resources available, the cyclist would have had a much more enjoyable and less arduous experience. The environment was the primary factor in his suffering.

Excitement, desperation, and self-pity are all feelings the cyclist had because of the setting. He was really excited to get to Yosemite Park because of its peacefulness and contrasting environment. He said, “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite are calling my name.” He wanted to get there because it was so hot where he was currently cycling. He started getting desperate for water, so he drank out of a hot water hole, but it was undrinkable: “I tried a drop or two, tasted like battery acid.” He was running out of water, so he got desperate for some, no matter the source. He also started to have self-pity, thinking, “sometimes life can be so cruel.” He was feeling pity for himself because he had such a long way to go still under such difficult conditions. These are all feelings the cyclist experienced directly because of the challenging and unforgiving setting.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist’s moods in many ways, as the story illustrates. About forty miles into the pedal, he arrived at the first "town," likely already tired from the long journey. Discovering the town was deserted made him a little frustrated. This feeling was compounded when the next few stops were also deserted, and with his water supply almost gone, he became desperate. The physical challenges of the setting intensified as the road became bumpy and a large snake blocked his way, terrifying him. Finally, reaching a bait shop with cool water provided a profound sense of relief. As this progression shows, the cyclist goes through many distinct moods, each directly caused by the evolving setting of the story.

The way the features of the setting affected the cyclist is that the journey takes place in June in the middle of the desert, a time of extreme heat. This harsh environment was a primary source of his hardship. Also, he was given wrong or misleading information, which further complicated his difficult situation and left him ill-prepared for the challenges he faced on his arduous journey.

The cyclist was affected by the climate, the people, and the surroundings. The climate was that of the desert in June, which was very hot with little available water, a condition that made him dehydrated and miserable. The old men that “helped” him accused him of being responsible for the difficult guiding situation he was in, adding to his distress. There were no surrounding shops or buildings that were inhabited, leaving no place for him to get any water or nourishment. These combined elements of the setting created a profoundly challenging experience for the cyclist throughout his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in several key moments. When the story says “Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts,” this statement affected the cyclist because he didn’t know which way to go, creating uncertainty. Another feature is when the story says “I got on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength.” That statement shows the cyclist was dying for water and doubted any would come out, highlighting his desperation. The last feature is when a sign read, “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit.” This shows the rider had to go under a speed limit, but being already tired and traveling slowly, he was concerned about whether he could make it up the difficult rough road ahead.

The dry, deserted area the cyclist is in has many cacti and vast, empty stretches of land. This barren landscape contributes to a feeling of isolation and physical challenge, as the terrain offers little respite or resources for a traveler. The harsh, sun-scorched environment profoundly shapes his difficult experience on the journey.

In the text, the author was cycling to Yosemite park through a vast, arid desert which severely dehydrated him and profoundly changed his mood. Going through this unforgiving desert, he completely ran out of water and was forced to stop. Some of the small, dusty towns he had been told of turned out to be completely deserted, and as he could not find any water there, he soon became dangerously dehydrated. This is the most obvious physical affect the setting had on him, but another significant affect was to cause him to doubt the reliability of old people and to change his overall mood from confident to desperate. As he was cycling through the relentless desert, desperately clinging to life in hopes he could find a source of water, he realized that old people know of the past better than the future, as they don’t get out into the ever-changing world as much as they used to, whereas at the beginning of his journey he had been entirely confident in the directions and wisdom of the old men. Ultimately, the harsh setting he was in made him a little more wise about the world and his own place within it.

Because the setting of the cyclist's ride is a dry, unforgiving desert, it makes the cyclist seem more and more determined as he presses onward. He is going against the formidable odds of the environment, so it seems like he is pushing himself to his absolute physical and mental limit. Against the oppressive heat and the long, empty road he's on, and having no water left, all seems lost for the cyclist as despair begins to set in. But in the end, through sheer force of will, he pulls himself together and makes it happen for himself, finding a final reserve of strength to triumph over the adversity and complete his arduous journey.

From reading the story, I believe the setting of the desert he was cycling through affected him immensely, primarily in the way his attitude changed for the worst. At first he was very motivated, determined, and sufficiently hydrated for the challenge ahead. As time and miles went on, however, the monotonous scenery never changed, which can be really hard on the spirit. In heated conditions, you need to be as hydrated as possible, especially when enduring a strenuous physical activity. When time went on, he was getting dangerously low on water and had nothing else to think about for long stretches other than how much farther he had to go, how profoundly thirsty he was, and questioning if this entire effort was worth it. It is a lot harder to stay motivated when there is nothing to look at to keep your mind off the struggle, and the attitude of the cyclist certainly changed for the worst. In my point of view, I strongly believe that this shift could have been from working his way across the sandy desert for what seemed a long period of time. I have some experience in exercising while in a monotonous setting; it’s hard to see the same thing for miles and miles. My own attitude will go from “I’m so determined” to “I’m bored” to “what’s the point.” But I thought it was great how he never gave up even when things got incredibly bad. It opened my eyes to see how rewarding it is to reach your own goals through such perseverance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by severely dehydrating him and presenting physical obstacles. The cyclist said, “I toiled on. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is the condition of the roads, which were cracked and covered in gravel. There were many land features that affected the cyclist and his trip. First of all, it is a desert, which greatly affects him as there is no water in deserts and the air is dry. When the cyclist first starts his journey he is very sure of himself, his confidence buoyed by the clear instructions from the old men. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in this story a lot. The feature of the setting affected the cyclist, because as his surroundings changed he lost hope of making it to Yosemite National park. The setting in this short story causes the cyclist to doubt his survival. The main problem is water, or lack thereof, a fundamental need that becomes his primary obsession. The features of the setting of “Do not exceed posted speed limit” greatly impact the cyclist, in a negative way. For example, when the road changes from smooth and easy to rolling and full of hills, it introduces a new layer of physical hardship. It makes it difficult for him to bike, forcing him to stand on his pedals and strain. He needs to use more energy to get over the hills, precious energy he cannot afford to waste. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways, primarily through the harsh desert environment. The first of these is the blazing heat. He is basically in a desert and he is running low on water, a situation made more dire by the relentless sun. As he starts to run out of water he starts conserving it, which is dehydrating him so he is becoming weaker, a fact he acknowledges by stating, “I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so- a test of my inner spirit.” Next up is the rough terrain, which presents a physical challenge that compounds his distress. When you hit rough terrain on a bike it can get hard to keep going and the cyclist was already short on water, a cruel irony highlighted when “a large highway sign jumped out at me. I read: rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit sometimes life can be so cruel.” Finally is the structure of the settlements he encounters. First there was the Ghost town with the “battery acid” tasting water, a bitter disappointment. The author finds the desolate and harsh settings to be not discouraging, rather they stand out as a cause of amusement and fun, quest-like tests that challenge his perspective. The author writes that after arriving at his first ghost-town, he chuckles, amused by the funny “old codgers” and their crazy ideas, finding humor in the desolation. When he arrives at the second establishment, and realizes it isn’t the least bit established anymore, he’s slightly disappointed, but sees it as “a test of [his] inner spirit,” transforming letdown into a personal challenge. At the third building, an abandoned factory, he still appreciates the irony of the situation, recognizing the absurdity amidst the disappointment. While biking across the desert, he refuses to be discouraged by the empty horizon and instead uses it as a point of reference to work his progress and as a way to push himself further along his journey. Though the author is faced with empty disappointing views, he keeps his spirits up and keeps pushing, demonstrating a resilient and optimistic outlook throughout his arduous trek.

In the story Rough Road Ahead: do not exceed speed limit, the reader sees the scenery and terrain get rougher, and lonelier, and as the cyclist travels and limits are being pushed his outlook is somewhat grim as he only expects the worst from his surroundings. The rough road starts out after a water pump he finds gives him piping hot, brackish water that tasted like battery acid, a pivotal moment of disappointment. Water in a sense in this story is a metaphor for his life, and is the source for him living, its quality mirroring his changing fortunes. In the beginning he drank it regularly and when he gets to the pump it is bad, just like when things start to turn sour in the story itself, marking a descent into hardship. The cyclist in this story is very aware of how his body is and acknowledges his dehydration, a constant physical concern. At one point he says “and the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke simply because I had listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porches in a decade" he later said it caused him to laugh sadly, hopelessly as the lack of humans and their technology really broke him down, leaving him isolated and demoralized.

The desert is the cruelest of nature’s environments, presenting a formidable challenge to any traveler. Its lack of water, dry air, and punishing heat are enough to kill even the hardiest creature, demanding constant vigilance. When traveling through a desert, one must maintain a constant water supply and know their path with respect to the power of nature; in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” cyclist Joe Kurmaskie must overcome the desert’s heat and lack of water to survive this very test. As the author observes, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, I could drop from heatstroke,” a clear sign of his body’s distress. If the human body overheats, it becomes sick and unable to properly function, a dangerous state in such isolation. Kurmaskie begins to realize the danger of running out of water in the desert, noting “ I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June.” As this water starts to run out, Joe suffers from dehydration, despair, and a loss of balance, his condition deteriorating rapidly. Water is essential in a desert environment, without it, as Joe grimly observes, “the birds would pick (you) clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear,” a stark reminder of the stakes of his journey.

The setting affected the cyclist because it made his ride harder. The features of the nearby setting affect the cyclist in a negative way. The main things that impact him are the intense heat, his lack of water, the absence of nearby buildings, and the wildlife. For this cyclist, one of the biggest problems is the oppressive heat. He states he “was travelling through the high deserts of California in June,” which shows that it is quite hot outside by the month stated. June is a very hot month, especially in California's deserts. The second problem is the cyclist's lack of water. He says throughout the story how thirsty he is and how much he needs to drink. When he reaches the end, however, he finally finds water. The third problem is that when he needs water, he can’t find anywhere to get it due to the complete lack of buildings. Truly, the features of the nearby setting are affecting him in a traumatizing way, because so many challenging elements like the heat, lack of water, buildings, and wildlife are constantly impeding his progress.

The setting affects the cyclist because in California it can be extremely hot. The cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” had to go through a hard time in the California desert. It was hard for him primarily because it was very hot in the desert in June, and he was almost out of water, leading to dehydration. At first his ride was easier on flat ground, which provided some initial relief. This combination of extreme heat, scarce water, and demanding hills made his passage through the desert a truly arduous ordeal.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was already really thirsty, and then the dry, dusty air with no town or water source nearby made his condition even worse. Finally, there was the sight of the factory in the distance, its smokestacks a cruel reminder of industry, which made him think about cold, refreshing juice and consequently made him thirstier yet, amplifying his suffering on the long journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by presenting an environment where old people reinforce the traditional advice of "don’t talk to strangers," creating a social barrier. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because a real cyclist inherently knows what a suitable speed is for a bike on a given terrain, so external instruction is unnecessary. A real cyclist possesses the endurance to go as long as they want before needing to stop, driven only by their own fatigue. A real cyclist knows how to perform tricks on a bike and does not have to practice them over and over again just to be able to execute them. Ultimately, a real cyclist does not have to undergo formal training to enter a tournament and win; they simply must have practiced consistently to be able to win, relying on their ingrained skill and experience.

The setting in the story had a big effect on the cyclist. The hot, deserted surroundings made the cyclist become tired and discouraged. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One of them is that it was in the harsh daylight and the bright, glaring sun bothers the cyclist, making the ride more uncomfortable. In the narrative "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist was affected in a deadly negative way by the setting. When riding a bike for a very long time with no water is bad but is even worse when your surroundings are at their worst. In the story “Rough Road Ahead” the cyclist is affected by the features of the setting in many ways. One way the cyclist is affected is when they have to cross the hills and plains. The features effect the setting of the story in a big way. At the beginning of his ride there are people around and he has no troubles, feeling confident and secure. The features of a setting, such as terrain and weather, greatly affect the cyclist who is biking in it. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, directly influencing his ride and his physical state. The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit” greatly affect the cyclist, impacting both his physical endurance and his mental state. When the cyclist passed through the old towns the old man told him to, the setting played a big part in making his situation harder to overcome, testing his resolve at every turn. There are many different features of a setting that can affect a cyclist, such as the weather, road condition, and how the person is feeling at the time. According to the essay, the features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist. If the cyclist is in the middle of a hot desert in June with no water, the cyclist will become excessively thirsty the longer they go. For example, the author states, “I had been hitting my bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high desert of California in June.” The terrain then changes to short, rolling hills from flat land, causing the cyclist to push herself to get to the next town for water. For instance, she states, “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view.” This causes the cyclist to use what they thought was their last burst of energy to get down there, but the building was abandoned, thus making the cyclist feel profoundly let down. As the cyclist continued on, a setting of a bait store appeared, and the cyclist felt immense relief because now she could finally get water. These examples clearly show the change of setting on the cyclist’s trip and how it directly affected her physical and emotional state.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” a cyclist was trying to get to Yosemite National Park. He followed the ‘short cut’ that some old men gave him, instead of taking the longer and more reliable route. These old men had no clue what they were really talking about, so the cyclist ended up taking a path through more obstacles and difficult terrain. When the cyclist was in desperate need of more water, he ran into "several rusty pumps." Unfortunately, no water would come out of these pumps, so he had no choice but to keep going without any water. As he moved forward in his travels, he said that the “Flat roads were replaced by short, rolling hills.” Without any water, he did not have much strength left to face the rolling hills, but he had no other option. The cyclist had to go on for miles without seeing anyone or anything. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind," he observed. His troubles finally came to an end after getting helpful directions from another man at a fish camp, which led him back toward civilization.

The setting adds a powerful sense of urgency to the cyclist's predicament. The cyclist is running out of water, and he is in the middle of the desert, an environment that intensifies his peril. If he had been in a forest or the suburbs, the situation would not be so grave or life-threatening. He talks about the very real possibility of passing out and dying, revealing his despair. He exclaims, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds were going to pick me clean.” This grim thought highlights how the harsh, unforgiving desert setting directly contributes to his feeling of hopelessness and the critical nature of his struggle for survival.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist was significantly affected by the road ahead. He took advice that he thought was sound and reliable, but it ultimately proved to be wrong. This misguided advice led him astray, taking him off the correct track from the good path he was trying to reach. The way the settings affect the cyclist is very cruel. First, the cyclist took directions from someone who has not left their porch in decades, so the information was outdated. Furthermore, when he finally arrived at his anticipated destination from his arduous journey, he found only a deserted town, offering no respite. So in conclusion, the cyclist learns a hard lesson and uses his own directions from now on to avoid such treacherous and misleading settings.

As the setting changes in the story, so does the cyclist narrator’s mood. His mood changes from happy and confident to indifferent and scared. The cyclist was eager to get to Yosemite park, and he listened to the “old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” Trusting their local knowledge, he went the way the old men told him to take. He went down a hill into a town which was empty and quiet, then onto a hard road where he had to dodge snakes in his way. After climbing another hill, he went down the other side and saw an abandoned “Welch’s Grape Juice Factory,” a sight that deepened his sense of isolation. Before he got there he was getting thirsty and tired, and when he saw the abandoned building he saw a young boy drinking a juice; he wiped his eyes to see if he wasn’t seeing a mirage. His thirst growing unbearable, he then sticks a few pebbles into his mouth, having read that sucking on stones help take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. Then he left, but a stone went down his throat, causing a moment of panic. Yet, his troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind him when he saw that sign for “Gary And Wilber’s FISH CAMP-IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE’RE YOUR BEST BET!” promising the relief of civilization ahead.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways, primarily through the oppressive environmental conditions. One feature of the setting was the intense, unrelenting heat. It affected him by getting him severely dehydrated, sapping his strength and clouding his thoughts. For example, the text states, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips; I could drop from a heatstroke.” This meant the heat was getting to him, pushing him toward a physical breaking point where even a few drops of water became a critical resource. The author made the setting seem long and unbearable, full of undesirable heat and a profound lack of water at hand. This feeling is specially conveyed in the way he kept describing the road with all the challenges that kept appearing, like after several miles to a town and then more miles passed that he, “came to a park of ramshackle sheds, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold in the tamest mule greeted me. One can imagine the heat, and the unbearableness of the journey still I face." The bike seemed endless under the sun. Then with a thirst gaining on him, for example, "I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph, sanctuaries of life can seem so cruel." This made him feel his constraints, a regret for the journey he had undertaken. It made the reader feel a constrained sorrow for his endless journey he had to go through. Another example is, "I ripped the sweat from my eyes to make sure I wasn't a mirage" upon seeing a building abandoned years ago. This made his journey seem hopeless and long, an endless road with the first wave of problems getting at his strength. In the story, “Do not exceed the posted speed limit,” many features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly. First and most importantly, he is affected by the people who live there, specifically the local advice he receives. “Never accept travel advice from a group of old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porch since Carter was in office.” This quote describes the frustrated feelings the cyclist has towards the old men in hindsight. Because he listened to their directions, he traveled through ghost towns and nearly died from hourly dehydration pangs. Also, the overwhelming lack of people and civilization affected the author deeply. There was no one around that he could ask for help from, amplifying his isolation. “...but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” Here, the author is trying to stop for water, but since no one lives in the town any more, he gets none, compounding his desperation. Finally, the pervasive lack of water has a huge effect on the cyclist’s physical and mental state. “That smoky blues tune ‘Summertime’ rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating brain.” This vividly describes how the author is really dehydrated and he feels like his brain is drying up from the strain. However, his intense need for water ultimately makes him more determined than ever to keep going until he reaches another town, or his goal destination of reaching Yosemite National Park, showing his resilience against the setting's challenges.

The features of the setting affect the man in many ways, shaping his mental state as he progresses. One way is that when the man notices the terrain starting to change, becoming rougher and more difficult, he becomes more and more distraught. He sees the sign that says “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed the posted speed limit,” and it is almost as if he thinks the sign is mocking him and his slow, arduous pace on a bicycle. The ironic warning feels like a cruel joke in his situation. Also, when the rider says “In an ironic twist that should please all sadists…” he is telling the reader that this situation is very ironic and that he was expecting nothing but further hardship from the journey ahead, highlighting his growing cynicism and despair fostered by the unforgiving environment.

In the story I read, the setting is a big factor to the effect on the cyclist. For example, it talks about how the cyclist sees the sign that says, “Rough road ahead! Do not exceed posted speed limit.” This immediate environmental cue forces the cyclist to be cautious, compelling him to slow his pace and pay closer attention to the deteriorating path. The setting thus directly dictates his actions and imposes a physical demand for greater care and control over his bicycle. This interaction shows how the physical landscape actively shapes the cyclist's experience and required response.

The cyclist was in a horrible, nasty environment for cycling, characterized by relentless heat and desolate, empty roads. But the thing that really threw the cyclist off was running out of water. There were no houses to refill his bottle and no one around to give him updated directions. The oppressive heat made him drink more water and also made it harder to breathe in the extreme conditions. These compounding difficulties created a severe physical strain. Without those critical faults in his environment and preparation, the cyclist would have been fine, but as it was, the setting presented an overwhelming challenge.

I think that the features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. For example, he talks about things that he had to endure while he was riding. He had no water, so he was parched and physically drained. Furthermore, there was a huge snake that took up half of the road, presenting a sudden and dangerous obstacle, and there wasn’t a building in sight to offer refuge. So the setting affected him with doubt and fear, but he had the confidence of getting where he needed to go. Then, when he finally arrived at his destination, it was a sign of immense relief. That is how the setting affected his journey, testing his resolve before granting him reprieve.

The setting in the story affected the cyclist both physically and mentally. It affected him physically because of the rough terrain and the intense heat, as he was cycling through a desert and mountainous region. Also, because he didn’t follow his plan on the map, he had no clue where he was, and the anxiety of the whole situation took a toll on his physical well-being, exacerbating his fatigue. It affected him mentally because every town he passed through, or every building he passed, was completely deserted. He had no idea where any people were, so that isolation had to stress him out significantly. This mentally taxed him, and he genuinely thought he was going to die, which is not good for anyone’s state of mind. He really should just do what he thinks is right and not listen to crazy old men anymore, as maps don’t go crazy and they don’t really get outdated. Maps don’t lie to you, so he has obviously learned a crucial lesson about preparation and self-reliance.

Some of the features like the change in landscape affected the cyclist significantly. Differing from flat land to miniature hills to busy highways is kind of hard to cope with, demanding constant physical adaptation and different levels of exertion. This was especially challenging considering he was already dehydrated and had no water, which sapped his energy and made each new topographical feature a greater test of his endurance. The relentless variation in the environment thus compounded his physical distress throughout the journey.

The features of the setting in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” affected the speaker by presenting challenges such as dehydration, dangerous animals, and rough terrain in order to teach him a lesson about following travelling advice from old men. In the essay, he starts out confidently on his journey after following “their advice,” reasoning that the men sounded “no sense of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off town names." The setting initially changes from cool to dry and barren with the mention of "tumble weeds," and the landscape becomes increasingly harsh. It then changed to dangerous with the appearance of a diamondback snake that blocked his path, creating a moment of intense peril. In the end, the setting changes back to comfortable, allowing him to learn his lesson through the hardship of the features of the setting, and he resolves to follow his own map from then on, having understood the folly of his initial overconfidence.

The features of the environmental setting are affecting the cyclist. A setting is a certain time and place an event is taking place, along with the setting there are features, which is the background description basically giving away additional information about the subject or idea. The features along with the setting are interfering with the cyclist by the hot temperature in Lodi, California making the cyclist or biker hotter than usual as he heads in the wrong direction closer and nearer to the hot, blazen, scorching desert. In addition to this, he is running out of water and is beginning to get more and more exhausted from the heat; plus, he is starting to lose consciousness along with getting dehydrated. This is a major problem for the character because he is losing his sense of direction, and because of this, he is getting more panicky as his supply of water is running extremely low. An instance of the environmental setting affecting the cyclist is “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweet circled my skirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June (Joe Kurmaskie)." Another example is “This sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June (Joe Kurmaskie)." The hotness and heat had also increased the character’s anxiety, yet strangely, his confidence in himself grew as he became more panicky, focusing on sheer survival. An instance of this is “I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it this far, I’d be fine (Joe Kurmaskie)." In conclusion, the hot setting in California had affected the cyclist in a number of ways: it had exhausted his water supply and this caused him to become exhausted, dehydrated, and lose his logical sense to make decisions; however, his loss of a clear sense of direction also gave him a desperate self-confidence as he strove to reach the service town that was about twenty miles away in order to get water so that he could survive.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie in many ways. One way the setting affected the cyclist was when it got hot and the rider was running out of water, which created a dire physical threat. Another way the cyclist was affected by the setting was when he said he "could die of heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades," a thought which caused him to laugh bitterly at his own predicament. A third way the cyclist was affected was when he went inside the bait shop and cooled down, finding a crucial respite from the oppressive heat outside. Lastly, he was affected when he rehydrated himself in the shop, regaining his strength and clarity of mind. So the setting was a main factor for the cyclist in the essay “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie on his way to Yosemite National Park, fundamentally shaping his difficult experience.

The cyclist chose to ride through the worst terrain one can ride through, a decision that would test his limits. The cyclist rode through deserts and deserted towns, landscapes that offered no relief. That is when he started to get truly thirsty. At first, he wasn’t tired or thirsty because he was riding by cool trees and rushing water in the morning, a pleasant and energizing start. Once he got to the desert part with no water source, then he got thirsty and started to drink his water, which depleted fast under the relentless sun. The lack of a damp or shaded place can make you thirsty by itself, but after riding a while in the arid heat, it became bad, pushing him toward a crisis. The setting had everything to do with how the cyclist had no water and thought he was going to die from heatstroke, as the environment provided no resources for replenishment. That is how the setting profoundly affected the cyclist, turning his journey into a fight for survival.

The setting affected the cyclist's mood in the story, casting a shadow over his entire journey. The cyclist was riding rough terrain and rolling hills, a physically demanding route that wore down his spirit. This made the cyclist feel like his journey was hopeless, as if he could not make any meaningful progress. When the cyclist arrived at the abandoned Grape Factory, he felt one twist of many disappointments. He was extremely thirsty, and there used to be a building there; when the cyclist was at the fork in the road, he thought he could get some water, a hope that briefly lifted his mood. When this failed, the cyclist was even less determined, his optimism crushed. He felt like the world was against him, a sentiment directly fueled by the unforgiving and desolate setting surrounding him.

The oppressive settings profoundly affected the cyclist, because wherever he went it seemed to never end. Like when he was riding along the route the old men had told him to go, the landscape stretched on interminably. He went through a ghost town exactly as they said he would, but the empty windows and dust-choked streets offered no respite. Then he kept on going, pedaling further into the emptiness, but the journey never ended and the relentless summer heat started to get to him, pressing down with a physical weight. His mind began to falter under the sun's glare; like when he started to dehydrate near this old juice factory and started imagining that he was drinking juice, his thirst conjuring vivid mirages. So he started seeing things, his reality blurring with desperate hallucinations born from the heat and his isolation.

As the author cycles through this dangerous shortcut, he is trapped in a very perilous setting. As said in the poem, he is in the high deserts of California in June, a time of extreme heat. A desert makes the heat unbearable for the cyclist, with no shade for relief. Its just sun, sand, and him, a solitary figure in a vast, arid expanse. Then it tells the month; summer of course makes the temperatures for the cyclist soar to about one hundred degrees, almost maybe even hotter. This intense heat could cause him to drink plenty of water and almost lose all of his water supply far too quickly, a terrifying prospect. “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips,” highlighting his dire situation. Then there is the immense distance of his ride, stretching endlessly before him. The author is always saying “About twenty more miles” or “Twenty miles up the road,” phrases that emphasize the daunting scale of his journey. All of this hard work in such extreme conditions can easily cause heatstroke and kill him, making every pedal stroke a fight for survival.

The features of the setting like the desert, the sun, and abandoned towns affect the cyclist a great deal. The dry desert makes him feel as if he were riding forever, the sameness of the scenery distorting his sense of progress. And it probably makes him wonder if he is ever going to make it to a real, living town. The sun makes him even hotter than he already is; it beats down relentlessly, makes him sweat more, and makes him even more thirsty, sapping his strength with each passing mile. The abandoned towns make him lose hope in finding water or even if he is ever going to make it to Yosemite, each empty building a symbol of failure. The mood of this story goes from content to sad to happy, mirroring his journey. He is content after riding to the first town, but then the rest of the towns are abandoned too and he starts to run out of water, and he thinks he is going to die, which makes it sad and desperate. Then he becomes profoundly happy and relieved when he finally finds the bait shop and finds life-saving water, his spirits lifting with his fortunes.

In “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist negatively throughout his journey. The story takes place in June in California, which is a very hot time of the year, especially in such a desert location. The extreme heat adds to the speed at which the cyclist becomes dehydrated, as well as his inability to think as coherently as he could had he not been in a desert in June, his thoughts becoming muddled. The cyclist is also travelling through desolate, uninhabited land, with no signs of life. The author says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” a statement that emphasizes the character's total lack of resources and profound isolation. There is nowhere within sight that he can turn to for help, water, food or shelter from the punishing environment. The road itself was also rough, plagued with many rolling, crippling hills that demanded constant effort. Such terrain is much harder to maneuver, especially in such an already dire state of physical and mental despair. Ultimately, the harsh setting of the story, "Rough Road Ahead," greatly impacts the cyclist, testing his limits at every turn.

There are a lot of things that affect the cyclist, such as the extreme heat, having no water, the rough roads and the long, exhausting trip. The cyclist is out in a desert so it is very hot, the air shimmering with waves of heat. The narration says, “and the growing realization that I could die drop from heatstroke” (Kurmaskie), which means that he or she was very hot and dangerously dehydrated, facing a real mortal threat. The roads were very rough, for example, signs warned “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT” (Kurmaskie). The roads became bumpy and uneven, and there were a lot of hills the cyclist had to go over, each ascent draining his remaining energy. There was no water either, no source to replenish his dwindling supply. So he/she was running out of energy and the combination of factors made the journey even harder, each challenge compounding the next. In the end, despite the overwhelming odds, the cyclist survived and drank a lot of water, a hard-won victory over the elements.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a very harmful way. The hot temperature and boiling sun made the author hot and took his energy away quicker, baking the arid ground beneath his tires. The emptiness of the setting can make a person lose hope of finding any civilization, amplifying the sense of solitude. The narrator said, “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you...” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). That is not the last of the harmful setting, the dry desert air has the biggest impact on his life. The dry air makes him more thirsty for water he doesn’t have, making him dehydrate faster and parching his throat. The narrator says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The lonely and dreadful features of the setting the cyclist was part of, with its vast, unforgiving landscape, made it so much worse that he had no water, pushing him toward a physical and mental breaking point.

In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” a cyclist follows some bad advice, which leads him on a tough ride through the desert with little water. The setting has a large effect on the cyclist because it causes him to be dehydrated, which presents the main conflict of the story and threatens his well-being. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips,” the author states when his fresh water supply begins to run out, highlighting his growing desperation. Another factor the setting presents to the cyclist is the extreme, relentless heat of the California desert. This adds to the cyclist's thirst and dehydration, sapping his strength with every passing mile. The reader can tell it is unpleasantly hot when reading, “wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt…, that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” The rough roads and challenging terrain, full of gravel and steep inclines, also present a challenge to the cyclist that slows his advance to Yosemite, extending his ordeal in the harsh environment.

The cyclist is profoundly affected by the features of the setting. The cyclist has been pedaling his bike in the direction that the old men told him to go to get to Yosemite, a route that proves more demanding than anticipated. Soon he is out of water and very tired, his body weakened by the journey, and he believes he will die soon in the isolated landscape. But then he finds a fish camp, a small sign of human presence, and goes in the bathroom to revive himself with water, a moment of critical relief. When he comes out a man is sitting on the porch, offering a human connection. The author gets directions from him and is happy that he is on the right track again, his hope restored by this fortunate encounter in the vast wilderness.

There are many effects of the setting in this essay that can be good and or bad. The setting is alone on an empty mountain road, with no house, no cars, and no people for miles around. I am now going to give you some good and bad effects. One good effect is that you are by yourself so while you exercise you can relax and enjoy the natural energy and peace. One bad thing is that what if you pop a tire or need help; you are stuck because there's no one around to assist you. Another good thing is that you are being by yourself, @CAPS1 any cars. You don’t have to worry about getting hit so you’ll be able to just relax and enjoy the ride without traffic concerns. Another bad thing is there is no water available, so you might want to bring plenty with you to avoid dehydration. So whatever you decide to do, just be careful and think your idea through completely before embarking on such a solitary journey.

The setting or environment the cyclist was in made him feel isolated from the rest of the world, a single figure in an immense, silent landscape. He knew there was no turning back once he started his adventure, committing fully to the path ahead. No one was there to help him, emphasizing his complete self-reliance. The environment made him realize the many risks involved in this adventure, from physical exhaustion to the lack of resources. The knowledge that there is no help was his motive to continue on his long journey, forging a determined spirit fueled by necessity and the will to persevere through the challenging terrain.

The features of the setting make the cyclist feel hopeless after realizing he is not on a short cut. The cyclist has the "growing realization that [he] could drop from heatstroke" as he rides along under the relentless sun. Also, the only building he sees for miles "had been @NUM1 Welch's Grape Juice Factory," a hollow and abandoned structure that offers no refuge. The cyclist is driven deeper into despair and feels that all hope is lost when he sees this building, a monument to his own foolish misdirection. As he rides on, the song "'@ORGANIZATION2' rattled aroung in the dry honeycombs of (his) deteriorating brain," a maddening and ironic soundtrack to his demise. At this point, the cyclist believes his own death to be inevitable. He says “with any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat” when talking about pebbles he placed in his mouth to stave off thirst. Finally, the cyclist reaches a small bait shop, and all hope is returned as he “drank deeply from the sink,” the life-giving water restoring his spirit. The desert setting, with its lack of water, shelter, and people was the cause of this mans concern and later panic about his own life. The hopelessness of this cyclist is much like the hopelessness of those in the @ORGANIZATION1, who trapped in a blizzard far from civilization, resorted to eating their dead just to survive. While the @PERSON1 @ORGANIZATION1 went to extremes for their survival, their setting caused them to feel the same profound hopelessness as the cyclist, proving how environment dictates the limits of human endurance.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the features of the setting affects the cyclist because he has to cross different types of land marks which challenge his journey. First, he got information from the old people, which turned out to be unreliable. For example, when he showed the map to the old people their only going to know the old short cuts not the new ones, leading him astray. Second, when he ran out of water his situation became critical. For instance, when the cyclist ran out of water he had to climb hills and that tired him out, sapping his remaining strength. Plus when he tried to get water from that one thing only hot water come out, deepening his desperation. Last, when he finally got to a story the old guy had a map, which revealed the truth of his predicament. For example, when he asked the old guy about the place he was going to he said I have my own map, and it showed the cyclist was far off course. So therefore he knew he was in trouble, realizing the setting had conspired against him. In conclusion, this is how the features of the setting, from misleading advice to arid landscapes, affects the cyclist and his perilous journey.

The features of the setting effected the cyclist in many ways, primarily through its harsh physical demands. The setting was verry hot and there were a lot of hills, creating a grueling path. The cyclist had been riding up and down hills all day and it took a lot of energy; when he saw the building that he thought could help him he said, “... last burst of energy, i mane'uvered down the hill,” using his final reserves. By saying that it showed that the setting of where he was contained a lot of hillsy terrain and they effected him by taking up all his energy, leaving him physically drained and desperate. That is how the setting, with its relentless topography and heat, had effected the cyclist, dictating his struggle and consuming his vitality.

In the short story Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted  Limit, by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affects the cyclist by dictating his emotional state. When at the old codgens house, he is confident in himself, because they have told how of a shortcut to Yosemite, giving that confidence he needs to embark, as he leaves, he is still confident, these as the settings changes, so does the mood of the cyclist. After "about @NUM1 miles into te pedal", the cyclist arrives at the first town, he has despair because it is a ghost town, a place devoid of life and aid; still having confidence, he lack of water, he continues on. After a couple more miles, he comes to small fork with a pump. Thinking its cool, water he goes and pump, he finds out it is @NUM2∞@CAPS1 and tastes like "battery acid", a crushing disappointment. Now he desparate, no water, dehydrated, and no towns around, he began to pedal and pedal, hoping to find a town around, his hope fading with each rotation. When he does find a town, with water, the setting to relieving and better for him because he find water, a salvation from his ordeal. In the end, the setting effect how the cyclist back against confident, then desperate as water is used, than relieved when water is found, charting his emotional journey through the landscape.

This would be a hard risk to begin with, but the cycalist is taking it in the desert, a landscape inherently hostile to such an endeavor. As we all know, the desert can get boiling hot, so a bike ride could get enjoyable quickly, turning from adventure into a fight for survival. Also, when the only thing you see for miles is rode, sand and an empty factory, your moral can easily dray quickly, leaving only a sense of profound isolation. It’s just an overall way setting to give lost in, a vast and unforgiving expanse where hope is as scarce as water, perfectly designed to challenge the human spirit.

The effect of cycling in such extreme heat is very dangerous and trending because a lot of things can go wrong. You can feel so hot that having and drinking water wouldn't cool you down; it simply didn't matter. But when a drop of that warm water landed in your mouth, it had the unpleasant flavor of battery acid. He or anyone could just drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June. It was so hot that you are seeing things, like a mirage of a town. The heat was so intense that pouring a supposedly refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still leave him feeling utterly parched and desperate for relief from the oppressive conditions.

The features of the setting dramatically affected the cyclist. He started out in a confident and energetic mood, until he arrived at a town that was completely deserted, which dampened his spirits. His confidence was still pretty high but not like it was prior to coming upon the unsettling ghost town. Twenty miles up the road after that, he came to a fork which contained a ramshackle shed, some rusty and unclean pumps, and a small, empty corral. The desert was relentlessly hot and his lack of water was severely dehydrating him. As the text states, “This sight was troubling…I had been hitting my water bottles regularly, and was traveling through the high deserts in California.” With little water and a short energy supply he was getting tired and dehydrated quickly. The land started turning into rolling hills which demanded more effort and caused him to become even more exhausted. His mood had gone from confident to hopeless and desperate. He even planned on changing a diary entry in case he died of heatstroke, showing his profound despair. The features of the environment obviously greatly affected the mood and physical state of the cyclist, proving that sometimes disappointment can come from taking the so-called “easy way out.”

In the story the setting affected the cyclist all through the story till he arrived at Body and Wilbers fish camp. As the man rides his bike for a while he is optimistic, but as he rode into the first town it seemed to be a ghost town, which was disheartening. As he pedaled on, “The sun was beginning to beat down but I barely noticed it,” indicating his initial focus. At that time the weather is affecting him a lot but he keeps the mental image of Yosemite's cool pines and rushing rivers in his head to cope. He also only had a few tantalizing sips left in his water bottle while going up a big, demanding hill, which intensified his struggle against the harsh, arid landscape surrounding him.

The setting of this essay is to tell cyclists where to go without getting them lost and to never take advice from old people, as their directions may be outdated or unreliable. The narrative uses the environment as a map and a warning, illustrating how certain paths, while seemingly straightforward from another's perspective, can lead to difficult and unforeseen challenges. Therefore, relying on personal preparation and modern tools is far safer than following potentially misguided suggestions, no matter how well-intentioned they may be.

The features in the setting greatly affect the cyclist, as the setting was hot with rough terrain and he was tired and thirsty. The cyclist said, “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view.” He meant that he needed water so much and the hill was so big and exhausting that the sight of potential refuge was a powerful lure. Also he says, “Summertime ‘rattled around in the dry honey combs of my deteriorating brain’.” It is summer time where he is riding and to keep his mind off of his thirst, he hums the song “Summertime” as a mental distraction. He wants to show that the heat cannot overtake his body and spirit completely. Furthermore, he says, “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake.” He is noting that the terrain is not only harsh but also deadly because of the dangerous snake that passed by him. He needed to show that with all these objections and hazards, he was determined to overcome anything. As you can see, the setting greatly affected the cyclist both physically and mentally throughout his arduous journey.

Many things can affect a cyclist, but in the story three main features of the setting affected the cyclist the most. While the cyclist was riding it was very hot, a fact we know by looking back at the text. It gives us this quote, “That I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” Because it was so intensely hot, this could make the cyclist dangerously thirsty and fatigued. Another feature of the setting was the multitude of hills. This constant climbing and descending would create physical exhaustion. We know there were many hills because in the text it says, “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” Going over all those hills can really tire someone out, draining their energy reserves. A third feature of the setting would be nature, which can affect us in many ways by weather, by terrain, and as in this case by animals. In the story the cyclist comes upon a large snake, this encounter making the journey dangerous and heightening the sense of peril. The setting can affect anything, and it would have been a totally different story if the cyclist had been in the summer during a different season, not June, altering all these challenging conditions.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting is used to alter the cyclist's mood and as a reflection of his situation. For example, the statement “the cool pines and rushing river of Yosemite had my name written all over them” helps describe the cyclist's hopeful situation. The idea of lush, cool water and vegetation gives the cyclist hope during his increasingly hellish trip, serving as a mental oasis. The beauty of that setting also reflects on the comfort that would come from reaching Yosemite; the good setting equals a good outcome, a stark contrast to his current state. Later on, the cyclist comes across “one ramshackle shed, several rusted pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule.” This is a depressing setting symbolizing a complete loss of hope, and in fact at this point the cyclist becomes troubled by his situation. While pedaling through the desert, the cyclist becomes even more fatigued when a tumbleweed, which is always a symbol of a deserted area, comes by, reinforcing his isolation. The use of setting to affect and mirror mood is nothing new, as there are many examples of this literary technique throughout history. For example, in his story, the author describes a desolate land filled with wild beasts to symbolize and cause a character to change his personality, surrounded by uncivilized people and creating a situation where he tears his clothes and hunts like a dog. The setting of a desert in the uncultured, colonial world simultaneously causes and reflects on this profound change. Therefore, the setting in the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is used as an important tool for character development.

The features of the essay explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist for many reasons. When the author writes “tumbleweeds crossed my path” it shows that he is most likely in the middle of a deserted nowhere. This is true because tumbleweeds are usually signs in movies and t.v. shows that the place is empty and isolated, enhancing the feeling of solitude. Also, when the author writes “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke” and when he writes “a ridiculously large snake” show the growing danger that he is getting himself into. This is true because the snakes could attack at any time or he could just collapse from the lack of water and die, presenting a constant physical threat. Lastly, the name of the store is relevant because it is a fish bait store and he is desperately thirsty. This is relevant because fish live in water and he is thirsty, so seeing the sign relieves him completely by promising a potential source of aid. Therefore, through these details, the features of this essay explain how the features of the setting profoundly affect the cyclist.

The cyclist is faced with many challenges on his journey to Yosemite, one of which is travelling through the California deserts. This was quite a challenge because a desert is very hot and dry, plus the author was riding his bike, making himself more thirsty and hot from the strenuous exertion. He also encountered a big snake that appeared to be a diamondback, which he carefully avoided even though it almost covered the entire road, adding a element of sudden danger. The author also had to deal with rough terrain when he rode his bike through the hills, which tested his endurance and resolve. Ultimately, the biker met all these challenges and progressed through them with considerable bravery, overcoming the harsh environment.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed Speed limit” many different settings took their toll on the cyclist. For example, in the beginning he started out with a nice smooth ride, but it was very hot, creating an immediate hardship. Then he began to get into a series of short rolling hills which were taking their toll on his legs, sapping his strength with each ascent. Then he entered into a rough area where he had to be more careful of the uneven ground. The roughness of the path probably wore him out from all the constant bumps and bounces, adding to his fatigue. He went through a lot on that bike trip, and who knows, he might have never made it back to where he was staying given the cumulative difficulty of the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making it harder for him to pedal and complete his ride. For example, the text notes that “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This should make his trip harder because instead of being able to pedal at one consistent rate the whole time, he would have to start pedaling harder and easier over and over again, using more energy and causing fatigue to set in more quickly. Another example is the location described as “through the high deserts of California in June.” This makes it harder for him because he has to do all his work in a scorching summer heat, which saps his strength. Finally, the first three stops he made had no place to fill his water bottles, take a drink, or cool off. This would make it hard because he is becoming dehydrated during his whole trip, increasing his physical distress. These are some features of the setting that affect the cyclist by making his trip harder and more demanding.

One feature that affected the cyclist was the rolling hills. The text states “two miles into the section... I noticed the terrain changing.” This shift from a flat, predictable path to an undulating one forced the cyclist to constantly adjust his effort, expending more energy on the ascents and then bracing on the descents. This constant change in resistance, compared to a steady, flat ride, made the journey far more physically taxing for him as he progressed.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting affects the story very much for many reasons. First, it is in the summer, so it is very hot, which drains the cyclist's energy. Also, it is in the desert in the west, so there is a very warm climate already, with intense sun and little shade. Third, there is not any civilization on the “shortcut” he follows, so there is no way for the author to get any water to replenish his body with, leading to severe thirst. This is how the harsh features of the setting affect the cyclist in the story, creating a significant challenge.

The setting affects the cyclist a lot, because if it was windy too it would be hard for the cyclist to control the bike, fighting against the gusts. Also, if there were a lot of buildings and people outside there would be a lot of traffic, so they would not be allowed to let the cyclist go there and the cyclist would have to turn back, ending his journey prematurely. Then if it was a clear road and nobody was there and no buildings or houses were there then it would be an easy ride for the cyclist, allowing for uninterrupted travel. So as you can see the setting affects the cyclist in many ways, from the weather to the man-made environment.

The cyclist was affected majorly by a few dreadful parts of the setting. In the beginning, when it was not as hot and he had plenty of water, the cyclist was absolutely fine and making good progress. As the day went on, he felt the heat bearing down on him, becoming oppressive. He drank all his water, and now he felt desperate and increasingly weak. His mood changed with the setting, and he was extremely happy once he reached Gary and the store, finding relief. Also, this cyclist decided to blame the old men for giving him bad directions when he was in trouble, but he thanked them once he realized they were correct, showing how his perspective shifted with his circumstances.

If it’s a good day, the cyclist will want to ride, feeling the sun on their back and the wind as a welcome companion. If it is a bad day, then they will not want to ride but probably will anyway, driven by a sense of duty or a stubborn determination to not be defeated by poor conditions. This internal conflict between desire and obligation is a fundamental part of the cycling experience, where the decision to ride is often a compromise between one's mood and one's willpower, ultimately concluding that the ride itself is what defines the cyclist's day.

In the essay, "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, features of the setting affect the cyclist profoundly because there are old people who have been around for a long time. A cyclist cannot ask them for reliable advice because they are often too old to give accurate information and likely would not know what they are talking about, being disconnected from current routes and conditions. As Kurmaskie wryly observes, “A better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, ‘Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.’” That statement perfectly encapsulates the features of the setting and provides a clear example from the essay on how local characters can mislead rather than guide a traveler.

The features for the cyclist in "Rough Road Ahead" are not the kind of war one would be in at forts; it is a personal battle against the elements. I thought it was going to be a simple scenery story, but it turns out he was not that prepared for the harsh reality he faced. He took directions from some old-timers who had not left their house since Carter was in office, leading him astray. He was a bike pedaling through the California desert with only the things you can carry because you are on a bike, which proved insufficient. He ran out of water and could have gotten heatstroke or collapsed in the middle of nowhere with no one around to save him. So the heat can drive you insane and make you thirsty, and you have to endure the bite of desperation. The conditions this biker was in were horrendous, and I do not think he was prepared at all, which teaches the lesson to always stick to your gut instinct when planning a journey.

In the story, the fact that no one was around, there were no buildings in sight, he had no water left, and he was utterly lost had a profoundly negative affect on the cyclist, causing him to doubt himself the whole time. This isolation and scarcity of resources created a mental battle that was as challenging as the physical one, filling his journey with anxiety and second-guessing. Although he did persevere and made it through the tough situation he was in, the experience underscored how deeply the features of a setting can impact a traveler's resolve and state of mind, proving that survival is as much mental as it is physical.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead” the setting and the features significantly affect the cyclist, shaping his desperate actions. For example, in the story he says, “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you had left to circulate.” This shows that the features are rough because he would most likely not be that desperately thirsty unless it was very hot and arid out, pushing him to extreme measures. The setting and features of this story are that it takes place in California, on a brutally hot day. Another quote that could support this is when the author says, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage.” This shows that it is hot because he is sweating profusely, and it also could show that it is scorching because he thinks it’s a mirage, and people usually see them in the desert where the heat distorts reality, confirming the oppressive nature of the environment on his journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. To begin, as the cyclist rode on for the first miles, he did not see anything in sight, just an empty and monotonous landscape. This isolation and lack of visual progress made him less determined to reach his goal. Then, in a later paragraph, the cyclist saw a building appear on the horizon, which helped him to gain strength and renew his focus to reach his goal. The cyclist’s determination went down as long as he was riding through the barren and featureless terrain. But then at last he came to a building that gave him relief and more confidence in himself, serving as a tangible marker of his progress and a source of much-needed morale. This cycle of despair and hope, dictated entirely by the environment, illustrates the profound impact of the setting on his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by him dehydrating and running out of time and energy. The harsh, sun-baked environment directly contributes to his physical decline. The quote, "I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state," proves the severe dehydration of the rider, showing how the setting impairs his basic motor functions. Furthermore, the thought, “The glowing realization that I could die from a heat stroke,” proves the time and energy of the rider is running out, as the extreme heat pushes him to the brink of physical collapse. These ideas and quotes show the features of the setting of the cyclist are not just a backdrop but an active, dangerous force that threatens his well-being and challenges his endurance on the journey.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead” the author takes a trail he had previously heard about, expecting a certain experience. After the ride didn’t turn out to be what he expected it to be, the setting began to “set in” with its true, unforgiving nature. The aridity of the climate, with its dry and relentless heat, would cause the author to have to struggle against himself and the harsh conditions around him. Also his lack of water was a problem to begin with, a critical miscalculation for such a journey. This initial shortage, combined with the scorching sun beating down, would make him become dangerously dehydrated, compounding his physical struggles and highlighting the trail's severe challenges.

The cyclist runs into some pretty tough challenges during his journey. The various features of the setting affected him, because there were so many obstacles that he had to overcome. For example, he got directions from some old men who moved them along lively but didn’t really know what they were talking about, leading him astray. Then he ran out of water so he had nothing to drink, and the road started to get bumpy and he saw snakes, increasing the danger and discomfort. There were no buildings nor cars around so he had no way of asking anybody for help if needed, leaving him completely isolated. He came up on an old factory, that was thought to be the Welch’s Grape Juice factory, but was abandoned and looked like it had been for a while, dashing his hopes for refuge. Towards the end he found this fish camp where he finally got water and was around people, which provided a crucial respite. These different obstacles affected his mood and how determined he was throughout the difficult ride, dictating his spirits.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit” has a great effect on the main character in the story, shaping his emotional and physical state.
