In the beginning of the story, he passes the first ‘town’ and continues riding his bike, following the directions some old folks gave him with a sense of purpose. The line, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over it,” shows his initial excitement. His mood at this point was already confident, but this adds to it, with words like “rushing” being encouraging to him and the pleasant environment boosting his morale. Then, he continues moving on the road, and the narrator states, “Not two miles into this section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing.” At this point, he is becoming unsure of how good the directions he obtained really were as the landscape turns less welcoming. Once he is already tired, rolling hills isn’t what he wanted to find, so this adds to his doubt and saps his energy. Further along, he said, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This profound isolation adds to the despair he was feeling, because he feels he is going to die in Yosemite, with the empty setting amplifying his fear. Not seeing anyone was probably extremely discouraging, so the setting really affected him by making him feel completely alone. Then he said “over the long crippling hill, a building came into view.” It is at this point that he uses the word “crippling” because he is just about exhausted and can’t go any further, and the sight of the structure becomes a potential turning point, demonstrating how the setting's features directly influence his capacity for hope and endurance.

The features in the setting greatly affect the cyclist as he navigates a challenging and intimidating landscape. He is riding through this deserted and beaten up town, with its crumbling facades and eerie silence, that makes him feel profoundly weird and uneasy. After that he starts to ride through the vast, open desert when a huge, coiled snake suddenly gets in his way and scares him even more, causing his heart to race. When he arrives at the abandoned juice factory, its rusted machinery and dusty interior a testament to its decay, he is almost completely out of energy and almost can’t go on any further in his journey, his legs feeling like lead, until he finally arrives at the isolated bait shop. Most of the features in the setting scare the cyclist, from the desolate town to the desert creature, but they all affect him by steadily draining his physical stamina and mental resolve.

The cyclist was begging to feel that death was coming his way as he continued without a building in sight, the endless, featureless horizon offering no hope of shelter or respite. This made him grow histerical over the situation, his mind conjuring fears of a lonely end, and still have enough energy to feel sorry for himself, wallowing in a pit of self-pity. Then when he finally did see a building, a small, weathered structure in the distance, he thought it was a mirage, a cruel trick played by the heat and his own desperate mind, and he hesitated to believe his eyes. This moment of doubt highlights the profound psychological toll the desolate environment had taken on him, leaving him wary of even potential salvation.

The location of a cyclist’s ride profoundly affects the person’s attitude and physical strength throughout the journey. If the road is full of steep, unrelenting hills, it takes a little more strength to maintain speed, quickly depleting one's energy reserves. When put in this situation, Kurmaskie writes “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” This shows how one gets emotionally and physically drained by hills, where even dark humor becomes a sign of exhaustion. Also, being in a harsh desert situation can severely weaken a cyclist due to intense thirst and exposure. The cyclist in the reading was desperate enough to try pump water that looked “brackish,” a clear sign of his deteriorating condition. So, whether through taxing terrain or a lack of resources, the setting can ultimately break a cyclist's spirit and body.

The setting in the passage is working against the cycler, creating a series of physical hardships that threaten his progress. He's running low on water, his bottle nearly empty, and he's almost dehydrated, his throat parched and dry. The weather where he's at is very, very hot, the sun beating down relentlessly, and he can't see a town for miles in any direction, leaving him isolated in the vast, arid landscape. This combination of heat, thirst, and isolation creates a formidable challenge that saps his strength and tests his will to continue, demonstrating the environment's powerful opposition.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist significantly because it was really hot out, he had very little amount of water left in his bottle, and a long, demanding way to go. The temperature was so hot, the cyclist said he felt dehydrated and lightheaded, the heat waves shimmering on the asphalt ahead. He also had to go over a lot of steep hills, which strained his muscles, and go through vast, sun-scorched deserts to get where he needed to go. He took a “shortcut” through a particularly barren area, but it ended up taking longer and he got severely dehydrated, a miscalculation that worsened his plight. This is how the setting, with its heat, difficult terrain, and his own dwindling supplies, affected him both physically and mentally on his arduous trip.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a profoundly good way. For example, he would be in excellent physical shape because cycling is a demanding and continuous sport that builds endurance and strength. Furthermore, he would likely become rich because he would win the competitive contest of cycling, earning prize money and sponsorships. These positive outcomes demonstrate how a supportive environment can foster both personal health and professional success for an athlete, ultimately leading to a rewarding and prosperous life.

In the essay by Joe Kurmaskie, many obstacles are caused from the different settings, creating significant challenges for the protagonist. For example, the intensely hot temperature caused the character to get severely dehydrated, a condition he recalls by stating, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This physical distress caused a critical loss of determination, which led to him losing his consciousness and jeopardizing his journey. The formidable hills he had to cycle also negatively effected him, as the steep and relentless inclines caused him to become increasingly tired and weak and to lose his resolve and determination, as well. Just like the temperature problem, this progressive loss of determination could eventually make him lose consciousness entirely, a fear he voices by saying, “if it looked like i was going to lose consciousness for the last time.” Thus, the harsh environmental elements directly threaten both his physical well-being and his mental fortitude.

The setting of the story had profoundly effected the cyclist's journey becuse if it was in the suburbs he could have stoped any where and got water easily, but the plot was set in the middle of a vast desert where all he could do is keep rolling and hoping to find some water eventually. For example, he had to go many miles to get to the next town to get a fresh supply of water, and if he was not in the challenging desert with its endless hills and sand, he could have made that journey in no time at all. The isolation and harsh terrain of the desert setting therefore directly intensified his struggle and prolonged his suffering.

The cyclist was significantly affected by many challenging features of the setting throughout his arduous journey. The initially flat road soon became a series of bumpy and steep hills, which were made exponentially harder to cycle because of his critical lack of water and the resulting fatigue. Furthermore, the relentless hot desert sun beat down upon him, and the complete lack of nearby towns and people also made the journey profoundly difficult and isolating. These combined environmental factors created a formidable test of his endurance and willpower.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist primarily because it is excessively hot. It is hot enough that his precious water tasts like battery acid, making it difficult to consume. Then he has to deal with difficult trails and a confusing breakway, exacerbated when he said “old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” This is sayin that the old-timers gave him old and unreliable directions, leading him astray. Plus, what made the setting feel even hotter was the fact that he has been cycling nonstop without rest. Then, when he was riding, he found a mental escape by thinking, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over it.” With him thinking about this refreshing destination, it momentarily made him forget about the oppressive heat. This interplay of physical hardship and mental refuge was precisely why the setting was so powerfully affecting the cyclist.

There are many reasons as to why the features of the setting affects the cyclist. One reason is because it is so hot, I know this because it was summertime in the California desert, a time of intense and unrelenting heat. Another reason is because the road was very rough. I know this because of the sign that he saw that said “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed.” This tells you that the road is very rough and uneven. And being that he is on a bike, rough roads are not very good for him, making the ride jarring and difficult. Another reason as to why the setting affects the cyclist is that there is no one to get directions from, leaving him potentially lost. There is no one around to give him a drink of water, which is a critical need in such a harsh environment. These are a few of the many reasons why the setting so profoundly affects the cyclist and his challenging journey.

The setting of this story is outside. Yosemite is outside riding her bike. She is around hills, no water, and very hot land. You know that she is around hills because she says to herself, “I maneuvered down the hill,” indicating a steep and challenging descent. You also know that she starts off around no good water, as the available water was undrinkable. “When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid,” that shows the water was bad and provided no relief. Also the land is very hot because it says “in the heat of two hundred degrees,” creating an oppressive and draining atmosphere. Yosemite starts off bad then ends up learning to stick to it and never give up. Yosemite’s biggest problem is her lack of water due to the fact that it is hot outside and the water she had was bad, tasting like battery acid, a combination that tested her resolve to the very limit.

There are many things that could affect the cyclist. Like when they said, “tumble weeds crossed my path is a ridiculously large snake,” showing how the desert landscape presented unexpected and startling obstacles. Another example would be when they said “Not two miles into this next section of the ride I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This shift in the land required more effort and energy to pedal through, directly impacting the cyclist's stamina and progress. The changing features of the setting, from wildlife encounters to the physical lay of the land, are how the environment continually affects the cyclist throughout the ride.

The story of the cyclist shows how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The cyclist had to go through a lot, facing numerous challenges along the way. "The speed limit was posted, but the cyclist was doing a water depleting ride under the scorching sun. Sometimes life can feel so cruel," especially when confronting such harsh conditions. Despite the hardships, the cyclist loves to ride their bike and they enjoyed the serenity of an early summer evening, a moment of peace that contrasted with the day's struggles. This love for cycling provided the motivation to persevere through the difficult journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. First, the river and the pine trees provided a mental escape, as “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them." Thinking about that pleasant destination helped the cyclist keep going through the difficult patches. Second, the road was getting harder to travel. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" and a sign on another road said “rough road ahead.” The roads made the cyclist work harder to get to Yosemite National Park, demanding greater physical exertion. Finally, the cyclist's water supply was running low. “the water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Not having a lot of water is really bad when you're outside in the heat and the cyclist had no idea where to find more. The towns the cyclist ran into were abandoned or a “ghost town,” empty and offering no resources. The cyclist had nowhere to go to get help, feeling completely isolated. This cyclist faced many problems during his bike ride to Yosemite national park, each one shaped by the challenging features of the setting.

The older men gave him directions that were actually really bad, leading him astray on a route they had not traveled in decades. Nature wasn't on his side, that's for sure. First of all he ran out of water because of the oppressive, unrelenting heat. Secondly a venomous snake blocked his path and he didn't want to tempt it, forcing a long and anxious detour. Thirdly he became so overheated that it was possible for him to suffer a heat stroke in the middle of nowhere, with no one to come to his aid. Also he kept going in circles to abandoned buildings that offered no respite. It was so bad that the stone relied on for his thirst got stuck in his parched throat, a desperate trick that backfired. He was then lead to a desolate bait shop that was absolutely in the middle of nowhere, a place of false hope where he had no way of getting home and his ordeal continued.

The features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist. The dry desert landscape affected the cyclist because there was no water to be found and the cyclist was severely dehydrated, his body weakening with every mile. The strong, punishing heat was another factor, because the cyclist could barely pedal and had a real risk of a heat stroke. The animals presented a clear danger because the snake could have killed the cyclist and there was no one in miles to help had he been bitten. In the story it says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind,” which underscores the absolute isolation. If the cyclist had needed immediate help then he could most likely have died, as rescue was a distant possibility. If I was the cyclist, I probably would have given up by then but I’m glad the cyclist didn't, showing a resilience against the harsh environment. The features of the setting affected the cyclist significantly because of the many perilous things that could have happened to him in such an unforgiving place.

The features of the setting that affected the cyclist was the intense, dry heat because he was getting lost on the confusing backroads and he was slowly running out of his precious water supply. The cyclist said, “That you should never accept travel advice from old timers that haven’t left their porches since Carter was in office”. This means that because the cyclist followed their outdated and inaccurate advice he got lost in the vast desert and was running very low on water, his situation growing more desperate. He was so desperately thirsty that he put stones in his mouth to create saliva and keep him from thinking about water, a testament to his suffering. In the end the cyclist learned a valuable lesson to trust the map and the road signs instead of listening to really old people who haven't left their homes in years and were disconnected from the current reality of the land.

The setting of the desert is a hard, unforgiving setting to be in with no ready water or hope of help. If the author would have been on a populated trail with water fountains and shade, he would have been perfectly fine. But, he was in the stark desert with no one around, the air hot and dry, with no water, and no shade for relief. “tumbleweeds crossed my path” describes the emptiness and his loneliness because no one was in the desert to help him or offer directions. The harsh setting could have easily killed him if it was not for the chance discovery of the fish camp, which provided a crucial reprieve. The setting had a huge and dangerous affected on the author, shaping his entire difficult journey and highlighting his vulnerability against the elements.

The feature in the short story affect the cyclist because with no towns around for supplies there is now water to be found. In the story is says, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” This means the cyclist was critically short on water and desperately needed to find a town soon to refill. Cycling in the barren desert and up and down the steep hills made the journey harder and the temperature feel even hotter. The heat could cause severe dehydration or a dangerous heatstroke because it says, “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke” a fear that became very real. The buildings the cyclist did see were not any help to him because they were abandoned and had no water, offering only shade and disappointment. Eventually he came to a fishing camp and found his salvation, water in the sink of the bathroom, a moment of profound relief. The story says, “I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink.” This is where the setting changes for the better because the cyclist found cool, life-giving water finally, ending his immediate crisis.

In "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit", the author faces many obstacles because of the different terrain changes on his journey to Yosemite National Park. Taking advice from a group of old men, he headed to his first stop. The old men said he would see a thriving town but what he really saw was a sort of ruined "ghost" town, with dilapidated buildings and an eerie silence. Then he came to a fork in the road and was running out of water, his supply dwindling to a few last drops. He had been riding on flat road when the terrain dramatically changed without warning. It became hilly and very inconsistent, with sharp inclines followed by brief, jarring descents. This sudden change in terrain caused him to get more tired, thirsty, and hot, sapping his strength with every pedal stroke. The cyclist then came to a huge hill and, using his last bit of energy, rode down the other side, his body aching. He was exhausted, completely spent from the effort. All the terrain changes not only changed the cyclist’s physical state, but his mood and determination as well, testing his resolve to continue the journey.

The setting affected the cyclist in many ways. "The journey nass make an snake," this quote made it seem like he is in the middle of nowhere and is uncovering no place because the man on the porch said it would not be too far, fostering a false sense of security. The first town also was empty, and when he saw the town from a distance he was excited to go and feel a little relief, but when he got closer he realized that the town has been abandoned this whole time, with dust blowing through the silent streets. So he was forced to keep going, and the empty town made him feel almost hopeless, crushing his initial optimism. In his attempts to make it to that next town, that is how the setting most affected the cyclist in the way that it did, shaping his emotional journey through isolation and disappointment.

The setting of the road affected the cyclist in many different ways. Because there were no towns on the road it made it very difficult for him to find water which led him into a dehydrated state, his throat becoming dry and parched. “The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so,” he thought, trying to maintain hope. The rolling hills of the road were making him use more energy, each ascent a struggle that drained his legs. Because there was no buildings for miles he broke the ride into short distances, focusing on reaching the next bend or a lone tree in the distance just to keep his spirit from breaking entirely.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in so many ways. Some ways the cyclist was affected is, the lack of water was the biggest problem he had, a constant and pressing concern. The group of the old guys that gave him directions weren't a big help at all, their memories faded with time. The men gave the cyclist directions based on what they remember when they were younger in age, from a different era entirely. The cyclist knew not to take directions from the old men, but they seemed so sure about what they were talking about to him, their confidence momentarily convincing. The cyclist first had determination to get to his destination, a clear goal in mind. As he began to get hotter and more thirsty, he started thinking about giving up, his resolve weakening with every mile. As soon as he was about to give up, his troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind him now, a sudden turn of fortune. He stumbled across water, a blessed discovery that renewed his hope and allowed him to continue.

The features in the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. One way is he is round stuck with only a little bit of water, a dire situation in the heat. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips” (Kurmaskie), a meager reserve that heightened his anxiety. Also the cyclist was lost because of the old men's directions that got him nowhere because their directions were out of date, leading him to abandoned places. “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven’t left the confine of their porches since carter was in office,” (Kurmaskie), he realized too late. He was given bad directions and wasn't too pleased, feeling a mix of frustration and foolishness for trusting them. Therefore the cyclist went through some tough times, his journey becoming a test of endurance against the misleading and unforgiving landscape.

Different features of the settings profoundly affect the cyclist. The setting of the story, which is based in the harsh desert, has a significantly negative affect on the character. The desert land is baron and unforgiving, leaving him only with his small, precious supply of water. During his arduous journey he runs out of water, a critical event causing him to lose contact with reality. The extreme, relentless heat in the desert causes him to begin to hallucinate vividly. The cyclist begins to see a grape juice factory, a vision which cruelly interrupts his trip. To his dismay, it turns out to be a no more than a devastating mirage. The lengthy road also severely affected the trip. The immense length and punishing roughness of the road had worn the cyclist down both mentally and physically, defeating his spirit. Ultimately, the hostile environment proves to be an overwhelming adversary.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he thinks, after a nice afternoon in a pleasant campground, that a shortcut to his next destination would be very nice. He thinks the shortcut will be a nice, relaxing alternative to taking the original longer way to Yosemite. But the trip he makes changes his mind a lot, proving far more difficult than anticipated. In the essay the narrator is talking about what the old guys had told him, recalling their advice. He says, “The old guys had sworn the next town only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that. I would conserve my water…” He did conscientiously conserve his water but the town was very old and desolate and didn’t have any water for him to drink. So throughout the essay the narrator went without water, suffering from thirst, until he finally got to a factory, got some water to drink, and got new directions. The trip was very different from what he had expected, transforming from a relaxing detour into a struggle. It was more depressing and challenging than he could have imagined, teaching him a hard lesson about the land.

A response that explains how the feature of the setting affected the cyclist would be that the setting affected him because its features were based on a harsh and deceptive reality. So that would be a primary reason how it would be affected, as the environment directly challenged his plans and well-being. Because there are differences in the stories and the actual conditions encountered, the cyclist's experience was shaped by this disconnect. The physical hardships imposed by the setting, therefore, had a tangible impact on his journey, leading to a difficult and enlightening outcome about the power of place.

You cannot always choose your environmental features because your initial idea might be changed over time by experience. The setting one encounters can forcefully alter preconceived notions and plans, demonstrating that external conditions have a powerful influence on personal outcomes. This interaction between an individual and their surroundings ultimately dictates the course of events, showing that adaptability is often necessary. Therefore, the features of a setting are not passive but active elements that shape one's journey and perspective.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist mentally, physically, positively and negatively, creating a complex interplay of challenges. For instance, he had been at CAPS1's Grape Juice Factory and bottling plant. A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still been seen." This vivid image affected the author mentally, making him acutely remember he had no water, which tormented him. Which inturn affected him physically by worsening his condition as he became more dehydrated with each passing moment. So overall that setting features had a negative, direct affect on the cyclist, deepening his despair. Another example is, "One ramshacked shed, several rusty pumps, and a coral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling." This scene affected the cyclist mentally by making him think he was never going to see civilization again, inducing a sense of hopelessness. It also affected him physically because the little water he found tasted like "battery acid," which put him deeper into his dehydration state and physical decline. This setting features had a profoundly negative affect on the cyclist, eroding his resolve. The setting features and how they affected the cyclist is analogous to an environment a person is advised in and how it shapes their character and trials, ultimately defining their experience.

He is going on a journey on his bike across a demanding landscape. He has to go down steep hills and deal with the pressing fact that he has no water, a situation that grows more urgent with each passing mile. That is basically what the setting is about, establishing a simple yet challenging environment for his ride. The journey's difficulty is defined by these two core elements of terrain and resource scarcity.

When riding a bike the features around you can profoundly affect the cyclist's physical state and mental resolve. Some primary things that can affect the cyclist are the immediate weather and the surrounding scenery. If the weather is cold and rainy the cyclist would not want to be riding, facing discomfort and reduced visibility. The dangers of riding when the weather conditions are bad, such as slippery roads, will make the cyclist second guess the decision of riding or not. If the weather is extremely hot the cyclist will get dehydrated quicker and become even more exhausted from the relentless heat. The scenery can also significantly affect the cyclist's morale. When a cyclist is riding and all he or she sees is a barren desert then they might have doubts on where they are going, feeling isolated. If there are abandoned buildings everywhere the cyclist might become frightened and want to head back or lose hope, as shown in the story “Do not exceed the speed limit” when the rider gets over a hill and begins to think that he will never make it to Yosemite. Many things in the environment can affect the cyclist, shaping the entire experience of the journey.

The features of the setting consistently exacerbate the cyclist's difficult situation. The intense June weather added to his critical water depletion, being the beginning of summer when temperatures soar. When the cyclist arrived at the first so-called "town" it was completely deserted, and the water he found there had a disgusting quality, making it undrinkable. The author uses verbal irony when labeling it a "town," having it not really be a functioning town anymore but a ghost of one. The large snake presented an air of immediate danger and another abandoned structure, the Grape Juice Factory, added to the hopeless, lost tone of the narrative. These elements collectively create a setting that is both physically threatening and psychologically draining for the protagonist.

Many things in the setting directly affect the cyclist and his journey. The first thing that profoundly affects him is the oppressive heat. The heat is actually what causes the central conflict in the story of the cyclist desperately needing water. If the heat was not present in the story then the cyclist would not have such a pressing need for water and he would be able to continue on his ride without the constant fear of dehydration. Another crucial aspect of the setting that affects the cyclist are the rolling hills. These hills also exhaust the cyclist, demanding great physical effort, and cause him to need more water to recover. If these hills were gone then the cyclist would have tired less quickly, making his journey significantly easier. The setting in this story greatly affects the cyclist, proving that the environment itself is a primary antagonist in his quest.

The features of the setting in, "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," affect the cyclist in many ways, both physically and psychologically. After following the old men's advice he sets off on his journey with some initial optimism. After the first town appears the sun really starts to beat down which really affects the cyclist, sapping his energy. In the essay it says “The sun was beginning to heat beat down, but I barely noticed it.” He may have not noticed it yet, but then later on the long winding road across the new flat terrain he runs out of water and that is really dangerous in weather that hot. The text states, “The speed limit was fifty-five. I was doing a water-depleting nineteen.” In this part of the story it proves that the cyclist is dangerously out of water. Furthermore, in this kind of setting you can run into dangerous creatures that pose a direct threat. In the story it says, “I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake. It really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” This entry proves to the reader that there are hazardous snakes in this sort of arid setting. The features of the setting in “Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” from the climate to the wildlife, affects the cyclist greatly throughout his arduous trip.

The terrain setting affected the cyclist in many ways. The fact that he was in a vast, barren desert made him intensely thirsty. There were no towns or any sign of water to quench his growing thirst. The relentless hills he would descend and then ascend on his bicycle just made him more physically tired and drained. These are the significant effects the setting had on the cyclist, ultimately shaping his difficult journey.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed” by @PERSON1, the cyclist faces severe problems caused by the setting. The biker was riding under a scorching sun, and the heat was so intense that the biker was really getting dehydrated and tired, and he was running out of his precious water supply. Because it was so oppressively hot, the biker had to drink more water to replenish his body of all the sweat he was losing while biking. Furthermore, the steep hills of the terrain were making it harder on the biker by forcing him to use more energy and liquid just to keep going. If it had been a cool and breezy day, he would have had no problem making that distance. Similarly, if the surrounding area was full of people and not abandoned towns, then he would have had access to water to drink and could have continued his ride with ease.

Everybody experiences physical and emotional pain, but most probably wouldn't have survived what the cyclist in this story went through. The man started a simple bike ride towards Yosemite National Park, but when some elderly men told him about a shortcut, his adventure had just begun for the worse. First of all, every "town" and "building" the men told him he would come to wound up being completely deserted and lifeless. At first, this wasn't a big deal to the cyclist. In the fourth paragraph, when he came to his first deserted town, he simply "chuckled, checked [his] water supply, and moved on." @CAPS1, as his journey progressed, his water supply decreased alarmingly. He was then in a state of desperation for a functioning town. On top of that, in the story he wrote, he noted that "the flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This change in terrain made his biking much harder, and he was then becoming dangerously dehydrated. He finally found a town with water, but he had learned a hard lesson from taking advice from strangers and old men, a mistake he would not make again.

The features of the setting would have affected the cyclist a lot during his journey. There is a man who takes the advice of old men and takes a “shortcut” to Yosemite Park. The shortcut only leads him to immense thirst, and no park in sight. The narration states, “A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen (Kurmaskie @NUM1)." This particular feature could affect the cyclist by discouraging him profoundly, as the cyclist comes to the first “town” but only finds yet again no water, and is instead taunted by a picture of something that makes him even more thirsty. It could also make him be more angry at the old men because they led him on this pointless and arduous journey. Another feature that would affect the cyclist is the complete lack of trees or shade along the route. The only thing he could feel was the relentless sun beating down on his back. The narration states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt.(Kurmaskie @NUM1)." This physical evidence of his struggle also makes the cyclist firmly believe that old men do not know what they are talking about.

There are many features of the setting that affected the cyclist in "Do not exceed the posted speed limit." The time of year affected the cyclist because it’s mid-June, @CAPS1. Furthermore, the specific region affected the cyclist because mid-June in Arizona is extremely hot and dry, creating a harsh environment. If the ride was in a more northern state in @DATE1 or in a cooler climate, it wouldn’t be as bad and you would not have the same danger of heat-related struggles. @CAPS1, when the terrain changed from flat ground to rolling hills, this also affected him significantly because it made it much harder for him to ride and required greater exertion. These are some of the key features of the settings that negatively affected the cyclist in "Do not exceed the posted speed limit," demonstrating the power of environment over human endurance.

In "Rough Road Ahead" by Joe Kurmaskie, the harsh features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist. Because he was cycling through the desert of California in June, his water supply was quickly depleted and his hope began dwindling when he came across a desolate ghost town. His desperation grew until he found a water pump, but it only produced a tar-like substance, which deepened his despair. As a result of the desert's extreme conditions and the critical lack of water, he felt so defeated he wished he was dead. This harrowing experience led him to decide never to take advice from strangers again and to trust his map exclusively. That is how the environmental features ultimately affected his journey and his resolve.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting significantly affected the cyclist both physically and emotionally. First of all, he was traveling in the desert, which means it was very dry and arid. This meant that the cyclist could not readily refill his water bottles and was slowly getting dehydrated under the relentless sun. Also, the cyclist was biking in the oppressive heat, which meant that he was continuously sweating, a process that also depleted the water from his body and played cruel tricks on his mind. Finally, the steep hills caused him to exert more energy, furthermore making him more and more dehydrated with every arduous climb. The hills also put a damper on his spirits, which made him have to muster a great deal of inner strength and sheer determination just to keep going, affecting him emotionally. Overall, the setting had a comprehensive physical and emotional effect on him, testing his limits in every way.

The cyclist is alone, traveling on a flat land at first, following the direction in which the old men told him to get to Yosemite National Park in California. During his travels, he becomes severely dehydrated while cycling over endless hills and deserts with the sun beating down on him in the hot June weather, and he realizes he could get a heat stroke without water. His travels are desolate and lonely, and when he finally sees buildings which turn out to be merely ghost towns, he briefly recovers his spirit and finds some determination to speed up. The cyclist, in a fortunate turn, eventually found a camp site which served to save him from passing out in the desert, a place where he could finally rest, get life-saving water, and then carry on his journey using his own map for reliable guidance.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed Limit,” the cyclist is trying to get to Yosemite with directions that some codgers, or eccentric old men, gave him. The cyclist said the old men looked as though they, “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” Well, he takes their advice, and he gets lost about twenty miles along on his journey. While looking forward to the “cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,” he was instead traveling through a barren and featureless desert. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This type of bleak setting could really bring down a cyclist’s mood, especially while thinking of the beautiful Yosemite. It could make him lose all hope of ever finding Yosemite at this rate, creating a stark contrast between his dream and his reality. If you have a nice setting, it makes the trip worthwhile, and your ending point even better, but this journey was defined by its hardships.

The setting affected the performance of the cyclist and the mood of the cyclist throughout his difficult journey. The rolling hills the cyclist had to get over most likely made him more fatigued and thirsty because he had to put considerably more effort in to get over them. As he struggled, “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view.” The long, big hills that he had to go up not only made him more thirsty, but probably made him feel more satisfied when the climb was all over. Ironically, the building was a grape juice factory; it was abandoned and rusty, but the sign featuring a boy drinking a refreshing glass of juice was still noticeable. This cruel sight brought his hopes down considerably, yet he continued to move on despite the disappointment. In my own life, I have never had such an extreme experience where I had to keep pushing and urging myself toward a goal, but the closest I have come involves situations where the more I near my objective, the more distractions get in the way to try and stop me.

The short story "Do not exceed posted speed limit" follows a man bicycling through Yosemite who asks a group of elderly men for directions. They lead him onto an "old" shortcut that takes him through a landscape of tough terrain and subjects him to extreme famine. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways throughout the story. For example, when the bicyclist came to a completely deserted area, he observed that "there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind." By this point in his journey, he was malnourished and in desperate need of water. This extreme thirst resulted in a particularly cruel moment when he passed an abandoned Welch’s grape juice factory. He saw an advertisement featuring a young boy pouring a fresh glass of juice into his mouth. He notes, "In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building," before going into detail about its dilapidated state. His mood and feeling by this time was utterly tired and worn out, and the mocking advertisement did not help the situation at all. The author's mood did change with the setting, and before it eventually got better, it became significantly worse, highlighting the profound impact of the environment on his mental state.

The young cyclist began his day confident and looking forward to his day of riding across California. He started with a carefree spirit, ready for anything and barely noticing the initial effects of his surroundings. He writes, "I checked, checked my water supply & moved on. The sun was beginning to heat down, but I barely noticed it." At this early stage, the surroundings have little effect on him. Later on, however, as he recognizes he has been directed wrongly, his mood begins to change. He realizes his water was going down and he is getting increasingly tired, his mood shifting to one of exhaustion and dejection. It is here that he writes, "I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles & stuck them in my mouth with any luck I’d hit a bump or lodge one in my throat." This sarcastic and grim action shows he has become saddened by the hopelessness of his journey. Eventually, he finds relief as the cold water helps to bring up his spirits and restore his sense of humor, marking the final shift in his emotional journey.

In the essay, the features of the setting profoundly affected the cyclist throughout his journey. In the beginning, the setting was at the old men's place where the cyclist was happy and confident about the route he was given. When he reached the desolate ghost town and found himself out of water, his emotional state turned to one of upset and frustration. The sight of a building initially offered a moment of relief, but upon discovering it was an abandoned factory, his hope vanished and he was filled with sadness. This series of environmental disappointments culminated in his final push, and when he finally reached the store, he was excited and profoundly relieved to have found sustenance and an end to his ordeal. That is how the specific features of the setting affected the cyclist's emotions and resolve during his difficult trip.

Weather, places, and the will to continue are all reasons that explain how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, the weather affects the cyclist because in hot weather you lose a lot of water and sweat a great deal, making it physically hard to pedal. The constant, sunny hot weather also affects his mental state and will to ride, as the oppressive heat is demoralizing. I mean, come on, who wants to ride when it's burning hot outside? Furthermore, the specific places the cyclist went through, like the abandoned towns and the rough, unpaved roads, would affect him because navigating such terrain is pretty tough and isolating. These combined environmental factors work together to challenge both his physical endurance and his mental determination.

The story “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit” tells of a biking trip gone wrong, but the story would not be as terrifying if it had happened in a different place. The setting plays a large role in creating the narrative's tension. The story begins on a pleasant summer evening, but as the man bikes further, he arrives at a ghost town devoid of all life, which introduces a sense of unease. Later, a feeling of doubt sets in when he arrives at a location described as “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule.” Further on, we see panic begin to set in as the terrain becomes hilly and tumbleweeds and snakes cross his path, evoking the harshness of a cold western. Finally, all hope seems lost when he reaches the grape juice factory and finds only “a sand blasted picture of a young boy,” a cruel reminder of his thirst. The setting is a powerful tool which greatly influences the cyclist's experience and emotional descent throughout the story.

In the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affected the cyclists physical abilities. The features affected his abilities because the climate and dangerous environment was hot and rough to handle. These features were hot and rough since he was in the California deserts in June. The passage that supports this is, “Tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake- it really did look like a diamondback- blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” This encounter with the snake highlights the physical challenge of navigating a hazardous landscape while already weakened. Also, the features of the setting give him determination. They give him determination because each horizon he sees gives him hope. They give him hope since he knows he is that much closer to Yosemite National Park. The passage that supports this is when he drops, “.distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that I could move it that far, I’d be fine.” In the story, "Rough road ahead, Do not exceed posted speed limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of his settings affect both the cyclists physical and mental abilities, pushing his body to its limits while also fueling his will to continue.

The features of the setting have a huge effect on the cyclist. There was a point in the story where he ran out of water and he remembered that the old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. He was tired and dehydrated but he thought he could make it along the road. So he started off and then two miles later the terrain changed and so did his outlook on this entire journey. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. "Sometimes life can be so cruel.” These hills took a lot out of him and he was now on a highway. Before this terrain change the rider is very positive and thinks he can do this easily, exclaiming, “I could make that!” But after the terrain change he loses hope and almost doesn’t make it, thinking, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” The sudden shift from manageable flat land to exhausting inclines directly triggers his despair. It is obvious as you read that when the terrain becomes tough it has a huge negative effect on the cyclist, demonstrating how the physical landscape directly shapes his mental state.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in a few ways. The roads were nice and smooth then turned to hills, which required much more effort to pedal. It was a hot day in June and he had a sparse water supply with him, increasing his vulnerability to the heat. He was pedaling through the deserts of California, a vast and exposed landscape. The last thing that effected him was that there wasn’t very many places to stop for water, leaving him isolated and without resources. These combined factors—the difficult terrain, the intense heat, and the scarcity of water—all worked together to challenge the cyclist both physically and mentally throughout his journey.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist is on his way trying to find his way to Yosemite National Park, but runs into a little trouble when getting directions from a couple of older men. The one lesson the cyclist learned was to never to listen to short-cuts given to you by old men who are extremely out of date and haven’t left their porch since Carter was in office. The cyclist learned this the hard way when he ends up lost and almost died of thirst. The setting takes place in the desert of California or in deserted ghost towns. On his journey the cyclist says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” This feature effects the cyclist because of the extremely dry heat beating down on him makes him dehydrated, sapping his strength. Also along his journey the cyclist encounters hills, which present a formidable physical barrier. The feature of the setting effects the cyclist by tiring him out and making him believe there isn’t any hope of him getting out alive, as the relentless climbs drain his energy and morale. Features of the setting like hills and deserts dehydrate a rider and create a profound sense of hopelessness, directly impacting the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. It seems to be the more desperate the situation the more determined he becomes. On page one, he thinks, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Right after he thinks this he climbed away from the abandoned factory of Juices and dreams, showing a resurgence of will. He says on page one that his “troubles, thirst and teen were all behind me,” this shows that after a desperate situation the narrator feels relieved of all earthly obligations, as if he has passed through a trial. Not only does the setting affect the cyclist but the entire story around him, as the harsh environment shapes the narrative's conflict and the character's ultimate sense of release and perseverance. The landscape acts as both an antagonist and a catalyst for his personal journey.

The setting of the story is very dry and humid, flat, and hilly. The author noticed the terrain changing, as “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Joe Kurmaskie). Being out in the middle of a desert-like surrounding during June, with nothing surrounding him, is a scary thought. The heat and lack of water affect him significantly, causing him to possibly see mirages or even faint because of the heat and how much fluid he has lost through dehydration. The hills don’t help any either, adding physical strain to his already difficult journey through the harsh environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is riding through the desert in the middle of June, yet he has very little water. This affects him because he is constantly thirsty, but he doesn’t have a lot of water to drink, and he is in a desert in the middle of June which makes it very hot, intensifying his need for hydration. Also, in the story it says he comes to Welch’s Grape Juice Factory where on the side of the building he sees a picture of a “young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth.” This makes the cyclist even thirstier, taunting him with the image of the drink he cannot have, but he continues on to find water at a bait shop, pushing forward despite the mental and physical challenge.

The cyclist in this essay is trying to go to Yosemite National Park. He feels confident in him making it, not realizing what is up ahead. First come the windy roads. As he goes along, his confidence starts to wither away. The desert hits him like a boulder because he is running short on water and needs to rest. The extreme heat just makes everything worse. “Not many miles into this heat section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This shows that the cyclist did not expect to meet this kind of terrain and is overwhelmed by it. The one thing he never does is give up. This is important because as he went along, just before giving up, he found a place to get water and to relax. “Then, as easily as running about, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.” This shows that he was strong and determined to survive, and he finally found what he needed, which made him happy and gave him a will to live. Everyone in life needs to be determined to overcome their own difficult journeys.

It gave him a hard time, so he learned a lot of things from that; he knows that it is not always easy. It was not a big problem, but sometimes some small problems become bigger. Life is like riding a bike; you have ups and downs, sometimes you have problems, sometimes you get lost, but that is life and its inherent challenges. The experience taught him resilience and the importance of perseverance through all of life's varying terrain.

The features of the setting very much affect the cyclist. He had to ride through tough conditions and became very exhausted. I believe the toughest feature of the setting was the heat. He told us, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” He was talking about how he needed to sip from his water more than normally, a clear sign of the oppressive climate. Another tough feature of the setting was the hills he had to ride up and down. As he was riding he said, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” I believe riding over these hills in the hot sun of a California desert was a very tough task for the cyclist, draining his energy further. I believe the terrain very much affected him, proving to be a formidable opponent on his journey.

The features of the setting in this story make the ride more difficult for the cyclist, primarily through the challenging terrain and altitude. For example, the cyclist is moving through the high deserts of California. This shows that the cyclist is at a high altitude, which makes breathing more difficult and adds to the physical strain. Then the cyclist notes that the flat road was replaced by short rolling hills. The hills would make the trip more demanding, requiring greater effort to pedal and maintain momentum. This is evidenced by the cyclist describing one of them as a long, crippling hill, a description that underscores the grueling nature of the ascent. Clearly, the terrain, which got increasingly difficult, negatively affected the cyclist's progress and energy levels.

In the story, the setting affected the cyclist in many ways, creating a harsh and unforgiving environment. For example, the condition of the road was bad, presenting a constant physical challenge. It changed from flat road to short, rolling roads, which disrupted his rhythm and demanded more exertion. Furthermore, tumble weeds crossed his path, creating obstacles that required careful navigation. He had a lack of water, and the water he did have tasted like battery acid, which made staying properly hydrated a miserable experience. In the story it says, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state,” a statement that directly shows how his physical capabilities were compromised by the setting's harsh conditions. These combined elements of the environment significantly hindered his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by introducing demanding physical obstacles that complicate the journey. The challenges are evident if you have to go up hill or along long bumpy type roads, both of which require increased stamina and concentration. Then in the essay it says “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit,” a warning which does make things more difficult than average by forcing a slower, more cautious pace that prolongs the effort. This difficult travel is compounded by external factors, especially with a lack of water to make things worse, creating a situation where the cyclist must contend with both the physical terrain and his own diminishing resources. Ultimately, the setting presents a series of interconnected hardships that test the cyclist's endurance.

The setting greatly affects the cyclist trying to get to Yosemite National Park by presenting multiple environmental dangers. First of all, the cyclist says he’s in Lodi, California on a “gorgeous day in June.” It’s very hot in California in June, so the biker is affected by the weather because he could die of heatstroke, making the heat itself a serious threat. Also, he is in the middle of the desert, where he faces tumbleweeds crossing his path and a large snake that is possibly poisonous in the way. Such encounters add a layer of constant vigilance and potential peril. That puts him in more despair, because he could get hurt by a wild animal, or run out of water with no place to go get more, leaving him isolated and vulnerable. So the setting mostly negatively affects the cyclist by combining extreme heat with hazardous wildlife and a lack of resources.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist profoundly, particularly through the scarcity of resources and the demanding landscape; the author says he is in the California desert. This means that the cyclist must conserve water so he can stay hydrated for the trip, a constant and pressing concern. Also, there are many hills, as the author says, “over one crippling hills,” and with a lot of hills to climb, the cyclist uses up more energy and will become dehydrated quickly, if he isn’t careful, creating a vicious cycle of exertion and resource depletion. Finally, there are many abandoned towns that are several miles apart from each other. This again affects how the cyclist uses his water, as he thinks that there is a prospering town coming up, so he drinks his water, thinking he’ll get more soon. However, when he gets there, there is no water, and he must pedal several more miles to the next town with very little water, a situation that heightens his desperation. The setting is a great effect on how the cyclist acts, forcing him into a careful calculus of survival especially with no water available in the desolate environment.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affect the cyclist, whose journey is a continuous emotional response to the harsh landscape. Depending on what sort of new terrain or landmark he came to, his determination increases and decreases, charting a course of peaks and valleys in his morale. For example, when he saw a building come into view ahead of him, a stark contrast to the desolate plains, he got excited and used all his energy to get down the hill to the building, propelled by the promise of shelter or resources. Also, when he came to the next building and found a working bathroom, a small but significant victory, he drank from the sink as his hope of not dying was renewed, the simple act of quenching his thirst restoring a fundamental sense of possibility. Conversely, the vast, empty stretches of road and the relentless, unforgiving sun served to drain his spirit, making every turn of the pedals a monumental effort. The man riding the bike in the story had many different changes in his emotions during his long trek in this story that were dependent on the setting, demonstrating how his internal state was inextricably linked to the external world through which he traveled. Ultimately, the narrative illustrates that in an environment defined by scarcity and isolation, even the most minor feature of the landscape can become a powerful catalyst for either profound despair or a fragile, yet essential, hope.
